Not a guide. No pictures or step-by-steps. This is a description of various massage terminology and technique.The information given, though, was clear, concise, and easy to understand. Enough for 3 stars.

This was a great how-to manual of crafting runes-with-a-purpose. I hadn't ever heard or read such a powerful description or plan for runes. One could easily adopt it for sigils, too.Any cons? Some of the rune descriptions don't specifically match up with many resources I own, so read them with care.

The scribe-publisher of this tome did no editing. It is very apparent, once downloaded, that these "calls" are merely scanned-in PDFs of a greater document. There is no explanation, only text through which an English statement is followed by what appears to be gibberish.I'm not sure to whom the Calls are to be made, or for what ritual(s) they are designed, let alone parts or attenuating circumstance of the rituals. The statements made in this text seem to be in ritual format, but not in readable syntax. Sentences rarely begin or end before translation of the English phrase/ statement is made.I'm sure the information presented here is worth an immeasurable amount to the Initiated, but I have no scroll or code.

I've read 40+ books and practiced Taiji and qigong for about 15 years. This book does cover "basics" of poses. Stances, body poses, poise, breathing... All these things are covered sufficiently. That's why I gave it 3 stars.Unfortunately, there is very little about the motion or cycling of chi (Qi), if any at all. What I am unsure of is: what good is a book about qigong if there is no Qi or gongfu? Hence, only 3 stars.

I appreciated the discussion and descriptions of the Protestant practice of laying on of hands. Hagin begins with checking the scriptures for it, trolling both old and new Testaments. He gives "How to know it's real". He finishes up with words of caution and made-up beliefs and practices.I enjoyed the brevity and practical application of Biblical principals throughout it all.
Short introduction to several concepts, with basic how-to steps for the newbies. If you want a Freshman-level Pagan 101 course, this book is for you!

The author made a good book about dream-time quantum-physics and its ritualistic applications for the imagination of the Magus to "become" a werewolf. Kind of like path working. Brief, but wordy.Negatives: the author had an inappropriate love for using semicolons.
This is only a few pages long. Not detailed. This seemed to be what someone wrote down while attending a weekend Tantra workshop: summaries of concepts without depth.

I thought this book would be instructional. I wanted to know about crystal healing with chakras. So I got it.Positives (why this book received 2 stars):Information: it had descriptions of various chakras which seemed consistent with other sources. It gave names of crystals and stones which are supposed to correspond to each chakra.Negatives:1). Poor Presentation: Google translate seemed to have been used, because syntax and word choice were just "off" quite a bit. I'm familiar with the syntax of Russian, a little Hebrew, and the Romantic languages, but this didn't quite match those. Any native English speaker would be able to tell this was a Translate problem, and not an "I'm an idiot with a word processor" problem. It was distracting.2). Lack: It gave absolutely no information about healing, or the process one may undertake, or experiences that may occur, or which stones/ crystals would work better for which manifested condition, or which chakras were necessary to employ stones with them, at which times.... I really have no background with chakra-stone healing, but these are questions I'd expect answered by a quality resource.3). Lack: the book just... Ended. As if the author were sick of the writing process, the book stops in what I thought was mid-paragraph. I was surprised the "Before You Go" Kindle page popped up. I gladly took advantage of the Review this book feature (as you can tell, because you are reading this).Don't get this book. I'd let you know which resource to purchase instead, but I really don't know about this topic yet. This book was no help.

Why not 5 stars? Holder tends to meander up to his stated topic, be it the premise of the book, or chapter sub-headings. It takes a while. Plus, the syntax Holder uses is not "standard English". But at least it isn't Yoda-like.That said, Mr. Holder gives 5 ways to open your third eye, about two-thirds through the book. One of them is the "vibrate Thoth through your tongue and teeth method.  I tried it, because it was the one I thought made the most sense.On the last night of the procedure, I experienced full-on colored images in my visualizations that I had trouble believing what I was seeing. I know that one works.Why did I get this book? I wanted to see what he said on the subject to let you know if it actually worked. I know for a subjective fact, at least one of them does!

Mr. Holder does not actually tell how to activate the Third Eye.He tells what food he believe will "decalcify" it. He goes on, at length, about the damaging effects of fluoride compounds to brain function without actually tying it to pineal-gland dysfunction. He raises the topic of the illuminati pacifying the global population with television and fluoride-added tap water.Does he actually describe what to perform to awaken the Third Eye? No. Does he illuminate the mystery of what to do with an awakened third eye, after you eat the right kind of algae and drink the right bottled water? Nope.If this book doesn't do what it promised, why did I give it 3 stars instead of just 1? Because it DOES inform you about random, interesting facts, and is entertaining to read, terrible sentence syntax notwithstanding.

Ramses does nothing to transmit the value of Karma Yoga. Her descriptions are like a car magazine ad about driving: colorful, incomplete, and ultimately NOT the same thing as actually doing it.I will give you two examples which support my claim:Verbatim, Kindle location 25: "After the action of the enlightened there is no author, you could say that the author is nature itself."Uh. What?It gets worse.Kindle location 36 (again, verbatim): "Karma yoga involves a complete reversal of human nature, requiring that each action is performed with an array of radically different from the way we are daily mood."Huh?!? I downloaded this book while it was free. It's only 97 locations long. I hope beyond hope you don't waste any resources on it.

The first couple of chapters are devoted to "Surrender". Letting go. Allowing the mud in your puddle of consciousness to sink to the bottom, so you may think clearly. This is very important, and I was glad the author opened this instructional book with this. Surrender is not a subject "shiny, happy, popular" or more famous faces like to address, because it gets messy quickly, for people to open up and forgive... themselves... others... God.These two chapters are worth the two stars out of five. However, from chapter three up to the last two pages of the book, information is typed out in a style which clearly broadcasts that all of it is actually transcribed Q&A conversations of instructor-to-paying-customer, where terms are either undefined, loosely defined, or written as if instruction has already taken place, and the reader just "misses out" because they weren't in California at the right hotel for two days in the same forum as the questioners.The last two pages are extant apart from his wandering waffle of instruction in telepathy: They are clear, concise, and practicable if the reader is fortunate enough to have a partner who doesn't care if you try to invade their mind just before they go to sleep. Let me draft a summary:1. Find someone willing to co-practice reading each others' minds.2. Write a bunch of different emotions out on separate slips of paper. Place the slips into a proverbial "hat" to be pulled out by one of you.3. Sit 5 feet apart, facing each other.4. One person pulls an emotion slip out of the "hat".  A) they facially act out the emotion. The other person guesses it. (This is supposed to align the pair of consciousnesses.) Cycle through all the emotions.  B) they cycle through all the emotions at random again, physically masking half of the details, but mentally projecting memories of these emotions to the other person.  C) again, cycle through them at random, but giving no physical clue what is supposed to be projected.5. Take notes on what worked or did not work. Compare them. Try to get better.Remember, this is all suggested to be done just before one of the partners goes to bed, to cut down on individual mental chatter.If I suggested this to my wife, the only person around whom I live that retires near the same time as me, she would Commit me. My kids would probably tell stories about it to friends or their teachers at school, if I asked them, which would get back to my wife, who would then Commit me.Other than the first two chapters, I think this book was a waste of print.

Okay, okay: read the first few pages, there are a few nuggets in them. When you get tired of idiosyncratic use of words and phrases that may not fit anyone else's preferred pattern of speech, skip to 58%. You will miss out on inappropriate use of contractions, sentence fragments, and unnecessary comma placements throughout an aimless waffle of redundant chatter loosely based on the topic of meditation.After that, the author does share GOLD. I've meditated for two decades, and never considered some of it. An example: hand posture, what some may call "mudras". I have 5 books on the subject, but never considered WHY some of it works, and the way he explained two examples was so "common sense", I marveled that I had never seen it before, and felt that half of the book's cost was worth that alone!The author clearly knows his subject, and just as clearly has some good stuff to say. What keeps this book from being five stars is 1) the overall lack of organizational flow, and 2) the conversational tone was too loose for a non-fiction book.However much I may or may not like the presentation, though, the "meat and vegetables" of this dish were too good not to give a decent score. Sort of like getting a 5-star restaurant to deliver their food in McDonald's wrappers.Overall, I'm glad I read it. May the author enjoy the function of a good editor in the future!

It's almost a noir. It's decidedly American. All things Urb-Fantasy included.Meet Markowski: a "calloused yet aware" detective from Scranton's Supernatural Crimes division. If you haven't heard of him, lucky you. If he's heard of you, you're either dead, undead, or you cause people to be one or both of them...In the opening chapters, we see his connection to a few deaths (work related), learn the process of the Supe investigations involving a White/Grey witch, wizards, goblins, and become wary of the intrusion of a 16th-century wizard turned vampire who just might be more than an innocent bystander....Get it. If you like the Dresden Files, the Iron Druid, or Rachel Morgan, you'll be very pleased. Gustanis writes in their all-inclusive vein, but he has set up a unique spin to the Urb-Fantasy-noir style.*there are a few editing issues, but this is from a smaller publishing house, so please do not let them detract from the excellent story craft. Read.

This is both a good primer for those yet unaccustomed to the discipline of meditation AND a refreshing take on a popular spiritual topic that "practiced" individuals will like; instead of being touchy-feely, the author describes the process, common issues and solutions, and uses simple (yet effective) imagery.For "old hats" to meditation: In the 20 or so years I've given over to mental disciplines, the strategies, goals, techniques, and "levels" expressed in this work really are unique. I found myself making notes about them, more so than the last 15 books I've purchased and practiced through. Chances are you'll find many "take-with-yous".A small sticking point for me: It makes strong claims of "quick" advancement (months instead of years), but as there is no way to prove one's own growth (with whom could you or I compare such subjective results?), the claims would be difficult to verify.That said, the author spells out what to do, possible ways to do it, what to look for, and WHY the Rose Way process works. Give it a whirl.Chapter headings include:1. Introducing the Rose Way meditation (RWM)2. An overview of the basics3. Preparing for the RWM4. The RWM up and down the chakras5. The level of the Rose6. The four higher levels7. Exercise to completely close the chakras8. Practicing the higher senses9. The Rose Way Meditation (enumerated without commentary )10. Who was Joe Kasperski (her teacher from whom she learned RWM)I like it and am taking strides to add the RWM to my daily practices.

This book is a more modern treatise on New Thought, the Law of Attraction for Fringe Christians, and something like the Sedona Method or EFT/TFT: I realize my place in the world, and therefore begin to shape it with my awareness.Why not 5 stars? I believe it came across as a heart-felt journal entry. It clearly needed a streamlining editor. Kind of like visiting an Arboreal nursery because you want to buy a sapling you can plant, but the owner has placed all these flower arrangements in front of all the trees to the point that you can see the bark and some leaves, but it takes shifting the flora to see what you want.Is that clear? He gives you the goods, but sells his viewpoint on a lot of other little issues.

You get a chance to taste the difference between fighting styles and cosmological theory with this snippet of a story.It makes me think that the Egyptian and Greco/Roman worlds will eventually unify against Chaos/Titan/Gaia Forces.It left me salivating!
Short, to the point, no filler junk info. I was curious about the Paleo Diet, and this book answered all my pertinent questions. It also gave some great recipes for me to tweak to suit my preference.

The author starts out with personal testimony that seems common:1. Fat man looks for change agent.2. Fat man finds change agent, and commits to it.3. Not-so-fat man gets pulled away from change agent due to life events, time constraints, or insufficient benefits.4. Fat-again man repeats steps 1-3.Then he realizes how to stream-line the yoga process. Spiral Up Yoga is the result.His premise is this: even if Something is good for you, if it costs you too much time or inconvenience, you won't follow through. And millions of my fellow Americans' waistlines are testimonies to this. And let's face it: he's right.So he stream-lined yoga to 5 to 10 minutes a day, incorporating parts that bring your body, mind, and soul into alignment.I've done yoga off/on for ten years. This book has been a great "at least I can do This so I don't totally fall away, because if I can sit here playing video games I can give myself 10 minutes to contribute to my wellness" resource. Even on days I get yoga in (5-6 days a week for me normally, this year), this is a great process to supplement it, hours after I work out and am feeling sluggish. And of course, I get to think, "hey, I worked out twice today!"Great book.

I received this book as a gift almost 20 years ago when it was a new release. I had no idea Christian Horror Fiction was so... intense! This was the first book that caused me to sit up until 4 am to finish it!.A preacher man moves to a small town, where people seem normal, but everything is just... off. Then the murders begin.Description, characters, plot, and climax were done so well, when the Internet came to my college a year later, I actually did a search to see if the story had any basis in reality.Read it. And take cover!

In college, studying the sciences, I read several reports and studies that involved the heart and cardiovascular fitness. I came to conclusions that disagreed with the general consensus about health, but, not being a doctor (or even pre-med), people wouldn't listen to me.Now, nearly 20 years later, all my suspicions and thoughts are not only vindicated, but furthered and explained succinctly.Read this, apply it, and live. Live well, long, and without drugs!

Summation: At 163 kindle locations, it's a short book. It has some good points, and is, as I said in the title, a great summary of The 5 Reiki Principles.Why 2 stars?Translation: at times, the book was perfectly readable. However, that readability was brief and spread through the text. Everything else was taken up by partial phrases and terrible syntax.Example: location 37:"You must thank you have to keep getting."Uh. What?It's like that all through the book.If you can get past the feeling that the author wrote this after ingesting psychotropics, you might like it.

The book is worth 5 stars -- for free. That said, THIS BOOK IS NOT WORTH $15.THE BAD: If I had gotten it for $15, I would have read it, taken notes, and returned it. Why? It is very short, incorporates no data, cites no other sources, and the author's voice does not come through as authoritative.THE GOOD: It is 156 Kindle locations. It shows how to make a psywheel, and discusses how to use the scientific method to detect whether or not you can influence the psywheel with only your mind.The author discusses how people tend to fool themselves by illusion rather than actual telekinetic phenomena by moving things "at a distance". This feature is not covered in other related texts, and I appreciated little details that never would have occurred to me.All in all, a VERY good book -- for free.I think this book would sell fine for $3 max.

As the author says a few times, in the last two decades there was a lot of fascination with this stuff. I grew up on Indiana Jones and the Stories of Lost Nazi Occultism. Naturally, this book's title caught my eye.For me, I read what the author collected and penned here, finding clues to Pop Culture hits like the recent Marvel's "Captain America" movie, the basis for the general plot and a character's name from my favorite urban fantasy series "The Dresden Files" (Jim Butcher), and other mystifying ideas.The author writes in a reporter-like fashion, leaving one to wonder about the topics after fair treatment of both sides of each issue.Right now it's free. Pick it up, give it a whirl, if you like this kind of stuff. You won't regret it.Why only 4 stars? There were a few awkward sentence structures, and its organization, while not seemingly arbitrary, did seem erratic; at times the author covered topics he entreated in prior chapters, in a tone of introduction, rather than recall. Somewhat annoying, but not at all detracting from the value of the work.

I'm not sure whether or not this is an "authentic work" of somebody ancient. I am sure, however, that it is deep. Deep, deep, deep.If there were a "Book of Magic(k) Proverbs", this would be it. I think it is a combination of the Biblical Proverbs, the Tao Te Ching, Gibran's "Prophet", the Zohar (but way easier to understand), a "middle-path" version of Stephen Mace's "Stealing the Fire from Heaven", and C.S. Lewis' "Abolition of Man" (for logic).Anyone interested in metaphysics needs to put this pot over a cooking fire and consume small doses over several days until finished.

Seventy percent of this work is flowery speak on metaphysics. The last 30 seconds of reading were taken up with pithy statements about yoga. This was enough to give the book three stars.Literally, it took me two minutes to read it through.

There were no techniques, or philosophies, or positions, or anything. This book was an arbitrarily connected set of facts one would come across while investigating what massage is.Was it tastefully done? Yes. That afforded it the second star. The information in this, though, seemed random to me, as well as an inch deep but none too wide. At less than 500 kindle locations, how much "real" information would you expect?Two stars.

I thought the towel would be more... steady. But I guess you can't expect to not slip on a sweaty towel.... Excellent quality, excellent workmanship, but I have a few other priorities in front of a $58 towel. Oops.

I love this product. I have been using rugs and a weight bench mat up until now. This is great, wish I'd had it years ago! It is not sticky, but allows my feet to grip it pretty well even when I sweat. Rolls up so compact. Incredible product!

...to the true believer, that is. Mr. Lamont uses the invocation of Dark Spirits and the "prince of darkness" to empower spell effects. Though, he does show (later on in the book) how to adopt your own spells to deities you may already follow.Why 3 stars? Well, I thought his methods of talismans and letters were novel. I've read probably near 100 different manuals and grimoires by as many authors, and I hadn't come across those particular methods.Why not 4 or 5 stars? For $23, there were only 19 pages....

This pamphlet has "page 1" information. The mandalas are cool to look at (which affords this title the 2nd star), but 100 kindle locations don't offer any information you can't read off of a generic Mandala website.

This book wasn't what I thought. The clear, high-quality pictures are pencil-art. There is a poem about each chakra along with the drawings.Originally I planned on giving this book a 1-star rating because I was not expecting, but a gut feeling told me to go see what the book promised in the product description; I don't like giving negative reviews based on misaligned expectations alone. I checked. Then I decided to rate it according to that. I considered the book again.Even though its not what I had in mind, this book delivers PRECISELY what it promises in a clear, straight-forward, nice format. The painstaking time and effort to put it together became evident to me once I took a little time and effort of my own to reconsider it.  Now that I'm aware of what it's supposed to be, I think a 5-star rating is exactly what this $3 book deserves.

My second favorite of the entire Riordan universe. Why? The labyritnth. Genius. Battle. Love. Tension. Grit. Friendship. I think this story must be allegorically parallel to my own. I resonated with all the struggle, confusion, and everything.Thank you, Rick Riordan, for writing such an excellent series.
Good, for the would-be stage magician.The author covers multiple ways to do what he promises in the blurb of the book. Not what I was looking for, but exactly what it claims!
This work is the entrance to a wider imagination.I read it in Fourth Grade, and return to it still.Read it, and love a story penned by a Master.

In my undergrad degree, I studied physics, up through atomic and nuclear (and aced my classes). I used all available resources and research materials to check out McTaggart's sources and interpretations of concepts.I don't know why I wasn't taught these things at University.But McTaggart got them right. Everything is cited. Everything is published. Nothing is feigned, exaggerated, or unsubstantiated. What is still theory is clearly delineated by the author. May the reader decide if they will re-close their mind, shut their eyes.

I read this book, got a quarter into it, and was motivated. In the book, the author gives a web address from which the reader can download an mp3 audio of his self-hypnosis track.I used this track for months.In the last year, I've put his principles to practice in my own way, using my own methods. I've lost 60 pounds, and I can attribute my success to 3 main authors: Gabriel (this book), Paul McKenna (I can make you thin), and Jos Silva (the Silva Mind Control Method). I lost 32 pounds using nothing but their principles of thought control and portion control in less than 3 months, doctor-weighed and proven. This is after twenty YEARS of weight-loss efforts.Thank you, Jon Gabriel.

I tend to shy away from mainstream things, believing that "popular" more often equates to "most advertised" than it does to "best of the market".This is one exception.I haven't enjoyed a devotional like this since I used "My Utmost for His Highest" for the better part of a decade.Why?Quotes, founded in Scripture, challenging and motivating suggested courses of action, humor, and seriousness, well-balanced.These words helped me change.Excellent.

The twelve poses presented here are central in several yogic workouts I've experienced. I cannot attest to their individual contributions, but over the past year I've lost about 60 pounds; yoga is one of the factors of this body change, and I can attest to excellent effects I experience every time I complete a routine.Why 4 stars? I think the book would be even better if it had put the poses in an instructive, do-this-then-this format for maximum practical benefit.

I ate up all the other books in the entire series. As much as a 30-something conservative male can appreciate female teen drama, I liked the premise and development of the storylines.Until this one.IDK why, but the characters feel flat, predictable, and terribly immature, even the older immortals portrayed. Complaining, petty, morose, weepy. Every vamp character's comment motivated by internal vindictiveness.As every other title in the series took me less than 3 days to finish (in limited personal time), I have tried to read this several times uncounted; I flip pages twice and get turned off by some silliness.I'm only 17% of the way through. I'm sure my curiosity for the story's resolution will eventually outweigh my peevish reception of this printed version of the authors' imaginations. Too bad for me I can't stand their concerted voice....

I have deeply appreciated Mr. Ashe's prior works. They detailed arcane information in straightforward terms. So, when I saw this one, I bought it immediately.Well, this book is more a booklet (641 Kindle locations). Also, it wasn't as much instructive as commentary. First disappointed, I realized that my difficulty lay more in my expectation than in what was promised and delivered.Practically: Anyone wishing for instruction in the various esoteric concepts presented should look elsewhere. (1 star) However, those in search if commentary on familiar qaballistic concepts written in decent tone will be pleased with it. (5 stars).So, the 3 stars is not a reflection of content, but of personal utility. I understand my review may get a few more "no" votes than "yes" for usefulness. But I believe my review parallels the book's size and content....

I purchased this book because I am increasingly interested in the "Energy Matrix-manipulation" concept, and thought the take on it from a ritual viewpoint was an incredible idea. So many authors are choosing to self-publish, and I was excited to dig in to a fresh garden of ideas. Besides. For $2.99, what could I lose?Turns out, I could lose $2.99. Trying to write a topic sentence for my review, I had several ideas. I couldn't settle on one. "Why?" I asked, self-reflectively.I realized I was using the text of the book as a whole to compare the point of my review. The author, while having a good Intention to write an instructional book, did not execute well.In reflection upon her words, I saw that she assumed a few things about her audience, the major three being: 1) the reader already had experience with ritual terminology and schema; relatively few of her terms were defined, and the book has a general tone of a Spiritualist community member speaking at a Wicca/Pagan festival (I understand she stated clearly, multiple times, that it wasn't a book of witchcraft, but there aren't too many practices out there utilizing all the tools of witchcraft without espousing it... see Assumption #3). 2) the reader wanted to know her views on various topics indirectly related to her chapters' headings, and 3) the reader was tolerant of her idiosyncratic use of "common" metaphysical ideas without identifying their relation to the Energy Magic practical set of ideas (it IS a "Guide", right?). I will attempt to show these wrapped in commentary about each successive chapter.Chapter 1, "Tools", had an eclectic synopsis of various points of view on seemingly random ideas. Not until the ninth paragraph did she begin to enumerate the tools, and only after commentary on eclectic musings did she start: altar, elemental totems, grimoire, container. Yet she neglected to include what importance each of these things had specifically for her concept of energy magic. Lacking in appearance in this Number 1 chapter of Energy Magic was... ENERGY! And a definition of Magic! And what ritual had to do with either concept! And why each tool listed above HAS to be there for Magic's efficacy to be highest possible (something she reports she spent considerable time poring over...).Chapter 2, "Meditation", had a few "warm-up paragraphs" of commentary (difficulty, what to expect, common issues) before she detailed three paths to experiencing altered states. She ended the chapter with the assertion that "MEDITATION IS THE MOST IMPORTANT PART OF RITUAL" [sic], but if it IS, why wasn't Altered State listed among the tools of ritual in chapter one? (Recognizing by assumption, of course, the magus' number one resource in magic is Mind... also not enumerated above.)Chapter 3, "Ritual", had a cleaner start: only four warm-up paragraphs of commentary. However, none of her terms were defined (sacred space, modifications, candle ritual, basic ritual [used in comparison with an undisclosed, subconsciously understood "normal" ritual], "really basic", the addition of "interesting details" later on, etc.), and their relations to the viewpoint of Energy Magic were not elucidated.Ritual steps as penned in this book: 1. Assemble altar; 2. Meditate; 3. Create sacred space; 4.raise/gather energy (this is the FIRST mention of Energy in the entire book, whose premise is... ENERGY! And according to the Kindle locations percentage bar, we are exactly 33% of the way through it!); 5. Charge your tools (no mention of this in the warm-up paragraphs of prep), 6. Use your tools; 7. Empty the Sacred Space; 8. Ground; 9. Clean up.For someone not wanting to present a book on witchcraft, she goes through a standard Wicca 101-type ritual, complete with asking cardinal directions to come into a circle... not their personification, or anthrorepresentative (I just made that word up to cover my concept), but the actual Directions of North, South, East and West. There is quite a bit philosophically wrong with this practice alone.Anyway. Chapter 4, "specific Rituals". She annotates her previous ritual layout slightly. Energy is seldom mentioned, and not as a focus concept.Chapter 5, "timing". There are only four instances when energy is mentioned, and none of them are the focal point of the topic, neither are they described in practical detail. Example: paragraph 2, "times when ritual is powerful". Quote: "raising energy and sending it out to heal the world sounds simplistic... but every bit of positive energy helps."Chapter 6, "Stars and planets". Absolutely no mention of Energy at all.Chapter 7, "Rocks and Plants". The author asserts "Energy exists in everything." But other than saying that different objects have "special" or "specific" energy that you should "connect with", the entire chapter has nothing to do with it. Chapter 8, "Spirits and Deities" is written in the same style.Overall, this book was not written in keeping with its premise.I do believe the author had an incredible premise, and she clearly has experience working with the concepts she so wanted to cast into words. I want to read this book when the author has clarified her purpose in EVERY paragraph.

With all of reality to play with, you'd think Simon R. Green could come up with a mind bender of a story.And he did!Play with existentialistic nihilism, or agnostic faith. Question the fact of unreality, of circumstantial absolutism. Revel in playful serious adventure, and you're ready to read this next installment of John Taylor in the Nightside. One of the six impossible things to imagine before breakfast.

I haven't the words to describe how utterly pointless this story is. The actions of the heroine and the police were mind numbing. I won't recommend this story, nor will I be reading anything more from this person.
This is a badly translated story, or the author doesn't speak English too well. I couldn't make heads nor tails of it.

This short story had everything I like in a short. It was a nice little mystery that had me wondering just what the heck was going on, and it was also bloody and truly disgusting! I'd love for this to be made in to a series. Yep, I'd recommend this story. But really, only if you can handle the ick factor!

I've been reading variations of this story for as long as I've been reading, but this is a tale that always fascinates me. Some are done badly, and some are so good they blow me away. I wasn't blown away with this one, but I thought it was done extremely well. That first wish was something I've not seen before. I will be reading more from Mr. Hill, and I would recommend this story.
A prolific serial killer who one day goes too far, and gets his supernatural comeuppance. This story had some truly skin crawling moments. I'd read more from this author.

Michael Bray can tell a story. This one put me right in that little boys shoes, or should that be old man's shoes? He got my heart pounding, and left me feeling broken for what this boy to man had lived through. Good tale that I would recommend.
A pretty good short story that took an interesting turn along the way. I wasn't expecting the ending at all, and I'm cool with that! Yep, I'd recommend this story.
What a very funny short story! I loved how Mr. Londergan didn't have a clue about what was going on. Hysterical! I'd read more from this series. Yep, I'd recommend this story and author.

I read this short story over a year ago, but I decided to read it again. It's a tale that's managed to stick with me all this time. Every other reviewer has told you what the book is like , so really all I have to say is read it, and enjoy the season of Santa Christ in all its glorious weirdness! Yep, I'd recommend this story and author.
As always, a well told short story from one of my favorite authors. I d recommend everything by this author.

This is my least favorite story by Mr. Padavona. I knew who the killer was immediately, and there wasn't a whole lot of slasher action. Except for the opening of the book, which was great, and kind of scary, the rest of it was just slasher 101. The story was good, just not much substance. Also, it ended at the 59% finished mark.  While I wouldn't recommend this story, I'd still very much recommend this author.

Angela's on husband #6, but he just married her for the money. He loves his new car. Now that he's old Angela that he never loved her, he'll be spending all the time he wants now with what he's always loved most. Yep, I'd recommend this story.

This was a well written short story, but there wasn't enough time spent on it to build up the true horror of the situation. I can see this author improving. I'd read more from Mr. Terence. Yep, I'd recommend this story and author.
Another great tale by this wonderful storyteller. I still won't be eating any eels though! Yep, I'd recommend this story and author.
Excellent short story with one heck of an explosive ending! I sure didn't see that one coming, and neither did Zukie! Yep, I'd recommend this story and author.

3 1/2 stars. I guess I'm the odd one out on these reviews, but having read all of Kealans other books, this one just wasn't up to the standards he's set in his other stories. Kealan has the unique ability, along with a handful of other authors to place me right into his tales, and in the process I feel the dread and slow build-up of fear. I didn't experience that this time. I was a good story, and definitely won't put me off from reading everything that K.P.B. releases. Would I recommend this story? Why not, everyone else seems to be raving about it. I do recommend this author, because he's one of the good ones!

I loved this dark and dare I say, delicious tale? It's starts off with me hoping those dastardly bad guys get their butts handed to them on a plate, "sort of happens," but it's ending is just beyond what I expected. Good vs. bad? Sometimes it's hard to tell the difference. Highly recommended.

You wouldn't know it by my rating, but I enjoy Mr. Black's stories. My main problem though is with the way he ends his stories. It always seems about half-arsed. It's my third short story from this author, and I've enjoyed every one, except the ending. I'll keep reading his stories though, because one day he'll maybe get it right.

Excellent story. Brian is absolutely the best when it comes to Vampires that scare me witless. No review from me on this one, as I'm ready to get going on the next. Even though I've read them all numerous times. If you want one heck of a story and vampires that are terrifying, then you can't go wrong with any of Brian's Necroscope books.
A halfway decent story about cops and a killer. I was enjoying it, then the Author threw in some random twist. It made sense at the end, but it did kind of ruin the story for me.

Jason has again managed to touch my heart and leave me with huge tears rolling down my face. I might need a hug too. There's something very special about this author, and it manages to shine through in every tale that he writes. I consider myself very lucky to have discovered this fine storyteller. Yep, I would recommend EVERYTHING by this author. He's a definite keeper.
Good short story. It made me a little teary eyed. I loved how it all played out in the end. Yep, I'd recommend this story and author.

3 1/2 stars. This was a well written short story, and I think this author will improve. For me, it was great up until the ending. It wasn't a bad end, just one that I personally didn't care for. Still, I would recommend this story and author.
This was a lovely homespun kind of tale. Not my usual reading material at all, but I was hooked from beginning to end. I will read more from this author and would recommend this story to anyone.
This was a short and fairly spooky story. It kind of made my skin crawl! Probably one of my favorite stories by Mr. Scribner. Heck ya' I'd recommend it.
Dang, this short story just creeped me out. Yeah, I loved it! Yep, I'd recommend this story and author.
Another short story from this very talented author, unfortunately it was also a head scratcher. Loved the short, but I do wish there had been more to it.
This was probably my favorite story out of Glen's "America" series. It was intense and one heck of a ride. I'm so ready for what's next! Yep, I'd recommend this story and author.

Joshua writes some really great stuff...most of the time. This short story was a mess. Reading it was great. I kept waiting to find out what was going on, or as one character kept asking himself, "what rule has been broken?" What was broken was that awful non-ending! There was no resolution, and no answers. No, I wouldn't recommend this story to anyone. I would however recommend almost everything else written by this author.

This was a fairly creepy tale. Something about looting tombs just gives me the creeping willies! I probably watched too much Scooby doo as a kid! I also enjoy the small bits of history that Mr. Stevens adds to every story. Yep, I'd recommend this story and author.
Love this guy's stories. This one was just creepy! Yep, I'd recommend this story and author.
I kind of loved this story.
This short story was odd and funny. Some times the dead just want to be left alone to sleep, and I say, good idea! Yep, I'd recommend this story and author.
Man's best friend tries to protect his owner in this short but very effective story. I felt sorry for the little guy by the end. Yep, I'd recommend this story and author.
Mr. Vernon is a storyteller. These were some good tales. I always recommend this author.

I enjoyed every single story here. The campers were funny, and I liked their take on how a short story should go. I bet authors hear that all the time! I'd read more from this author. His stories are varied, and he's got a sense of humor. I love that in a storyteller. Yep, I'd recommend this author.
Good story so far. I liked it enough to buy the second bok in the series. Yep, I'd recommend this book and author. I'm looking forward to more.
Nicely twisted short story! Dang, that ending was harsh. I'd read more from this author. Yep, I'd recommend this story and author.
Another good short story. I like how this story is playing out, and I'm looking forward to many more adventures from Jim and his magical friends. Yep, I'd recommend this story and author.

Well shoot, there I went and did something that I swore would never happen. Werewolves? Yeah, I can't stand reading about them, but I love this series, and I love Jim, and his wolf pack. I even bought the next story in this series. Great work, Mr. Myatt. Yep, I'd recommend this story and author.
Great story! I'll read more from Mr. Myatt. Yep, I'd recommend this story and author.

Mr. Gifune is high on my list of what's right in this world. His storytelling is some of the best stuff ever. I go in to any book from this author knowing that in less than a chapter I'm going to be full of dread. The different aspects of these characters and what they've been and are now going through made me feel like I was there every step of the way. Loved the story from beginning to end. Yep, I'd recommend this story and author.

Now this was one heck of a story. It had me hooked from beginning to end. Matter of fact, it was good enough for me to pick up a few more books from Mr. Dillard. Yep, I'd recommend this story and author.
Good short story, although I do wish it had been longer. I liked the surprising ending. I'd read more from this author. Yep, I'd recommend this story and author.

Another good short story from this talented author. I liked Jennifer, she had her funny moments. Unfortunately she also had one dumb moment too. Oh well, now she can eat all she wants without worrying about her weight! Yep, I'd recommend this story and author.

Wickedly good story. This is definitely one of my top favorites by this author. I also liked how it was a longer story than most of Mr. O'Donnells usual tales. Heck of a job on this one. Heck ya, I'd recommend this story and author

I loved The snow and the darkness, from this author, and I just knew I was going to enjoy the heck out of this story. I didn't. That's not to say it was a bad story. Somewhere in all this backwoods talking gibberish there may actually be a really fine tale. But, I cannot nor am I willing to read a story that doesn't speak the English language. These people were so uneducated and their way of spieaking actually ruined the whole thing for me. It drove me mad! I tried for 4 days to read this, and yes I understood every word, but it was maddening. I couldn't finish it, and that slightly pisses me off. Only because I do like Mr. Wilson's stories. This, I wouldn't recommend to my worst enemy. Horrible.

Although this story has been done before and in a much better manner, I still couldn't help but enjoy this short. Jubilee has some talent and if this story had gone on just a wee bit longer with a bit more resolution, then I probably would have given it 4 stars. Keep writing! Yep, I'd recommend this story and author.

While not any where near as creepy as most of Mr. Little's books, these stories were nicely done, and they all connected in a way. The first story had one of the funniest endings. A little tongue in cheek, if you will. The rest of the stories we're good and I can say that I'd have no problem recommending these stories.
Three of my favorite authors and three of the most ridiculous short stories ever. Honestly, .99 was way to much for these incredibly lame stories. Nope, I can't recommend this at all.

Wide variety of emotions when you read this one.Tanner (Rylee's brother) is a bit of an emotional loose cannon after his friend and photographer are killed while covering a war.  He finally gets what he wants, sent back to the thick of things where it happened, but his bosses don't think he is stable enough to handle it.  Not to mention he doesn't exactly have people jumping up to work with him.Beaux is there working as a freelancer but quickly finds herself as his new photographer.  He is a complete jerk to her right from the start, even after they sleep together.  I honestly did not like him at this point.  I felt something was suspicious about Beaux too, I just knew she was more than what she seemed.Secrets come out, and once again Tanner is thrown into turmoil.  I knew where this story would end up but it was a messy road to get there.

It was a quick read no doubt, but it is a novella.I however did expect more build up to a relationship, perhaps expressing more from the characters outside of the bedroom.I expected a little more angst prior to the epilogue.  Even a few chapters of their relationship after their commitment but before the epilogue would have been nice.

Haley is the shy, never out spoken, perfectionist who just happens to get the biggest slob, and to her, jerk of a neighbor, Jason.  For five years she's silently dealt with his parties, unkept house, and girls showing up at all hours yelling and him from his front yard.  Worse yet, they work together and he is just as bad there.But one day she has had enough when she finds him tearing up her prized tulips.  She takes matters into her own hands with the help of a hose full of freezing cold water.  After that, they quickly become friends, then lovers.  But what would life be without a little drama thrown in?

Rusty, the perceived guitar playing player of Black Addiction meets Alison in a bar and there is something different about her that drags him in.  Unfortunately, she is still with her loser soon to be ex and turns him down.  Weeks later Alison, who's entire life is falling apart finds him again with the intention of seducing him.  But what they both get out of that is the beginning of something more.  Of course there were a few road bumps, the past coming back to cause problems, and insecurities causing unnecessary reactions.I liked Rusty, he was an all around good guy.  Alison was a bit flighty but she was never a bad person.The HFN was adorable.

Ryleigh is my kind of gal, she's quirky and confident in who she is even if it isn't following the norm.  She owns and operates an adult themed ice cream parlor, with hilarious names for each treat.  She fancies herself kind of in love with her high school crush and sets out to get him at their high school reunion.  Of course, fantasy does not always play out the same in reality. And what she finds is that they really aren't perfect for each other at all.  However, his best friend and the guy helping her complete her new shop, Hunter is perfect for her.There is a moment of intensity and sadness when one rash decision threatens everything they were building.The HFN was worth it.

Three years ago Kian went to prison for protecting Jordan from her abusive foster father.  He killed him when he found him using a knife on Jordan.The world turned on her blaming her for everything so she had to go into hiding, changing everything about herself.  But now Kian is out early and the one thing he wants is to see her.She half heartedly tries to stay away but when her new identity is blown, Kian comes to the rescue again.The story wraps up kind of quick, and leaves you with a HFN.One thing that irritated me,  her room mate/best friend always seemed to be bullying her into things she didn't want to do.

Quick but cute read.Phoebe grew up crushing on her best friends older brother. Colton never looked at her as more than his kid sister's friend, he was too busy hopping from one girl to another.Seven years later, ten years since they have seen eachother, she returns to town after her sister's death.  Colton can't believe the beautiful women Phoebe turned into, and when she suggests a friends with benefits arrangement until he returns to the Marines he can not say no.There was no real drama in this story which I liked.  I look forward to following the rest of the Brody siblings stories.

Once again Noelle and Drake find themselves working together to solve a string of murders.  Of course them having to cooperate in any kind of professional way makes them fight every second.  Add in his ex that is quite stalkerish and Noelle is about to start shooting people, Nonna and her perverted parrot Gio included!Noelle and Drake come to some hard truths, and sweet confession.  I'm not sure where their relationship is headed but I do think they are a match made in a heavenly hell.  (side query, are the cupcakes the only thing making Noelle's pants tighter?)There were a few editing errors, words missing, and the name Jason instead of Jackson a few times.As a believer in the goddesses, I was a little miffed by Noelle's disrespect toward the Wiccan culture.

Kennedy and Graham became room mates after she answers an ad he placed.  A little unconventional since he is 5 years her senior.  It seems she is the crazy yang to his calm, ocd ying.  Ken to his Barbie.  The work as friends, but she wants them to be more.  Turns out he does to but is just really awkwardly slow about letting her know that.  That is until his brother, Blake, turns up and sets his sites on her.They both grow during this book.  Kennedy is extremely immature through most of it, I dare say she has ADHD.  Graham goes from closed off and robotic to passionate and angry.It takes a long time, the last few chapters, until they get their crap together and we get a HFN.I see no mention of Blake getting a story.

The book is split into two parts.  The first for me seemed slow, perhaps a little drawn out.  Kayla acted like a sorority girl instead of a thirty year old woman.  At this point I still wasn't liking her much, she was still the girl who slept with her best friends sorta guy.  Lachlan is Linden and Bram's adoptive cousin.  He is quiet and withdrawn from most everything around him.  He doesn't share much with anyone and prefers the company of dogs to people. He has scars from a childhood that was never happy, abandonment and abuse. Yet Kayla pursues him despite her vow of no guys for the near future.Lachlan and Kayla start a fling that will only last a few weeks before he has to return to Scotland.  But neither expected to not want to see the other go.Part two,  still slow for a third of it.  Kayla begins to be a different person.  Not the man eating hell cat anymore.  Lachlan's inner demons start coming out the longer they are together.  She finds out just how bad it can get and on top of that tragedy strikes her family.At this point you are on the fence as to whether they should be together at all.  Lachlan needs to fight his demons and Kayla needs to get herself out of the hole she let grief put her in.There was an HFN but I would like to see more of a wrap up with all three couples.

I followed this story through the weekly newsletter releases, but I have to say I thought it was much better reading it as a whole.  I was able to get into the story in a more emotional way.Teagan is Bryn's baby sister, and she has come to tour with the band much to Bryn's displeasure. From the moment she lays eyes on Jax she is drawn to him despite his bad boy ways.Jax is lead guitarist for Ruby Riot, he is full of himself when he is in rock star mode and has a no holds bar approach to living his life in that persona.But one girl, one smart, beautiful, and take no prisoners girl is about to bring him to his knees.  Of course it won't be that easy for him to grow up, he has a belief of what being a rock star is and it is hard for him to live a normal life.Being together is not easy for them, from those in their lives against it to the rabid violent fans making Teagan's life hell.  Add in Jax's out of control partying and Teagan's fears that she can't trust him, and it sounds like a recipe for disaster.But sometimes, even young love is the strongest.  Sometimes you find your soul mate where you least expect it.  And sometimes, you fight for what you know you can not live without.

4.5 stars (rushed editing in a few middle to back chapters)I wondered how Chloe and Jackson's story would end, especially seeing how disconnected they seemed to be in previous books.No doubt Jackson screwed up in a big way, almost in an unforgivable way.  But with a little help they were able to work through their problems.I only have one huge question....what book are the gals from the law firm from?!

If you've followed the series you know Gavin and Dixie's history.  This book leads off with Dixie discovering Gavin has been lying about where he was and not contacting her when they were in the same place.  Now you would think that she would be done after that.  But not Dixie, the girl is as stubborn as they come when it comes to those she cares about.Gavin has secrets, ones he'd rather Dixie never know about.  But in order to get her back he is going to have to come clean and hope that she forgives him.  Some of his secrets were doozies, not that he filled her in on the graphic details.The Liam storyline, I can understand why that had to be in there but I really questioned whether Dixie's obsession was unhealthy.  Yes, she wanted him to be safe and happy but I just don't see that it had to be her or nothing.There was a HFN finish to wrap up the series.  Liam's point of view at the end was sweet.

I thought Brin and Rye's practical jokes were a mess but I think being able to triple dare someone into anything may take the cake!Corbin and Ruby have been best friends since they were kids.  But one epically stupid mistake he makes when they are nineteen changes the course of their relationship.  Yes they are still friends but they are never as close as they once were.  I can't blame Ruby, honestly I think I would have thrown his triple dare in his face and told him to piss off if I was her.  But Ruby loves Corbin to much to push him out of her life so she endures.I loved the extra scenes in the back.  Especially the Halloween one!
It was good to see more of Iain and Page.  I haven't read more into the series yet so the update on others left me a little lost.The ending was sweet and I can not wait to read Malcolm's story.

Ah Buck, more than a Yeti.Buck just can't seem to get past his infamous past.  He wants Sunny (Waters' sister) and he is doing everything to make her believe that.  But time and again she proves that she won't trust him, even listening to everyone else instead of her own head when it comes to him.I can't blame Buck for finally having had enough, I actually applauded him for walking away.  Doing it helped him to open up the side of himself that only those closest to him have ever known.But alas, they do have their HEA.

I had no idea where the mystery was going.  Now I can not wait for the next book.Leonidas (Leo) thinks he is just an ordinary human, one hunted then desired obsessively by a vampire.  Alasdair is that vampire, he is ruthless and doesn't have any qualms when it comes to getting what he wants.  He only went after Leo as a source of food, one he enjoyed hunting first, but after he had Leo in his clutches he realizes their is something different about him.  A mystery he intends to solve.But Alasdair has a possessive and jealous sire. One who does like that his precious boy is turning toward another.When things start to come to light about Leo, they put his life in mortal danger.The ending of this book has me on the edge of my seat for book two.  What is going to happen if Vasilios has his wicked way?

I really liked this.  The first for me from this author but I have since added her to my favorites list.Matt is a Druid, though he has renounced.  He blames the head of the Druids for his father's death.  He wants nothing to do with them anymore, so when a witch he is destined to shows up he is less than thrilled.Kat is a witch, she doesn't fully understand it, and she can't really control it.  When she was ten her mother put her into hiding with a normal family to keep her safe so no one was there to guide her into her powers.All they each know is that they are drawn to the other and can't keep apart when near.Will Matt get over his hatred to be with Kat? Or will he break her heart again?

Great debut for Katie McCoy!I originally downloaded the sample to try but I clicked buy as soon as I got to the end of that!Sophie is a journalist assigned to get the story on baseballs soon to be it boy Nathan Ryder.  Problem is, Nathan hates reporters.  But Nathan doesn't meet Sophie as a reporter, he meets her as a women in a bar that he is attracted to.  Once the truth comes out Sophie has to work hard to get him to trust and believe in her in order to get her interview and most likely save her job.These two have chemistry there is no doubt about that, but the trust from him is still lacking.  Which become painfully obvious when a fellow reporter (snake) is sent to 'help' Sophie with her story.  Nathan doesn't believe her when she was only trying to save his skin and keep the snake from printing a horrible story.I did like the ending, but had a problem with it coming out that Nathan still hadn't believed her for weeks.I loved Mandy and Chris!  I'm not sure we need their book since we know their outcome but they were so cute!

Jackson, the biggest playboy of the brothers has met his match.  When he went after Bailey no one thought he was being more than his horn dog self so he backed off.  But he was through waiting and when he wants something he goes after it full speed ahead.Bailey is attracted to Jackson, no denying that.  But when his father unexpectedly has a massive heart attack and dies, she feels a connection to him.  Bailey lost her brother to suicide so she feels what Jackson is going through.They start a relationship that is full of sweetness and burning up the sheets moments.  But an old hook up of Jackson's threatens to ruin it all.I look forward to Noah's story.  But I have to admit that I really don't like story lines where ex's showing up with children they kept secret.

I think I may have liked this more than the first book.Alex was so lovable.  There was never a moment where you were mad at him, even when he was being a man-ho.Tripp, that girl was sometimes a mess.  You knew she loved Alex and I understood her fear but still being with the other guy while mad over your bf? no.The HEA was sweet.  I hope to see more from Memphis and Lyric soon.

Definitely different from Jo's other books.In this, Storm aka Troy is a very wealthy young man but he still has a ton of problems, some deadly.  He meets a strange girl walking down the beach where he is hiding out.Raylin is hiding out too, on the run from dangerous men who want her dead.  Her father and brother betrayed her putting the blame on her for money they took from other criminals.Storm and Ray are drawn together, though neither can understand why since they both have serious trust issues.Together they try and put down the dangers coming at them, along with his friends Rook and Hawk.There were a few editing issues that had me stopping to read the passage again.

Kennedy and Grayson forged a friendship out of shared pain, both their parents were abusive.  When they were 20, the friendship was lost after a night they crossed the line.Six years later they meet by accident.  Kennedy's friend had brought her to a fight that unknownst to her one the fighters is Grayson.  He sees her and immediately goes after her.  She knows they shouldn't be together because of a secret she has kept from him.  But Grayson won't take no for an answer.  That is until someone from their past tells him before she can.While I understand his anger, she did try to tell him.  He rejected her again and again and she did what she felt was right.The ending is an HEA.

Gabe and Holly met at a birthday party thrown for her.  She let go of her uptight style and had fun that night, fun that led to her going to a hotel with Gabe.  She snuck out while he slept, before he could get her number or last name.Two months later and she discovers that she is pregant, no something that fists into her life plans.  Now she has to track him down to let him know he is going to be a father.Six years ago Gabe lost his first wife in a car accident.  He is still very much hung up on her.  He lets Holly know that Jasmine was the love of his life time and time again but he still persues her.  I thought it was out of left field that he proclaimed to love Holly when he still dwelled on Jasmine.Holly was hard to like a few times too.  She is supposed to be a highly intelligent woman but she kept having near temper tantrums over things Gabe would do.  I hated how back and forth she could be.All in all, there was an HEA.

Dove finally has her man, but is he the right one for her?Johnson is Dove's dream guy, but he is also so opposite of her personality wise.  And Duke, he is so sweet, and there was a hot guy under all his grossness!Shannon finds her bizarre yang to her yin in Preston and heads off with him on shouldn't be without supervision destiny.Flower is unearthed as a beauty when she sheds her goth amidst a broken heart.And Dove, she has to decide who is her real soul mate.

Holy awkward Batman!!Dove is outrageous!  She's socially awkward and just uncomfortable in her own skin.  She is also surrounded by a band of equally bizarre neighbors.  Her best friends Shannon and Flower, a stalker and a girl who doesn't speak more than ten words a day.  And Duke, he is a disgusting free balling, fart wielding, sausage eating dude.Dove meets Johnson, the fill in pharmacist, when she goes to fill an embarrassing prescription.  He is a weird duck himself. He seems incapable of talking in less than surround sound volume.  She immediately begins crushing on him and does the most awkward things while around him.This book had me laughing and cringing in the best possible ways.

Second chance love story.Jensen and Mia were college sweethearts. They grew up together but didn't become a couple until she started college.  They were together a few years until he went off to grad school and they decided to be apart during that time with the intention of coming back together eventually.  Only that didn't work out since Jensen got a girl pregnant and decided to marry her.  Naturally Mia was upset, she had every right to be, and Jensen was selfish and acted like a jerk because she wouldn't have anything to do with him.  How in the world could he expect her to be ok with that and to stay in his life while watching him have a family with another.  That whole, we were on a break saying is just crap in my opinion.  If you knew that the girl was your future, why did you jeopardize it?So fast forward five years.  Mia has taken a temporary  job in NY where he is and ends up working with him.  Though she says no way will she be with him you just know she took the job with that idea somewhere in her mind.  And get with him she does though she tries to keep it casual. He of course wants her back and just wants her to accept what broke them apart.They go through a few wishy washy moments but in the end of course the guy gets the girl back.

Jax, Cash and Lily's son, has met his boom.  She just happens to be the girl he helped rescue along with his cousin July.Ellie has had a hard life. Growing up poor with a bad mother who only got worse after her father died.  She then loses her brother and his girlfriend in a car accident leaving her to raise her infant niece.  She's making a good life for them though, until her mother sells her off to a sex trafficking ring.After Ellie is out of the hospital, she and Jax go to get her daughter, Hope.  He takes them home with him knowing they are meant to be his.Between psycho unstable ex's, bad guys still out there, and one very precocious little girl, they find the family they both want.

Ally and Mark's story.Two people who were as stubborn and they were naive to each others true feelings.Mark wasn't the type to show his emotions and Ally was too scared to push the issue.  Also standing in their way was Mark's over whelming sense of duty and putting his job above all else.  It takes an accident to make him see what he may lose if he doesn't fix his priorities.I liked that they were each committed to only each other even if they were having a rough patch.It took a lot of back and forth but in the end was a sweet HEA.

Tony was a bit of a player in book one, until his life changed with an unexpected baby girl.  He's a different guy now.  All about baby Brianna and none of his old vices.He's not even tempted, until she walks into his life.Nicole is in River Bend to settle her grandma's house and get out.  She doesn't need the complication of a man, especially after everything her ex husband put her through.But after two hard hits to her bank account have her taking a job being the babysitter to Tony's daughter, she finds herself drawn to him in a way that she can't stop.She just has to figure out if she can let go of her insecurities and let love in again or walk away and never look back.

This is now in the tight running for my very favorite steel water bottle, neck and neck with the Contigo one. For me, 16oz is the ideal size -- anything larger and it's awkward to hold and probably doesn't fit in my car drink holder, and anything smaller seems to disappear in a gulp or two. Just like the Contigo one, this does a great job of preventing spills, even if you are as klutzy as I am. One of the things I love about my Contigo is that I can even drink water from it while lying down in bed without splurting water all over my face (a blessing while on bedrest, let me tell you!) -- this Aladdin mug isn't quite that adept, but I only have to raise my head a little bit. This Aladdin mug also has two advantages over the Contigo one -- it is easier to get the lid/mouthpiece totally clean, and it doesn't do that "release of pressure spurt" that the Contigo one sometimes does when you push the button. Other pluses here:* The coating is very smooth and nice to touch, and it doesn't freeze my hand straight out of the fridge like many steel mugs/bottles do.* The color is gorgeous, and it seems to hold up well to every day drops and bumps. I've had other steel water bottles that within days showed every scratch and ding in the color, but this one seems much sturdier in that regard.

This is one of those products where you can actually trust it to be exactly as described. It's a thicker, more durable material than your typical re-sealable bag, and it is indeed super easy to get completely closed with the sliding lock. I've had unfortunate experiences with generic versions of this in which the plastic slider kept the bag from quite sealing closed that last two milimeters, and that can lead to problems since air gets in and liquids can leak out. With this one, though, no such issues. The only minor challenge I encountered is that because the material is thicker, it is a little bit more work to get all the air squeezed out (which I generally try to do when freezing things). I still created a good near-vaccum state in the end, but it took a bit more attention on my part.

This wind spinner is far brighter and more glittery in real life than it looks in the picture -- but I have a feeling that it would have looked much better in a nicer yard than mine. I had hoped it would the the kind of thing that I could plop into an especially bare and ugly part of the yard as a nice distraction, but instead, it's a little bit like having a neon sign that yells "DEAD YARD HERE!" I've left it where it is because the cats do seem to enjoy watching it from the windows, but it would probably look quite a bit nicer in a better kept part of the yard. That said, there were some definite pros and cons here:On the upside --* Super easy to assemble and install -- it only took a few minutes, and I don't think it would have taken even a child much longer.* Thus far, it's held up relatively well to the elements. I'll update later if that turns out to no longer be the case.* As I said above, my cats find it incredibly appealing. My grandmother probably would find it so, as well.On the downside --* It's not quite as 3-dimensional as I'd thought from the picture. Admittedly, I didn't look or read closely enough, because I was expecting something a bit more globular in shape. Instead, this is has two 2-dimensional circles parallel to each other and spinning in opposite directions. The butterflies tweak out a bit in different directions, which both gives it some shape and allows the wind to catch it better, but it's still very much two plates with their backs to each other rather than a 3D globe.* It's almost too bright and cheerful for me -- almost as if it will start shooting out Hallmark greeting cards at any moment.

Medicine balls really don't need anything fancy to be functional, and so going "generic" with AmazonBasics totally makes sense for something like this. The weight is distributed nicely and evenly, which was definitely not the case for the brand name medicine ball of the same size I'd picked up at Sears and returned. I like that the material is just grippy enough that it's easy to hold (even with sweaty hands), but not so grippy that it would pick up lint and cat hair and such (which my yoga mat totally does). I also like that the colors are bright without being flashy or distracting. All in all, this is what I want in a medicine ball at a good price.

Although I usually like my books to be densely packed, so that I can feel like I'm getting my money's worth, I really appreciate that this particular book is paced more gently with double-spaced text, plenty of white space, and great water color illustrations. I'd always found the idea of birdwatching tempting -- I get a great variety of birds in my yard, and my hiking pace is perfect for birdwatching (i.e., slow with plenty of breaks). But the various field guides and such that I'd picked up all seemed to assume that I already understood the basic mechanics of bird watching, and so I never felt quite sure what I was doing or what I needed to be looking for.This book does an excellent job of going step by step -- and not in a patronizing way, but in a clear and enjoyable way. The steps are "bite sized" enough that this book would work well across a wide age span, or for a family venturing into birdwatching together. (As a side note, this book would be truly first rate for a family wanting to do Charlotte Mason style nature study together). So the book doesn't just have information for you, it also has activities at each step -- for example, there is information about the different types of field guides, and then activities around buying a field guide and becoming familiar with it and learning to use it. There are other guided activities on a range of topics, including using binoculars, sketching birds, creating a bird-friendly yard, and becoming involved in online birdwatching communities and their efforts in tracking birds and species.My only minor beef with this book is that the font they used makes the page numbers hard to read at times -- but while that would be a serious hassle with a field guide where you are referencing the index frequently, it is only a minor irritation here.

Although I love zip-up swaddle sacks because of how easy they are to use -- and how blessedly quiet they can be in the middle of the night -- these SwaddleMe swaddle wraps are probably the easiest way to get a dependable swaddle with a custom level of snug-ness. You can also customize how tight and snug a swaddle is with a regular blanket, but that can be more challenging to do in the middle of the night (especially if you don't have a good space for blanket origami), and it can be pretty easy for some babies to wiggle loose from. With the SwaddleMe, it's easy enough to get the baby swaddled up as snug as you want them, even in total darkness and in limited space, and the velcro keeps the swaddle exactly as you set it. Although some babies are going to be strong enough to Houdini themselves out of the SwaddleMe, those babies are also likely rolling over already -- and once a baby can roll over, it's no longer safe to keep their arms swaddled at night.The packaging on the SwaddleMes claims that you can easily remove the legs from the swaddle for a diaper change, and while that's kind of true, I haven't been able to figure out how to make it happen without undoing the middle velcro (the one that attaches the legs pocket to the first wing at the baby's chest). The've used a relatively strong velcro to hold the swaddle firmly, but that means that it takes some tugging and makes some considerable noise to undo -- and then once you're done with the diaper change, it is a little awkward to re-fasten that way, since you're having to sneak a layer of fabric under the velcro and then fasten it there. There definitely are other swaddle wraps out there that make for much easier late night diaper changes than this one. On the plus side, as the velcro goes, I really appreciate that they have stay-put tabs for the velcro to fasten on to during laundry, which keeps the velcro from snagging on the other clothes in the load.Lastly, I will say that the cotton knit fabric these are made from feels a bit rougher straight out of the packaging than do some other types of swaddle wraps, but they do soften up considerably with washing.

I have several other puppets from Folkmanis at this point, so I inevitably ended up comparing this one to those. And you know, there are ways in which I would expect a T-Rex puppet to differ from a monkey puppet, and Folkmanis did not let us down in that respect:* Whereas my other Folkmanis puppets are all soft and fuzzy (even the pig), this T-Rex is sleek and glisteny, which really works.* It has very visible teeth, all ready for a big roar. My only concern about the teeth is that they are made out of stiff felt, and I'm not totally confident that they will hold up as well or as long as the rest of the puppet. This T-Rex may eventually need some dental and orthodontic care.* The proportions are a little different, in that it's not quite as heavily foreshortened as many of the other puppets I have. The only odd thing about the proportions for me is that if I try to have my fingers in the arms and in the mouth at the same time, the neck/shoulders area basically collapses down because my hand isn't quite big enough to reach. That may be less of an issue for those of you who don't have my tiny mutant hands, or who aren't trying to operate the head and hands at the same time.All in all, it's a good T-Rex puppet. I will give the heads up (in case it isn't super obvious from the item picture) that this puppet is more of a "fierce" dinosaur than a "happy and friendly" dinosaur like Barney -- while some kids would absolutely love it all the more for that reason, this puppet comes across as just fierce enough that it has scared a few little ones.

This is a great pig puppet. Unlike a real pig, it is made of this deliciously soft plush. That said, I appreciate that they tried to make it a more realistic pig rather than a "cute" pig -- it's a little on the funny side, the the grunting noise it makes when you squeeze his haunches is a a nice deep, throaty grunt, and nothing like the squealing oink you hear from so many toy pigs. The hands and head are quite easy to manipulate --- I just don't have quite the right fingers to do a great job of manipulating the mouth on this one, although that may improve with practice. Even so, he's incredibly expressive, and I know that I'll have a lot of fun with him.

This is such a very awesome puppet. I love how very soft the plush is, and that it's big enough to be convincing. I was also thrilled that instead of the typical puppet mouth movement, with this one you can turn the head around just like a real owl. When I first tried it, I couldn't get the wings to flap realistically, but then I tried using it with my hand inserted palm up -- it was just as easy to manipulate that way, and the movement looked awesome. In case it's helpful, I have relatively small hands (i.e., I wear children's gloves), and was still able to use this just fine.I am sure that people might have many reasons for wanting a snowy owl hand puppet -- but I can tell you that this one will be a truly excellent Hedwig for anyone dressing up like Harry Potter. :)

It's entirely possible that I would have enjoyed this game more if I wasn't -- like so many other reviewers here -- comparing it to the version that I played as a child. In comparison, this one is not only a lot easier, but there are a couple of things about it that are frustrating:* The tweezers you use to extract the items from the body are attached to the game board with stiff plastic rope -- not only does it make it hard to get just the right angle for some of the spots, but the rope also flops awkwardly across the board.* This may sound petty, but I was irritated that so many of the pieces now aren't really linked to the body part in an interesting way. In the original game, there was a mix of actual body parts (bones and such) and pieces derived from the common name for things -- like an apple at the Adam's apple. This version has things like a cell phone to extract from the hand, etc.* And as far as why it's easier, I think there are a couple of things. Almost all of the pieces have handy ridges in the middle that make it extra easy to grab with the tweezers, even if you can't reach any of the edges. On top of that, the slots they are in on the game board are larger, and so it's pretty easy to use the tweezers to move the piece around until you have a good spot to grab.While I was pretty disappointed with the game, I still think it will be fun enough to have around for parties and such -- which is why I'm giving it a 3-star rating instead of 1-star.

These are awesome! I have taken to making my salads in batches (like everyone else who has seen the Pinterest posts about mason jar salads, I'm guessing), and the great thing about that is that it makes sense for me to buy my greens whole instead of in pre-packaged bags or boxes. Between the arthritis and my general impatience, though, the idea of tearing up all those greens by hand had no appeal for me. These salad scissors made short work of my lettuce, kale, and chard, and were even handy for the chunks of vegetables that were missed by the food processor. I found them super comfortable to use, even when I was cutting things at odd angles or through thick chunks.

Given my food allergies, I was all excited to find a new nutritional shake powder that was soy-free and dairy-free. Unfortunately, once I received the product, I saw information on the label that wasn't in the product listing here -- that the shake includes plenty of other signifiant allergens, including berries, mushrooms, etc. Especially for products like this, I'm always surprised when no one includes the ingredient list somewhere in the product listing. I shared it with my housemate, though, and it sounds like it tastes pretty similar to the pea protein powder we get at our local organic grocery store -- perhaps not surprising, since pea protein is the main ingredient here, and they are also the same color and consistency.
