3:23 MinsWireless is super convenient. Being able to move freely without removing the headset is just pure enjoyment. Initial pairing process was easy, just press and hold the play button until light blinks. Reconnecting is also quick thanks to the 4.0 technology. But if you want wired, a aux to aux cable is included.Buttons on headset are large and accessible even for first time user. A English speaking female voice will prompt when reaching certain commands like Power on/off, Bluetooth pairing, Maximum Volume and such.The muffs are large enough to cup over the entire ears, lined with a soft smooth synthetic-type leather. After several long hour sessions, my ears were warm which are expected but not overheated/stuffy. The pinch of the muffs were just right for me at the near largest settings. It is also fold-able for travel, includes a hard foam-like zip pouch for storage.Sound is balance and clear. Not bass heavy, providing a solid experience for any type of music or entertainment. Even though the muffs fully cover the ears, at higher volumes (70%up) sound begins to leak.The glossy reflective exterior is nice to look at but easily attracts oil/fingerprints. The modern design and color combinations (red, black and silver) are done well to look stylish and high tech.Overall, surprisingly comfy with user friendly functions and reliable connectivity, sample given for review.

Lights up really well, reminded me of the power puff girls, especially when holding the 3 connectors together. (blue, red, green) Cable material are tough and strong but soft enough to roll up for storage.Have been great for all sorts of make and model devices that charge through USB, like the older models of iPhone 4 and iPad 2 using the wide 30 pin connector, and also the now commonly known Apple lightning connector for iPhone 6/6 Plus and iPad Air/Mini.For micro USB, which the majority of portable device uses includes Android phone/tablet, Bluetooth headset/speaker, portable battery, camera (GoPro), exercise wrist band, list goes on...Overall, it looks cool and colorful while charging your device. Great for trips and handy for most devices.  Sample given.

These eye masks comes in a nice pouch, you get three pairs, can pick between black or one of each colors, and three pairs of earplugs. Overall good product!

I always wanted to get a seat belt for Cannes, my 70 pound blue Pit, thank you Vastar for giving me the opportunity to review the product and I am absolutely satisfied and would recommend to all dog owners, all feedback are my own opinion about the product.Cannes loves going on car rides with us and it doesn't matter where she sits, front or back, there was numerous times that when we had to slam on our brakes, she would either hit the dash board or the driver/passenger seats.  There was one time that she had a small cut from hitting the dash board...  This seat belt is perfect, it will prevent Cannes from hitting the dash board again for sure.  The strap is made with a pretty durable nylon, adjustable, shortest 15" and longest is 22".  The metal buckle fits both of my cars perfectly, I think it should be universal.  The latch is made with metal too and it can be easily snap onto Cannes's collar.Very compact, can be easily stored in the car.  5 stars product, all dog owners that take their dogs on car rides should consider getting one~

I cannot wait until December 1st arrives and we can start this new tradition with our son.  An advent calendar is nice, and we've done those in the past, but with those, most of the time your child is receiving something.  The Good Deeds Manger makes is easy to make it all about giving and doing good deeds for others.  Baby Jesus comes swaddled in a piece of linen, he comes laying in a real wood manger.  The set also includes 25 pieces of real hay in a burlap bag, a gold star to symbolize the North Star, and a proclamation to hang on your tree.  The idea is to start December 1st(parents, keep baby Jesus tucked safely away). do at least one good deed a day, when the good deed is done, place one piece of straw in the manger.  On Christmas morning baby Jesus will be in the manger, resting on a bed of straw, each piece representing a good deed performed by your child and/or family.This set is so well thought out, the details are amazing!  The manger itself is a true piece of craftsmanship.  The entire set is made in the USA.  I highly recommend adding this to your family Christmas traditions.  It would be a PERFECT gift also. Truly something for your family to enjoy for years to come.Good Deeds Manger provided at a discounted rate in exchange for my honest, unbiased review.

Easy to use, lightweight digital thermometer. I also noticed that there is no backlight on the display, so you need to be in a lit area, or move to a lit are after you take the temp. On a positive note, I do like that the tip is flexible and waterproof, this makes it easier to use with little ones and of course, gives you peace of mind when cleaning. While the concept is great, in reality, they are simply too thin to truly protect you personal information and data.  I personally tried this at a local CVS while my CC was in the Anti-Theft RFID Sleeve and the card was easily read at the RFID payment terminal. That's right, I was able to swipe and pay WITH the sleeve ON my CC!!  A thief will have NO PROBLEM scanning your CC for data if they have the means to do so!  I truly wanted this product to work, as I know identity theft is on the rise and the chances of it NOT happening to you are smaller than the chances of it actually happening to you.  Stay safe and vigilant out there!Anti-Theft RFID Sleeve 12 Pack provided free by LINKYO in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

I was really looking forward to this book, but after getting through half of it, I'm admitting defeat - so far I've found very few redeeming qualities. I recognize this will not be a popular viewpoint, particularly since it's hard to get published and easy to be a critic, but I'm just not a fan of this author's style or story.Briefly, the book sets up a war between the depraved King of England and the wonderful folks of Ireland, the land of magic, which is ruled in a tremendously democratic and delightful way by the stout-hearted Celts and their faerie friends.  The bad guys are very bad (and all evil Catholics, funded by Jews).  The good guys are generally good, as druids are, even if they keep getting forgotten for many pages at a time.  There's some confusing double-crossing, lots of gratuitous bloodletting, and rather too much un-steamy sex.  The story moves from 2016 to the late 1300s, forward 20 years, back 17 years, forward 7 years, back 3 years until you don't know (or care) whether the characters are coming or going.  Speaking of the characters, they are flat and poorly defined, and by turns whiny and then suddenly omnipotent.  The main character was supposed to suffer when her twin sister was killed.  This was clearly indicated by the fact that she voluntarily married a man who she knew was cruel and he promptly sodomizes her.  After 50 pages, he gets his comeuppance, but was any of that really necessary.  The plot appears to be just as clumsy - almost an afterthought to the rather lousy world-building.  There are too many flavors of faerie and not enough space for them all to have their own little corner of Ireland.  Oh, and there are Vikings, somewhat inexplicably.  With an armada poised to invade, I gave up.  It was never clear to me why so many people (including the reader) should remotely care what happened to Ireland or any of the characters therein.So why was I looking forward to this book?  Well, the 'reviews' by people I'd never heard of looked good until I started reading the book and understood what they meant:"simultaneously sweeping and intricate" means the passage of time is handled very poorly.  Pages upon pages deal with a single day, but then the next page goes backwards or forwards 20 years or 200 years."plundering the treasure troves of myths" means half the ideas are stolen and that Geoffrey Chaucer turns up halfway through, sounding thoroughly misplaced and completely out of his element."a wild grab bag of myth, history, folklore, and the fantastical" may sound great, but remember that most of what comes in a grab bag is stuff you didn't really want or need.If you want better world building, I'd recommend Bradley Beaulieu's Twelve Kings of Sharakhai or Robin Hobb's Assassin's Apprentice, which has just as much blood but for a much better reason.  If you want some old school magic, try TH White's Sword in the Stone.

I was really impressed with this chocolate.  The positive impressions started with the packaging.  A large bubble wrap envelope held a fairly large cardboard box that looks like it would hold a piece of electronics (like a hard drive) rather than 3 bars of chocolate.  Opening the lid of the sturdy box revealed the three bars, surrounded by a significant amount of shock-absorbing cardboard.  Needless to say, the three 100g (~3.5 oz) bars arrived in pristine condition.  The actual packaging of the chocolate is nice, but not quite as upscale as you might expect, but this is probably for direct consumption rather than gift-giving.  Black box with red and yellow trim and silver foil are all nice enough.  The important part is what's inside the packaging.This is 84% cocoa solids, which means it's on the dark end of dark chocolate.  Typical milk chocolates are 30 - 45%.  Dark chocolates are usually anything above 50% cocoa.  As one approaches 100% cocoa, the chocolate is basically cooking chocolate.  So this is a very dark, almost bitter, quite edible bar of chocolate.  It has a very nice texture with almost no graininess, despite not having any soy lecithin (an emulsifier often included in chocolate).  It's brittle with a nice rich mouthfeel.  The tasting notes describe this as floral and bittersweet.  I would describe it as not very sweet, quite bitter, not terribly floral, perhaps a bit flat at room temperature, but very chocolately.  The finish is almost pure cocoa and lasts for a very long time (at least 5 minutes).The bar is made by Nestle in Switzerland and branded for the North and South American market (mostly Brazil and Mexico).  Somewhat strangely the ingredients list is: Chocolate, cocoa butter, sugar, cocoa powder, vanilla extract - which is a bit like listing the ingredients of coca-cola as: coke, water, sugar, etc, etc.It's a bit bitter for my taste and not as interesting as some other chocolates that are out there.  If you're after a very clean bitter cocoa taste, this could be your bar.

This is a perfectly good moisturizing cream, but I still don't fully understand why I should bother with this product.  Will it really help my skin over the long-term?  How can I assess that in the 30 day period I have to review the product?Instead, I'll start with a quick analysis of the chemicals that are used in this thick white basically unscented cream.  It's pretty standard, with a fair amount of water, some alcohols, various components/precursors of fat and oils (eg, glycerin and long-chain fatty acids), some vitamins (notably E and A), some plant extracts (oatmeal?), and some preservatives.  Of all these chemicals, three need specific callouts:1, Parabens - cheap preservatives that have been widely used for a long period of time.  That doesn't mean we know everything about them.  They have weakly estrogenic (feminizing) activity in the lab, and have been linked to both cancer and DNA damage, since they can radicalize in the presence of UV.  Definitely not one of my favorites.2, BHA - there's probably only the tiniest of quantities of this Butylated Hydroxy-Anisole in the cream, and this stuff is routinely used as a preservative in food products, notably breakfast cereals.  But it's basically another form of toluene, which is a pretty potent carcinogen.3, Vitamin A - as at least one other review has pointed out, this is a potent teratogen, usually available only by prescription (or in ROC anti-aging cream).  It is often prescribed for acne, which is where my familiarity with this stuff comes from.  On the plus side, it's very good at dealing with mild to moderate acne over the long term - it takes a minimum of 2 weeks to have an effect and you may break-out more in the first two months before it really starts to improve things.  On the minus side, it makes your skin more sun-sensitive (ie, prone to sunburn) and has been shown to cause chickens to grow extra wings in the lab.  Of course, we don't know how much is included in this cream, which is one of my biggest issues with this cream.  There's a big difference between 0.5% and 5% - how much does this stuff have in it?Due to these three caveats, I'll probably discontinue use.  I've been testing it by applying it only to the left side of my face for a few weeks.  There are some pros and cons, as one might expect:PROs1, This is perhaps the only moisturizer I've ever used that doesn't make me break-out in seconds2, A little goes a very long way, and continues to work for at least half a day - you can still feel it at least 6 hours after you apply it3, It's not greasyCONs1, If you exercise with it, it will make you sweat more - is it blocking pores?  I can't tell, but I really notice it2, I didn't really notice any short-term benefits - my skin still creases in all the same ways, but it's just more moist now.3, As already mentioned, I just don't know if there are any long-term benefits.I'm a pretty critical reviewer yet I don't hate this product.  If you need a moisturizer, it's worth trying.  It may appear expensive, but I predict it will last a year with judicious application.  However, I'm concerned that we don't know enough about the composition of this, particularly since there are some potent chemicals in there, nor the long-term consequences of use.

Reflecting the latest trend in cases, this case is constructed so you can see through to the back of the phone - ooooh!Seriously, this is a great case.  It covers the back with clear tough ABS plastic and the sides are made of a generous layer of colorful silicon.  There is no protection for the front of the phone (ie, no scratch-resistant screen is included with this case), but the silicon extends a couple of millimeters above the screen to give a good lip.  It seems like this will protect your phone from a drop onto a flat surface, but probably not if you drop it onto a rocky one.  The silicon part of the case is also a bit wider than it probably needs to be.  When in the case, the phone has a nice low profile, but it's pretty wide, which could be problematic for those with small hands.  Unlike some purely silicon cases, this one doesn't seem like it will loosen with time.  I'm confident it will remain a tight-fitting case.As you'd expect from Otterbox, the quality is high - all the cut-outs are in the right place for either the iPhone 6 or the iPhone 6S (this case is not the correct size for the iPhone 5/5S or the 6+).  It's easy to push the buttons on the sides of the phone.  I've bought other (similarly highly rated) cases from other companies in the recent past, and this one is better, offers more protection and is sturdier.

...and that's it.The first book in this trilogy made me want to read everything Robin Hobb has ever written.  It was an excellent story with a fun and engaging main character.  The second book in the trilogy piles on the injuries the main character a little too much.  This last book is 770 insufferable pages in which the main character is assaulted in almost every imaginable way: physical, mental, spiritual.  He is stripped of all the interesting layers and left as not even a broken shell of a man.  I think Ms. Hobb was trying to reimagine the cliched "to defeat them you must become them," but it just left me thinking that Ms. Hobb is a bit of closet sadist.  I was enough of a masochist to read the book, but I won't be reading any more of her writings.Two notes:1) Like many others, I was surprised to get to page 700 before things started to wrap up.  The mysterious and terrific enemy established in the first book and belabored in the second is dispatched in about three pages with about as much preamble as the character usually gives to his evening meal.2) It appears from the jacket covers of the follow-up trilogy to this story that even Ms. Hobb relented and reimagined a happier ending for the main protagonist...

I have used daily disposable contact lenses for about 15 years.  I prefer daily disposables to those that have to be cleaned daily because they are much more consistent, easier to deal with, and if you rip one it doesn't matter.  J&J Acuvue Moist are pretty good and have all the things I like in contact lenses: they're comfortable, tinted to make them easy to find, and offer UV protection.  Recent changes in regulations have pushed some daily disposable contact lens prices through the roof, including most J&J lenses, so I started looking around at other brands.I really like some of Ciba's Focus Dailies, but the ones I used to use don't offer UV protection.  J&J's Acuvue Moist are even more comfortable and offer all the things I like, but for a high price.  B&L's Biotrue lenses are also quite comfortable and offer UV protection for a very reasonable price.  However, these Clariti lenses are just dreadful.  The price is high, yet the packaging is poor and the lenses are very uncomfortable, particularly around the edges of the lenses.  My eyes became itchy and tired in minutes.  I wore them for five days, often for my usual 15 hours, but I couldn't wait to take them out.  It's strange because they should be just like Acuvue Moist - they are the same price, very similar composition (around 55% water), and offer UV protection, but I think the difference is in how the manufacturers 'round off' the edges.  For the price, I would rather have Acuvue Moist than torture my eyes with these.  However, I will continue to look for cheaper lenses that are legally allowed to be discounted. I was really shocked at how poor these lenses were.

This lightbulb is nicely constructed but not what we'd hoped for.  Although the 'temperature' is rated at 2700K (warm yellow light), it's too harsh for our living room.  In addition, it's too tall to fit in our light fixtures.  Finally, although it claims to be dimmable, it really only has three states: fully on, barely on, or off.

I received this machine for review purposes - I would not have purchased it with my own money, having previously had a poor experience with a Toshiba Portege R500 about 10 years ago.That having been said, this machine is a reasonable desktop replacement with a large hard drive, relatively fast processor, and a dedicated video  card.  It also has good speakers, a DVD drive, an SD slot, and some USB 3 ports.  The 15.6 inch screen has a relatively small half-inch bezel, a reasonable chiclet-style keyboard, and a nice big trackpad.However, it has many issues:1, Build quality is pretty bad - Plasticky, sharp edges, and a trackpad that feels like I'm about to press through it2, Weight is significant - It's a 5 pound brick and really only good as a desktop replacement3, Keyboard is only OK - The layout is OK but the keyboard is not backlit and the spacebar is a bit small.  The trackpad is too easy to swipe, moving the cursor to a completely different part of the screen, which gets really annoying when typing.4, Hard drive is huge but slow - This machine has a slow-spinning 1 TB hard drive; it does not have the more desirable solid-state drive.5, Included DVD drive is a waste of space 99.9% of the time - None of my other machines have an optical drive and I've never missed it.6, Screen is old technology - The resolution is low (1366 x 768 isn't even 1080, let alone "4k") and is not touch sensitive.The compromises aren't awful, but they do raise the question of who would want to buy this machine.  The high-end core i7 processor, dedicated graphics card, optical drive, and big hard drive might make this machine great for students who download movies and play a few games.  However, the resolution of the screen is not that great and it weighs too much to carry around.  In addition, the battery life is pretty lousy compared to the HP Elitebook that I use at work.  It's probably intended as a desktop-replacement, to be hooked up to a decent monitor and keyboard.  If that's what you're looking for, this may be a reasonable machine for your purposes.

There are two types of electric shaver.  The first, epitomized by Norelco/Philishave and Remington, has a set of blades on a little circular platform that are spun at high speed behind a grate.  The second, most famously from Braun and now Panasonic, has a set of blades that oscillate from side-to-side beneath a very thin guard foil.  I won't consider electric clippers (as used by most barbers), since those really are best for trimming hairlines, rather than removing stubble.This shaver is a very respectable example of the second type of shaver, with oscillating blades.  One important question with any shaver is how it deals with the contours and curves of the face, especially if the blades are straight.  This shaver features two adjusting pieces.  First, the entire head can pivot at the 'neck' (around the power switch) from side to side.  Note that some shavers move forwards and backwards too, but this one does not.  Second, the individual foils are mounted on springs and can move independently of each other.  (Sidenote: this shaver advertises three foils, but there's really only two, connected by some weird bladed thing in the middle.)  All in all, it works fine, especially on flat/slightly convex facial surfaces like cheeks.  The shaver does struggle on the angles of the face, particularly the sides of the jaw and the very edge of the chin.  It is possible to get a reasonably close shave there, but you have to hold the shaver at the correct angle and do multiple passes.  The next important question is how quiet is the shaver.  Although it's pretty quiet, this shaver is definitely a little louder than most rotary Norelcos from the last decade.  I think it's probably quiet enough for most folks, but if you want a super-silent shaver, look elsewhere.Other features that some will value include the following:1) battery life, which is about an hour - on the high side of average2) battery life indicator, which is poor - I had a Norelco that counted down the minutes left; this one just has 3 blue LEDs that light up for the briefest moment after you've finished shaving3) battery type - lithium ion, which is the current benchmark for this product type4) weight, which is again absolutely average for an electric razor5) ability to use in the shower or with lather - still a somewhat unusual feature, of limited use for me but necessary for some folks6) Sideburn trimmer - standard on all but the smallest travel electric shavers, this one is fine but no match for a dedicated clipper.7) Travel cover - a clear plastic piece to protect the blades and the power button from getting knocked around8) Clipper converter - an interesting device to turn the whole shaver into an adjustable clipper, but still no match for an actual clipper...The other cool feature of this shaver is the fact that it comes with a charging stand / automatic cleaner.  Braun and Norelco first introduced these a decade or so ago as a way to differentiate their top of the line shavers.  They're hard to find on such a reasonably priced shaver.  This one has a useful filter to ensure that all the little hairs removed by cleaning don't get cycled back into the shaving head.  The cleaning cycle is quite a bit noisier than just using the shaver and takes 20 minutes.  The noise prevented me from using the cleaning stand too early in the morning, which is a bit of a nuisance.  Another drawback of the cleaning stand is the need to buy (overpriced) foil pouches of detergent (ie, soap) with EDTA (ie, the same anti-microbial used to keep humidifiers from getting moldy).  On my old cleaning system, I would change the solution just a few times a year, which sort of defeats the point.  The solutions last longer if you just lift off the foil covers and knock out the excess hair before loading the shaver in the cleaner.  Although annoying, such cleaning stands do improve the quality of the shave and are worth having.Time will tell how the blades last over time.  I found my Norelco shaver blades last about 2 years or so before they really start to get appreciably worse, but then they cost one-third the cost of this shaver to replace.  Replacements for this shaver are hard to find, but look like they'll run twenty to thirty dollars.  I'll update this review as necessary.All in all, this is a perfectly respectable lightweight wet/dry shaver with pretty good battery life and lots of add-on features (cleaning stand, clipper converter, travel cover) for a reasonable price.  Step-up models spin their blades faster and have better battery life indicators.  If you have really thick stubble, it might be worth looking into a faster model.  If you travel a lot, you might need a better battery life indicator.  In short, this is not the best shaver on the market, but it is pretty good value.(Disclosure: this shaver was provided free by the Amazon Vine program)

After a very enjoyable first foray into the realm of A Secret Atlas, I was looking forward to more.  Well, no longer.  I'm 150 pages through the book and will not continue.  I will try and explain why without revealing any spoilers for those who do wish to read the book.All the characters from the first book are back, but most of them have changed substantially in very odd ways.  Several characters carry on with a surveying expedition for no apparent reason, at least two characters quickly becomes gods, and at least one main character becomes completely possessed and, jarringly, starts getting written in the first person.  There are still one too many characters to keep straight (is that Prince Cyron or Warrior Cyrus?  Which minister is that again?), having four parallel plots is challenging, and the existence of a parallel dreamworld into which several characters are absorbed just adds to the confusion.

I don't want to give away too many details of this excellent book, but suffice it to say the short description on the back of the book does not do justice to the story within, nor does it do justice to the quality of the writing.The book starts out as an engaging tale of swashbuckling that is leagues better than the overrated Lies of Locke Lamora.  There's a little less dry wit, but the characters are well-differentiated and well-drawn.  The setting for the book is remarkably well-described through beautifully transparent prose that never gets in the way, but rather draws the reader in.  The plot is complicated enough to be interesting but not too complicated to follow, with plenty of intrigue.As the story continues, there are two narrative arcs: present day and a decade earlier.  These are interwoven in a very clever way, revealing exactly the right amount of information at the right time in a way that only once seems slightly contrived.  The characters all evolve in a rewarding, impressive, and believable way.  The plot continues to suck the reader in and the prose never gets in the way.When I finished this first volume in the "Song of the Shattered Sands" series, I couldn't wait to start the next one, which is not yet available at the time of this review.  In the meantime, I will go back and pick up some of the author's earlier works.  It's been a while since I've been this excited to find a new author.

Although I've given this book a three star review, that hides the bi-modal nature of the book.On one hand, the 47(!) principles of success are useful, astute, and the kind of thing one usually only gets from experience.  It's clear throughout this book that the author has had those experiences ... in the peculiarly confined world of strategy consulting.  I've also had some of those experiences in the same peculiar world, and most of the principles really resonated with me.  The principles described are worth four or five stars.  If I were to write all of them here, you'd have one fewer reasons to buy the book, so I'll just list a few:1, Focus on what really matters2, Start with the hard stuff in the morning3, Catch small signs and make a difference4, Have a 30 second answer for everything5, Frontload your project...19, Pause 3 seconds before answering difficult questions20, Question more and talk lessThe 47 principles are helpfully divided into four sections:1, Building the better self2, Growing with others3, Excelling in process management4, Going the extra mileThe last section (Become a thinker and a writer) is a little self-indulgent acknowledgement section, which is fine, except that there's already a self-indulgent acknowledgement in the beginning AND a self-indulgent introductory chapter.If you're beginning to sense a theme that the writing style left a little to be desired, you've already realized why I only gave this book 3 stars.  In true consulting style, there are three reasons why I didn't like the text.  First, it's written in a very conversational style, but that leads to lost clarity on quite a few occasions, not helped by omissions of punctuation (at least in my pre-publication copy).  Second, a substantial portion of the text is re-quoted from other self-help books you've probably heard of ("the seven habits of highly successful people"), or in one egregious example, the oracle from the film The Matrix.  Lastly, despite being a very structured and organized thinker, many of the author's stories ramble and a few are not even relevant.  Several times, he delves into pseudoscience explanations for why it is best to do hard work at 4:30 am or why running is the best exercise.  As a side-note, since the author also recommends eating dinner with interesting people, even if it means putting off work until 3am, I'm left wondering when the author slept.  In the final chapter, the author reveals that he wrote most of the book by "bulldoz[ing] through several sleepless nights."  This flagrant flouting of the author's own second principle is very apparent - the writing deserves one or two stars at most.It seems unfair to bash this book for the writing when the bullet points are so useful.  If you can get past the poor writing, the 150 pages in this book will go by quite quickly, and many of the 47 business principles are definitely things I wish I'd known earlier, rather than having to learn through experience.  My only question to the author is whether it really is possible to learn these principles without experiencing them personally...If you didn't like this review, please let me know how I can improve it in the comments section.

This book was published after the author passed away in late 2014.  That makes it very hard to describe how little I liked this book, but I'm required to review it, so here's what I think: if you're a big fan of the author it's probably worth reading.  However, I won't be reading any of his other works to compare them to this one.  Anyway, regardless of whether you agree with my review, please use the voting buttons if you find the review helpful or not.This book purports to be an epic adventure covering 3 billion years.  It explores aspects of time dilation and also imagines what a society of humans might evolve into if their entire world were a tree on a comet.  The tree on a comet concept was first described in the 1920s, something author reminds us of at least twice.The story moves along at a reasonable pace, although it's hard to care for any of the characters.  They appear to be there solely to keep the plot moving along.  The plot itself is little better, and appears to be there only to allow the author to put together some claptrap pseudoscience ideas in a way that sounds vaguely plausible.  That's fine, until it goes too far, towards the end of the book, when it just becomes an unbearable diatribe.  The bad guy is a bit deranged, for no apparent reason.  The good guys are beyond good.  Inexplicable, improbable things happen and mind-blowing coincidences are just part of the story.  And then you get hit with 20 pages of gushing partial scientific explanation, some of which isn't even really relevant.The book, in short, is a mess.  I would much rather read some Joe Haldane (Forever War) or even Cloud Atlas.  I should have realized what was wrong with this book when the best quote they could find to put on the cover was, "the science is so good, it's hard to believe he's not a scientist!"  Well, having struggled my way through most of the book, I can believe he wasn't a scientist.  One other thing to keep in mind: there's nothing about the story in that quote, or any other.  Yeah, there's a reason for that.

This is a white paste toothpaste from Colgate that's not very different from the last few generations of Colgate Total.Based on the ingredients list, it is almost identical to Colgate Total Whitening, except that it no longer contains mica (a family of silicates that usually contain sodium, potassium, calcium, and/or magnesium).  Compared to the gels, it also does not contain FD&C blue #1.The good news is that it contains fluoride, which helps to strengthen teeth, and triclosan, an anti-bacterial agent.  Triclosan is usually used to kill bacteria outside the body.  For instance, when doctors scrub in for surgeries, they use soaps containing triclosan.  At the low concentrations found in toothpastes AND as long as you brush for 2 full minutes, triclosan appears to be a pretty good anti-bacterial agent that reduces bacterial colonization of your mouth, especially between teeth (plaque) and around the gums.  Triclosan remains a little controversial, although it's been in toothpastes and other household cleaning products for many years.  All the dentists I've spoken to agree that the fluoride is the most important active ingredient.The bad news is that this toothpaste doesn't taste minty.  In fact, it's almost impossible to describe the flavor.  The first time I used it, it tasted a bit like a dentist's office, which is not an especially appealing flavor.  Since then, it just tastes bland each time I use it.  I miss the mint, but if you're not a fan of minty toothpastes, this might be the one for you.Nothing else major has changed over Colgate Total Whitening.  The tube is a little smaller for the pricepoint.  They used to sell 6.4 oz, then 6.2 oz, then 6.0 oz for the same money.  This is 5.8 oz.  It still claims to reduce plaque, gum inflammation, and also whiten teeth.  In addition, this paste claims to be capable of 're-mineralization!' to 'promote enamel re-growth!' and other such things.  There is no good evidence for these claims - they're certainly not conducting clinical trials like drugs - but there's no evidence against them either.  These new claims for the same old paste appear to stem more from changes in dental beliefs than from actual changes in toothpaste formulation.  I'll check with my dentist next time I go to visit, but for now I'd say that if you're looking for a non-minty toothpaste with fluoride and triclosan, this is probably fine.  For my part, I'll keep using the virtually identical minty version that doesn't claim to add back lost enamel but does come in a bigger tube.

I cannot stress this enough: do not buy this watch.  It is monstrously overpriced for a poor Japanese movement assembled in China with the cheapest possible materials.  Even an Akribos would be better.  The following issues have been reported with this watch:1, Sub-dials may not work2, Quality is extremely low3, Does not keep time4, Breaks frequentlyApparently "Superjeweler" will sell you this particular model for about one-fortieth of the price listed here.  Even at the price of a cab ride, this is still not worth purchasing.

Although it's not clear from the picture, this is a four foot long cable.  The cable is flattened, making it easier to coil or slip through narrow gaps.  Otherwise, it's a pretty standard cable.Plug one end into a USB socket, such as you'd find on a computer, some newer travel adapters, or the plug that came with your iPhone or iPad.Plug the other end into the "lightning" connector on a new iPhone (5, 5S, 6 or later) or iPad (anything made after mid-2013).  This is not compatible with Android or other non-Apple phones or tablets.  It is also not compatible with "30 pin" connector Apple products (iPhone 4 and earlier, etc).Oh, and it's purple!  What's not to like?

I enjoyed Half a War much more than I ever expected to.This is essentially a medieval fantasy which involves a fair amount of swords and swash-buckling.  The story apparently concludes a trilogy.  I say apparently because, unlike many trilogies, this book stands alone extremely well.  I can say this with confidence since I thoroughly enjoyed it without reading either of the two prior books.  I may now go back and read those, even though this genre isn't really my favorite.The pacing is steady and the writing is good.  There isn't too much technobabble/altered vocabulary to plough through, although the names are a bit challenging at the start.  For instance, it took me 40 or 50 pages to realize I had Raith, Rakki, and Brand mixed up as being just two characters, mostly because I was confused about how Thorn and Rin fit in.  So far, so three stars.The two standout aspects of this book, which elevate it above a typical fantasy, are the strong character development and light-hearted yet suspenseful writing style.  The characters are drawn a little sketchily at first, but are definitely allowed to grow and develop over the course of the book.  At least four major characters are almost unrecognizably different by the end of the book (assuming I kept their names straight!).  These transformations were handled very well and made me care enough to finish the book.  I probably would have finished the book anyway, since the plotting and writing were good.  The author clearly had fun writing some of these characters and that really shows through.  It's not all earnest "defeat the powers of darkness or else!"  The author makes time for some humor and does a nice job of revealing the inner thoughts of most of the protagonists.So why not five stars?  Well, the plot had a few twists, but nothing earth-shattering.  Several character threads were left disappointingly unresolved, to the point that I'm forced to wonder if there will be a fourth book in this "trilogy."

This is a spy novel, set against a sci-fi backdrop.  It aims to be like Fleming's "The Spy Who Loved Me" and in many ways it's almost as fun.  The plot moves along as rapidly as a summer blockbuster, and the writing is reasonably taut.  The two central characters have chemistry, despite their differences.  The book tries to ask some Big Questions, much bigger than the airplane-suitable thriller this book could easily be mistaken for.For instance, the book explores the idea of what you might be capable of if you weren't 'cursed' with a memory or a conscience.  Through a barely believable sci-fi plot device, the main character (Peter Caswell) has his memories selectively removed.  Knowing that he is unencumbered by memory, the book explores what Caswell is and is not prepared to do.  How callous are human beings?There's also some interesting allegorical reference to the Cold War, as seen through the warped vision of someone drunk on James Bond and using hazy hindsight.  Instead of East vs West, there is a war of North vs South.  Instead of an iron curtain, there is a no-man's land called the Desolation.  What is it that we were fighting for?In the end, though, this is just a good action read, with more emotional awareness than your average spy story.  It's not the best thriller I've ever read, and it can't really hold a candle to masters of the genre, but I had trouble putting it down and the main characters were much more likeable than they had any right to be.  This book stands alone, but I wouldn't be surprised if there are sequels.  I'd probably read them, too, and that means it gets four stars.

I've used Eagle Creek luggage for over 6 years, which included a two year stint of weekly cross-country travel.  For the most part, it stood up to tremendous abuse with very little visible wear and tear.  In short, I'm a fan.One of the best features of the luggage was the shirt/trouser pack-it bag, which is one of the pieces included in this set.  It's deceptively simple: a bag with a stiff base and a (smaller) 'template.'  Using the included instructions, you can fold a collar shirt or pair of trousers around the template and about 10 items will fit in the bag perfectly, where the stiff base keeps them from folding.  This new "Specter" version further improves on that concept in two important respects: it's about half the weight and the capacity has gone up by a claimed two shirts.  Actually, the dimensions are the same as before but the velcro is a little more generous.  I now use the template on top of the pile of clothes to make it easier to shut the velcro closures.The other two pieces are carefully designed with bag dimensions in mind: the bigger one is about 13 x 10 inches and the smaller one is about 10 x 6.5 inches, both perfect for airline carry-on bags with external dimensions 22 x 14 x 9 (pretty standard in the industry).  The bags are really lightweight ripstop nylon parachute material.  The smaller one is good for underwear, while the larger one is the perfect size for t-shirts.  They're also covered in some amazing non-stick because they're really slippery.  That's great for pulling things in and out of a well-packed bag, but it can be a double-edged sword if you're relying on friction for everything to stay in place.I really like the lightweight nature of these packing pieces, which will work well with any standard-sized airline carry-on.  However, I wish they had thrown in one more small bag for this price.  Also, to save weight the shirt packer has sacrificed the template-storage pocket in the base.  But having now used this for a couple of trips, it's a product I wish I had bought earlier - even at full price.

There's a lot of confusion about this product on Amazon, probably because there are two distinct products being sold on this page.  One is an "Enamel Health" toothpaste that combats sensitivity.  The other is an "Enamel Health" toothpaste that whitens teeth.  I am reviewing the latter, which makes no claims about its ability to combat sensitivity....and why should it?  The ingredients list makes this a very standard whitening toothpaste.  There's fluoride, which is a critical component of most toothpastes, and not much else.  There are no anti-bacterial "tartar control" agents like triclosan, which means this toothpaste will not reduce tartar or promote gum health.  I've been using tartar control toothpastes for over 20 years and have had consistently excellent results with them, so I miss this feature.Contrary to what other reviewers have mentioned, this product does NOT supply additional calcium in any form (unless they're using brittle mica rather than the more common sodium and potassium-containing forms of mica).  Colgate remain unclear on this issue, claiming only that their formulation "helps replenish natural calcium."  This toothpaste's big selling point appears to be that it is alkaline rather than acidic.  Acids dissolve enamel, so perhaps that is what they mean.  In my view, this is weak logic, since the bacteria that live on your teeth (which this toothpaste probably isn't doing much to combat) produce acid fairly consistently during the day and night and probably overshadow any benefits an alkaline toothpaste has.The toothpaste itself is pretty unsatisfying to use: it's watery and tastes chalky, minty, and chemically.  The texture isn't that great, either.  It reminded me of Arm & Hammer's classic baking soda toothpaste ... without the baking soda.  If that's why you want, that's probably a better choice.  In fact, at first I thought it was a watered down kid's toothpaste, but the package explicitly notes it's only for kids over the age of 6 (presumably because of the titanium compounds in it). For me, I'll stick to my Colgate Total gel, which has a better texture and triclosan.  (For those who are justifiably worried about antibiotic resistance, triclosan is not generally used as a systemic antibiotic and should not contribute to the spread of antibiotic resistance, but please feel free to correct me in the comments section if you disagree).

Historical fiction isn't my usual genre, but I'm quite enjoying this book.  The writing is really good, even without considering the author's Italian background.  The story is atmospheric without dwelling too much on irrelevant (or sordid) details.  The characters are developed quite nicely, and are more multi-dimensional than I'm used to, which is a very pleasant change.As far as the setting goes, there isn't quite as much about 15th century Florence as I'd hoped (or feared), but the story and political intrigue move along quite quickly.  I'm looking forward to reaching the conclusion.

This product is great for those of us suffering with mild acne.  It's only 0.5% salicylic acid, about one-quarter the strength of most Clearasil overnight products, but that turns out to be good enough for me.  I get the best results when I leave it on my face for about five extra seconds before washing it off.I love the foaming nature of this facewash, as well as the light scent.  It doesn't dry my face out, either.  The size is very convenient and seems to last quite a while.  All in all, I'm very happy with this product.  I've used many products over the years (except ProActive and others of that ilk) and this is definitely not going to help moderate or severe acne.

Pretty disappointing.  The plastic is cheap.  The bristles are extremely hard and inflexible.  The whole thing is unnecessarily bulky for what it is and not very good to use.I love Denman hair brushes, but this is not up to the name.

This aerosol-type clear sunscreen is really quite good, but isn't quite as good as the confusingly similar "Neutrogena Ultimate Sport" sunscreen that we like to use in my family.  Both are sweat/water resistant for 80 minutes.  Both have the same active ingredients (avobenzone, homosalate, octisalate, octocrylene, oxybenzone).  Both are around 5 oz.  The big difference is the feel of the product as you spray it.The Ultimate Sport feels like a fine dry powder the moment is touches your skin and cannot be rubbed aroundThe Cool Dry Sport is (somewhat confusingly) the one that goes on wet.  It can be rubbed around, but dries very quickly.  The product reminds you that it does not feel greasy, which is almost entirely true.  I'd say it feels a little oily until it dries a few seconds later.The other slight difference is in the cap.  The Cool Dry Sport has a great cap that locks by turning it.  The Ultimate Sport requires a separate, easily lost plastic cover.In the end both of these sunscreens are great products.  They are easy and quick to apply, offer excellent sun protection, and last for quite a long time.  I would not hesitate to recommend either.  I will continue to buy the Ultimate sport because I like the feel just a little better.  I just wish it came with the cap and slightly larger quantity (5.5 oz) of the Cool Dry Sport.

This is exactly as promised - it works beautifully to switch something on at dusk, leave it on for 2, 4, 6, or 8 hours (or all night) and then turns it off.  It'll take a 3 prong plug.  There are cheaper models but this is the one to get - thanks to all the other reviewers who were spot on in their reviews!The only problem I can see is that you can't reverse the switch (on during the day, off at night).

This is a somewhat short but often entertaining collection of short stories by Jonathan Lethem, who is known for his astute and sometimes surreal fiction.  If you're a fan of Haruki Murakami, you'll probably really enjoy most of these stories.  I say most because there was at least one pretty weak story (The Dreaming Jaw; The Salivating Ear).All of these 9 stories have been published before, 5 in the New Yorker, 1 in the Paris Review, 1 in Harper's, and the last two in one-off hard-to-track-down volumes.The only common element in these stories is Lethem's ability to build a world for his characters in a very short amount of time.  He's clearly comfortable writing about New York City but also surburban California.  His characters inhabit slightly odd places (but nothing as odd as Gun with Occasional Music), and get into some strange situations, but Lethem is at his best when he's describing the almost real oddities of life, as experienced by the stranger-than-real characters he develops so effortlessly.

I should clarify that I really like the SINGLE flask that I received.  The description that Amazon offers this flat bottomed flask under is "pack of six."  The price is expensive for one flask and cheap for six, but I wanted six, as it was originally listed (for over a year) in the description.If you order this product, please be aware that you will only get ONE flask, not six, no matter what the description promises.The flask itself is really quite good.  It is Bomex glass, which means it should withstand direct heat from an open gas flame - it should be safe for your gas stovetop, if you want to test your luck.  Bomex is a cheaper copy of Pyrex and Kimax glass, both of which I would have preferred.  The flask also stands up and is reasonably stable, thanks to its flat bottom.  You will not need a tripod/clamp to use this flask.

I had hoped that this book wouldn't be like every other business book out there: one short idea that is somehow stretched, mostly through innovative use of 'chapters,' into book length, when in reality it would have been more efficient (but less lucrative) to just tweet the idea in the first place.Unfortunately, this book has exactly the same flaws as most business books:1) A single central theory that really needs only a napkin to explain, yet gets a whole book2) No actual analysis or evidence to support the central theory, but a whole lot of marginally relevant anecdotesIn this case, the book's central theory is that implementation is worth more than the foundational good idea.  How much more?  A lot more - apparently, you don't even need the initial idea.  Wow!  What insight the author is demonstrating!  I almost swooned.  The problem with this, of course, is that you can't just have an idea OR implementation - you need both.  Maybe I'm over-intellectualizing this, which the author is clearly not a fan of.  In fact, he devotes five pages of his precious allocation (a whole chapter!) to bash a dead economist (Keynes), claiming to agree with Orwell that "some ideas are so absurd that only an intellectual could believe them."  Sadly, Mr. Schrage, there are some ideas that are even more absurd, like the idea that you don't need ideas.  Or have you tried building a house with no actual foundation?  While we're at it, why not pick on someone who can defend themselves, instead of a dead guy?There are also problems with the implementation portion of this book.  First, it takes a while to get there.  Second, it's so general as to be useless.  Here's my evidence:  The book promises much early on but struggles to get to the point.  On p 47 he states "the best way ... to advance the boldest ambitions is through the ... most fundamental experiments.  This book explains how."  Great!  Except it doesn't.  Instead,  the entire next chapter is on how much the author enjoys hobnobbing with the wise and witty Warren Buffet.  After another 20 pages of hero worship (Bezos, Jobs, etc, who are definitely not known for their good ideas), we get to the author's much ballyhooed "5x5 experimentation methodology," the author's recipe for implementation.  Well, not quite.  First, there's a lengthy explanation of what the framework is not.At this point, we're about halfway through the book and losing patience fast.  [Quick aside: Schrage, you told us a good idea should be tweetable.  Well, after 80 pages, you still haven't got to the point.  Instead you're outlining your "80/20/20 vision."  Great, now you sound like one of those football coaches telling us all to give 120% effort.]Ah!  Here it is: your tweetable idea: "give a diverse team of 5 people no more than 5 days to come up with a portfolio of 5 business experiments that cost no more than $5000 (each) and take no longer than 5 weeks to run."  Brilliant!  Pilot experiments for all!  Oh, wait, we're already doing those.  Never mind.Now that I've given away the thrilling conclusion of this book, you can decide if you want to read the remaining diatribe on things that even NASA figured out in the 1980s ("innovators ... go beyond throwing a prototype against a wall to see if it sticks." and "Low hanging fruit tastes delicious.").  If so, by all means pay this author for the privilege of reading his big idea.  I won't even be donating this book to a prison.

I was really disappointed with this product.  It doesn't really do a good job and it isn't as clever or as high quality as I would normally expect from OXO.The head is fine, but kind of annoyingly shaped.  The handle isn't all that generous, but I guess it's fine.  The extension system doesn't really work as I expected.  There was no "twist to tighten."  Instead this product seemed to rely on friction to keep itself extended.  That just didn't really work.  Maybe I got a defective one, but I basically can't really use it extended.  In which case, why not just get a decent brush.If I'd bought it, I would have returned it.  I think that says as much as I need to say.

I'm really pretty impressed with this product but I have very little experience with its competitors.It charges easily and quickly using a micro-USB cable (although no data can be transferred using the included cable, but I found I could charge it with another micro-USB cable, which was nice).  The earphones are pretty comfortable, exclude external noises well (but it is NOT capable of active noise-cancelling, merely noise isolating).Connections to sound sources are pretty easy: you can plug in a standard stereo jack or you can connect over bluetooth to your phone.  I only tested it with an iPhone, but connection was extremely easy, the range was comfortably 25 - 30 feet.Sound was good, but not great.  What really blew me away was that I could answer phone calls, even though there was no apparent/dumb-looking microphone.  I only tested this indoors, but the microphone seemed at least as good as a bluetooth headset and picked up my voice even if my hand was in the way.If you've been looking for a lightweight, comfy, simple, effective cross between headphones and a bluetooth headset, this product is definitely worth looking into.  Is it cool?  No.  Is it well-designed?  Yes.

Having read this book all the way to the end, I noticed that the author notes he completed the work in Moscow in 1999.  That means this is one of his early works, if not his actual debut novel, and that makes sense.This book reads like a debut novel from start to finish.  Sure, the author is definitely one to watch and there are some very inventive ideas in here.  It's also engaging and quite well-paced, although the denouement takes about 20% of the book to unfold.  However, the characters are one-dimensional (partly by design, to be fair), the plot is simplistic, and the entire book isn't quite funny enough, nor is as serious as it sometimes thinks it is.  There are some political messages woven rather clumsily into the final few pages, almost as if the author realized he hadn't made the points he wanted to and was running out of pages.  But it was mostly readable, except for the biological science parts, which I found just beyond silly.I usually leave synopses to others, but I will say this starts out promisingly with an intriguing premise (you wake up to discover you remember nothing, but that you still have some very well defined skills).  The protagonist quickly gathers a rag-tag crew, gets a spaceship, and rapidly ends up in the center of criminal investigation.I'd recommend Charles Stross' excellent Glass House over this book, since it starts from a remarkably similar premise, and delivers much more in the end.  Meanwhile, this book will pass the time if you're a fan of the author.

The only reason you might want to purchase this game is to experience how truly awful it is.The ... um ... concept of Concept is related to all those fun games where you have to use verbal ingenuity to define words without actually saying the word you're thinking of.  In this case, you have to try and define words without saying anything at all and instead pointing to pictures on a big board.  There are about 100 pictures to choose from.  The game uses a series of color-coded blocks to allow the expression of several different ideas at the same time.  The initial question is posed using the green question mark and up to five little green cubes.  Then subordinate clauses (if any) are constructed using the exclamation marks and more little colored cubes.Armed with this information, gleaned from the sub-standard and ill-thought-out instructions, I assembled four smart people over the age of 10 (the minimum number of players required for this game), added an appropriate amount of wine for the adults and sugary beverages for the rest of us, and tried to explain the rules and the scoring.  Having read the instructions aloud and then passed them around for review, we were all left with the same burning question: huh?The crux of our problem is this: what is the incentive for a player to play?  Let's say we split into teams and it's my team against your team.  My team will try to come up with a creative way of explaining a concept using the picture board.  Your team's goal is to try and guess the concept in exchange for light bulbs (the person with the most light bulbs at the end wins).  This immediately creates three huge issues:1, What defines the "end"?  I guess you could say the game's over after a certain amount of time...2, What is the incentive for the people putting together the concept definition?  They don't get any light bulbs or points whether they do a good job or a poor job.  If they do a poor job, no-one guesses and the game just gets bogged down.  If they do a great job, the game keeps moving but that effort is not rewarded in any way.3, The guessing team actually ends up competing with each other as two light bulbs go to the person who actually makes the correct guess, whilst all other team members get just one light bulb.  Since light bulbs are essentially handed out for every turn that is taken, we ended up with a draw between players on opposing teams, and it would be perfectly possible for all participants to be "the winner."We looked at the rules to see if they would shed any additional light on these issues.  We found instead a little note that says something along the lines of, "after extensive testing we determined that the game was more fun without scoring!"  Except it isn't.  And you don't even have to take my word for it: a quick sample of the top ten suspiciously positive reviews of this game reveal that everyone abandons the scoring system sooner or later...  The reality is that the pictures are too limited to make this anything other than a fancy guessing game.  That would actually be fine if the scoring system worked well, or somehow rewarded the people creating the concepts rather than the ones doing random guessing, but it doesn't.The most fun thing about this game was when we gave up at the end and tried to figure out what would be more fun than playing this game.  Here are some samples of things that we thought might be more fun than this game:1) Any other game, including playing Frogger ... with real traffic2) Elective dental procedures without anaesthetic ("at least you'll be able to smile afterwards!").3) Watching any movie, even "The Room."4) Frontal lobotomy (although, to be fair, this one was debated for a few minutes).There are so many great games out there.  Don't waste your time or money on this one. Recommended alternatives include Taboo, Pictionary, Labyrinth, Apples to Apples, Cards Against Humanity, or any other game ever made.

I'm really enjoying this tale.  Yes, it's a little predictable and various plot points have been telegraphed from at least fifty pages away, but there are plenty of things to enjoy.  The plotting is sufficiently interesting to hold my attention.  The characters are more interesting than Karpyshyn's standard Star Wars Good Guys and Bad Guys, although the Bad Guys are still pretty bad - it would have been nice if they'd had a bit more nuance.  The writing style is unobtrusive and not noticeably good, bad, or strained.I hadn't read the first book but the story is accessible enough that I didn't feel like I missed too much.Briefly, a small gang of five characters has been flung together and, guided only by a flimsy ever-changing prophecy, are attempting to collect various talismans to fight the forces of Evil, who are attempting to take over the world.It's probably exactly what you're expecting to read, but nonetheless entertaining and engaging.  Definitely not a memorable five star book, it gets four stars because I'll almost certainly read the sequel.

I'm really torn by this book.  I fervently believe that family dinners are important, something that was pounded into me as a child, even as my Mum perfected the art of putting four different dishes on the table simultaneously (whilst holding down a full-time job).  No, I don't know how she managed either.This book starts off as a painfully aware self-help book.  It even contains a page entitled "In case you are flipping through this book and saying to yourself, "Suckers, who's going to buy this gimmicky self-help book?"  It's filled with underlinings and circles and checks and arrows that attempt to draw your attention to key parts of the book, but only succeed in distracting you.  After a significant number of pages proselytising, the book suddenly starts to get useful with instructions on how to make a meal plan.Then we get to the recipes.  These are variations on the '30 minute quick healthy meals' with a few bonus more involved meals thrown in for good measure.  There's a lot of kale, but not a lot of red meat.  The attraction is that all the meals are rated kid-friendly by at least a few kids but don't appear to be too bland.  Some of those recipes are simple: baked potatoes, for example.  Some are a little more interesting: chicken in a creamy mustard sauce is a winner.And here's what it boils down to: if I take away even a couple of these recipes and add them to my repertoire, it's a success.  I could look up a new recipe on the internet every night and try that, but I'm more likely to flick through this collection of recipes and try a few of them instead.  This isn't a great cookbook, but it has something to offer those of us who have got a little stuck in a rut.If you can look past the annoying style and preachy voice, you'll get to some solid recipes.  If the author ever makes a second edition and fixes some of the formatting and digs up a few more interesting recipes, I'd recommend it more easily.

I have never owned a Tempur-pedic pillow, but I have owned a variety of other memory foam, latex foam, down, feather, and polyester fiberfill pillows in my quest for the perfect pillow for a broad-shouldered side-sleeper.  This one is definitely not a keeper.It is a fairly lightweight pillow, which at first I ascribed to the fact that there are ventilation holes in the pillow.  Those holes are considered de rigueur for memory foam pillows/mattresses at the moment, since they're supposed to make the pillows cooler.  Unfortunately, sleeping on this pillow is like resting one's head on a short pile of hot bricks.Despite the holes, the pillow gets very warm very quickly.  There are various gels, cooling covers and other ways to prevent this - I'd never realized why it was so important until I tried this pillow.  The lightweight nature of the pillow stems from the fact that this foam is pretty unyielding.  A good memory foam should have a higher density and be more elastic/yielding, but that tends to be a bit more expensive.  This pillow isn't that cheap, but it really feels like it is.One other note: if/when you buy a memory foam pillow or mattress, be aware that they absorb moisture quite effectively.  It's worth putting a waterproof barrier around the pillow or mattress.  Often these will also offer some protection against today's most popular scourge: the bedbug.

I regard this book as a best-of-breed business book.  It was interesting, entertaining and educational.  I found the sections that dealt with effective innovation particularly useful.Just because I like this book does not mean that it doesn't suffer from the afflictions of most business books: it is repetitive and (short) sections of it are insufferably bland.  Whereas most business books feel like the original draft could have been written on one side of a single napkin in a fancy restaurant, this one feels like it was always supposed to be a book - but perhaps one that should have been half the length.

I mostly enjoyed this collection of short stories, even though I've never heard of the author or his most famous set of characters (a set of semi-supernatural defenders of humanity, all with the family name Drood).I won't bother with a synopsis of all 17 stories - part of the joy of books like this is not knowing exactly what's about to come next.  The first ten or so stories are new and the last few are stories the author wrote when he was first starting out.What I will say is that this book is written with a uniquely British voice: it's breezy, a little colloquial and refreshingly blunt.  The stories are not immersive, but very few short stories are.  These are not exactly hard SF, deep space stories - instead they tend to ask questions about what's really going on in the world that we can see, and the one we can't.There's a short afterword after each story to explain the circumstances under which it was written, and these really start to shed some light on the things that changed and the ones that didn't over the author's career.This collection is entertaining, imaginative, and fun.  Highly recommended for those who love British sci-fi/fantasy with comic undertones, especially readers of Terry Pratchett and China Mieville.

First there was Bic pens for women and it was hilarious.  We laughed.  We cried.  And about half of the population felt a little bit left out.  Fortunately, my prayers have been answered.  Proctor & Gamble have clearly decided to redress the balance with dryer sheets than can only be described as heaven-scent.  How did I live my life without these?  Specifically, how did I get through so many years without knowing that "As a result of the friction between fibers, electrons are transferred across surfaces, resulting in a static charge and that annoying high-pitched sound when you touch them."  I'm not sure exactly what high-pitched sound is being referred to, other than my significant other's howls of anguish when she discovers that I failed to use this product in the manner for which it was intended.Even though I'm a typical man and would never actually read the instructions, I felt compelled to at least understand how to use a standard dryer sheet that differs only in the added perfume.  According to the strangely over-enthusiastic and sadly under-edited advertising copy, these sheets can be added liberally to your washing machine yet are not safe for your washing machine.  They are not safe for use with a single blouse, but that's OK - I'm a guy; I don't own a single blouse.  And if I did, I certainly wouldn't want it to smell like a man.  Further concern furrowed my ridged brow when I realized that I cannot use this product with my underroos, since it may cause them to actually catch fire whenever my significant other tries to "permanently dispose" of them.As I reflect further on this product, silently and stoically, I realize this product's perfection is probably wasted on me:  I do actually rely on a little static cling to supplement my natural animal magnetism.  Furthermore, I pull most of my garments out of the dryer slightly damp to avoid shrinkage (mostly because I like my clothing as baggy as possible; it's hard to be manly in overly tight trousers, unless you're the Incredible Hulk and thus so manly that you explode out of your overly tight trousers or your Hulk underroos), so this product isn't actually very useful for me.  However, I may still buy this product, safe in my manliness, if only to ensure that somewhere, somehow, I can help whoever wrote this winning copy continue with their dream of pursuing a PhD in English Literature without having to resort to doing an MBA afterwards.

I spent a long time looking for a great watch.  This isn't really it, but it has stopped me looking for a great watch anymore.  I needed a work-suitable replacement for my Luminox diver's watch.  Although this one isn't waterproof, it does feature the same tritium tubes, a Swiss quartz (battery-powered) movement and it's all wrapped up in a simple, elegant package.  I love the highly visible red second hand and the look is quite distinctive - many recognize it as the Swiss Train watch.  The leather strap is quite comfortable.  It's definitely not the best strap, but it's definitely better than most cheap watch straps.However, it's not perfect.  The tritium tubes are a bit dim - they only last 20 years or so and this may be five year old stock.  The most annoying thing about  the watch is also its best feature: the relatively huge date.  In order to get the date to be so large, two wheels are needed: one for the tens (0,1,2,3) and one for the ordinals (0 - 9).  This means that after you get to the 31st of the month, comes the 32nd, 33rd, and so on until the 39th, then 00.  It means that every month you have to manually set the date.  As you can tell, that's not really a big deal in exchange for such a readable display, but it was a bit of a surprise.  Also, the watch is not very waterproof.  It's not worth risking swimming or even showering with it.  You'll rot the strap and probably end up regretting it.  It will withstand sweat and hiking near waterfalls, etc.Overall, I'm really happy with the watch.

The reviews are all true.  It's simple and bulletproof, but it just works, even with low quality/cheap paper towels.  There's no annoying spring to load.  It's just brilliant.Two models are available for a similar price - this one is the 'deluxe' with a bit of extra rubber on the base.  I highly recommend this one.  Why not spend the extra dollar or two and get the one that just works.I haven't noticed any excessive lint generation from friction with the base.  I'm really happy with it.  I give out five star reviews very rarely.

I had an Oregon Scientific atomic clock with projection and a temperature sensor that I loved.  I particularly liked the way it projected both the time and the external temperature on the ceiling throughout the night, bright enough to see but not bright enough to wake me (and I'm very light sensitive).  However, first the atomic receiver stopped working, then the external temperature sensor stopped, despite a clean and new batteries.  Finally I decided to replace it and I was hoping for a model that was almost equivalent.Well, this clock does all that, and more:1) It's better built2) It can be entirely powered by A/C power (but still has a battery back-up)3) The weather predictor / barometer on this model is really good - several times it has correctly predicted rain on an apparently gorgeous sunny day.4) It displays internal and external humidity, which is great in the winterWhen I stacked it up against the competition, it looked better than the rest of them.  Now that I own it, I can tell you it's even better than my previous benchmark.

This book contains a collection of 34 autobiographical stories by food writers and chefs, most of which are good.  Each story is about 10 pages long and many manage to mention interesting foods and interesting locations.  Many, but not all, have a clear point.  Some manage poignancy.So why only three and not quite a half stars?  Well, I don't really know who most of the people are.  That wouldn't matter if the book really were written as if the food and/or location is the most important star of each story, but it isn't.  The editing is clearly good, but there's still lots of variability on display.  I particularly enjoyed Curtis Stone's story, but not all of them are so gripping.I can't decide if I would have preferred shorter stories, more about the locations, longer stories, more of an introduction to the authors, or just a different book entirely.  However, for people who are in the mood for reasonably engaging reminiscences that tend to dwell on the importance of food and/or travel, this is probably worth a look.

I just got back from a 9 day trip to Siem Reap/Ankor Wat.  This guidebook was excellent for that area.  I particularly liked the small size and light weight, the good maps, and the good suggestions for activities that are a little further afield.  The temples section is really quite good, including just enough points of interest and things to look for.  It helped me get more out of my trip than just going from temple to temple.So why only 4 stars?  Well, there are a number of reasons:1, The temples section could be organized more intuitively - it was hard to relate the order of the temples to what I was actually visiting.  Also, one or two good temples are not included yet one disappointing pool is (although I guess it's a bit different from all the temples...).2, The restaurants section is already a bit outdated.  While the recommendations are generally solid, there are some really good new alternatives if you're prepared to venture beyond Pub Street.3, The trip backgrounder was fine, but missed a few key items, including but not limited to: flashlights, bandana/face masks, the use of US dollars as the main currency (even the locals use them), bike or motorcycle rentals.I only wish I had found a similar book for Phnom Penh!

There are 64 stories nestled in these 272 pages, equivalent to about 4 pages per story.  Some are longer, but many are shorter, with a few being only a few words long.  This, then, is a collection of short, short stories.  There are no sub-plots.  There's very little characterization.  This is a book about ideas.  Often the ideas are quite smart, but sometimes they are not.If you can get past that stylistic quirk, you'll find a collection of humorous ideas that are played out quite well.  The language is often quite coarse, especially at the beginning of the book, but that doesn't detract from the wit on display.It's hard to give much more information: there's no plot as such, although several of the stories are interconnected in amusing ways.  The best I can do is compare BJ Novak's debut work favorably to another similar book: Demetri Martin's "This is a book."  I thought both were similarly funny and follow a similar short, short format.  While Martin's book is more visual, Novak's book is a bit more literary.In the end, I will recommend (and lend) this book to friends, and I'll want it back when they're finished.

I try not to give three star reviews - I'd rather adopt a clear position.  So why have I given this book three stars?  Because I really wanted to like it, but I just didn't.  It's not a bad novel, and I will probably continue to follow this author in the future, but I can't recommend this novel.Briefly, this is a story that explores class relationships in a future society, specifically the relationship between lower and upper class Westerners and lower-middle class Asians.  There isn't much science behind this fiction - it's definitely more soft SF than hard.  It is written by a Princeton writing professor who clearly believes that science fiction needs more pretentiousness in its writing.  The story starts awkwardly, settles into a nice enough rhythm in which we follow the eventful life of an uneventful character, and ends somewhat unexpectedly.Once I got into it, it held my attention, but I was ultimately disappointed, especially with the lack of character development and the unimportance of the near future setting.  It did have some of the whimsical feel of Murakami, and I'd recommend The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle or Kafka on the Shore.  It also had some of the depth of Nicola Griffith's early work (Ammonite, Slow River).  I would recommend any of those works over this one.If you found this review unhelpful, please leave a comment to help me understand why.  I didn't want to give away too much of the plot but I'm happy to give more details if that would be helpful.

I absolutely do not understand the tremendously high ratings for this "travel guide."It's more of a lecture course in ethical behavior, but having just returned from a trip to Cambodia, I can confidently say this is no substitute for a Lonely Planet or similar guide.  My day in Phnom Penh was completely wasted thanks to the poor maps, inadequate suggestions for what to do, and lack of accessibility of this guide.Under no circumstances should it be the top-rated guide to Cambodia.

I actually met the author of this book and I told him the same thing: this is not the idiot's guide to dating, nor is it really the geek's guide.  Instead, I think it's more of a male computer game player's guide to re-entering real life.That doesn't mean it doesn't have a fair amount of useful advice.From the eight-bit graphics to the gratuitous video game references, this is a very accessible and breezy guide to everything from identifying a person of interest, asking that person out, dressing appropriately for the date, going on the date, and handling the post-date expectations.  It does have a lot of useful non-intuitive advice that is particularly useful if you're 16 - 26 years old and male.The author includes a note saying that this guide could be useful to women, but it really is written from a male perspective for (straight) men.  I guess it could be a useful insight into straight male dating norms for other potential readers, but that clearly wasn't the main audience for this book.The other issue is that, unsurprisingly perhaps, there is no definitive guide for creating a couple, and this guide is even more generic than others.  If you use these tips to prepare for a date with a woman in her 30s, you're unlikely to learn much new.However, if you are a male gamer targeting less nerdy co-eds, or you're looking for a fun gift to get for one, this is worth a look.

This set is very hit or miss, and needs to be reviewed piece-by-piece:1) Bag - nicely built nylon bag with mesh pockets to allow the gear to dry out; single off-set shoulder strap doesn't have or need a lot of padding2) Fins - universal fins will definitely fit anyone who can use the mask; probably good for kids from 14 years onwards3) Snorkel - so much better than a tube, this one has drainage valves to allow easy emptying and a wave-stopping valve to stop water coming in from the top.
