It's a little disconcerting to find you suddenly can't breathe if a wave triggers the wave-stopping valve.  However, once you get used to it, it does seem to work for me.4) Mask - the critical part of any of these packages was pretty disappointing for me.  Visibility is good, but fit was awful for me.  There is plenty of room in the nose for those of us with bigger noses, which is good news.  However, this mask will only be comfortable if you have a flat/broad face.  If your face is long and narrow like mine, you will find the mask hits you right between the eyebrows, becoming extremely uncomfortable within a minute.  The only way to fix this issue would be have a larger silicon gasket, which is not available.  The glass lenses are high quality and distortion-free but fog up quickly (easy to fix: just spit on or lick the lenses before use; it's glass so you could also use an anti-fog solution without fear of scratching the lenses, unlike plastic).  I could get a seal, but not without considerable pain, which increased with dive depth, becoming unbearable at 6 feet depth (2 yrds/2 meters).If you can't test the fit of this set before you buy, be aware that the mask is the big area of concern if you have a narrow face.

The main protagonist in this engaging tale is 15 years old, and I think this book would appeal to anyone over the age of 14 who enjoys mild fantasy.  I say mild fantasy because it has magical elements, but doesn't read like it was lost in the mists of distant time.  There aren't 10 pages of Elvish poetry.  Instead, it's a very readable adventure in which a young girl grows up very quickly.Without giving away more than the back page, the pacing is generally very good, the story covers a lot of ground yet takes the time to explore the character's emotions.  It's sometimes a little simplistic and clumsy, especially in trying to convey some of the romantic pieces.  I also have some quibbles with the things that just seem to happen by chance - some seem awfully improbable.But these are minor quibbles.  I'll definitely be in line to read the sequel and I look forward to continued character development.

Nanoblocks are a small Japanese building block that, on the surface, look like a miniature version of Lego. This review will note the major differences first, then talk about this specific model: A Dutch Windmill.Differences between Lego:1) Size - most obvious perhaps, but these things are tiny. They're about the same proportions as Lego, but each dimension is roughly half what you'd expect. That doesn't sound like a big change, but it means that each brick is about 1/8th to 1/10th the volume of a traditional lego brick. This makes these sets small and fiddly. Nanoblocks do not interact with Lego in any way - these are 100% NOT compatible.2) Diversity - there's lots of different colors but very few different types of piece, in contrast to Lego, which has a somewhat limited color palette (much less so these days) but many more types of piece. Lego includes slopes, smooth pieces, and many different types of hinge. Nanoblock sets really only include basic building blocks, with very few hinges or pieces that allow rotation.  The issue of how to get a rotating windmill blade mounted without using any rotating pieces is the main point of interest in this set.3) Quality of instructions - all Nanoblock sets come with minimal instructions. For most sets that I've built, it's just one sheet. For those familiar with Lego's outstanding step-by-step piece-by-piece instructions, this will come as a bit of shock. For those who are used to building plastic model cars, it won't be quite so much of a transition.Dutch windmillThe finished set is a bit delicate, especially the blades, and quite well designed.  However, it's quite uninteresting and there isn't a lot of long-term playability.  The blades are mounted by using a long stack of circular bricks to create an axle.  However, the axle isn't secured by anything, which is fine since the model is really only for static display.I think this set is ideal for an adult who really enjoyed a trip to the Netherlands, or a 7 - 11 year old child who likes model landscapes and has (or wants to develop) a fair amount of patience. This set is one of the easier ones to put together but still took this adult 2 - 3 hours. For a similar price/theme, the Space Shuttle Nanoblock set is more fun, more challenging to build and offers more long-term playability, although it's still delicate.If this review was not useful, please let me know how it can be improved in the comments section.

I've been using electrical implements to clean my teeth since I had braces 20 years ago.  I started with an oral-B rotary brush and have been using a sonicare for the last 3 years or so.  I started flossing about 10 years ago, after an ordeal at the hands of a particularly sadistic dentist (who I would thank profusely and happily treat to a great dinner - she spared me a great deal of subsequent oral health issues!).I provide that background so that you know where I'm coming from when I got this electric "flosser."  I've put quotes around it because it's really a compressed air gun that aims to replace one of the two functions of floss, without actually using any floss:1) Stimulating gums to prevent inflammation2) Removing food particles/bacterial build-up (plaque) from between teethIn my hands, this gizmo only really seems to perform the first of these functions.It's about twice as fat as a standard current model sonicare toothbrush.  (Note that it does use exactly the same charger as a standard current model sonicare toothbrush.)  There's a small reservoir that can be filled with water or mouthwash.  It's pretty messy to fill, since it's hard to judge when it's full enough, and the reservoir is so small it really only lasts for a day.  I fill it with water over the sink.  I imagine it would be a real waste of mouthwash.You can change tips if there's more than one user, but I don't think the tip is really consumable (unlike a toothbrush).  I'll update if it becomes apparent that it is.  So, with the reservoir filled and the tip in your mouth, you're ready to start squirting.  Where do you squirt?  Well, this is pretty critical.  Basically, you want to aim between two teeth at the gumline.  Flossing really benefits gum health and that is the function that this squirter is supposed to replicate.  Most people who floss also do it to remove food particles, and this device isn't as good as floss for that function.So, who would benefit?  Well, if you need a portable waterpik-style irrigator OR you have braces, this is the device for you!  It's well-designed, holds a good charge, and is satisfying to use.  Although I've only been using it for a week, it's now part of my standard routine and I really enjoy using it.  It's caused my gums to bleed a little (which I take as a good sign) and it's reduced the effort required for me to floss, plus my gums look a little better.  But I do still floss after I use this gizmo because I don't think it's quite as good as floss at removing food particles.  So now I brush, use this gizmo, and then floss!  Why bother?  Well, I think it's a little better at stimulating my gums and reducing inflammation than brushing/flossing alone.  Time will tell, and I'll edit this review as appropriate.Will it replace flossing?  I don't think it does.  I think you have to use it just right to see much of a benefit and, as others have mentioned, even after brushing and using this gizmo, I still sometimes find food particles on my floss (but much less than before).  It's a bit wet and messy, and it does add a little extra time to the evening routine, but I think it's making my mouth cleaner and I think it's a great/fun way of introducing kids/people with braces to the joys of interdental cleaning!I wasn't expecting to like this gizmo as much as I do, so even though I don't think it will ever replace floss for me, I still think it's worth at least four stars.

Nanoblocks are a small Japanese building block that, on the surface, look like a miniature version of Lego.  This review will note the major differences first, then talk about this specific model: Air Force One, a modified 747 that the President of the US uses to fly from place to place and the subject of several films.Differences between Lego:1) Size - most obvious perhaps, but these things are tiny.  They're about the same proportions as Lego, but each dimension is roughly half what you'd expect.  That doesn't sound like a big change, but it means that each brick is about 1/8th to 1/10th the volume of a traditional lego brick.  This makes these sets small and fiddly.  Nanoblocks do not interact with Lego in any way - these are 100% NOT compatible.2) Diversity - there's lots of different colors but very few different types of piece, in contrast to Lego, which has a somewhat limited color palette (much less so these days) but many more types of piece.  Lego includes slopes, smooth pieces, and many different types of hinge.  Nanoblock sets really only include basic building blocks, although this one does have a universal joint that allows the finished model to be displayed at different angles of attack on the included stand.3) Quality of instructions - all Nanoblock sets come with minimal instructions.  For most sets that I've built, it's just one sheet.  For those familiar with Lego's outstanding step-by-step piece-by-piece instructions, this will come as a bit of shock.  For those who are used to building plastic model cars, it won't be quite so much of a transition.Air Force One Nanoblock modelThe finished jet is a bit delicate, especially around the wings, but is quite well-designed.  The fuselage narrows at the rear in a particularly clever way, and the tail section is definitely the most interesting part of this model.  The jet is attached to its stand by a universal joint, allowing it to be displayed at almost any angle, although the looseness of the piece means that it will probably adopt its own configuration sooner or later.  The colors of the set are good (note that dark grey is not the same as black - the only truly black pieces are used for the stand) and it displays nicely when finished, but the set will have limited playability: it has no wheels for landing and is a bit delicate.I think this set is ideal for a 7 - 11 year old child who has (or wants to develop) a fair amount of patience.  This set is one of the easier ones to put together but still took this adult 2 - 3 hours.  For a similar price/theme, the Space Shuttle Nanoblock set is more fun, more challenging to build and seems to offer more long-term playability, although it's still delicate.If this review was not useful, please let me know how it can be improved in the comments section.

This book is somewhat engaging and a very quick read.  Unfortunately, I can't help feeling that the material in it is really only worth a newspaper article (or a review!) at most.  So, here's what I learned (which you can learn from the author's website without buying the book):1) There are five flirting styles that the author has identified (although his definitions are neither mutually exclusive nor collectively exhaustive, but they're fine): Physical, Playful, Polite, Traditional, Sincere2) The author believes that most people exhibit just one or two of these styles and that this explains why some folks mesh and others don't.So what, then?  Well, I don't want to bash the book too hard, because I learned at least one interesting snippet.  For instance, folks who go to a bar meet someone interesting around 10% of the time, but if you break that down by flirting style, you find that physical flirts reporting meeting someone interesting about 25% of the time.  Does this explain why those of us with other "flirting styles" are even less successful at bars?  Maybe.  Is it useful?  Perhaps.  But, and here's the crucial question, do I believe the author?  Um, yes and no.I don't really buy into the idea that folks have just one or two "styles" because I see bits of myself in all of them.  If you take the on-line questionnaire, you'll find it forces you into one or two "styles" but that's just a poorly designed questionnaire, not proof of accuracy.My title for this review was "book teases but doesn't please" and yet I've told you very little other than that I disagree with the central hypothesis of this book.  I had hoped to learn something more but was left with something between disappointment and irritation.  It seems pretty clear the author did some research that was enough to get him a PhD (oh, how things have changed!) and he felt like he could make some money on the side.  Well, sadly, I don't think there's really enough here for a book (or a degree, for that matter, but I clearly wasn't on his examining board!).  Ultimately I didn't learn enough new things to make purchasing the book worthwhile.  But, with that having been said, if you see a copy it might be worth a quick browse, which is all you'll need to get 90% of the useful content.If you didn't find this review useful, please let me know how I can improve it in the comments section.

I guess it was my fault for expecting a product like this would solve all my problems.It is a couple of 1-inch thick foam pads, held together by a piece of thick, flexible plastic, with two carry handles sticking out from the sides.  There's a set of holes in the front 'half' of the seat, which go all the way through.OK, good parts first: there are no stray threads and the foam is satisfyingly dense.  The holes don't have any loose bits around them.  In general this feels like it would last.  The solid (hole-less) back 'half' of the seat is firmer than the section that has holes.  If you sit on that bit, your legs will feel a little less pressure, so the holes do relieve that a bit - I guess just because there's less material to sit upon.Now for the bad bits: the smell is awful, like really cheap new car smell.  I aired the product out for a few days but still can't really stand to sit on it.  When I did spend the day sitting on it, it was initially quite comfortable, but quickly became uncomfortable and left me with more back pain at the end of the day than I have without it!  Add to that that the material makes you sweat and that the thick, flexible plastic 'hinge' isn't really hinged and doesn't seem like it would hold up, and top it off with the weight (it's surprisingly heavy), and I'll pass.I guess if you're looking for a foam pad to sit on, you could do worse, but I found it less comfortable and worse for my back over the course of four or five hours than not having it.UPDATE:I left this in the office for others to try.  After four weeks, no-one has taken up the option of using this foam cushion full-time.

I get the feeling that, when it comes to dishes, people are either sponge people or brush people.I am the kind of person who cleans dishes with a brush.  I appreciate the reach that the handle gives me, allowing me to keep my hands far from the dirty dish, or to reach all the way to the bottom of a tall glass.  I find firm bristles allow me to attack stuck-on dirt. However, there are definitely sponge people.  They believe that a sudsy sponge is the only way to distribute soap to every part of the dirty dish, and they like the idea that they can scrub dirt away.Like the scouring pad before it, this is a hybrid.  While the scouring pad is effectively a bristly sponge, this item is a spongy brush. It's got a nicely weighted wooden handle, and lots of bits of cut-up sponge on the head.  I'm not sure it's really all that ecological but it's much better for removing lipstick from wine glasses than my brush.I'm not really sold on it, but I'd recommend it to all my sponge-loving friends - it's definitely better than a regular sponge.  However, it won't convert me from my favored bristles.  I'll update this review with longevity information eventually.  Use the comments section to let me know how I can improve this review.

I've owned a couple of Lowepro camera bags and they always have surprisingly good hidden features.  The general build quality is high and I know from experience that they generally use materials that last.Here are the features of this particular bag:1) Single shoulder strap - not just less dorky than a double strapped backpack, the real advantage of this system is that you can move the drop the bag from your back to your side without removing it, by rotating the bag across your body.  This is only useful because one of the two ways of accessing the bag is a side-mounted pocket that's perfect for a mid-sized camera body and medium lens.  If you need additional support, there is a hidden strap on the right side that plugs into the single shoulder strap about half-way up.  I thought this would create a waist strap, but instead it gives you a very strange triangular attachment that leaves all the weight of the pack on a single (right) shoulder but prevents excessive lateral movement.2) Waterproof cover - one of the major selling points of any Lowepro bag, this is a little poncho for your bag that stores in a pocket in the base of the pack.  If you're caught in a sudden downpour, it's convenient enough to pull out and cover the bag within a few seconds.3) Tripod carrying system - a fixed loop, an adjustable loop, and a pocket that drops out of another hidden pocket conspire to give you a way of carrying any reasonably compact (max 15 inch collapsed height) tripod.4) Internally re-configurable - lots of velcro separators and a clever panel that's the width of the pack but contains a lens shaped cut-out means you should be able to accommodate some combination of a small-bodied SLR-type camera with a lens attached and a couple of other lenses OR a full-sized SLR with a zoom lens that protrudes 8 inches from the body.  The maximum internal dimensions of this padded pack are: 14 x 8 x 4 inches, although the shape of the pack means if your lens is longer than 8 - 9 inches and you want it stay on your camera you probably need a bigger bag.5) Extra pockets - a tablet/document pocket right next to your back (but still well padded), an outside zip pocket for small items, a mesh pocket for lens caps, and an internal zip pocket with a key loop all give you extra flexibility6) Lightness - by any standards this is a lightweight pack - it feels like it weighs about 2 pounds at most.This is great for traveling with your camera for quick access, but only if you're carrying your camera as a carry-on on an airplane - I wouldn't trust my camera to the luggage hold in this bag.  It's great, but it's not indestructible...

Reviewer copies of this book (similar to those provided by the Vine program) advertise this book as being the first of up to 7, to be distributed to at least 18 countries, and the film rights have been optioned by none other than Gollum (Andy Serkis from Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit).  That's a lot of hype for a first-time author entering a crowded space.Despite the horribly mis-leading title, this is neither fantasy or overly gory.  It's also not really science fiction.  Let's call it speculative fiction, set 40 years in the future in an alternate universe involving some "aliens" and a fascist government that's very reminiscent of "1984" or "V for Vendetta."It turns out that the easiest way to categorize this book is what it reminds you of.  Contrary to all the reports that this is completely new, etc, it's actually more than a little reminiscent of "1984," "The Matrix," and Phillip Pullman's "His Dark Materials" trilogy.  No, not the awful movie version, but rather the excellent books, that I still recommend highly.  In fact, with its Oxford setting, emphasis on a parallel spirit world, and stratification of society by something mystical, this book reminds me of that series in all the right ways.I don't want to ruin the book for you with a plot synopsis.  If you like hard sci-fi, space opera, or swords & dragons fantasy, this might not be for you.  If you enjoy speculative fiction, character-driven stories, and just enough of a twist on reality to keep things interesting, I recommend this book.  It definitely caught my interest and it's been hard to put down.

I've read most of this book now.  I find it thought-provoking, but extremely annoying.The book is basically a written version of a course that the author teaches at a university to make economics more accessible to her students.  It must be a *really* basic economics course; I never took an economics course and I haven't come across anything new yet.  I think the content would work quite well as a series of entertaining lectures.However, as a book it falls flat.  Lots of "studies" are peppered throughout the text, but the reader never has any idea how reliable the studies might be - were 10 people studied, or 10,000?  Given some of the claims that are made, I would like to have more information to evaluate the evidence.  How many contrary studies were ignored?  Quite a few, I imagine.If you do take everything at face value, prepare for a very warped view of dating and sex.  Much of the book is grounded in sexism, on the assumption that sexism has been practiced by society for millenia.  Ok, but that doesn't mean that all men are going to enslave all women.  It also doesn't mean that all women are servile.  I understand that I haven't read as many studies as the author, but I couldn't help but feel that I was getting a profoundly one-sided view of the world of sex and dating.As well as appearing biased, the arguments are also hard to string together.  By page 160, I'm still not sure what the point of the book is.  Is it to make all men feel dreadful?  Is it to make all women feel like they can't hope for a happy partnership and must choose security or loneliness?I'm hoping the end of the book will make the rest make sense, but I'm not sure I can bear to finish it.  I'd much rather be having a drink with someone lovely.  Perhaps the author will feel similarly, and not write a sequel...

I've used an electric toothbrush for 20 years.  For the first 15 years, I was a fan of the Oral-B Braun electric toothbrushes with a rotary head.  I really liked the cleaning power and the reach/accessibility that the small, round brush gave me.However, Oral-B lost its competitive advantage some time ago.  My teeth and gums feel cleaner with Sonicare.  I really like the battery life yet lightness of the handle.  The brush is even quieter...  The only issue I've ever had with the brushes is that I don't have quite as much accessibility to the back of my mouth as I had with the Oral-B Braun brushes.To fix that I've relied on the compact brush heads that are available for Sonicare.  This new brush head is the same size as the full size brush head, but has bristles at different heights.  At first I was tempted to dismiss this as just another gimmick.  I've tried the "diamond head" brushes and found them to be only marginally better than the regular brush heads; they seem to last a little longer.  But these are different: this brush head gives me the size of a regular brush with the reach/access of a smaller brush head - I can finally get back behind my rear-most teeth because of the shorter bristles.  My teeth feel really clean now.So I would definitely buy these again, as long as the price is similar to the regular/compact brush heads.

I only have a relatively small apartment, but the configuration means my bedroom internet radio receives an intermittent signal.  I thought a range extender like this one would solve my problems, so I requested one through the Vine program (ie, it was sent to me for free).This product arrives in pretty good packaging.  It's a small box, about 2 inches in each dimension which takes up one plug, even in a double outlet.  There is a single button on the box, and a single LED lamp.  The instructions look simple - plug it in, press a button on your router and press/hold the button on your box and you should be all set.Except that I wasn't.  The configuration failed in its original location.  Following the instructions, I moved the box closer and closer to my router.  Even at a distance of less than 1 foot from my router, the WPS easy push-button set-up didn't work.  Instead, I used the set-up that requires some typing on a computer that will connect to both your router and the box.  That did seem to work.But, and here's the reason I only gave this thing two stars, it didn't appear to improve my internet radio reception.  The issue appears to be a *very weak* radio inside the box.  So, you might get the signal extended by a few feet, but I couldn't see any evidence for signal extension of the 10 feet that I needed.I did give it two stars because the instructions were generally easy to follow and did just about work, in terms of making the little flashing lights flash in the way they said they would.  So it should be working, but I would have had to actually see more evidence of working to give it more than two stars.

You should probably dismiss this review: I couldn't read the book.  I struggled with the unbelievable arrogant writing style that comes over like too much of a sales pitch.Message for the author: I already bought the book - you don't have to be obnoxious about it.

Beware the design of this pitcher!  It has numerous problems: cheap construction, stupid lid design, and a drainage hole that allows unfiltered water to dribble directly into the filtered water at the bottom of the pitcher.  Plus this isn't even that good a price.AVOID this pitcher (but other Brita pitchers are fine and Brita filters are generally pretty effective at reducing Chlorine in water)

I thought I would add my voice to the chorus of disappointed pitcher purchasers.  This is my fourth Brita filter and by far the worst!It's made of cheap plastic (I remember the old ones were made of glass)The curvy lid may look good but introduces two problems: first, you can't bring the pitcher under a stream of water without soaking everything around you.  Second, if you fill it too high (and there is no line to know how high too high is), water runs out of a little hole in the back and directly into the bottom of the pitcher!  I understand you might need an overflow, but it shouldn't run into the filtered portion of the water!  That's a bit like hooking up your toilet overflow to your showerhead!Oh, and the lid sticks closed sometimes, or falls off completely at others.Never again.  And Brita has plenty of competitors now.  I might have to invest in a rival system.

I got this set of gloves for three reasons:1) Color scheme looks pretty good2) It should keep my hands warm3) Metal fingertips for using a smart phoneWell, I'll give it two stars for looking pretty good.  The globes are pretty well made with good attention to detail, especially around the fingers.It all starts to go wrong from there, though.  First, the sizing is a little too snug - I usually take a medium glove, but I should have got a large in these.  Next, as another reviewer noted, these aren't winter gloves.  They're not going to keep your fingers toasty for a day in the cold or snow.  They're better as wind protection on an Autumn day.  Last, the metal fingertips are not nearly as effective as others I've tried.  The metal pieces need to be smaller so that the phone can actually interpret them as a finger.  These pads are too large, so the screen just doesn't really pick it up at all.

This book is remarkably engaging - not quite on the level of a good thriller, but surprisingly close.  It achieves this feat by having a significant number of interesting anecdotes woven into the text.  Crucially, it skirts around the problem of basing too many conclusions on a single anecdote by having good supporting evidence that is reasonably current.  The book appears to date from Q1 2011, and contains a lot of tables that include 2010 as the final year.  It was good to see a chapter on expected US Healthcare reform impact, even if it was very short (3 pages).The book is divided up into lots of sub-sections, like most textbook-type volumes in this series.  The first few sections set the stage.  The book starts with an excellent discussion of the pharmaceutical business environment.  It is succinct and highlights all the major issues in a very readable form, although it is a little too focused on the US and EU at the expense of Japan and other Asian markets.  Next, there's an excellent introduction to patents, again very focused on the US but with mentions of situations in the EU and Japan.  There is very little discussion of the patent situation (or lack thereof) in developing markets.The next few sections delve more deeply into Lifecycle management (LCM). This starts with general strategies, which are somewhat obvious from the early part of the book and general knowledge.  Then there is an exploration of personalized medicine (treatments for subsets of the population).  The next few chapters discuss ways to extend the useful life of a drug (reformulation, new dosages, chemical modifications, etc).  All in all a useful section to skim.The next few sections after that get to strategic choices that you can make for a particular product.  The discussion remains readable and pertinent throughout and is useful.  It's a bit like hiring a consultant for a day to discuss options with - the book acts as its own sounding board, bringing up possibilities and then discussing their merits.  There's substantial discussion of how to deal with generics (and biosimilars).  There are 14 pages on "10 keys to successful lifecycle management" that appear to be the crux of the book, but they're actually not as useful as the earlier sections and the subsequent one on how LCM integrates into overall portfolio management.The last section is how LCM integrates into overall portfolio management and is also an excellent introduction to this area.  This is followed by a useful set of appendices (case studies/examples) that are useful to refer to when you're trying to make a point.In short, this is a really useful introduction for brand managers and commercial strategy folks within the pharmaceutical industry.  As written, it's accessible to others working in the pharmaceutical space (ie, educated investors, consultants, etc), and it does a great job of explaining things that really aren't visible from outside a pharmaceutical company (or even inside it sometimes...).

These Nanoblock sets are superficially quite similar to Lego.  From a distance, this Space Shuttle set looks for all the world like a 25% scale model of the Lego model of a real Space Shuttle.  That scale difference is the most obvious way that these blocks are different from and perhaps more challenging than a typical Lego set.  They're really small pieces, easy to lose even if you're being super-careful.  Fortunately, many spares (ie, more than 50 spare pieces) are included in the set.Like Lego, the little blocks have studs/nobbles and the idea is to lock the studs of one piece into the bottom of the next, so building the blocks without having to stick them together using glue or cement.  Lego pieces stick to each other quite tightly.  These blocks are made with similar levels of precision, but the bottom sides of the pieces are missing some critical structures, which makes it possible for these pieces to slide around on top of each other.  I mention this in particular because it's the second factor that adds to the challenge (and also the frustration) of this set: the blocks won't line themselves up as beautifully as Lego blocks do.  This set needs an even greater eye to detail than a typical Lego set.Another point to note is that the instructions are sufficient, but not detailed.  The base and tower take 8 steps, the boosters require 6 steps, the orbiter and main fuel tank just 3 each.  Several times I had to consult the color scheme on the box and the detailed side view at the bottom of the page to ensure I had the correct fit.  In short, these instructions are more like you'd get with a model car or airplane and less like your typical very detailed Lego (or Ikea) instructions.  I mention this because it's the third factor that adds to the challenge of this set.So: i) smaller piecesii) that fit together less securely and with more wiggle-roomiii) according to instructions that are much less detailed than you might be used toAll these things combine to make Nanoblocks intriguing, challenging, and a little frustrating.  If you're buying this kit for someone over 10 years old who likes to display models, I think these sets are pretty good up to age 70 or so.  This space shuttle in particular is a nice introduction to these sets, and will keep even a good builder occupied for 2 - 3 hours.  I really like some of the lovely touches in this model: the orbiter engines and tail are especially well-done.  The simplicity of the blocks (like Lego used to be, before the pieces became so specialized) means that the designers had to come up with pretty ingenious solutions to getting a triangular arrangement of the engines.  Your mileage may vary, but older folks may struggle with the small size of these pieces, which requires more patience than Lego.If you're looking for a set to co-build with someone, or for a kid/teen who will play with the set, "fly" it around, explore strange new worlds (rooms of the house), then buy one of the Lego versions (set 10231 is excellent, or set 3367 is about one-quarter the price and pretty fun, too).  It will be more expensive, but much easier to handle and much more fun to play with after it's been built.Or buy all of them and have the ultimate homage to a really clever spacecraft - still can't believe they actually built these!

I have the 10231 version of this set, which incorporates a few re-designs to improve durability during play (eg, better method of attaching booster rockets and providing scaffolding for the main fuel tank).  It is an excellent set, with two astronauts, a cargo bay with robotic arm and a satellite, retractable landing gear, detachable boosters/main fuel tank, and even a little launch center.The most important thing to note is that this set should be available on Amazon or from Lego directly for a reasonable price (about 10 cents per brick).  If you see it advertised at much more than that (eg, current price as of writing is more lik3 15 - 20 cents per brick), please re-consider your purchase.  If you're a collector and understand what you're paying for, that's one thing.  But if you're looking for a set for your child, be aware there is an improved version of this set (10231) which is cheaper and better.  Please do not support high prices for Lego on Amazon if you can help it.

I'm not sure how good this would be for a child, but as a desk toy for anyone who's a teenager onwards, this product is great.  It's a set of twelve very durable wooden blocks all interconnected with heavy-duty elastic.  I've bought 3 of these for various people and none of us have had a problem with breakage/perishing over the course of one year.  It does loosen a little over time, but remains very fun.Starting from the cube, if you pull the pieces apart, you'll get a wood block "bracelet."  It's not actually a bracelet, of course, but you can fit your hand through the hole.  Each block has limited degrees of freedom and can be re-arranged to some extent to form hundreds of different configurations.I love mine!

There are two views of this product.  The uncharitable view is that it is a glorified overpriced chocolate-covered raisin.  My view is that it's much more than that.First, the chocolate is a generous coating of high quality dark chocolate.  I think they say it's about 65% cocoa solids, which makes sense.  It's not too dark/bitter but it's darker than semi-sweet.  So the chocolate is a bit darker and much thicker than the dark chocolate-covered raisins that you'll find in the grocery store.Next, the raisins are definitely infused with wine.  This does two things: makes them more moist and also imparts a lovely red wine flavor (I think they claim to use a Shiraz).  There's not enough wine to really tell what type of wine they've used, but the flavor is strong enough that it stays with you.  In fact, I ate one before sitting down to compose this review and I can still taste the chocolate and the wine right now.Of course this means that each raisin is substantially larger than a typical chocolate-covered raisin, perhaps four times the volume.Apparently, the vendor has had some issues with shipping during the summer, so it's worth ordering when it's cool out.  Even in December, several of my raisins had stuck together, but separated easily.  They're fine eaten from the fridge, but definitely better when eaten at room temperature.  They appear to store well at room temperature.Last, there are several sizes available: a small bag, 8oz, and 16oz boxes.  The latter is a bit expensive, but comes with about 4 or 5 dozen raisins, plenty for a dinner party/group.

This is a really good book, as other reviewers have commented.  I'm not an architect, but I've read many (biochemistry) text books.  I was drawn to this textbook because of the outstanding illustrations.  They really are impressive and help to visualize exactly whatever the text is discussing.However, it's important to know the limitations of the book.  First, very little of this book is actually original.  The introduction describes that the book is actually a compilation of key chapters by the (prolific) Francis D.K. Ching.  The source books are:1) A global history of architecture - appears to be reproduced in chapters 2 and 3; provides snapshots of architecture every 200 years or so from 2500 BCE to present day.2) Architecture: Form, Space and Order - appears to be the source for chapters 4 (Form), 5 (Space), and 6 (Order)3) Building Codes Illustrated - interspersed and probably forms the basis of chapter 114) Building Construction Illustrated - Chapter 105) Design Drawing - Chapter 86) Interior Design Illustrated - summarized in chapter 147) A Visual Dictionary of Architecture - interspersed8) Language of Space and Form: Generative Terms for Architecture by James EcklerSecond, the font is difficult to read for a long period.  I know that shouldn't be a big deal, but it's not conducive to reading much of the text at a time.Third, the text is kind of obtuse.  The descriptions are not as clear as they could be.  For instance, you might build a building on a hill to make it more prominent.  This book notes that "elevating a portion of the ground plane establishes a platform or podium that structurally and visually supports the form and mass of a building."  I realize there's a need to use the appropriate terminology but the best textbooks make that really clear (eg, Immunobiology by Janeway and Travers, another beautifully illustrated book that uses all the right terminology to explain the complexities of the immune system really clearly).However, as other reviewers have noted, the diagrams really make this book excellent.  If you don't already have all of the books mentioned above, this is probably one of the better introductions to an interesting subject for students and the interested general reader alike.

As of now, this case is clocking in at one-quarter of the price of the camera.  For a while, Amazon was selling the same case for less than five dollars.  And that one came bundled with a 4Gb card.  In truth, that's all this case was ever worth.Buyer beware of the price, lack of features, and availability of better cases for less.

I was really surprised when I received this case with a bonus 4 Gb memory card.  If I'd known that was included, I probably wouldn't have ordered an 8 Gb card.The camera fits in the case snugly, making this case ideal for storing the camera in.  As others have said, there is no belt loop.  In addition, the camera must be fully removed from the case to actually use the screen or any of the rear controls.  These two facts make the case less ideal to actually carry the camera around while it's in use.The case will accommodate the XZ-1 with a lens cap, including the separately available Olympus "auto-open" lens cap, although it's a tight fit.  I'm fairly sure it won't accommodate the XZ-2, which has a revised front grip.If you didn't find this review helpful, please tell me how I can improve it.

This review will be in four sections: 1) Why use a screen protector? 2) How good are 3M privacy filters? 3) How well does this product work? 4) Brief conclusionsScreen protectors are really helpful to prevent two big problems with smartphone/kindle/tablet screens.  First, the oleophobic coating (ie, a chemical layer on the very surface of the screen that repels grease from fingers) rubs off within a few months.  Second, even in the softest cotton pocket, the much-vaunted gorilla glass will still get many fine scratches on it.  Neither of these really affects utility, but it will affect ultimate resale value, and I found it annoying after a year.  I've found that applying a screen protector prevents both of these issues without creating additional problems.  In fact, these screens can reduce glare and improve contrast.  Obviously, the sooner you apply the protector, the better.3M does a great job of making privacy filters.  These are thin polarized pieces of plastic that substantially limit the viewing angle of the screen.  If you view confidential information and/or spend a lot of time using your phone on planes, subways or other environments where people's eyes will be on your screen, this really helps.  However, it's worth remembering that privacy screens only work in one dimension.  In this case, when you hold the phone in portrait mode, anyone whose head is more than about a foot away from yours will have real trouble seeing your screen (at a normal distance).  If you hold the phone in landscape mode anyone significantly shorter than you will have trouble seeing your screen, but other folks will be able to see it.  I've used privacy screens from other companies and some of them are not nearly as good as these 3M ones from an optical point of view.  This screen is really clear, with no distracting lines.So, how does this work on the iPhone?  Well, the package is a bit stingy.  It claims to contain 3 items: ONE screen (many competitors come with three or four), 1 lens cloth, and an applicator.  At first, I couldn't find the applicator, until I realized it was the cardboard insert from the top of the packaging.  It will work, but many competitors give you a small piece of plastic.  If you don't have one of these, I'm a fan of using a credit card.  I didn't attempt to use the cardboard.  Like competing filter, this one is applied by cleaning the phone screen with the cloth, partially peeling the protective plastic off the filter, pressing the top portion of the filter in place, and then use the applicator to gently press the filter into place as you continue to peel the protective layer off.  A better description appears on the inside of the package, and there's a website with pictures that can help.  That all having been said, it's not rocket science or brain surgery.I think this is a great product - it's about time someone came out with something like this, but it is a bit pricey.  There are plenty of cheaper protective non-privacy screens that doe a great job, too.  I really like the matte finish ones made by Halo.  They are virtually indestructible.  I do not yet know how long this 3M product will last - it seems like it should last for a while, though.Let me know how this review could be improved.

I got this book thinking that it might be as good as some of the Annals of Improbable Research (AIR) Ignobel prize round-ups and some of the other outstandingly funny science books that have been written.But no such luck. Instead, it's a fake textbook, split into astronomy, biology, chemistry, earth science, physics, and two other random chapters.  In the interests of scientific method, and in response to some of the other comments that reckoned every page was hilarious, here are excerpts taken at random from every 50 pages:Pg 50: (Astronomy) "Our universe began about 14 billion years ago, give or take 12 billion.  It's believed that the universe was packed into a hot dense particle the size of a popcorn kernel, but scientists are almost certain there wasn't any butter."Pg 100: (Biology) "Moss is a flat plant that covers rocks and land quickly, like slime but soft. New Zealand is covered entirely in this soft, fabric-like plant, which allows its people to travel barefoot wherever they go."Pg 150: (Chemistry) "We shall fight them on the beaches, we shall fight on the landing grounds, we shall fight - okay, very funny.  Did someone put helium in my microphone?" - Winston ChurchillPg 200: (Earth Science) "The seasons feed into each other in a weather cycle. They are spring, summer, autumn, and winter, and without the variety of seasons we'd have to appreciate the one we're currently in."Pg 250: (You're a scientist) [annotated diagram of a scientist] "Shoes are necessary to maintain dignity, but if they are unavailable, you can use some acid to give your feet some healthy calluses."Fortunately, the book runs out of pages at 270.  If you thought those quotes were even vaguely funny, you should probably buy the book and/or book an operation for a sense of humor bypass.  It's all like that which, to be fair, is exactly what it promises in the product description.There are lavish illustrations throughout, just like a textbook.  In short, my opinion is that this is a one-joke book: textbooks can be incorrect.  It's a pretty reasonable concept for a book, but it just falls so flat that it's not worth the paper it's printed on.  To be even more blunt: I won't be buying any copies, not even for people I don't really like much.UPDATE:I may not like this product, but I am trying to write a helpful review.  If you don't find this review helpful, please tell me why, so that I can address it in the future.  Even if you're the author of the book.

In the interests of full disclosure, I received this food processor through Amazon's Vine program.  Despite the exterior badging it is a Sunbeam product.  Having had one of their bread machines, I was expecting cheap and cheerful.  This processor does not disappoint: it's really a 3.5 to 4 star machine so far.When it arrived, I concocted an excuse to chop various vegetables and 3 lb of meat into a dumpling filling.  Should be pretty easy for a 500 watt large capacity food processor like this one.Impressions during unboxing: The cord is SHORT - only 2 feet long at it's fullest extent.  This needs to be situated right next to a power outlet.  The round blades (grater and french fry chopper) are made of a reasonable steel that isn't too sharp, except for the cutting surfaces, that are clearly from another kind of steel and bolted on afterwards.  They are sharp, but how long will they stay that way?  Both blades were a little warped, but nothing significant.  All the blades have a single central somewhat soft plastic piece that slides onto the spindle.  The chopper plastic piece already had some scoring, and there was some residue left in the plastic bowl.  It's possible I received a refurbished unit, but it was professionally packaged and I don't think it was a big deal, but it's definitely worth washing every component (except base!) before using it the first time.As far as size goes, the base is pretty large: about the size of a 3 quart pot.  The bowl is similarly large, and the lid is about half that size.  I have room for it in my kitchen, but it's definitely a consideration.The motor unit is large, but not too heavy, with four pretty reasonable rubber suction cups for feet.  The large serrated blade was missing one of the protective sleeves and I almost cut myself taking the blade out of the packaging.  Given how hard I gripped the blade, I'm surprised and not entirely pleased that I didn't draw blood.  The blades measure about 6 inches across, which leaves a quarter inch margin between the furthest edge of the blade and the inside of the bowl.The instruction manual seems fine and is generally pretty clear.  There are odd exceptions: After washing the parts in hot soapy water, I'm instructed to "rinse them dry."  All the parts except the base are dishwasher safe.  The unit will NOT "chop ice, whip cream, beat eggs, grind coffee beans, spices or other items with high oil content, or slice/shred hard-cooked eggs, marshmallows, or soft cheeses."  The manual doesn't give any indication of how to use the various attachments.  It's not rocket science: the grater looks like a flattened cheese grater.  The french fry disc has perpendicular blades.  The confusing one is the one that looks like a half-grater, half-chopper.  I'm going to assume it's for shredding.General fit and finish is definitely on par with what you'd expect for equipment of this price.  The lid portion is the worst designed element: annoying to clean and kind of clunky.  The seal around the lid on mine was a little wonky, but doesn't seem to affect function.The processor assembles easily and quickly.  The blades have enough power behind them to make short work of carrots, onions, mushrooms, etc.  Some folks have complained that the plastic bowl feels a little flimsy.  I think if you're careful and buying this for weekly/irregular use you'll find it great for large capacity chopping.  If you're going to be dicing celery or doing other challenging things on a daily basis, I think you might want to invest in a more substantial piece of equipment.

I've used a couple of different types of screen cleaner and this one is really pretty good.  The pack comes with a generous 7 oz (200 ml) of almost odorless cleaning solution and a really nice cloth.  Switch off the TV/laptop/tablet/whatever and let it cool down.  Two squirts from the bottle onto the cloth and then wipe down the screen.  Fingerprints, dust, and other dirt disappears with very little effort.  The cleaning solution evaporates very quickly, leaving a perfectly glassy screen.In short, this is a nice product.I noticed there's a table in the product description that tells you what kind of screens you can use this product with.  Well, I am quite unconvinced that this product is significantly different from the smaller sizes that are recommended for smaller screens.  In fact, I think the only difference is that they sell you less solution and a smaller cloth for not much less money.  So, there's plenty of this product in the container and I'm pretty sure it'll be good for all your household screens.  I wouldn't use it on oven doors (just use ordinary glass cleaner for that), but I'll be using this product for all my TVs, laptops, digital picture frames, GPS devices, kindles...So why only 4 stars?  Well, if you don't have little ones with wandering hands, you may not need a product like this at all.  My 6 year old flat screen TV (a 26 inch behemoth!) has never been dusted, so I used this product on it.  Although the plastic bezel if filthy, the screen has always been quite clean and this product didn't make a difference.  Plus there was nothing on the cloth when I'd finished.  However, if you know you have a fingerprint, dirt, dust problem, then this product does seem to work.

This product is designed for the iPhone 4 or 4S, the equivalent iPod touch, or some android phones (with screens under 4.3 inches).  It will not fit the latest iPhone 5 or Samsung Galaxy III phones, since they are too big.If your phone doesn't fit, you're not missing all that much.  It's really just a well-constructed plastic steering wheel, which looks like fake carbon fiber.  There are four buttons, two on the front and two on the back.  These are mechanically connected to buttons that will activate a touchscreen phone.  For this reason, the instructions recommend the use of screen protector.  There are no electronics or connectors to worry about.  The phone is held securely, although the locking mechanism is a little clunky.  If you're buying this for a child, they may need some supervision the first time they try to fit it the first time.  Once you get the hang of it, it's relatively straightforward.You have to download the game itself, which seems to work just fine in or out of the holder.  So why buy a piece of plastic so you can play a "free" game?  I don't get it.  The game has two problems:1) It's very hampered unless you buy in the in-game extras2) The physics just don't work - there's no way you could execute tight turns at the apparent speedsBut don't take my word for it.  Download the 2XL MX offroad game for free.  If you think it's the best game ever, but needs a better steering wheel, then go ahead and buy this.

Physically, this is very appealing: it looks like a large bottle of shampoo or conditioner and comes in a variety of bathroom-matching colors.  Perfect for a bathroom radio!The radio takes two AA batteries, which is not many.  However, installation requires a screwdriver and there is no obvious rubber seal.  My other waterproof radio (a Sony) does not require a screwdriver to change the batteries.Setting the clock is OK - there are a couple of buttons on the bottom that allow the clock to be set (but only moving forward - if you miss the right minute, you'll have to press the button for a while to cycle through the minutes again).Turning on the radio is relatively straightforward.  There is an on-switch and an off-switch, a band selector, and two tuning buttons on one side of the radio.  These 5 buttons look identical to the five buttons on the other side of the radio, which control the pre-sets.  Once you get into the habit, it's easy enough.Ok, now here are my issues:1) Reception was poor, since the antenna is internal not very effective.2) Sound is poor, since the speaker is remarkably tinny.3) There's no sleep function, which means you have to remember to turn it off (and remember which of those 10 buttons, labeled in tiny writing, is the right one).Upshot: I don't use it anymore, and would rather have my Sony - with an external antenna, sleep function, and easily-installed batteries - even though it doesn't match the bathroom decor as nicely.

I realize this is not a very helpful review: although I was intrigued by the back cover, I just couldn't get past page 10 of this book.  I found the prose unengaging and unwelcoming, although I suspect this is just my experience.

This is a very standard deodorant/anti-perspirant.  It features 20% of the active ingredient (formerly "prescription strength" or "clinical strength"), not the 16% that was standard for so many years.  As a result it is very effective.  The scent is fine.  It's got Aloe and vitamin E in it, so if you have sensitive underarms, this may be a good choice.However, the first few ingredients are waxes and oils, so it goes on white.  I'm not sure how it could ever be construed as an invisible solid.  I don't know for certain, but I would predict it will leave a waxy build-up on clothing over time, like almost every other underarm stick I've tried.I had bought this because Mitchum makes another product ("smart solid") where the first ingredient is water.  I had assumed this product was the next generation of that one.  No such luck.  I love the smart solid because it won't ruin clothing with waxy build-up over time - I just ordered more of that.

Pre-cut pieces with pre-punched holes sewing crafts are an excellent introduction to needle work. Dimensions NeedleCrafts features a whole line of needlepoint, punch needle, felting and applique projects for the novice and experienced stitcher.With less than 100 stitches - mostly the running stitch, an easy way to learn to embroider - and only 4 tie-offs, the Little Owl Felt Appliqu is perfect for between ages 5-8. The owl's features are sewed together before applying the entire body to the gingham background fabric. This approach eliminates requiring little hands to hold multiple pieces together while sewing. The effect is a clean line on the back (see picture), another important sewing technique that should be taught and mastered young.The Learn & Craft Owl kit combines skills building with pleasing design and aesthetic value while even offering a little bit of fun. A ribbon can be strung through the plastic hoop to hang the creation on a bedroom wall. It's a modern approach to an ancient art form.That blending of old and new in an attractive and easy-to-learn kit earns this craft a solid five stars. I highly recommend this for your crafting and sewing family project.

At the time of my review, this American Girl craft was "currently unavailable." That's disappointing, and I hope that Amazon is able to restock this "Sew & Share" kit as I found this to be an exceptionally well made, attractive and useful craft. We were so impressed with our original purchase that we bought nine more of these kits. Our children gave the completed sets as holiday gift ornaments to friends and family.American Girl Crafts offer generous and quality supplies for interesting projects at reasonable prices. The entire line features vibrant materials and whimsical designs. Each project comes with a brightly illustrated booklet that reads as both an instruction manual and as a "rah, rah, you can do it!" cheer.Hand crafts, particularly sewing, can seem daunting. Needle and thread work requires concentration and control. Pull the needle too tight and your fabric bunches. Thread your work too loosely and the pieces look askew. The individual working areas of this craft are small enough to allow sewing corrections so that the finished look is professional. Your crafter will learn as they go and feel accomplished, too.This project strengthens the fine-motor and attention-to-detail skills required for sewing while producing a useful and beautifully made gift that will make your crafter proud. There's a lot of value in such a small package. Put this American Girl kit on your Wish List. When it comes available, be sure to order one - or more - for your young crafting enthusiast.

Just like navigating the waterway itself, there are a variety of ways to explore the many books and stories about this national treasure.A first must read is the richly detailed but highly technical Waterway Guide: Atlantic ICW 2015. After the rough seas of that excursion, sail into calmer waters with Allan Fisher and James Amos's visual and poetic 1973 narrative, America's Inland Waterway. After the practical Guide and the dreamy National Geographic Society paean, Gene and Katie Hamilton offer a breezy travelogue of their 1,243-mile journey.The three works give you vastly different perspectives on the same body of water. The Hamilton's requires the least amount of `tacking' and `jibing' and makes for a quick read. Their personal touch is found in the movie and recipe suggestions they pair with each portion of their route - "Being in Virginia Makes Us Hungry for..." or "Our Favorite South Carolina Flick."This is a conversation in book form - it reads as if you are on deck cruising with them as they make their way south. It's an accessible style that is light on sailing terms and focuses more on the sightseeing aspects of this legendary waterway. Except for the heavy use of "really" and "very" and "nice", I really liked this very nice book.

Why cruise the America's seaboard waterway, a 2,000-mile inland route that runs along the Atlantic coast to Key West, FL?Allan Fisher, author of this National Geographic Society book, quotes Stamford CT mayor and sailing enthusiast, Julius Wilensky, who says it's because, "there's a bit of Columbus and Magellan in many of us."That sense of adventure and exploration infuse every page of this book. And although published in 1973, the book is as timeless and beautiful as the majestic waterway it describes. The lyrical text by Fisher is richly illustrated by the images of well-regarded photographer, James L. Amos. Six full-page, color maps outline each segment of their journey. The combined effect is to bring the reader right into the hypnotic beauty of this intracoastal waterway (ICW).Fisher describes the voyage through the eyes of a naturalist from the vantage of his 43-foot motorsailer, Andromeda. Putting in and out of anchorages all along the incredible estuaries, coastal rivers, creeks, canals, marches, tributaries, and tidal basins of the coastal shoreline, Fisher is a modern-day maritime explorer describing a world many of us only know at dockside. Amos focuses his lens on life - human and animal - both on and off the water, capturing the interplay between man and his environment in this unique ecosystem.This work is out of print and only available from third-party sellers. Yet, it is worth adding to your collection of ICW books. The outstanding writing and photos make this an unforgettable reading experience of one of America's great waterways.

Don't be fooled by the low price (I paid under $20): this ChargerCity holder is a solid piece equipment that will enhance your iPad recording experience.This is an accessory stick product that acts as an extension of a stand-alone tripod. I use the Targus-brand tripod for my digital and video camera mounts, both of which came with factory-installed screw bases. iPads don't have a screw base requiring the ingenious solution of the ChargerCity holder. The iPad slides into the holder which attaches to the tripod by way of a bendable gooseneck ending in a quarter-inch screw socket.With the iPad secured in the holder, and the holder securely screwed onto your tripod, you will be able to shoot or record wobbly-free images. The value in this product is pairing it with a good tripod. Bad shocks are going to give you a rocky ride no matter how comfy the seats. A flimsy tripod (bad shocks) is going to give your iPad in its ChargerCity holder (the comfy seats) a rocky ride.With my iPad mounted in the ChargerCity holder and attached to my adjustable Targus tripod, I've shot many clear, distortion-free videos. The swivel ball joint makes positioning the holder simple while the joint ring adjusts the tension depending on how fluid you want your shot. The gooseneck detaches from the holder making it easy to store flat.The ChargerCity iPad holder is a great accessory for your recording needs. Highly recommended.

I read this guide three times. The first time was as a tourist, blown away by the amount of visual and written detail describing the amazing breadth, complexity, and beauty of the Intracoastal Waterway. The second time, I read as a consumer, scrutinizing the ads, which were almost as informative as the guide, and definitely as interesting. The third time, I read from the perspective of a boater, mentally plotting my route as I studied the pages.This waterway guide is outstanding precisely because it gives the reader so many perspectives and angles from which to approach their journey - whether it be `by land or by sea'. Each section is color coded and uniformly organized. It's a generous amount of marine (bouys, tides, lanes), boating (anchorages, docking, facilities), technical (navigation, safety, equipment), and local flavor (historical, dining, points of interest) information supplemented by extensive charts, maps and photos.The "Goin' Ashore" feature that describes every port stop and appears in the many side trip notes, includes the well-researched "History" and "Points of Interest" categories that I particularly enjoyed reading. Salted throughout the guide was "Quick Facts" that described local animal life and explained quirky boating terms and waterway rules.The writing, layout, maps, guides, charts, and even the ads, are outstanding. This waterway guide is less a boating manual and more an expeditionary guide.  It's an excellent resource for the new or seasoned boater, as well as a vicarious thrill for the armchair adventurer. I highly recommend this guide.

After 5 years of heavy use, my padded Office Max chair was starting to show its age. It was time for a new chair. When I find something that I like, I usually buy it again. Instead, I decided to try out this mesh task chair by HON.Padded chairs have a soft, quilted design. What you get in comfort, you pay for in weight and bulk (see pictures). Foam padding can also get warm and, over time, lose its firmness. Still, padded chairs offer cozy comfort with a stately profile.In contrast, the mesh chair presents a sleek, modern, no nonsense profile. This is a chair that tells you to "get to work!" I liked the flexible mesh backing that is in contrast to the firm seat. Good posture is part of the package with the adjustable lumbar support. The arm rest has six settings and is easy to move, as is the lever for the seat height. I thought it an awkward design to have the tilt tension separate from the seat lever. And even when loosened, it barely provided any tilt.Overall, I think this chair is great for posture and for attitude: there's no slouching or getting comfy at the expense of getting the work done. I also liked the smaller 5-star base and lighter weight of the entire chair. For my money though, I prefer to have the tilt and seat height feature combined.This is a solid, good-looking, pricey chair with a 4-star rating.

My son discovered the K'Nex building sets in 2012, when he was 8 years old. The timing was perfect as he had already mastered the LEGO building kits up to the 14+ age range. K'Nex sets offered him the complexity of LEGO with the excitement of motorized or mechanical movement.In between designing his own creations, he worked his way through the K'NEX Robo Battlers, the Ferris Wheel (a favorite),  two sets of roller coasters, the Super Sonic Swirl and the diabolically clever K'NEXosaurus Rex kit. And while K'Nex went on to offer bigger and better versions of these highly original concepts, it seemed the product line had run its course.With the release of the K-Force line, K'Nex has returned to its roots of offering challenging creative design with exciting play options. K-Force combines the intricacies of LEGO with the mechanics of Erector sets, the sport action of Nerf with the interactivity of MindWare's building sets.Flexibility is the most important part of K'Nex products - not only in the Flexi-rod design, but also in the ability of users to reconfigure the manufactured set. Your young engineer can follow the 66 steps in the 24-page, full-color and detailed manual, or they can take the concept and reimagine it (see pix for my son's two-player design from the Dual Cross kit).K-Force is an outstanding building set. Kudos to the creative genius who dreamed up this product. K'Nex is a again a force to be reckoned with the Build and Blast product line. Highly recommended.

Since we bought this patio bench in June 2009, it has held up to three kids, three moves, 36 seasonal changes, including two record-breaking winters of 81" and 110" of snow. During MA's Snowmageddon 2015, the bench was buried under almost 7 feet of snow. That's 2,190 days of weather and family ab/use. Our next-door neighbors were so impressed with our unit, they bought one for their family patio, too.The bench is easy to assemble right out of the box. No tools are required as all the pieces simply snap into place. That's an important feature to consider for outdoor equipment that is exposed to the elements year round - you won't have pieces that rust and discolor the unit, your deck or clothes, or the stored items. The top can be popped off for seasonal cleaning. We splash on some Murphy's Oil Soap, scrub, hose down and air dry.Although we wrap mitts and other soft-textured items in large Ziploc storage bags, the bench is remarkably waterproof. Even torrential downpours barely penetrate the casing with only nominal water in the honeycombed base. It's a solid piece of outdoor furniture, despite the snap-in-place construction, easily holding two adults without the top buckling. Summer heat hasn't caused any warping, either, while the light color prevents skin contact heat burns.This was a big-ticket purchase that has more than proved its worth. The Suncast Patio Bench is a good investment for your family's outdoor needs. Highly recommended.

In our family, no matter the grade, there are three stages to our childrens' daily learning: school work, homework and extra work, otherwise known as studying. We use workbooks by Sylvan, Teacher Created Resources, School Zone, and the Summer Bridge series by Carson-Dellosa to enhance the classroom curriculum.The first third of this Brighter Child series workbook features exercises of English grammar. The language rule, such as nouns, verb tenses, subject and predicates, direct and indirect objects, and adjectives is reviewed on the first page of the main section, followed by 4-5 pages of subsection work. For instance, Adverbs is followed by Adverbs of Time, then Adverbs of Place and finally Adverbs of Manner. If your child is still trying to figure out the basic rules governing simple adverbs, the following three sections will be confusing and frustrating.The second third of the workbook features contractions and syntax rules such as "sit/set, can/may, good/well, because/so, this/these, and/or/but. The work was made harder by the absence of a typical fill-in-the-blanks answer format. Instead, all the possible answers were included in the sentence example forcing the reader to slow down and really read through the material. This section was my favorite for both its original concept and challenging format.The final third quizzes your scholar on their proofreading and punctuation skills.This is not a skills-building workbook; this is an intense skills-testing workbook. There's a lot of material on each page - an average of 15 questions - all of which require written responses. We're looking forward to tackling the next level with Brighter Child.

My kids loved these gummies, but at the price for the serving size of 4 gummies per day per child, we are priced out of the market. Here's the breakdown:  2 kids x 4 gummies per day = 8; 120 gummies per bottle  8 = 15 day supply. Meaning we'd need to buy 2 bottles per month at an average cost of $25 per bottle or over $50 per month. A year supply would cost $600.I could justify that cost if we didn't already eat healthy. Our vitamin regimen is added value to our diet, not a substitute for one.The SmartyPants flavor is outstanding and didn't require refrigeration to mask the fishy Omega-3 smell. Stickiness is a bit of a challenge, especially in summer, but not a deal breaker. The packaging, ingredients, and product story are all terrific.Except for the cost, this is a great addition to the dietary supplement market for kids.

As I don't suffer from seasonal allergies, the main reason I got this mattress pad is the fact that it could be washed in hot water. Detergent manufacturers claim that their products allow linens to be washed in cold water with the same cleaning power of a hot water wash. Blame my hot-water wash upbringing, but I'm not buying it.But, while I prefer hot water washes for my linens, elastic-cornered mattress pads are another story and require a cold wash before a delicate dryer setting. A hot wash and dry will melt, shrink and eventually rip the rubberized pieces of the material. Hence the conundrum: sheets washed hot only to be placed atop a cold-water washed mattress pad. Was that really clean?Thanks to Allerease, this conflict is resolved. The packaging prominently displays that their mattress pad was "hot water washable." My pad has been through several wash and dry cycles and all is well. The hypoallergenic fiber fill is still fluffly, and the stretchable sides are still tight.It's a comfortable - though slightly bunched - fit on my 9" deep IKEA mattress. One person can easily place the pad on the mattress since the sides are entirely composed of a loosely banded material that snaps into place without skewing the remaining corners. I found the top to be soft and poofy - a pillowy feel.For all the hot water washers out there, I highly recommend this mattress pad.

There's a whole field of engineering devoted to managing noise and vibration. Common industrial applications include mufflers for cars, soundproofing material for music studios, dampers for heavy machinery such as roof-mounted air conditioning units, and specialized floor mats for commerical gyms and fitness centers.Scaled-down designs made home-based fitness equipment possible. Yet, the market for mitigating the noise and vibration side effects of this equipment didn't likewise keep pace. Consumers didn't buy commercial grade soundproofing for their personal-use fitness machines for three reasons: it was usually heavy, smelly and expensive.SPRI, a leader in both the home and retail exercise market, has designed an attractive and affordable high density equipment mat suitable for your home. The Pro-Tech doesn't have a rubber tire or plastic smell; the texture isn't oily or greasy. This high density mat is surprisingly heavy but that heft provides the traction needed for a stable workout experience.While the Pro-Tech distributes vibrations over a large surface area (8ft x 3ft), which theoretically should help dampen noise, the reality is that exercising in a home on any level other than the basement is going to cause a lot of noise, regardless of the mat used. What this mat offers is excellent surface coverage with no slippage or migration due to machine vibrations or exercise patterns, and no smell at a competitive price.I've been using this mat for several months and am pleased with its performance. I recommend it for your home-based workout space.

Synopsis:  The Athenian king Aegeus marries Aethra, who mates with both Poseidon and Aegeus, to become the mother to Theseus. Poseidon sends Minos, the king of Crete, a white bull which mates with Minos's wife, Pasiphae, to birth a half-man, half-bull creature called Minotaur. Minos's son, Androgeos, is killed by the white bull. Theseus slays the Minotaur with the help of Minos's daughter, Ariadne, whom he abandons on a deserted island for the god Dionysus, before marrying her sister, Phaedra.Have you got all that?Theseus and the Minotaur could be an allegorical tale for the labyrinth that is Greek mythology with its complex relationships, confusing agendas, and confounding names. A graphic novel can be a great vehicle by which the elementary reader can be exposed to a-maze-ing tales such as this one.Toon Graphics tries to rise to the challenge with this beautifully illustrated work. Yet, the densely arrayed images per page, combined with the wordy narration throughout - in addition to the speech bubbles (in a different font) - makes this godly tale feel merely mortal. An exciting myth like this needs larger art and more than 48 pages to be told.There's terrific attention to detail including the 2-page trading card recap followed by the helpful index. Overall, "Theseus" is an artistic gem, but is way too wordy for both the graphic novel concept, and the target audience of elementary readers.I recommend this work for your middle and older readers.

For my 10th birthday, I received a mini pool table. The balls were the size of marbles and the cue sticks were like twigs. It was impractical and cheap, and I loved it. That little tabletop pool game was one of the best gifts of my young life.The Wild West Shootout by Sharper Image is like that pool table; it's ridiculous fun that will create memories for a lifetime. The best range of play is at 5 feet, but 10 feet back make for more competitive firing as players get more skilled.It's got the old-time arcade look and feel right down to the sound effects of Yee-haw! when the game ends. Speaking of, we taped a thick paper towel over the speaker to reduce the volume (there is no knob control). Four targets - a vulture, buffalo skull, cactus, tin can - are intermittently lit red for scoring action of 20 shots and a total possible score of 530. The target light moves faster the higher you move through the levels - whether you hit them or not. The first 5 shots are 10 points each (50), the next 6 are 20 points each (120), with the remaining 9 shots earning 40 (360) points each.The microchip technology makes it virtually impossible to memorize all the target sequencing - we stopped counting at 15 rounds of different combinations - meaning a new game is played almost every time.The Wild West Shootout is a solid piece of silly fun. Highly recommend this toy arcade shooting game.

Projects like paint-by-number, potholders, coloring books, puzzles, stained glass, and suncatchers are hands-on creative work and play. Besides being fun to do, they develop sensory and fine-motor skills, require focus and concentration, and teach task-and-time management skills.The end result of all that effort can simply be satisfaction of a job well done. Or the final product can be used, displayed or gifted for the enjoyment of many.With Makit Bakit, your young artist can make a festive suncatcher using the enclosed colored baking crystals. It's exacting work that requires use of a teaspoon or a pair of tweezers (neither included). This project also requires a steady hand and lots of patience - good skills to practice at any age.While the craft looks deceptively easy, it's pretty labor intensive. Your child's maturity level will determine whether they - or you - finish the work.My family loves arts and crafts and the Makit Bakit suncatchers continue to be a popular rainy-day project. Highly recommend the Makit Bakit line, as well as the other arts and crafts from the ColorBk company catalog.

It's a pretty safe bet that any product you buy from Melissa & Doug will be a keepsake piece. This is especially true of the Peel-n-Press line that includes the Rainbow Garden and Undersea Fantasy.We bought all three stained glass projects to make during summer vacation. My kids range in age from 8 - 12, yet they each found their gel-piece work exacting, yet fun. The end result is a gorgeous handmade artwork for display in a window or glass door.A review of the directions was required, but they quickly figured out how to match the gel pieces to the numbered template, working intently for at least two hours to complete the work.Each kit comes with the image encased within a wood frame which is painted on one side to match the main color scheme. The window-facing plain side allows the child to write the date or a message if giving the stained glass as a gift. Although no suction cup is enclosed, a color-matching string at the top can be hung off window latches for see-thru presentation (see Customer Images of Undersea Fantasy). Unlike traditional stained glass, this window art is lightweight and unbreakable.This art project combines sensory, numerical, and color learning within a play-like experience. It's a classic Melissa & Doug approach. Highly recommend buying all three kits. The entire line is a beautiful addition to your homeschool art studies program or simply as home-based arts and crafts project. I hope Melissa & Doug adds more products to this Window Art line.

This is a great bag for casual campers, road trippers, and sleepover use. It is not a bag intended for serious backpacking and, despite its 20-40 degree Fahrenheit rating, winter camping.We found this bag perfect for camping out inside while traveling away from home. The Coleman Sabine simplifies the logistics of our host family finding enough sheets and blankets to bed down a family of five.For road trips, we pack three Sabines and two twin AeroBeds.
