The adults sleep in regular beds with regular bedding while the kids bunk down on a couch and the blow ups. The bags take the place of linens making daily setup and breakdown convenient. The quilted design and generous polyester fill make for a roomy and comfy night's sleep.Besides being comfortable, these bags are toasty. Even in houses where the nighttime thermostat is set to 60 degrees, the kids seemed warmer and more comfortable in their sleeping bags than the adults who were sandwiched between cold sheets topped by layers of flannel blankets and heavy comforters.Although the bag comes with Coleman's QuickCord storage - a plastic hook catches and holds the rolled up end of the bag - we purchased three large Nelson-Rigg Compression Bags in which to stuff the Sabines. This kept the bags clean and made transporting and storage easy.The Sabine performed exactly as we expected which is why I give it five stars. It's a solid sleeping bag for amateurs, kids and weekend warriors (who are less than 5'8").

The makers of the ZhuZhu Pets, a toy hamster craze that dominated the Christmas 2009 season, have now released a motorized plush puppy and kitten line called The Happy's. The plush pet play can be enhanced by accessories such as the Zippy Skateboard and the Speedy Sports Car.This is a well-made toy that has held up to extended play for over 9 months despite banging into table legs, baseboards, and doors. The plush pet (sold separately) is belted into the car before pressing the motorized button found near the tail.There are three wheels on the bottom of the pet: one small pivot wheel under the front of the pet, and two larger wheels flanking the back (see Customer Images). It's the back wheels on the pet that "powers" the car; the blue car wheels are decoration only and don't move. The angle of the pet allows its treaded wheels to extend past the chassis of the car to zip around both a hard and carpeted surface.The beauty of this design is that the car never gets stuck since the pet's wheels spin either backward or forward - both together and independently - allowing it to back out of seemingly impossible spaces. It "drives" for over 4 minutes.I gave this toy five stars because it is well made, priced right, and wacky good fun. It's a great gift for the under five year old set. It is also a hugely popular chase toy for cats and puppies.

The uses of this little above-ground pool are limited only by your imagination. Obviously, it's perfect for refreshing home-based play for your toddlers. The shallow 18-inch depth fills up quickly while the 6-foot diameter comfortably holds 2-3 average-sized young kids. At less than 2 feet deep, the water will absorb direct summer sun quickly, too, offsetting the chilly hose water.As your toddlers turn to tweens, turn the pool into a refilling station for their water blaster and super soaker games.The complaints about setup and breakdown feel ill-informed to me since explicit instructions are enclosed that work as directed. The advantage to a small daily pool is that you use regular chlorinated water that doesn't stand overnight. There are no chemical or safety issues. Like another reviewer noted, a large, plastic tarp provides ideal ground coverage preventing dirty water from muddied feet, as well as protection to the pool liner against sticks and stones.We bought a couple of buckets and had the kids water the lawn and plants in order to empty the pool. With the water emptied to about a 2" depth, simply lift one end and drain out the remaining water. Hung over a porch railing, the pool will completely dry until its next use.The Snapset Pool folds up accordion style allowing you to pack it in a large bag and take on road trips. This was a great summertime fun investment. I highly, highly recommend this well-priced, fun, easy-to-use and multiuse pool.

My favorite line in Edmund White's memoir, "Inside a Pearl", is found on page 53, where a friend tells him, "...you are an artist - artists should never pay!" This quote sums up the spirit of this book - expansive, generous and rewarding. Every page is a delight of snappy dialogue, larger-than-life characters, and glamorous gatherings of people with a ridiculous amount of creative energy and savoir vivre.The majority of the book takes place in Paris, in the early 80s, where White moves to after winning a Guggenheim fellowship. He stays in France for the next 15 years. For the French, manners, decorum and talent are respected independent of affiliations and beliefs. It's a bigger sin in his adopted country to be boring than it is to be gay, liberal, aging, pudgy, and, eventually HIV-positive. His writing reputation opens salon door after salon door.What keeps White's story from veering into camp or eccentricity is how gracefully he writes about his friends and their adventures despite their excesses. Perhaps his Midwest roots (Ohio and Michigan), explain his lack of pretense or sarcasm in either his relationships or his writing, the latter of which brims with enthusiasm and wonder at how splendidly his life and work turned out.White is a natural storyteller who also clearly took careful notes of his times abroad. The ability to put the reader in the moment is a unique gift. Highly recommend this memoir and his many other excellent works, as well.

This memoir from writer Richard Hoffman, is a continuation of his family story, first told in "Half the House," and ends with the death of his father in 2008.Hoffman's first book, published in 1996, found its storytelling power through victimization, writing about his sexual abuse - at the hands of a youth coach - six years before the Catholic Church pedophile priest scandal broke in the "Boston Globe."In "Half the House," Hoffman is unflinching in writing about the evils of pedophilia and the pain it caused him and his family. The book's theme of death - of brothers, of small-town life, of trust and innocence - ended with an affirmation of forgiveness and love.In this book, Hoffman explores the evils of racism, classism, and sexism lived by generations of Hoffmans. It could have been an interesting juxtaposition of personal works. This book could have explored the idea of public and private harms within a family dynamic as opposed to an outside harm that invaded the heart of the family as described in the first book.Instead, Hoffman writes as if the family legacy of bigotry ends with his father's death. Hoffman was just another victim of another evil that has now died out and all is right with the world. The memoir reads like a weak and uninspired response to the corrosive power of the Hoffman familys heart of darkness.An honest reckoning would have made for powerful reading from this gifted writer. Advice: Read the first book, skip this one, and wait for his next book.

"It was the first time in a long, long time that a stranger recognized me as my father's son." It's a powerful line in the opening chapter of Arlo Crawford's memoir. The possessive form suggests a story about the bonds between a father and son not only to each other, but also to the land they work together one season at the family's organic farm in Pennsylvania.As the chapters unfold, though, Crawford writes less like a young man on a journey of self-discovery and reflection, and more like a bored Gen X-er spending down time with the farm folk  la Nicole Richie and Paris Hilton in "The Simple Life."The real story is his parents, Jim and Moie Crawford, who, over 40 years and against enormous odds, built up a 95-acre sustainable organic farm. It's where the younger Crawford was born and raised until leaving for boarding school - and for good - at age 16.In Arlo's telling, it's a family business without family since neither he nor his younger sister has any interest in farming. That lack of connection is what makes his memoir feel shallow and contrived. The pages most come alive when he's not in them - writing about how his parents realized their dream through grit, vision, and courage during the counterculture movement of the early 1970s.Skip the book and look up New Morning Farm on the web. It's a great story. Maybe the father's son will tell it one day.

This is an excellent product for use by teen girls or boys who are dealing with acne brought on by puberty. They'll appreciate the spa-like treatment and the fresh-faced results. You'll appreciate the affordable price. Two boxes (8 packettes) will last one month for twice-weekly masks at less than the cost of a large acne-causing pizza.While the drying properties of the ingredients may not be ideal for older skin, the affordable price, ease of use, convenient packettes and glowing results makes this a perfect health and beauty product for your young teen. Plus, it's a fresh, fun way to introduce the habits of lifelong skin care to an impressionable group.I liked how simply this product delivered on its promise of keeping "skin clear and healthy with deep-cleansing" masks. Highly recommend it for your teens' healthy skin regime.

Footwork is an underappreciated but essential part of any sport training. Strength and conditioning must be supplemented with balance and agility for optimal athletic performance. The SKLZ Speed Hurdles and Ladder allows even the recreational athlete to work on their "foot strike and lift frequency to improve maneuverability" and conditioning.The plastic pieces are easy to assemble and come packed in a generously sized cinch-lock type bag. Although the manufacturer cautions that the "Elevation Ladder is not intended to be taken apart after each use" I found that mobility is a key feature of this ingenious design. In the winter, we set up (with the flat or elevated rungs) in a common-use hallway where every transit requires engagement. In the summer, it's easy to move the ladder from yard, to track, to garage or gym, and other workout areas as needed. The Ladder has retained its shape and material integrity despite all the breaking down and rebuilding.The six 4" rungs are another excellent design feature. When snapped into the upright position, only a misstep will trigger a rung's collapse. Footfall vibrations do not trigger a response - even on a flat, hard surface. No false alarms will interrupt your momentum. If the rung falls, you'll know that your fancy footwork still needs work.Materials, design, ease-of-use, and price make this is a 5-star, and highly recommended, product for your sporting family. Buy two, lay them end-to-end, for an even harder workout.

Based on the 157 posted reviews (to date), the Philips Norelco Hair Clipper appeals to parents who want to cut the hair of toddlers, kids of any age with sensory issues and developmental delays, and families who want to touch-up barber straight or fine hair at home.I can another group to the list of users: Parents who want to trim the edges of their child's tightly-curled corkscrew hair without reducing the volume or "fluff" factor. This clipper does an excellent job of shaving all around the hairline - especially around the ears where painful snagging is most likely to occur.Ordinary scissors cut and trim hair. Only clippers (or a razor) can achieve that edge that gives fades their distinctive and polished look.For a lightweight and quiet tool, this is a rugged and precise pair of clippers. I highly recommend it for the non traditional hair household that is looking for a sharp yet safe cut.

Hands-on or experiential learning is the optimal educational experience. In my kids' elementary school, their curriculum includes growing chicks and frogs from eggs, butterflies from caterpillars, and plants from seeds. What these projects emphasize, though, is observation over participation, or hands-off learning - an incomplete model for experiential learning.Ms. Frizzle rides to the rescue on her Magic School Bus and the Young Scientist Club kits. You can supplement the static school experience with these interactive, hands-on and integrated home-based experiments. I suggest starting your young scientist with something they already know: themselves.The Journey into the Human Body kit starts with a clever experiment demonstrating the lungs and breathing, a functioning - albeit miniature - circulatory system and beating heart, and the muscular and skeletal systems - including hinge and ball movement. The journey ends with a taste test that explains both the senses and the digestive system while an ingenious glitter and water experiment explains both hearing and balance.The kit includes balloons, a pipette, string, glitter, glue, ping pong ball and cap (illustrating the ball and joint), a bendable straw, a paper fastener, and leg model. You provide common household items like salt and saran wrap and supervision. The 7 experiments come in a 12-page 81/2 x 11-sized glossy booklet that provides space for writing observation and notes and includes lots of "liner" notes about the human body.I highly recommend this and the other kits. Order the Magic School Bus Inside the Human Body for the best overall learning journey.

Despite the popularity of Facebook, Instagram, and selfies, Klutz continues to carve out a corner of the tween girl market through these keepsake-style books - the original social media.The distinctive features of this Klutz activity book - basically a peer-to-peer networking project - are the enclosed pencil with eraser and a multicolored and generous pad of paper on which answers can be noted and dated. Pockets on the interior pages allow these notes to be stored for future reference, comparison or audiences. It's a clever idea that adds an interactive-style element to the book.Each page features sentence starter-style questions such as "5 People Who..." followed by a dozen teaser ideas like "Drive me up a wall," or "Can always cheer me up." Although author Karen Phillips does an excellent job writing and organizing this book, her editors could update this 2008 work to reflect the changing demographics and social awareness of the tween market.I found the section "Boys and Other Animals" with topics like "Rank Some Romeos," and "Who's a Good Boy?" awkward and disparaging. With Macklemore singing "Same Love," and girls growing up with stay-at-home dads, two moms, and accepting of or experiencing different life expressions, these kind of sex-and-gender stereotypes don't fit either the hipster vibe Klutz strives for or the current reality for many tweens.Overall this is a good product, but only earns 3 stars for being old fashioned. Instead, I recommend Klutz's more recent offering, It's All About Us, also by Phillips, which is a more relevant and contemporary Q&A of tween life.

My maternal grandfather made his way to America from Germany as an 18-year old coal trimmer aboard the Imperator, a Hamburg-Amerika line ship launched in May 1912, just one month after the Titanic sinking. Although my interest in the Titanic stems from my family history, the Titanic tragedy is a storytelling form as old as the Greek myths from which the ship was named. This "titanic" book brilliantly captures the arc of that terrible night through the true story of two families told in simple prose accompanied by beautiful illustrations and photographs.It opens with the boarding of the first-class Carters and the third-class Goldsmiths, cleverly introducing the different worlds from which they came and continued to occupy while on board the ship by the four-page foldout depicting a full ship cutaway. The middle section of the book is the moment of impact with the iceberg and the catastrophic consequences that follow as the great liner sinks below the surface in less than three hours with 1,500 souls still on board.The third and last part of the book features the rescue and the aftermath. Both children survive although their family and personal history are forever marked by that night. This is an excellent story and resource for the young Titanic scholar. The information and pictorial detail is accessible and gripping no matter where they are on their Titanic journey. I highly recommend this book either to begin or enhance your Titanic exploration.

From the packaging and product write up, Science Lab looks promising. The description says that your young scientist can, "use household items in these engaging experiments." If you have yeast, purple cabbage, Borax, also known as salt of boric acid (used in kitchens to control for cockroaches and ants), or a single disposable diaper laying about your home, this kit may interest you. If not, I suggest the Magic School Bus Young Scientist Club kits, in which the one-off items like agar and gel crystals are included.This product is way overpriced given how many uncommon or bulk-sized items you must purchase to make these experiments work. One of the easiest and cheapest science experiments I did with my kids was the diet soda and Mentos geyser kit we picked up in our grocery aisle for five bucks (including the 2-liter soda).But the biggest missing ingredient in this kit is the lack of girls represented in the materials describing the experiments. Every single one of the otherwise well written and interesting 24-page booklet features a boy. Seriously, did Larry Summers, the former Harvard president, who said that the dearth of women in science and engineering was due to aptitude and not discrimination and socialization, help design this kit?At the impressionable target age of 8 and older, science projects should be accessible, affordable and interesting. This SmartLab product misses on all three counts and deserves only 1 star. Stick with Ms. Frizzle and her diverse crew for gender-free science fun.

3179. That's how many steps I've walked so far today. Pathetic, I know, but when I'm not sitting on my bum writing Amazon reviews, I usually have clocked in at least twice that, topping out around 14,000 steps - or over 5 miles - per day.I know all this thanks to my little pedometer. It acts as a friendly reminder to get and stay moving. The "no judgments" metrics record how far it is to where I've been - or not been. I'm constantly checking it to see how I measure up.The unit is simple to program, has a colorful, big key design and an easy-to-read display (although I do wish it had Indiglo or some other lighting display function). My unit is clipped sideways to my belt loop which prevents the popping off that other reviewers have mentioned - the orientation doesn't affect the step count. I also purchased a safety leash (free shipping as of the date of this review) and use that to anchor the unit for extra security.This is a solid value for the price. Sure, there are probably units with more bells and whistles that calculate body fat and take your blood pressure, too. For my money, though, this unit works great at simply counting steps. It's also perfect for young kids who are part of school-based or community walking group; I bought one for each of my kids. They compete to see who has the most steps at the end of the day.Enough talking; I gotta get walking.

Quiet. That's the best description I can give of this powerful, sleek, versatile and attractive stick vacuum. I've owned many brands: Black & Decker, Hoover, Eureka, Dyson, Dirt Devil, and this Electrolux is the quietest vacuum I have ever used.I was also pleased with its cleaning power despite its 25.2 volt motor - standard upright vacuums run between 10 and 12 amps or 120 volts. Lower power, lower noise would be the obvious conclusion except for the fact that I also own a 15.6 volt stick vacuum and a little 10.8 volt Dust Buster and both whine at an earsplitting high "C".Based on the marketing photos and lifestyle descriptions in Amazon's Product Description, Electrolux is pitching this vacuum as an upscale accessory for the urban hipster demographic, but the elder sub/urban market should also be considered. I got this model for my aging parents for several reasons: the cordless feature eliminates a tripping hazard that is a major concern for the elderly; the lightweight (6 pd.) design makes it easy for arthritic hands to grip; the 180-degree swivel head allows them to maneuver around and under furniture; the unit easily attaches to the charging station; and the lithium battery holds the charge long enough for them to do regular spot cleaning of hardwood floors and rugs.Those are all standard features of other brands, too. What sets this vacuum apart from the pack is how quietly this powerful vacuum works. That feature is priceless and earns this Electrolux vacuum a 5-star rating.

In my car owning lifetime, I have changed oil and filters; replaced spark plugs, batteries and fan belts; rotated my own tires and flushed radiators. Pretty simple stuff, but I felt intimidated with the installation of this tailgate light bar. If not done right, it can be an expensive mistake.So I cheated and took it up to my local garage and asked them to do it for me. Mine is a product, not an installation, review. However, it took my shop just under 30 minutes to install this light bar; they did fast work at a reasonable price. It seems Putco has designed an easy-to-use kit for the gear heads out there who have the equipment and expertise to do the job themselves. For myself, I am not worthy . . .The tailgate light bar has been installed on my vehicle for over a month.  It is a solid piece of equipment that looks like a custom made accessory. I like the slim, sleek profile that displays a penetrating, but glare-free LED light. The installation kit includes double-sided tape to anchor the bar for placement only - a nice touch.Since the majority of road accidents I see are fender benders, I think a tailgate light bar adds a vibrant layer of visibility in challenging driving conditions. When you buy a light bar, you are buying both style and safety. I highly recommend this Putco product and give it 5 stars.

Compilations are tricky business in that they can be accused of covering either too much or too little information. This book manages to do both. That inconsistency combined with boring graphic design knocks this work down to 2 stars.For instance, the period from prehistoric medicine to the dawn of modern medicine in 1920, covers 200 pages, but the era of modern medicine to the present including "genes and dreams" comes to only 142. Although the former category covers centuries of discoveries and advancements, while the latter barely covers one, it's seems as if author Steve Parker relishes writing on the ancient history at the expense of the present and quickly-evolving science.Yet, the modern-age AIDS makes the list, but the age-old bird flu does not. Medicine to combat biohazards such as radiation poisoning from the nuclear disasters of Hiroshima or Chernobyl or terrorist attacks by anthrax aren't even mentioned.Overall, the work felt both rushed and predictable thanks to the repetitive graphic layout and design. Most left-side pages featured an image in the lower left corner while right-side pages featured an upper right image (lots of head shots). Every 5th page featured a full-page color spread.I also agree with other reviewers that the 6 x 9 size was disappointing. I love medical books and wanted to love this one, too. Unfortunately the only cure for my affliction for this book is to kill it. Not sure who the audience is for this book and I don't recommend it.

Before Larry the Cucumber and Bob the Tomato from the "Veggie Tales" videos, there was Davey, and his dog, Goliath. The stop-motion animation series was produced by the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America in the 1950s and 1960s to provide a Christian-based show for young viewers.The 15-minute episodes center on Davey, a likable, polite, and hard-working kid who wonders how to apply his Christian faith and values to his everyday experiences. What made this show so approachable was its lack of good and evil dichotomies. Rather than sin and sinner storylines, these shows simply convey Davey's yearning to understand his place in God's creation. While some of the shows deal with large social issues such as bullying, racism, and death, the majority of the plotlines explore Davey's daily journey of a faith-based life with Goliath by his side, both as companion and conscience.Uncomplicated storylines, simple set designs of familiar characters and places, a thoughtful and kind central figure whose seriousness is balanced by his goofy yet loyal dog, anchor each show. The show's messages of love and forgiveness can trace its roots all the way back to Jesus and the New Testament teachings. I remember the powerful impression these shows had on me as a child. Despite the low-tech quality when compared to today's animation, my kids are equally riveted by this series.This review applies to all the other shows within this beautifully produced series. Highly recommend for your family.

When products are marked as "indoor/outdoor" it's generally a tip-off that their main use is recreational. This is not a backcountry camping lantern; this is a supplemental light for summer nights outdoors on the patio of your house or as an emergency light for power outages. I bought a lantern for each of my kids as a slumber party toy/tool.As a lighting accessory, the price of less than twenty dollars is appropriate, especially given that 4 D-cell batteries can cost half as much as the unit itself. Overall, I like the Emerson brand and have bought several of their products. For this price, you get a pretty solid value.This lantern is lightweight, and the 20 LED-generated light is a bright white that clearly illuminates a 10 x 20-sized room with remarkably little shadowing. Like newer LED flashlights, the lantern features a removable battery compartment accessed via the screw-off bottom; there's no fumbling around to figure out battery orientation.Although not as effective at illuminating broad outdoor spaces without ancillary light sources - the light gets swallowed up by the 360-degree darkness - this is an excellent all-purpose utility lantern for enclosed areas needing general throw light.Emerson delivers exactly what they promise in this product: a long-lasting, versatile and portable light source. For delivering on that promise with good design and style, this product deserves 5 stars.

My First Sock Puppets kit offers an easy introduction to crafting for your young artist without the messiness of glue or the stress of and coordination required for a needle and thread project. Instead, peel-and-press decals are used to create hand puppets from the three socks in blue, orange and lime green colors. The socks are large enough that on a young child they easily extend all the way to their elbow.Although my son is a skilled needle-and-thread crafter, I bought him this kit as a fun break from the intensity of his stitching work. He loved it. The socks are thick and fuzzy yet allow easy positioning and adhering of the decals.There must be 100 different decals of a dozen shapes including pom poms, wiggly eyes and other face and feature designs that offer limitless imaginative combinations. The finished product results in either silly hand puppet characters or a decorative accessory (my son placed his puppets on his bedposts).For a rainy or snow day craft, for play date fun or just family fun, this is a great project to have in your art bin. The generous assortment of decals means that your crafter can use cast-off socks to design more puppets or create art projects in combination with other materials.A great craft for any age - both the young and the young at heart.

After less than 3 years of use, our first two sound machines  from HoMedics conked out - one right after the other. In response to our emailed complaint, HoMedics offered to replace the machines for free. We ordered these new units rather than wait the 6-8 weeks for the replacement sets. Consumers should know that HoMedics stands by their products.In contrast, the Original Sleep Sound Generator (Single Frequency Model), that I bought from Hammacher Schlemmer almost 15 years ago is still going strong and comes with a lifetime guarantee. It was then, and still is now, 3 times the cost of the lowest-end HoMedics model, so the lesson here may be that you get what you pay for. Like any product, the higher price point may yield better quality and reliability in the HoMedics brand.If you are looking for quick value, this redesigned and lower-priced unit may be worth your expense. New sounds of thunder, white noise and babbling brook (known as waterfall on the old unit), have replaced the annoying heartbeat (a great Halloween sound effect), and rainforest settings while the ocean, summer night and rain sounds remain. The sound seems clearer, too - the old graininess and sound skipping is gone.I gave this product 5 stars because of the sound improvements and because the lower price seems to reflect HoMedics awareness of the model's longterm reliability issues. Bottom line: You won't lose any sleep in purchasing this product

Regardless of brand, most kitchen appliances are made with standard product features. You're not going to pay extra for the bread to bagel setting on your toaster or a locking lid for your slow cooker, for instance.Coffee makers are no different. The functionality in the middle price range is going to be the same no matter what you buy. Almost every coffee maker on the market is going to have programmable settings, clock display, auto shut off, brew strength cycles, and a reusable filter basket among other standard features.So, across the brands, functionality isn't going to be that different, but form will be. And form is what you are buying into when you buy the Bella brand. Whether you buy their coffee maker, waffle maker or blender, you get their signature look-and-feel dots with a variety of rich color selections. That's branding within the brand; form within the function.Make a great pot of coffee and a colorful kitchen statement with this coffee maker. The Bella line is perfect for newlywed registries, new home purchases or just to add some pizzazz in your kitchen.

Studying comics and graphic novels, writes author Karin Kukkonen, is no laughing matter. She analyzes a wide range of material covering political, social, personal and mythical genres: Art Spiegelman's Holocaust memoir "Maus"; Alison Bechdel's lesbian-feminist reflections in "Fun Home"; the King Arthur tales in "Prince Valiant"; as well as the more commonly-known comics of Batman, Superman and Donald Duck.I enjoyed reading this book even though I agree with other reviewers that the paperback and Kindle prices are outrageously high and will limit the market appeal to the textbook audience. In fact, Dr. Kukkonen's Introduction states, "(this book) is designed to provide you with all the knowledge you need for studying and analyzing comics on a university course."The ridiculous pricing is a reflection of that narrow demographic (remember buying college textbooks that cost almost as much as the course itself? Or a professor's self-published work that was required reading for their class?).Wiley-Blackwell is a scientific, technical, medical and scholarly publishing business. Given that their target market for this work is also a captive one, they can price a boutique book at a designer price. Works like this - a thesis turned into a course syllabus by way of a 177-page book - should really be downloadable open source material.Although well written and provocatively argued, for a more affordable analysis of comics, check out Scott McCloud's work including, "Understanding Comics: The Invisible Art," instead.

Lightweight, compact, and a quick heat time are some of the outstanding features to this reasonably-priced flat iron. The ergonomic balance between the top and bottom blades - making the angled presses to the sides and back hair more comfortable - are other great design elements.A lot of careful thought went into this appliance: you can lock in your preferred heat setting from the baseline of 300 to 450 degrees; the blades can be locked in the closed position for travel or storage; a swivel cord attachment at the unit base prevents snags or awkward hands holds - an important safety feature when handling hot surfaces; and a 6-foot long extension cord.I also liked the LCD Indiglo display on the top blade of this iron. This iron worked as fast on smooth, thin hair as on curly, thick hair. If you are in the market for a flat iron, I highly recommend this product.

Poor Hasbro. Trying to hit the 8 year old to teen girl toy market is tough work. Unfortunately, this Nerf Rebelle totally misses the mark. If this product had come with a felt board against which the Velcro-tipped darts could be launched from the Heartbreaker Bow, perhaps it would be more engaging. But, who or what is the target - or point - to this toy?Seriously, are tween/teen girls going to run around shooting darts at each other? Or at boys (hence the "Heartbreaker" tagline)? Maybe girls ages 3 - 7 would find that kind of play activity fun - basically the preschool through 1st grade age range. As a toy for that demographic, I say go for it.But the tween/teen girl takes their play far more seriously than Hasbro does. This toy needs to go back to the "drawing" board.

People who share a common vision or destiny are strengthened by forming communities in which their work and beliefs are supported and sustained. Many of these movements are religiously based such as the Amish, Mennonites, or Hare Krishnas. Secular movements that adopt a community-based lifestyle are harder to maintain on a broad scale because competing interests - like sex, money, and power - make coalescing around a common core more complicated.The Chelsea Hotel was a unique and beautiful exception to this rule. Despite vast differences in race and gender, age and income, education and experience, money and power, the Chelsea Hotel community was bound by one thing: talent.  Even the talent was expressed in widely divergent ways. Yet, for almost 100 years, this diverse energy found a place to call home at the Dream Palace.Sherill Tippins's opus pays homage to the idea that ideas can form powerful and perpetuating communities of believers. Emerson or Thoreau would have called the Chelsea Hotel home. Remarkably, Tippins also shows how outside influences and competing interests strengthened the intimate bonds between the Chelsea believers while propelling their creative work beyond its walls.The Chelsea Hotel was both a cultural and artistic incubator. Writers, musicians, graphic artists, filmmakers, actors and avant garde adventurists mixed in amongst regular people in the heart of New York City. Religious-type fervor within a secular, and sometimes sinful environment, somehow produced enduring art. The Chelsea Hotel was both wicked and wonderful - and so is this book. Highly recommend it.

Every family should own a globe. The Pioneer Globe is an outstanding product made by Replogle, a company that has been mapping the world for almost 100 years. Also invest in a magnifying glass to zoom in on the amazing detail included on this globe's 12-inch surface such as cities, islands, oceanic currents, mountainous and arctic regions that feature bas relief surfaces.The color and definition is sharp and the matte finish makes it easy to see under bright light without glare or reflection. There are little details that show the attention lavished on this project: the "Direction of the Earth's Rotation" with an arrow pointing to the right along the Equator; the Tropic of Cancer with parens that note that `most northerly vertical sun rays, June 21'; depth markings for waterways (the shallow depth of the Gulf of Mexico helps explain why hurricanes in that basin move so much water ashore); and even shelf ice markings off Antarctica.There are three other excellent designs: the time dial located at the North Pole from which you can determine the time anywhere in the world; the full rotation of the north and south axis allowing you to view the South Pole without lifting up the entire globe and stand; and the informational booklet.Finally, I appreciate the offer of 50% off the retail value of a new globe when the world changes. The Replogle Globe company has mastered the world. With their globe, so will you.

Growing up, my siblings and I filched palm-sized rocks from wherever we could find them, brought them home to wash and dry before we created Van Gogh-like designs on them with leftover model airplane paint. Those painted rocks became handmade gifts to friends and family. That was arts and crafts in the days before kits like this one marketed creativity.4M has produced an attractive and ingeniously-packaged kit of quality components. There are 10 2"-square tiles - enough to be enjoyed by two artists. What there isn't near enough of is the paint. If you purchase this as a gift, be sure to include an extra strip or two of model paint. It took me two coats of a color to create a solid base on which to paint my design and half the 1 ounce paint container was already gone.You'll also need to buy extra brushes since the one included will require lots of washings and dryings between colors interrupting the artistic flow. Unlike other reviewers, we had breakage when magnets fell off the fridge - where the box specifically suggests the magnets be placed. You can solve the problem by using the scrap magnetic strips to reinforce the sides of the tile rather than using the pre-cut 1"-square piece which isn't weighted or thick enough to prevent slippage during door movement.There are too many issues to make this more than a 3-star product. For the price, it is a visually appealing - if not particularly sturdy or fun - gift.

Dover has been creating quality and affordable books since 1941. I grew up enjoying their coloring, stencil, sticker and puzzle books. This is a brand that has staying power with that artistic tradition now being passed down to my kids. Holiday favorites such as the Christmas Stained Glass Coloring Book (1973) while the Goddesses Coloring Book (2012) offers a new look on an old art form.We bought this Old-Fashioned Farm Life after a visit to Greenfield Village, MI, part of the Henry Ford Museum complex in Dearborn, MI. If you are planning a trip to this Midwest museum, my recommendation is to buy and review these pages before your trip and then have your kids color/review it after.The 44 pages accurately illustrate both the historical structures as well as the costumed role-players who populate the working Firestone Farm accompanied by a brief description of the daily and seasonal activities of a large farming operation. For East Coast readers, Greenfield Village is the 19th-century version of the 17th-century Plimoth Plantation located in Plymouth, MA. It's a terrific resource to prepare for your travel through time.The 1990-issued book needs updating; the real-life version includes the lives and games of farm children - activities missing from this work that would help personalize it to the target audience of 10 and older. I agree with another reviewer that the detailed line-drawings discourages coloring. For the price, though, it's an excellent educational - not artistic - investment.

On downtown Boston's Rose Kennedy Greenway, are two solar-powered charging stations, designed like seats by MIT, to allow users - weather permitting - to charge their smart phones. A mobile world depends on its connectivity through a charged device.Charging devices have been available since before 1990 when mobile phones went mass market. Eventually, better batteries were developed allowing for longer device operating times. As a result, though, new applications emerged that drained copious amounts of juice requiring new charging innovations. A vicious circle ensued.So, although charging devices are not new, the peripheral needs are constantly being taxed and reimagined. What the Tylt model brings to the marketplace is an ergonomic design with enormous power. This little unit is like jumper cables for your devices. On 12-hour family road trips, we plug in to the backseat port allowing the kids to recharge their various devices simultaneously.Its tight fit into the port ensures a locked-in power connection. The compact profile of this unit is also an advantage - with no cords or other dangling features, it can easily be stored when not in use.As a side note, the old-economy car manufacturers could learn a thing or two from high-tech companies like Tylt: For electric cars to succeed in the gas or hybrid-powered marketplace, they are going to have to solve the charging station issues. Perhaps Tylt - or MIT - can show them the way . . . .

The challenge to being F. Scott Fitzgerald's biographer is originality of material. What hasn't already been written about a man who died over 70 years ago? On Amazon, there are over 300 biographies listed.Author Sarah Churchwell's book parallels the genius behind the "The Great Gatsby" to that of a true crime: a brutal double murder that took place in New Jersey at the same time Fitzgerald decamped to Great Neck, New York, to begin work on his third novel.It's an interesting angle, but ultimately a thin one that can't sustain the 350-pages that comprise this book. While I agree with her premise that the Mills-Hall murders influenced Fitzergald's Gatsby story and characters, the relentless side-by-side construction is too much and bogs down Churchwell's otherwise excellent narrative.Fitzgerald is famous for mining many real sources and personalities for his works including his wife and an early girlfriend whom scholars believe inspired his Daisy Buchanan character in Gatsby. Weaving in the murder as yet one more inspiration would have been enough, but to hinge her entire work on that singular murderous event and subsequent investigation, news coverage and trial is tiresome.Churchwell's exhaustive research uncovers previously unknown direct links between other events in Fitzgerald's life and Gatsby's development - she's done her homework - but the 1922 murder story ends up smothering her main literary investigation and earns this work 3 stars.

Just in time for the holiday shopping season comes the Kaotiks Psycho-Plex playset. Impressively packaged and easy to assemble - less than an hour by my 9 year old - this playset will meet your young race car track enthusiasts need for speed.The vehicle is insanely fast and once you get the hang of the infrared-controlled handset and the feel for the track, you'll be hugging the curves and doing backflips and spins off the stunt ramps like a champ. At high speeds, the vehicle even has the whine of a real race car.The handset features a simple backward and forward finger-trigger control. Since the maneuverability of the race car depends on the speed at which you take the curves, the need for directional controls is eliminated thereby enhancing the streamlined feel and quick response of the vehicle.The race car itself is a clever design in which the vehicle can move in either a rightside or an upside down orientation which keeps the action moving. The car battery is recharged via the handset. The charging problems mentioned in other reviews can be avoided by following the manufacturer's recommendation to use Ion Lithium Batteries.The genius of this playset is that you can get pretty good pretty fast. Expertise feels possible since the super-charged excitement, reflexes and pace keep you engaged despite the challenges. It plays like a video game.Kaotiks has built fun - not frustration - into this playset. This is highly addictive and I highly recommend it.

Play is the work of children, and it's a childhood tradition to play house. Perhaps nothing captures the imagination like a dollhouse. Melissa & Doug are known for their wide range of toys, games, arts and crafts, puzzles and learning sets. Our family has purchased dozens of their products over the years. The Victorian Dollhouse was our biggest purchase, but we made it in confidence based on our experience with the quality of the brand.You won't be disappointed with this purchase the memory of which will stay with the gift recipient long after their dollhouse-playing days are over. Our kids enjoyed unwrapping their enormous box and helped us to assemble the pieces into the finished product. This is a solidly built, heavy and richly-detailed dollhouse. It looks handmade.The furniture and accessories are sold separately the expense of which makes it an ideal holiday or birthday gift. Don't buy the house if you aren't going to get some of the interior pieces at the same time. Of the 6 room sets, we started with the kitchen, bath, nursery and dining rooms since those had the most knick-knacks and doo-dads (also sold separately) that kids love. The doll family was added value, but not essential to their play since my kids enjoyed playing interior designers more than re-enacting family life.Given the cost of the house and the numerous set pieces, I highly recommend this dollhouse for the imaginative and mature child(ren) in your house. They will love it.

I'd been looking for a replacement for my jogging fanny back (and hate carrying stuff as heavy as a smart phone in my pocket while jogging) and these seemed like a good replacement.  They fit well and stay in place, both of where were musts.  The two zippered areas in each belt are NOT equal in size or capacity but between the two, you could easily fit your phone and house key and maybe another few small items.  Fitting a phone and full size wallet might be a little tricky since only one of the two pockets is really big enough, but you could probably make do.  Regardless, the belt is comfy and held my cell phone in place to the point where I didn't feel it moving at all when I was jogging, which is all that I really needed.

The InCryptid novels were a lot of fun when they first started, but now they've started to bog down.  It doesn't help that Alexander Price is pretty boring as a protagonist, but the book was made worse by the incredible one-dimensionality of the supporting cast.  All of Shelby's family hates Alexander and the other Australians don't trust him.  That pretty much sums up the character development in the book.  The humor of the earlier InCryptid novels just felt flat in this offering, and Alexander himself lacked any real energy.  One of the problems that I've noticed with series that try to be humor-oriented is that they wind up fall flat on humor after a bit, and generally don't worry so much about character development in the meantime.  This is a shame, because the author has a really interesting and unique world that she's built up, but her characters seem to be meandering through it rather than bringing it to life in the last couple of books.  I will say that the author's take on werewolves and lycanthropy actually was pretty fresh, but it just wasn't enough to make this book truly interesting.I think the series could easily be salvaged, but only if the author moves away from Alexander as the main character.  The younger sister sounds dangerously interesting.

This is a book that I wanted to like more than I did.  Several of the characters were developed well and the idea of how a vampire might be challenged during a zombie apocalypse was an interested cross-over concept.  Unfortunately, I didn't feel that the big conflict was really all that big and was over with way too little fanfare.  Also, the "male" leg of the male/female/female triangle felt like an arbitrary addition, as if the author decided to perpetuate the now-tired love triangle trope and just needed a guy for it.  Any guy would do.  To be fair, I felt that he female/female leg of the triangle was a little rushed, but at least there was an attempt to build some chemistry.Still, I think that the author set things up so that future adventures (if there were going to be any) have a lot of raw material to work with.

This is actually a pretty solid case that's rugged and easy to grip.  My only word of warning is that it can be a little tricky to get the phone in there the first time, and make sure that the flaps that cover the audio and power ports are pushed through BEFORE you fit the phone and inner layer completely into the outer layer, because it could be difficult (if not impossible) to do it afterward.

Looking at some of the other reviews, I couldn't help but wonder if they were reading the same book.  While the main character of Jessa had occasional bouts of entertainment value, her obsession with food quickly made her into a one-schtick pony personality-wise.  Even worse was that Jessa was still a deeper character than pretty much everyone else in the book.  The Compass brothers were, from a character-depth perspective, completely interchangeable.  The were all strong, intimidating, "hunky," and obsessed with Jessa.  You could take any of their dialogue and if you hid the name of the brother, there would be no way of telling which of the four Compasses it was.  They were just that generic.  That was the extent of their "personalities."  The villains were generic in their villainy, and Jessa's family were bland in the extreme.  While I had hopes for Jessa as a character at times, they were quickly dashed.  In between bouts of crying and inconsistent behavior, Jessa wasn't much of a heroine.  She either needed rescuing by one of the strong, hunky men or when she did get herself out of situation, it was more by accident than design.  "Wait, I have this new power / ability that randomly decided to manifest itself now and save me without any conscious effort on my part.  Oh joy, oh rapture."As far as the notion of this being a fresh take on the genre, I can only imaging that the reader would have had to never have read other urban fantasy books.  There was nothing about the way that the different races worked that was unique at all, and the author seems to get the notion of "powers" and "species" badly confused.  The whole supernatural prison thing could have been interesting, but it didn't even really make sense that all those prisons would exist for such a comparably small population.  By the end of the novel, there really hadn't been a big (or even medium) confrontation, no real resolution to anything, and all we were left with was a rather weak cliff-hanger.

This was a tough book for me to review.  On one hand, I loved the world-building that the author performed, building an old-west, steampunk Rapid City from the ground up with a beautiful attention to detail.  That attention to detail unfortunately wound up causing problems, as the book took a really long time to get started (from an action standpoint) and never really built toward that crescendo that I was hoping for.  I liked the primary character pretty well, though there were times where she seemed to be more brave than truly heroic.  And while Memery (her spelling, not mine) had really developed a voice and personality all her own by the end of the book, none of the other characters came anywhere close, making them all pretty two-dimensional.And while I really, really wanted to support the Memery/Priya relationship (it's not easy to find a same-sex relationship as a primary relationship in a book which isn't specifically about same sex relationships), I felt the author forced it here.  Priya was never really developed as a character, and I never understood why Memery was drawn to her except . . . well, she was available?As I mentioned, I really wanted to like this a lot more and the book was very close to being truly special, but the author got so bogged down on developing her setting that the other aspects of a story that draws readers in suffered for it.

I really wanted to like this story more than I actually did.  The overall pacing was really good and we met a really interesting cast of characters.  Amber continues to impress with her depth as a protagonist.  Unfortunately, the normal cast of secondary characters was kind of wasted in this effort.  And after a really good build up to what promised to be an exciting confrontation, the author ran into the same problem that he did in the second book . . . politics broke out.  Much like in "Hidden Trump," the author squashed any real sense of urgency toward the end by having a protracted political debate break out that drug on for far too long.  It was like watching Die Hard for 90 minutes, and then switching over to C-SPAN.  At least in "Cool Hand," our protagonist actually did have a hand in the finale whereas in "Hidden Trump," she was almost entirely a spectator at the end.I still really like the series overall.  I want to see Amber's personal relationships develop (particularly with Jen, who is considerably more interesting than Amber's werewolf paramour), and it'll be interesting to see how (it at all) Amber's familial relationships are repaired.  I would like for the story to at some point move beyond the endless politicking, because the politics slows everything down at inopportune moments.

This book started off as potentially interesting, with a fiery protagonist in Lyza.  She had a cause and an attitude.  Unfortunately, the author goes completely off of the rails shortly after the free sample was over.  The plot meanders all over the place like a drunk monkey on a pogo stick.  The reader is bounced from one character's perspective to another, and a number of these characters are pointless.  Initially, it seemed like the primaries were going to be Lyza and Adriana, and it think it would have benefited the writer to stick with those two.The author introduces characters and "plot" ideas and then discards them almost at random.  It felt like the story was written at a number of distinctly different times and the author never bothered to go back and look at what he'd been doing before.  Character development was inconsistent at best.  And then the author just sort of steers everything toward a second book toward the end, but there's really no chance that I'd be willing to invest time or money in it.  The only thing that brought this up to two stars was the lingering sense of promise I had at the end of the first couple of chapters, but it was a promise that was never realized.

It's strange to give such a low rating to a story with so many promising elements.  The world building was rich and detailed, and the primary Jeckyl/Hyde character of Eliza/Lizzie was absolutely fascinating.  Eliza was the scientific, steady one while Lizzie was the passionate, devil-may-care type, and either of them could have been a wonderful protagonist in her own right, and watching them attempt to come to some sort of understanding was a treat to read.My frustration with this book was that Eliza/Lizzie was an amazing character who was utterly wasted.  The woman/women were supposed to be inordinately clever, and yet were outsmarted and outmatched at every turn.  Every major clue is basically handed to her by one of the male characters, all of whom seemed to be deceiving her and she was constantly in a state of surprise by this.  She never really figured anything out until it was too late or until it was handed to her on a silver platter.  I never really felt that she "bested" anyone.  I don't want to have a protagonist made up to be a strong, female character, and then have her either need the aid of (or to be rescued by) her male counterparts, much less have her seem to be constantly duped.  And the author spends so much time desperately throwing red herrings and false accusations into the mix that I was able to guess who the culprit was simply because this individual was the only one who DIDN'T have suspicion thrown their way.This could have been one of the best books that I'd read in a while, but the author just didn't do the story any justice with her remarkable main character.

While I liked the idea of twins as the primary characters and the author's decision to avoid an arbitrary romance in this initial effort, nothing really came together.  The characters were pretty underdeveloped (despite periodic clever snark), the plot just blundered along without any real sense of urgency, and the author's attempt to throw in a "twist" at the end felt more like a random afterthought.  Overall, it was just flat and anticlimactic, and there wasn't enough here to make me willing to invest in a second book.

While there were some interesting basic concepts here (magic vs. science-based agents), everything felt way rushed.  The author never really explains why the two groups are at odds, and there really isn't anything beyond the most superficial attempt at character development.  Since all the characters were paper-thin, the underlying relationships were also shallow.  It was a short novella already, and it felt like the author rushed through everything and didn't quite do anything well.

I like the character of Kate Prospero and thought that this book was a reliable (if not overly inspired) addition to the series.  It really is a pretty cool concept for a world, with potions and alchemy taking the place of more traditional wizardry/magic or vampires and werewolves.  Kate is the quintessential tortured soul trying to walk the straight and narrow after a rocky upbringing, and she as a character is intriguing.Unfortunately, the primary plot was a little sluggish for me, and the main villain was a little too distant from the action until the end.  Also, I dislike how the author seems intent to make Volos a love interest despite a lack of chemistry (or any reason to be attracted) between he and Kate.  The rest of the supporting cast felt a bit wooden this time around, and Danny (Kate's brother) is so incredibly annoying that I actually wanted something bad to happen to him.  I also felt that Kate spent a little bit too much time apologizing when she hadn't done anything wrong.I think that I'm still interested in following the adventures of Kate Prospero, but more out of a sense of approval of the underlying world building than the events of this particular novel.

These book was so unexceptional that I had to give up on it halfway through, and that takes a lot with me.  The primary character of Raven is a boring rehash of pretty much every "rebel cop" from any 80's movie or television show that you can imagine.  The character has no depth, and responds in exactly the same way to every situation: she shoots it.  What's worse is that the character is supposed to be a policewoman and yet, despite humans not known about vampires or the like, she isn't held accountable at all by her human counterparts.  When being a half-vampire isn't the least believable thing in the book, then you know that you have a problem.It doesn't help that there isn't a single character in the book that has any personality.  Normally, a good supporting cast of characters can help make even a mediocre book tolerable, but this story couldn't even provide those.  Even the villains were boring.  The apparent love interest of Levac certainly doesn't help matters, and I couldn't figure out for the life of me why he's a possible love interest.  Over the course of 3 books, there was zero chemistry between he and Raven.  Of course, it's difficult to have chemistry when you lack any actual character depth.  Raven herself was incapable of actually figuring anything out (because she was too busy randomly shooting it).  The author kept using the "felt it was important but didn't know why," which is usually a sign that the protagonist isn't actually going to figure anything else until she is handed a big old "reveal" late in the book that she didn't do anything to earn.  It's hard to rate the underlying plot itself because it was navigating by paper-thin characters.

At first, I really thought this was going to be a good book.  The plot seemed promising, and there were aspects of the primary protagonist that made it seem that she could be interesting.  There was a subtle snarkiness to her that I initially enjoyed.  Also, it seemed that the author wasn't going to force an arbitrary romantic interest down the readers' throats . . . at first.  Then about halfway through the book, everything took a turn for the worse.  We were introduced to the concept of "shades" as a group, but the reason for their existence was poorly developed and executed.  We wound up with an incredibly arbitrary "relationship" for Ayala that was wholly unbelievably, even for an urban fantasy book.  There was never a particularly good or even coherent reason for why the antagonist (who turned out to be a witch) was doing what they were doing, except maybe that they had to act evil because every book needed an evil person.  By the end of the book, I was just happy for it to be over, and don't think I can muster any interest in subsequent books.

Yeah, I'm not quite sure what the point of this book was.  The premise made it seem like it could be fun, and the main character initially seemed like she might be someone I could grow to like, but it turned out she was just a horrible person.  None of the secondary characters were likable either.  In other words, no characters in this book had any redeeming features whatsoever.  The plot just kind of meandered from place to place with no end in sight with our unlikable protagonist doing what felt like the same thing over and over.  The erotic bits weren't even particularly erotic and the action, which started as funny, just became tedious.  This leads back to the original comment of, "Yeah, I'm not quite sure what the point of this book was."

I love the concept, but I bout an XL shirt (which is usually a little big on me but comfy), and it fit like a size Medium, and that's if I'm being generous.  I've never had a shirt be that off on the expected size before.  The label does say XL.  Someone else mentioned that it seemed more like youth sizing, and that might not be too far fetched.

There were hints of potential throughout the book, but none of them were ever realized.  It was weird reading the blurbs associated with this book that say things like "mixes laughter" and "oozes sexual chemistry," since this book had nothing resembling humor and zero chemistry of any kind.The beginning of the story seemed to bumble along and then the reader finds himself (or herself) on a rather lackluster plot where you never even encounter the villains until the very end and there's an encounter that really had no sense of gravity to it at all.  It didn't help that none of the characters in the book had anything resembling a personality.  They were, A) Generic attractive woman with strange powers, B) Generic and incredibly predictable love interest with a tortured soul, and C) Generic best friend.  Even the villains, once we finally meet them, are bland, and villains are where the author generally has the most creative license.  And while I've already mentioned the predictability of the love interest, I think it is worth mentioning that the author makes no effort to actually develop chemistry between the two primary characters.  It breaks down to both characters are attractive and in proximity, therefor they must long for one another.  The insidious plan of the generic villains (the plan itself had a lot of potential for drama that was never really realized) seemed secondary to the tedious meanderings of Thierry and her incubus paramour.

Having read Weldon before, I was initially excited to see something new outside of the Zoe Martinique series, which I thought had grown a bit stale.  Unfortunately, the first book of the Eldritch Files was chocked full of flaws.  First, there were spelling/grammatical mistakes (e.g. Getting "right" and "write" mixed up).  Secondly, the author kept referencing things that happened prior to this story that seemed more like bits from another story rather than just general background, as if there was a prequel or some other kind of short story that set up the Eldritch Files that we should know about.  If I read a book that is the first part of a series, it bugs me when I already feel like I'm missing something.  Thirdly, the main character is initially made out to be some kind of powerful witch, but she is pretty much outmaneuvered and outsmarted at every turn.  Fourthly, the author keeps throwing swerves at the reader to try and make the story seem more clever than it was, but after a while the swerving just felt random.  Finally, none of the characters really had any personality, and left me with very little interest in finding out what happens to them (or the story in general) next.

Well after a fairly limited amount of use, this case wound up failing in every way that mattered.  It was really difficult to get it to stay in place.  The "velcro" part was less velcro and more of a light adhesive that lost its tackiness really quickly.  This meant that if your arm had any muscle on it at all, bending your arm can cause the band to pop open and leave you scrambling to grab your smartphone before it hits the floor.  It was so snug on my Nokia Lumia that I couldn't access the side controls very easily.  I wound up just putting my phone back in my pocket for a while because I couldn't get an arm band to stay on my arm (which rather defeats the purpose).

What the heck happened?  The previous book ("Iced") was an interesting story with a novel character, and I was looking forward to the confrontation between Mac and Dani.  While "Iced" did most things right, "Burned" did everything wrong.  First, it seems that Mac had turned into a vapid, pointless, mouth-breathing excuse for a heroine that turns into a drooling idiot anytime that a dreamy, hunky man crosses her line of sight or even crosses her mind.  It's like the author completely forgot how to balance an active lead's romantic interests with being a useful and proactive heroine.  Mac degenerated in this book from what she had been in previous efforts.  She seemed to lose every argument that she had with anyone, particularly the dreamy, hunky men.Also, the author managed to totally ruin the character of Dani.  Dani used to be the most interesting character, partially because we got to see what a young, rambunctious, and fearless young woman could be as she developed her superhero chops.  The author decided that rather than continue what was previously a successful bit of character development, that she wanted to instead bypass that and artificially age Dani.  She turned a unique character who could grow into being an adult into a full-fledged commando sex-bomb with none of the characteristics that made Dani special.  My guess is that the author wants to have another once-promising character be available for sexy-times with all the misogynistic, dreamy, hunky men that she's populated her books with.The story itself was fairly lame, taking a long time to develop and not really having what I would normally consider to be a "big conflict."  While most of the story was from Mac's point of view, there were a number of shifts to the perspective of other characters, all of which felt random and none of which were necessary for the story.  I've also become somewhat tired of "the Nine."  They're all huge and muscular and dreamy and they win every philosophical point when they engage in debate with the women-folk.I'm not sure why the author decided to go from a good urban fantasy story with an integrated romance angle to a bad romance in an urban fantasy setting, but I'm disappointed by the entire effort.  When I finished "Iced," I was really looking for to "Burned," and burned is just what I got.  Just not in a good way.

This book fell short in pretty much every way, not just overall length.  While the primary character had a lot of potential, I never really felt that she actually developed a personality, and ALL of the secondary characters were flat as paper.  This is a big problem because when the main character lacks personality and the plot isn't that interesting (both of which are the case here), you need a really good supporting cast to keep reader interest.  The villain was a complete non-entity, just thrown into the book because books need villains.  Again, there was no real personality there, no real excitement or tension  to the big confrontation, and there was no mystery in figuring out who it was because the good guys for the most part stumble on the antagonist by accident.  There is of course a romantic interest who is introduced with all the subtlety of a jackhammer outside your window at two o'clock in the morning, and there is no attempt to develop any chemistry between he and Jade.  Instead, we're treated to the typical, "They don't like each other but he's hot so they must be attracted to each other" nonsense.  If this entire thing were condensed to ten pages and turned into an epilogue for a book about Jade an her evil ex (who seems to be a more interesting adversary than the one that we saw here), then I might not be so annoyed, but instead the reader is given a fairly lackluster heroine with boring sidekicks and generic romantic interest facing an utterly uninteresting villain.

So far, I really like this mount.  I've tried the chest mount for my GoPro when doing mud runs, but my hands or something else tends to get in the way.  You have to keep the mount fairly tight which could be uncomfortable if you go to far, but I've done two 5k's so far without any real problem.  Word of warning, make sure to tilt your GoPro down a little further than you initially think because otherwise, you just catch the tops of peoples' heads.
This is one of those gems of a country song that not enough people know about.  There is something both relaxing and uplifting about the tune, and Carpenter's voice is spot on as usual.

Well, I really hope that this was the end of the series but, if not, it's definitely the end for me.  This book was such a mess.  Much like the end of the Aneka Jansen series, the author decided to bounce from one character's perspective to the next with no thought for story flow, giving the whole novel a very disjointed feel.  Every character that Teasdale had lying around got some paragraphs or pages told from their view.  There were multiple plots that could have been major but all just sort of sputtered and died with a profound lack of build-up or drama to any of them.  The author had made his main character so powerful that there was no mystery at all, because you knew that not only would Ceri survive, but that she wouldn't ever really be challenged.  Sure you can see if any of the supporting cast gets offed, but its hard to build tension if your main character's unfettered success is a foregone conclusion.  Then there was a rather random attempt to change or examine the dynamic between Ceri's partners which felt utterly random and unnecessary.  The author finally stopped trying to include sex on every page, which would have been an interesting change of pace if he had replaced it with an actual cohesive story.  Instead, Teasdale was just trying to wrap up lots of random threads that didn't even need to be wrapped up and wound up delivering a grab bag of ideas that left me rather unsatisfied as a reader.

While her acting skills could still use some polish (mostly in delivering her dialogue), watching Gina Carano in an action film is refreshing.  It is one of those rare occasions where they put an attractive woman in an action role and it doesn't feel like they took some eye candy and showed her some martial arts moves.  Carano can sell the action like a boss and the fight scenes alone in this are worth the price of admission.  Throw in a fairly talented supporting cast, a beautiful backdrop for the story, and this wound up being a surprisingly entertaining action flick.  I hope more producers and directors take note of Carano's performance because, like in Haywire, she proved how a strong female protagonist can and should carry a movie like this.

I'm kind of glad that I didn't read this book before Kay's "Good Intentions" and "Natural Consequences" books, because I probably wouldn't have risked them.  "Poor Man's Fight" is a poorly organized mess of a book.  None of the characters are likable or interesting.  The author switches perspectives often, usually with every chapter but sometimes within chapters.  A little less than half of what I read (about 50 percent of the book) is following the rather dull Tanner through boot camp, which was really, really boring.  The rest of the book to that point had been following space pirates and these pirate are indeed bad guys.  I'm not sure if the author was trying to paint them as sympathetic rebels or something because if he was, he failed.  These pirates are "kill innocents for fun and profit" types with a paper-thin coating of "sticking it to the man."The plot itself was . . . not really there.  Halfway through the book, there was really no convergence (or even an attempt at convergence) for the two totally disparate halves of the book.  Even skimming, it was borderline painful to get through each page.  With the Tanner story line, it was because the character was boring.  With the pirate story line, it was because everyone was unlikable.  I'm not sure if the author was trying to make some kind of social commentary about corporate mentality or something, but the book utterly failed to deliver on that, or any, level.

Well, it fits my Sony mp3 player and allows for a generic arm band to be attached, but that's about it.  The material isn't nearly sturdy enough to offer any real protection against anything except for maybe minor scratches.  Still, if you just want some help in attaching an arm band so that you can work out with it (arm band not included), then it will do.

Honestly, a very comfortable pair of shorts that makes riding a bit more comfortable as well.  Also, for those of us who acknowledge than spandex isn't and probably never will be our friend, they're a lot more soothing to the ego (as well as the posterior).  And unlike traditional bike shorts, there is actual pocket space which I use for my keys and sometimes my wallet, so you don't always have to have a pack or something when you go out on your bicycle.

This is really a very good piece of music.  The lyrics and music fit together, sometimes whispering and sometimes on the verge of bellowing.  It fit the film very well, but is enjoyable all on its own.

Biggest issue with this is that it wound up being shorter than I'd imagined it would.  I don't exactly have large arms, but it was still difficult at time to get this secured around one comfortably.  If you're planning on wrapping this around your upper arm, you might want to find something with more stretch or a little longer unless your arms are relatively slim.

I have to say that the second book in this series (and the last one that I'll be getting) really didn't do anything to improve on the strengths of the first book while embracing all of its weaknesses.  The constant back-and-forth between telling the story in the present and then the chapter-length flashbacks to fill in backstory was incredibly annoying, as was shifting the perspective away from the primary character.  The love interest remained incredibly, insipidly boring.  Seriously, the boyfriend is as boring as watching paint dry.  The relationship with Elise's mentor doesn't really develop at all, and the world / mythology building leans toward being muddled or nonsensical.  With the loss at the end of the book, I find myself with zero interest in what happens next.  It's a shame, because I really thought this series had potential.

The music was just "all right" and the plot was kind of funny if not overly brilliant, but there was some genuinely fun character interaction that made this an almost guilty pleasure kind of viewing.  Admittedly, part of that is Gabrielle Christian and Mandy Musgrave are destined to be an adorable lesbian couple in anything that the appear in together.  I mean, you can tell that it's a low-budget and independent film but if that doesn't bother you, it's a fairly entertaining diversion.

This is a situation where the free preview really managed to hide the numerous flaws of the book itself.  The preview is normally there to tease the reader without giving too much away of the main plot. Unfortunately, there really was no main plot.  This whole book was a tediously long sort-of romance that spent a great deal of time going nowhere.  I quit reading about 70% of the way through when I realized that nothing of interest had really happened yet.  The main character (Zelda) is a whining, insipidly boring, and mostly oblivious protagonist who spends a lot of time question anything that resembled good luck, hemming and hawing about if she's attracted to someone, and then worrying about her financial situation.  She was incredibly uninteresting as a character, but even she was more well developed than the Jessica character.  Trista was a little more interesting, but not enough to save the book.  The characters, the plot (such as it was), and the romances were all hopelessly flat and uninspired, and there was nothing here that would make me want to follow the story forward.

Like some other readers, I gave this book a shot because the premise sounding interesting and definitely outside the mainstream urban fantasy cliches.  The supporting cast (e.g. Murphy, the leprechaun, etc.) had potential to make things interesting as well.  But being unique doesn't help much if the underlying story just isn't good.  Karma was definitely not good.  First, the main character was really annoying in a childish kind of way, which made it difficult to get behind her.  The storyline itself couldn't quite figure out if it was supposed to be a serious idea, a comedy, or some combination of them. It was probably going for the latter, and just didn't pull it off well at all. And of course there was the incredibly badly done romance angle.  The entirety of romance seemed to be, "I hate him (Fate) and have no reason at all to like him, therefore I'm attracted to him."  Bleh.  I'm not sure why some authors think this is a good way to build a primary relationship, and I guess that it is mostly just a lack of desire to do it the right way.  Anyway, I got a third of the way through this before deciding that I had absolutely no interest in what happened to the primary character and moved on to better stories.

Wow, was this ever bad.  I'm not sure what the creators of this movie were trying to accomplish but unless it was to make my ears cringe, then I don't think that they succeeded.  While there was some friendly chemistry between the primary characters, the rest of the movie was just atrocious.  The acting was bad, and the music was even worse.  I wasn't expecting a musical, but the performances were so bad that I'm not sure this wound up qualifying.  The romance angle wound up being very disappointing, the humor fell flat all the way across the board, and the story just dragged.  I really wish that I could say something positive here because I would like to support these independent projects that are inclusive of the LGBT community but from an entertainment standpoint, this movie just didn't have anything to offer.

I never thought that I would say this about a Mercedes Lackey book, but "Children of the Night" was plant, flat-out boring.  Over the first half of the book, our normally brave protagonist does . . . nothing.  Okay, she has conversations with friends, gets drunk, and complains about how hard her job is (the same job that she doesn't seem to be doing), but that's it.  Then the author has us following "Dave" around, who's about as insipid and uninteresting of a character as you could ever hope to avoid.
