The Epilator portion works very well, like most it takes some time getting used to however thanks to the dual speeds it isn't as painful as some brands.Having the wet/dry function is extremely handy as I can use this is the shower/or bath and on the go with the travel bag and never worry about whether or not i have smooth hair free skin.As a shaver it's blades are small and precise good for underarms and legs.Overall this is a great wet/dry shaver for women one of the better ones i have tried and i would highly recommend.

The Timberland PRO Men's Gridflex Canvas Work Pants are extremely comfortable and durable. They fit as expected and are boot cut which are perfect for work boots.  The pants are comfortable to wear and aren't too rough on the skin and they are machine washable which is great. This is a great alternative to my Dickies and i would highly recommend them.

If you're familiar with Slendertone you're aware they're well known for electric (battery powered) muscle stimulation/toner products. From their very popular weight belt to the ReVive S5 Professional Muscle Simulator & Conditioner I have always been very satisfied with their products.The Slendertone ReVive S5 Professional Muscle Simulator & Conditioner unlike the stomach toning belt. Is for focusing on individual muscles such as your shoulders, arms, lower back and thighs. It is great for before and after work outs to help loosen up and relax your muscles and decrease risk of injury or soreness. It is cleared by the FDA and compatible with 10 different body partsThe ReVive S5 Professional Muscle Simulator & Conditioner is extremely portable and fits in your gym bag or a large purse. All it takes is a 9volt battery which is includes and you're on your way.i would highly recommend this to any active athlete or anyone with aches and pains.

The Invicta Men's Specialty Analog Display Japanese Quartz Gold Watch is absolutely beautiful. The large wide face and attention to detail give this watch a bold statement look that make it easy to pair with any outfit.The Invicta is keeping up to date and including a "Date window" at 5:00 mark. The watch itself is simple but stylish with the dark black offsetting the gold tones. The watch is also water resistant  up to  330 feetThe watch is simple to set like most pull out the knob on the side and twist to the correct time/date (etc) pop back in and you're set.The only downside is the band is HUGE right out of the box.  I have a pretty standard size wrist and so does my boyfriend. I gave this to him and he could slide it partly up his arm without it being adjusted.This is a beautiful watch and would make a lovely gift for any gentleman.

The Tresemme Enhancing Cream  "Makes Waves" from the Un-Done line enhances your natural wavy-ness and curls. Like most styling products apply to clean damp hair and style as needed.With Makes Waves you don't need a curling iron or any other styling tool, after application just twist with your fingers or comb and allow to dry. Once it does it doesn't make your hair feel stiff, it feels soft and natural and adds a little shine. Absolutely great for date night!I would highly recommend this to people with wavy hair or tight curls.

The TRESemme,TRESemme Expert Selection Gelee is a strong holding Gel that's great for us curly girls. It is part of the TreSemme Un-Done line for ladies and gentlemen who want to wear their hair down naturally.The Expect Selection Gelee is designed to enhance your natural waves and curls and hold them in place all day long and that's exactly what it does and without that horrible crispy crunchy left over feeling you get from some gels.This is a great alternative to hairspray or mouse and i would highly recommend.

The Tresemme Balm, Get Sleek Blow Dry is a typical serum for your hair. It is relatively thin and smooth and applies easily leaving your hair feeling soft and silky even after just daily application.When used with blow drying or flat iron it even adds a bit of a sparkle which is great for a night out and loads of fun. Compared to other serums you don't get as much as i would like for the price and the softness doesn't last all day. However overall for a quick night out this one really makes your hair pop and is a great quick fix.

The Lucien Piccard Women's Mirage Analog Display Quartz Black Watch is absolutely beautiful. The large wide face and attention to detail give this watch a bold statement look that make it easy to pair with any outfit.The Lucien Piccard  is keeping up to date and including a "Date window" at 6:00 mark. The watch itself is highly stylized with a white mother of pearl dial, with white crystal accent and rose gold tone hands. The watch is also water resistant  up to  165 Feet.The watch is simple to set like most pull out the knob on the side and twist to the correct time pop back in and you're set.The only downside is the band is a little short, i have a pretty standard size wrist and i had to put it on the last two holes in the band.This is a beautiful watch and would make a lovely gift for any young lady.

The Benzac Acne Eliminating Cleanser works wonders for me. The texter is light and not oily or watery. You simply wash your face once a day and work up to twice a day watching carefully for signs of dryness or irritation.My results were great, within two days the larger pimple i had shrunk to small almost not noticeable size, and by the 3rd day were completely gone. Also after a week i haven't had any break outs at all. I even tried using on the occasional spot of body acne (shoulder's) and those vanished immediately.This is a great acne cleanser and i would highly recommend.

The Disney Descendants doll set with Evie and Carlos are two times the fun in a great package. The dolls comes with 2 outfits, 2 pairs of shoes, 1 pair of earrings, and 6 accessories so they each have a change of clothes so you child will have more variety.The Thing i am most impressed with in the richness in color and detail in Evie's hair. The dark blue/purple really pop's and both dolls are a great likeness to their Disney Show character's.The dolls are made from standard plastics and are fully articulated for lots of pose-able playable fun.  These would make a great gift for a fan of the show or a little girl who loves dolls.

Worry Eaters "Saggo" is a soft plush with a unique zipper mouth. It comes with a plastic ring hook so you can hang him in your room or just clip him to a backpack.His zipper mouth is about 3 1/2 inches deep with a little stretch room so you can store little nick knacks and notes. Because he is stuffed it is best to hand wash him or take special care when machine washing ( http://www.wikihow.com/Wash-a-Stuffed-Animal-in-a-Washing-Machine ).I do kinda wish his mouth was a little deeper inside but that is the only negative thing i can say.Worry Eaters come in a variety of shapes and sizes and have their own website www.myworryeaters.comOverall this is an adorable stuffed animal, and would make a great gift not only for a teen/young child but also for an adult.

As a mother of 3 and one on the way : ) ClearBlue has always been my go to brand when it comes to finding out whether or not I was expecting. Now there is a New Clearblue Plus Pregnancy Test. Like All the previous Clearblue tests this one gives you the clear "+" "-" answer instead of one line two lines like other brands.As a bonus new feature the Clearblue plus Pregnancy Test now can be used to test up to 4 days before your expected period - which is 5 days sooner than waiting until you have missed your period. So no more anxious nights wondering.I trust Clearblue and I would highly recommend this test to every woman out there in need of one, and if you don't like the + /- they also offer great digital tests that are just as reliable.

I have always been a fan of Alba Botanica. They make great Natural product that a high quality and their Coconut Spray Sunscreen is no exception.The Alba Botanica Hawaiian Coconut Spray Sunscreen goes on easily with the touch of a button and has a wide spray range which is perfect for arms, legs, back, stomach, shoulders etc. Like all of Alba sunscreen products they are Water resistant for 80 minutes. They spray is SPF 50 and includes NO: parabens, phthalates, or synthetic fragrances is aerosol-free and has NEVER been tested on Animals.This is my New favorite Sunscreen it worked great during our sunny Spring and is just in time for Summer! I would highly recommend!

Skip Hop has created a cute travel cover for your Ipad 2/3/4 (Air with insert). It's made of a basic dense foam coved plastic with a felt liner to help protect your child's tablet.The Velcro straps attach behind your cars headrest for easy access as a viewing screen or there is a velcro secured flip out stand in the back for when you're at home or on the go and want to set it up on a table. As pictured, you can download zoo characters from a link enclosed for lots of fun backgrounds.This is a great idea, and my daughter and son both love it, however when it comes to use in the car it could use some improvement, specfically focusing on the velcro attachment straps. Over time as some know velcro tends to wear down and doesn't fasten as well, this would've been perfect had it been fitted with plastic snap attachments.Overall it's a decent case, my kids love it and it would make a great gift and it is handy on the go.

Clairol Natural Instincts Crema Keratina Hair Color/Permanent Color is a great option for hair dye. It's gentle and easy to apply to your hair and includes Keratin to help your hair look healthy and protect from damage during coloring. The Dye itself contains coconut oil and aloe to keep your hair feeling soft.  It comes with a Vitamin C Enriched Conditioner . Just leave it in for 20 minutes and rinse and condition. My hair is a dark brown with an auburn mix and it's now a beautiful shiny blue black. I absolutely love it. It's easy to manage and doesn't feel dry or frizzy and over styled.I would highly recommend this brand of colour

This Heavy Duty Wall mounted Baby/child changing station by ECR4Kids is made for industrial use. It would be great for a small diner/restaurant, day care, mall or any other place that is in need of a public changing facilities.The table folds horizontally and is basic White Granite color to match with any and every bathroom. It comes with built in safety straps to secure your child and sanitary tissues dispensers to line the table at your convenience. It also has two custom notches that allow you to hang your diaper bag or purse for easy access.If you're in need of a changing table in your professional establishment then this is the one for you!

When you're looking for a great Case for your tech, look no further than Urban Armor Gear. Their Samsung Galaxy S6  Edge case is made from a heavy duty military tested plastic. It's impact resistant (not proof so don't go throwing your phone and expect it to protect it) The case itself is extremely light and hard not flexible plastic. The phone snaps in securely and fits perfectly isn't too big or too small.It doesn't come with any extras just the case however there are two different color options ICE and ASH.Overall this is a top notch Cell Phone Case from a great company who are well known for quality and live up to it I would highly recommend.

Geoffrey Beene Men's Silk Pajama Pants are made of 100% imported silk. They are soft and gorgeous these were a valentine's day gift for my husband and he was absolutely thrilled especially because they have pockets.They are hand wash only and lay flat to dry which is extremely convenient. They come in a variety of 4 different colors and all net profits from sales go to benefit the Geoffrey Beene, LLC fund (causes that count). The Geoffrey Beene foundation supports  revolutionary research for treatments and prevention across all cancers as well as awareness and research for Alzheimer's, heart disease, scholarships, programs for veterans, protection of women and children and protection of animals.These are wonderful silk pajama pants from a company with a good cause. Would make a great gift.

The Eddie Bauer Big Girls' Hooded Cable Knit Sweater is from the School Uniform line however it is practical enough and fashionable enough to use for everyday wear.My daughter is a size 10/M and this fits her perfectly with one exception the hoodie is a little large. However she often doesn't use it so it's not much of an issue. The material itself is soft and stretchy it fits easy over shirts. It's machine washable and easy to clean, i find to keep it from stretching i just lay it flat to dry.Overall this is an adorable Cable Knit from Eddie Bauer, my daughter loves it, I love it! Would make a great gift and addition to your child's wardrobe!

The Havahart Fence Rabbit and Deer Repelling Pellets covers a Covers 2,500 square feet area with just a 5lb supply. They are weather resistant and will not wash away in the rain.  In The pacific northwest where i live we mostly have problems with deer and this worked wonders keeping them away from my flower and vegetable garden.I simply sprinkled the pellets around my garden and yard and the intense smell scent for the deer (not for you) which is supposed to smell similar to that of a dead animal seems to scare them away.So far so good! The Pellets themselves can be used as is or in traps, also they are made of Organic materials and are safe for Organic gardens. I would highly recommend this product for keeping nature away from your garden.

Adams Plus Flea and Tick Control for Dogs is a monthly application to get rid of those pesky pests that bug our best friends.It's simple and effective against  fleas, ticks, flea eggs, and flea larvae and very easy to apply. However you must follow the instruction and take care not to squeeze too hard or you will make a mess and end up spraying everywhere other than your dog. It's only for use on dogs 12 weeks and older and 15-30 lbs.I would highly recommend giving this a try, your family will thank you and so will your dog.

I use a lot of Scotts products and this is one I used on a regular basis to keep my garden from going wild.  I live in rural Washington so during the winter and spring then my garden gets a little out of control so I find using this product certainly helps.  Just sprinkle on the main problem areas and within days you will see a difference.  Definitely recommended.

I fitted these to my motorbike and was skeptical whether they would make any difference but was very impressed with the overall improvement in performance.  This wasn't just the improvement in power but also in the ease it now starts.  I would say the investment in these is definitely worthwhile and a quick way to improve your vehicle.  Only thing to watch when fitting these is that you set them to the correct gap for your vehicle, other than that fitting these is a breeze.  Recommended!

The Hideaway with Stand by Gumdrop Cases is the Otterbox Equal for your Tablet. It is specifically for your Google Nexus9 Tablet, but they do make them for other Tablet models. It's Rugged design is tough and great for kids and adults.It comes in 6 different color options and has two different viewing options with the pullout stand. There is no need to purchase a screen protector as this comes with one already built in.Because the case is made of thick rubber it is shock proof, and scratch proof, however I have never met a case that is dirt proof especially with children, however the built in screen protector is easy to clean and so is the case itself.This is a wonderful case and offers supper protection It's definitely worth the price to protect your tech.

This player is under $100 so now you can have Blu-Ray at a price which you would have bought your standard DVD player for not that long ago.  Also the move forward with technology means this player is compact and light so can conveniently fits into almost any entertainment area.  Another plus is that it will stream movies so connect to a network and you can have Amazon prime streaming through it like I do.As far as Blu-Ray playback quality and features this is a very impressive player for the price plus you get the reliability of Panasonic who are in my opinion one of the top electronics companies.  This player matches perfectly with my Panasonic Plasma TV and movies are a joy to watch.  Highly recommended, a great product for the price.

This is an Adorable Apron from the company ICUP. It features the character Elsa's Body from Frozen a popular Disney Movie. The Apron itself is 100% Cotton however the print of Elsa is a screen print/plastic and if stretched too much of scrapped will begin to break apart.Although there isn't a size listed this is an Adult size Apron, I'm quite curvy and it easily fits me with room to spare. It also fits my 8 year old daughter although it is a bit long on her. Because it's 100% cotton it's machine washable, and easy to clean just simply wash on cold and dry on the lowest setting to avoid damaging the design or hang to dry.Overall this is a very cute apron, that is functional easy to clean and a great present for any Frozen fan.

Goodnite Bedtime Pants aren't you basic Pull-Ups pants. These are made specifically for nighttime and for older/bigger children who occasional have problems with bed wetting. The Large/Extra Large size is for boys 80-125lbs / ages 8-14 and is 40% more absorbent than pull-ups.The cooling alert effect tells boys when they're leaked a little and they have to go potty. From what I can tell it's not always a strong enough sensation to wake my son up from a dead sleep, but he has had some success with it and is getting up in the night to go potty on his own now.They come in a variety of designs from Iron Man to Skateboards etc. And since they are stretchy there is quite a bit of room to grow in to. They are thin enough to fit under most outfits with ease without any uncomfortable bulk.I would highly recommend these Goodnites for any parents with young ones still needing that extra help at night time.

I have always been a big fan of Thirsties. As a mother of 3 diapers can add up and there are quite a few options for cloth diapers these days. Originally I tried Thirsties with Pockets.  These worked excellent, but a friend recommended the All in One so I thought i'd give it a try.The Thirsties All in One snap diaper is for babies 8-40lbs ( so quite the growth range). It comes with multiple snaps for easy adjustment and easy removable. Inside you'll see a thick 100% polyester/micro fleece layer as well as the layer underneath for twice the leak protection.These have worked very well for me and my two younger boys. Best thing about Thirsties are they are machine washable, just pop them in and either hang dry or tumble try on low and you're ready to go!I would definitely recommend to any family looking for a change from the conventional diaper!

I have always loved Otterbox and the new Symmetry Series is no exception. Otterbox as a company are top notch and have always made great cases. The case itself is light, sturdy plastic. The phone snaps in securely and fits snugly there is a a special crisscross layer underneath of your phone within the case for extra shock protection. The case itself isn't too big or too small and allows for perfect camera room.Unlike the Defender Series it doesn't come with any extras. However the Symmetry series does have 7 different colors/patterns available from Glacier to Anthrium. Overall Otterbox has lived up to their name of producing a heavy duty defender of cell phones, and this case is no exception.  I would highly recommend.

****** WARNING WARNING ********** This Case is NOT  for HTC One M9!!!Amazon sent me an Otterbox Defender Series Case fo the Samsung Galaxy S6!Since currently I have both phones I am able to still review this case.I have always loved Otterbox. They are top notch and have always made great cases. The case itself light, sturdy plastic. The phone snaps in securely and fits snugly within multiple layers of protection. It isn't too big or too small.It does comes with a snap on case attachment so you can attach your phone to your belt or book bag etc.  Overall Otterbox has lived up to their name of producing a heavy duty defender of cell phones, and this case is no exception.  I would highly recommend.

These quaint little Montana Swarovski Crystal Crossover Hoop Earrings are Sterling Silver and Feature Sapphire Blue and White Crystals. They have a standard snap lock clasp which i'm quite fond of.In the right light the white crystals shine exceptionally bright, however the blue crystals for some reason seem a little cloudy. They also can become overwhelmed by the white crystals. However if you prefer a touch more blue Montana Swaroski has a few more similar styles of blue and white crisscross earrings that offer more blue crystals.Overall these are quite lovely, they would make a great graduation gift or birthday gift.

This Bathroom starter set by "oceanic" is a great economical all in one set for any bathroom.It comes with the following:1: Ocean Blue Mosaic Style 72 by 72-Inch Shower Curtain,2: White Plastic Shower Hooks,3: Soap Dish, - patterned4: Cup ( for toothbrushes etc) -patterned5: Lotion Dispenser patternedThe shower curtain itself is the best value out of the set as it is a good quality polyester curtain. It isn't mildew and however is easy to hand wash or machine wash. The accessories are all plastic and nothing special but easy to clean and won't break.Overall this is a great started set for a teens/college or apartment bathroom.

The Speck Candy Shell Grip Case for the For Samsung Galaxy S6  is made from a heavy duty military tested plastic. It's impact resistant (not proof so don't go throwing your phone and expect it to protect it) The case itself is extremely light and hard not flexible plastic with ridges not just for the added design but also for added grip and protection. The phone snaps in securely and fits perfectly isn't too big or too small keep in mind this is only for the Galaxy 6 not the Galaxy S6 Edge.Unlike some other cases it doesn't come with any extras so you will need to purchase a screen protector and stylus (if needed) separate.Overall this is a great Cell Phone Case from a young company with great ideas I would highly recommend.

Calvin Klein Eternity for men has been around for years. It's one of my husband's favorite cologne's and mine as well. The Eternity Brand itself is not just made for men, but for women as well, and also comes in a variety of scents. However my husband and i still favor the classic. It has a warm, musky smell somewhat woodsy and it will last you throughout your day or night with just one application.  It comes in a standard steel grey box and is a great gift for any occasion, or just for no reason at all.I've always been a huge fan of Calvin Klein Fragrances and this one is top notch would highly recommend to the fella's.

Pull-Ups Training Pants with Cool and Learn for Girls are a wonderful potty training option for girls! My Daughter loves the adorable little designs and is proud of his big girl panties. As she is 3 1/2 now we use these mostly for night time and they're easy for him to slip on and off by himself, and are great for bedtime training with the added cooling alert.The cooling alert effect tells girls when they're leaked a little and they have to go potty. From what I can tell it's not always a strong enough sensation to wake my daughter up from a dead sleep, but she has had some success with it and is getting up in the night to go potty on her own now.Size 4t -5T fits girls 38-50lbs so there is quite a bit of room to grow in to. They are thin enough to fit under most outfits with ease without any uncomfortable bulk and come with Cute Princess Sofia designs that little girls love.I would highly recommend these Pull-ups to any potty training parents.

When you're looking for a great Case for your tech, look no further than Urban Armor. Their Samsung Galaxy S6 case is made from a heavy duty military tested plastic. It's impact resistant (not proof so don't go throwing your phone and expect it to protect it) The case itself is extremely light and hard not flexible plastic. The phone snaps in securely and fits perfectly isn't too big or too small.It comes with a glare free screen protector for your phone which is easy to  peel off and apply. I didn't have any air bubbles when applying mine which is a common occurrence with screen protectors and the screen was clear and not hazy.Overall this is a top notch Cell Phone Case from a great company who are well known for quality and live up to it I would highly recommend.

The Philips AVENT My Penguin Sippy Cup is a 100% no drip no leak sippy cup! It comes in 4 different colors, and you can get them individually or in sets of two. The My Penguin Sippy Cup also comes in two different sizes 7oz and 9oz which is similar to your standard large bottle.They are easy for my 15 month old to grip and he enjoys tossing them about, good thing they are well made and extremely durable. These sippy cups are hard tipped so they are bite resistant, and are also dishwasher safe.My son loves them, i love them it's a great next step for your young toddler.

My garden is probably the worst for growing anything, it is a mixture of small rocks and bad soil and to make matters worse moss grows in the grass.  I kind of solved this problem but now I get gaping holes where the moss takes hold.  I have used this Scotts turf builder before so I know it is a great product especially this one which is specifically for the Pacific Northwest and also has nutrients and water around the seed.  Basically it is blue in color so you can easily tell where you have dropped the seed, this is useful if you have 'patches' like I do.  To help this product I also use Scotts Turf Builder Lawn Food with Moss Control Fertilizer.  I have always had impressive results when using this combination so it is highly recommended.

My garden is probably the worst for growing anything, it is a mixture of small rocks and bad soil and to make matters worse moss grows in the grass.  I kind of solved this problem over the years but the moss still takes hold during the winter.  I have used Scotts Turf Builder Lawn Food with Moss Control Fertilizer many times and  I have always had impressive results so I can recommend this product.  Just sprinkle it over the areas where you see moss and in a matter of days you will see the moss dying.  I can do both my front and back yards with this packet and you don't have to overdo the amount you put down for it to work.  Great product!

The Baby Alive Sips and Cuddles doll is a cute little doll. However it is smaller than it appears on the picture. Also it comes with everything pictured, a plastic sippy cup, stickers to decorate, a summer/spring dress and a diaper.My daughter was supper excited when she saw this and couldn't wait to try it. However because the doll is so small the diaper is way too big and is almost twice the size of the doll itself, also the legs aren't flexible so it's hard to put the diaper on. Keep in mind this is supposed to be like a real baby so the diaper is a one use thing.If you're really careful i find that using a hair dryer on low setting can dry it out for a second or third use, but you will have to purchase the Baby Alive Diapers Super Refill Pack.Overall it's a nice doll, but it's not a great investment.

Wilhelmine Germany is not my historical strong suit; but I studied the history of the Third Reich & World War Two under Professor Spencer at Northern Illinois University so I purchased "Police and the Social Order in German Cities." Dr. Spencer's book has the deep research one would expect from a professional historian while chronicling the impact of the police service in Kaiser Wilhelm's empire. At the same time, "Police and the Social Order" is very 'read-able' for those (like me) that aren't well versed in pre-Great War Germany.

Doctor Waselkov really knocks it out of the park with "A Conquering Spirit." There aren't a whole lot of books written on the Redstick War; those that exist often focus on the role of Andrew Jackson. Waselkov chronicles the dynamics of the Alabama frontier--how the white Americans, Creek Native Americans, escaped black slaves, and people of mixed-ethnicities blended into a community. The community fell apart when the Creek nation split, with some members backing a Prophet who advocated fighting the whites; and the second group of Creeks opposing the Prophet (essentially a Creek Civil War). As so often happens in Civil Wars, the violence committed by all parties was amped up--as can be seen in the Battle for Fort Mims & Horseshoe Bend. In the end, the Redstick War was the excuse needed for the US to gobble up Creek land. Even the Creek members who aided and fought alongside the white Americans suffered and lost their lands.All in all, "A Conquering Spirit" is a fantastic historic work; it reads like a novel, but with a sociologist's eye for the human condition. If you're interested in frontier America or Native American history, you will enjoy "A Conquering Spirit."

"Of Sorts For Provincials" is an excellent addition to the historiography of the French & Indian War/Seven Years War. The author, Jim Mullins, has deep research experience, and it clearly shows in this book. Mullins does a fantastic job documenting the muskets, bayonets, and swords used by Provincial (British North American) soldiers. The photographs are clear and crisp--one can easily see the makers' marks and government acceptance stamps on the muskets. In every case, there is an ultra-close up of the locks & breech end of the barrels.If one is interested in the F&I War, flintlock weapons, or Colonial history, you would enjoy "Of Sorts For Provincials."

"A Soldier-Like Way," is an excellent addition to the historiography of the French & Indian War/Seven Years War. The author, J.J. Gale, has deep research experience, and it clearly shows in this book. Gale does an awesome job documenting the equipment and weapons of the famous Red Coats, as well as explaining the artifacts' meaning. This is a wonderful book, and would be a great addition to one's book shelf.

I have never regretted purchasing this game set! For me, Hnefatafl is a borderline addiction. Since the game is relatively unknown, I mostly play online. But I still wanted a set, to work through different strategies and problems. I found this version to be the best balance between price and quality. A few random points:1) The pieces are resin, cast in such a manner as to look as if they were carved from wood. That's a cool idea that balances the authentic look of the Hnefatafl pieces with a sturdy modern material.2) The board is also very sturdy and well made. I often take my set to the park, and I've carried the set while flying (carry on). Quite often when I play at the park, people come up and ask about the game. So this nice Hnefatafl set is a great way to introduce people to the game.3) The set includes directions for playing the game, as well as some strategies. One of the great things about Hnefatafl is that one can learn the rules quickly, and start playing. This rulebook pamphlet does help.4) Its produced by a small-business. The company owner includes his name & email address on his business card, with an open invitation to contact him if you have questions. You can't beat that type of customer service.5) Each set is hand-numbered--mine is Nr. 368. Its nice knowing your set is one of a short run, and not one of millions pumped out by a factory in China (no offense to Chinese folks).I apologize if this review is too long; its just that I'd like people to know what they're getting for their hard-earned dollars. This set is definitely worth the price, and will serve you well.

"Illinois: A History of the Prairie State" is possibly the best general history of Illinois currently available. Robert Howard had a long and distinguished career as a journalist; "Illinois" was apparently his retirement project! Howard's journalism career is put to good use, as this is a highly readable account of the events and people that shaped the state.

"Rising Up from Indian Country," is an outstanding Historical work. There are quite a few good books about Illinois during the War of 1812, but the themes of this book sets it apart. Ann Durkin Keating approaches the Battle of Fort Dearborn from the perspective of the pre-war local community, composed of the Native Americans, Europeans, and Metis who were involved in the fur trade. These three groups, from disparate cultures, created a fusion of all their cultures in order to successfully prosper in the fur trade.When the War of 1812 was declared, members of this fusion culture were forced to choose sides. Despite being official enemies, their interpersonal connections continued to serve them throughout the war--and resulted in lives saved during and after the Battle of Fort Dearborn.

This is an excellent account of the Georgia-Russian war, written by a subject matter expert. Asmus does a fantastic job explaining the political process that led up to the war. Though he does mention the war, Asmus is not a military historian, so one should not expect a treatise on tactics or equipment. Highly recommended!

Excellent documentary about the Danish soldiers who fought in Afghanistan, and the price they paid for their heroism. As US veteran, it was interesting to see the ways in which the Danish army was different than ours; yet underneath it all the feelings and emotions of the Danish soldiers depicted are the same as soldiers throughout time. Excellent documentary, and highly recommended.

Though a little dated, L.C. Scott's volume on the US Army canteen was the first modern attempt to catalogue the various makers and styles of 20th Century US military canteens. Despite its age, this book belongs in the collection of any canteen collector! I highly recommend this book.Also recommended: "The Civil War Canteen," by Robert Jones.

I bought two of these, and I am extremely happy with them both. The canteens are brand new, dark green w/ dark green caps; they do not have the tzahal property marks. I have three Israeli issue canteens, and these canteens are pretty close. The size is the same, but the canteens in these sets are a harder plastic.  The canteen covers are the best--they are heavyweight canvas with standard snap closure. The color is a type of light khaki that looks like the British Commonwealth color of World War Two. The back of the canteen has a wide strap for wearing on a regular belt; "c" clips for mounting on the British style pistol belt; and the M1910 style hook for hanging on US pistol belts. The two canteen covers I received were clearly dated 1968, and had the tzahal property mark.  For what its worth, I have never seen an Israeli canteen cup so I have no way of knowing if they would fit in the canteen pouch with the canteen. I was able to fit a US canteen & cup in the pouch.  All in all I think the Israeli canteen set is well worth the money, and I'm glad I purchased them.

I try to read every book I can get about guerrilla warfare, and this has become one of my favorites. "Pinoys at War" is part political science, and part oral history. The author interviewed Filipino guerrilla veterans, in order to learn about what motivated them to become guerrillas. The results are riveting, as the veterans tell their stories about their wartime experiences. At the same time, this is a political science book, and the author fits the guerrilla veterans' personal journeys into the "big picture" of guerrilla warfare and political violence.I enjoyed "Pinoys at War," and recommend it to anyone who wants to learn more about insurgent warfare theory.

I bought this watch five years ago when I was on leave from Iraq. I had gone through three watches in the first six months of my deployment, including an expensive "Navy Seal" type watch with tritium vials on the face. Anyhow, I bought this watch because I figured the white face and large numbers would make the watch easy to read at night (which it did, even with no moonlight). I just had to keep the silver band covered by my sleeve. This watch, which I think I got for less than $30, turned out to be a workhorse. It just wouldn't die. Five years later, and with one battery change, it is still my go-to watch. I highly recommend it!

Full disclosure, I am a gear junkie. If there is a book on web gear, I am on it! So I had to get "American Web Equipment 1967-1991." Having begun my Army service in the era of ALICE gear, I didn't think I would learn too much from this book. I am happy to say I was wrong, as there was a lot of information to be gained from "American Web Equipment 1967-1991." The author focuses on the development & improvement of web gear, so the reader can see how each 'generation' of web gear was an evolution of earlier equipment. I enjoyed this book thoroughly, and I recommend it.

For me, the title says it all--these are awesome gloves. We started using Mechanix Wear gloves in Iraq, because the issue nomex gloves couldn't stand up to the use & abuse we put them through (we were convoy escort, so we were always working on our vehicles & 50 cals). At that time, Mechanix Wear geared their gloves to the civilian market, so we had to buy the black gloves, and use sharpie marker to color in the white logos. Still, we had to hide the gloves from the Sergeants-Major, who would go into convulsions if they saw us using non-issue gloves...Anyhow, most of us brought our Mechanix gloves home at the end of our tour, because they were still in good shape. Now that the company is producing a more 'tactical' style glove, I bought a pair, and love them as much as the originals (plus the new ones don't smell like Iraq).  A few points about the Mechanix Wear M-Pact gloves:* Love the coyote brown tan color; works just as well with civilian clothes as with a military uniform.* The rubber finger & knuckle guards provide great protection, but are segmented so you can still flex your fingers.* The black rubber on the palms and fingers is 'grippy,' I can put away & take my car keys out of my pants pocket without taking off the gloves. The same feature helps with magazine changes, as well as working in the garage with tools.* The logo is also coyote tan, so it blends in with the glove...No need for a sharpie marker.* The price point is fantastic; I can get a pair for the garage, and one each for my hiking kit and for each car trunk.

Concord Publications produces a series called "Special Ops Journal," with each issue chronicling various military and law enforcement units. The journal is 65 pages, printed on thick, glossy paper, and very firmly bound.This particular issue, volume 32, published in 2004, features the following:* Australian Military Police & 2nd RAR in Baghdad, Iraq* Belgian Paratroopers & Commandos in training* Italian Carabinieri in Bosnia* French & Belgian Paratroopers in Kosovo"Special Ops" would be a valuable journal for many reasons. Current soldiers would enjoy it for the timely articles on current operations. Modelers would enjoy it for the detailed photographs--most pages have multiple photographs, and some have large 1/2 page photos. Airsoft enthusiasts and gear junkies will enjoy the photographs as they show clear detail about the web gear and weapons systems the soldiers carry...I read this issue cover-to-cover, and immediately purchased two more issues. I highly recommend it!

"The Collapse of Yugoslavia 1991-1999" is an excellent introduction to the wars of the 90's in the former Yugoslavia. Yes, it is an Osprey book, so know it will be a quick read, and not too in depth. But really, that is typical of Osprey publications: they are often a great intro to military history topics, though they do not bring anything really new to the historiography.A few minor points about the book:* Professor Finlan's writing style flows nicely, and is easy to follow; this "reads well," and not at all like a textbook.* The author does a wonderful job describing the numerous ethnic armies fighting for land in the former Yugoslavia (this was the first Yugoslavia Wars book I've read where I didn't need a cheat sheet listing the various sides). He carefully and easily documents the twisting alliances between the various Croat / Serb / Muslim factions.* The maps are excellent, and add greatly to the text. Best of all, the maps stand alone, so one does not need to keep flipping from maps to text.* The section on the Netherlands Battalion's attempted defense of Srebenica is both heartbreaking and infuriating. It is amazing how the Dutch soldiers were left without a real chance to defend themselves or the "safe zone" they were tasked with guarding, due to the bureaucratic mess in the UN command. Their failed defense of Srebenica is heartbreaking, knowing that thousands of civlians were murdered when the "safe zone" fell to the Serbian army.* Professor Finlan is British, and is understandably a fan of the British Army (I had the opportunity to serve with some Brits in Iraq, and I'm a fan too). However, his fan-boy praise for the British generals is a little over-the-top; I don't think a 95 page book needs a full-page photograph of General Smith, and a 3/4 page photograph of General Rose. Lest it seem I'm judging too harshly, the 7 page vignette on the Cheshire Regiment's tour is a great read.I have read about a dozen books on the wars in the former Yugoslavia, and I highly recommend "The Collapse of Yugoslavia, 1991-1999." Other books that would go well with this one would be Osprey's Elite series "The Yugoslav Wars (1) & (2), which are studies of the uniforms and equipment carried by the combatants.

I'm familiar with Doctor Borsarello's writings through "Camouflaged Uniforms of the Warsaw Pact & Non-Aligned Forces." So I quickly bought a copy of his latest work. I was not dissapointed; "Camouflage Uniforms of European and NATO Armies 1945 to the Present" is excellent. The book is not really an encyclopedia of camouflage, rather a survey, which shows how various countries have decided to hide their soldiers. A few points about the book:* This is a survey, not all-inclusive. So you may not see your "favorite" camouflage pattern. On the other hand, I'm sure you will find patterns you never knew existed.* I'm glad Borsarello lists a wide range of countries, not just the big countries whose militaries are often in the news.* Quite a few of the photographs and text are the same as Borsarello's "Camouflaged Uniforms of the Warsaw Pact." If you've read that book, be prepared for repeat. Since "Warsaw Pact" came out ten years before "Camouflage Uniforms," I hoped that Borsarello would include new photos, not merely rehash old photos.* As is typical with a niche book, this did not come from a large publisher, with highly paid translators. So the English language version can be tough to understand because of the broken English. It isn't a show-stopper, but will take a little effort.* Borsarello has a confusing tendency to invent names for camouflage, rather than using each country's designation. This can be confusing because he often gives different names to the same pattern. An example would be his using three different terms for the same pattern of Czechoslovakian Warsaw Pact camouflage; or his using two very different descriptions of the same Spanish camouflage.* Finally, a word of note...Though this book covers "1945 to the present," Borsarello's present ends when the book was first published in 1999. A lot of changes have come about in the 13 years since the book came out. Perhaps Doctor Borsarello will publish a second edition?All in all, Doctor Borsarello is one of the most distinguished military historians on the field of camouflage theory and patterns. I recommend this book to all my friends who collect militaria, and I recommend it to you, too.

One thing I've always found interesting about the Cold War, is that military historians have effectively ignored it since the fall of the Berlin Wall and the end of Communism in the former USSR. With a few minor exceptions, most of the information we have on the Warsaw Pact armies is the same info NATO had in the 1980s.Doctor Borsarello has attempted to rectify that within his historical specialty of military camouflage. Though this book was written in 1989, at the sunset of the Cold War, Borsarello used a lot of original research. Borsarello documents about 40 different camouflage patterns that were all used by Warsaw Pact nations. Some of the photographs are of the actual militaries, and many of them are Doctor Borsarello's collection. All the pho. tos are good quality, and show great detail.I've always been interested in the Warsaw Pact, having grown up seeing them on television (as the "enemy"). I read everything I can get my hands on on the subject. That said, "Camouflaged Uniforms of the Warsaw Pact" is a great book, and well worth the price.

I'm a big fan of Martin Brayley's writing, and have bought all his books I can find. Niche writing is always hard, because your readers tend to be knowledgeable on the subject. Brayley, however, always does a fine job of covering new information, and "Camouflage Uniforms 1940-2010" is no different.It would be impossible to list and photograph EVERY type of camouflage used in the last 60 years, as many are still classified or exceedingly rare. On top of that, many countries use the same pattern--it would be tiring to look at page-after-page of all the countries that use US M-81 woodland camoufage. So don't be surprised if your favorite camouflage uniform isn't featured. Brayley's book isn't an encyclopaedia, it is more of a survey.I would also recommend Brailey's new book on body armor, and his older books on web gear.

The Nite Ize figure 9 series have been around for awhile, but I just recently got turned onto them. I have to say, I totally love them. If you are not familiar with the product, it takes the place of knots on tent lines or guy lines, as well as allowing faster adjustment. The figure 9 does this by a series of angles and "teeth" that grip the cord.PROS:* Lightweight! You can throw these in your pack, and not feel any weight difference. Yet they'll allow you to secure a tent, or rig up a tarp for use as a shelter. Perfect for a survival kit, or in a "get home" bag.* The directions are actually molded into the plastic, so if you forget which order to manipulate the cord--it's right there. By the way, the directions are not complex; there's only two steps to locking down a cord.* For me, the true worth of the figure 9 is that I can use it with gloves on, or when my hands are cold. If I was in a survival situation where I wasn't operating at 100%, I would definitely want this tool with me.CONS:* This is a premature concern, and I have not had a chance to test it out. But, the figure 9 is plastic, and I wonder if it will get brittle and crack when used in sub-zero weather. I'll have to wait until winter and then post an update.All in all, I think the Nite Ize figure 9 is completely worth the money. I plan on purchasing more, and in different sizes, as they are handy to have around. I have no issues recommending these to my family and friends.

Just a quick caveat--I don't have an opinion on Bear Grylls. It seems that many of these reviews are a referemdum on the man, and not the equipment. Love or hate him, he won't be there when I'm out camping or hiking, so all I care about is the quality of the firesteel.That being said, I found the Gerber-brand, Bear Grylls endorsed firesteel at the local big box store. It was on clearance for a price that was less than Light My Fire firesteels, or the military issued magnesium firestarter, so I bought it. I'm always looking for better (or more) equipment, regardless of who's name is on it, and this was a good opportunity to try a new product.General Info:* The Gerber firesteel is relatively light; it weighs about the same as the military issue magnesium firestarter & striker but more than a Light My Fire-brand firestarter. It is just over 4 1/2" long when closed.* The ferrocerium rod is 1 1/2" long. As a point of contrast, it is 1/4" shorter than the Light My Fire, but the Gerber is thicker.* The two halves of the striker are held together by 22" of parachute cord. This cord can be removed from the firesteel in the event you need it. Minor point, but it is 3 strand parachute cord, not the military 7 strand.* A nice point about the Gerber firesteel is that it serves multiple functions in one tool. The body of the firesteel will hold tinder; I was able to fit a couple vaseline soaked cotton balls inside. I probably could have forced in more than 2, but I want to be able to get them out if my hands are wet or cold, or I'm not functioning at 100%.* The Gerber firesteel also has a small whistle which, for it's size, is very loud and piercing. My whistle & whistle housing broke off the parachute cord as I was taking it out of the package. The whistle still works, it just isn't attached.How Well Does It Start Fires???I tested the Gerber firesteel in my backyard here in northern Illinois. It had not rained in about a week, and everything was dry. The weather was in the mid-70's; breezy but not windy. I used the Gerber firesteel, the Light My Fire, and the military issue magnesium firesteel. For tinder I typically use vaseline soaked cottonballs, but for this test I also used cotton dryer lint.The Gerber firesteel threw great sparks! It only took two "swipes" to get enough coating off the ferrocerium rod to enable good sparks. Once I got the coating off, the Gerber lit the cottonball in two swipes. It lit the dryer lint on the fourth swipe. In an emergency situation, I would consider that acceptable. The Light My Fire took the same number of swipes, and the magnesium firestarter took one more swipe when lighting the dryer lint. Honestly, I consider them all about equal.In comparison to the Light My Fire and the magnesium fire starter, the Gerber performed well. I'm not sorry I purchased it, as it functions well, and I always like to have as many fire-starters around as I can find. I have no problem recommending the Gerber Bear Grylls fire starter to my friends.

"Total Resistance" is a Cold War guerrilla warfare manual prepared by the Swiss government for distribution in the event of a Soviet/Warsaw Pact invasion. I mention this first because all the different techniques, tactics and procedures in the book flow from this thesis. If you have read Mao or Che, and found yourself rolling your eyes at their overly-wordy political rants, then "Total Resistance" is for you.PROS:* The concepts are easy to understand & easy to implement. I get the impression that this manual was meant to be handed from guerrilla-to-guerrilla, rather than sit on a bookshelf as a reference.* The manual covers a broad range of scenarios for combat action. Whether you have two guerrillas or two hundred, this manual will list an operation that works at your manpower level. Typically, the safest operation for a guerrilla unit to engage are the enemy's logistics and communications network. "Total Resistance" follows this concept, and shows how to perform roadblocks, attacks on trains, and attacks on telephone lines.* Beyond small unit tactics, "Total Resistance" explains how to grow your resistance movement (page 103-109). This is important, since insurgent movements can wither when members quit believing in the cause. As a historical example I would mention the large number of Sandinistas who became Contras after being disillusioned with the 'revolucion.'CONS:* The manual leans on the assumption that you will get support from fellow citizens (page 20-21). Historically speaking, this is incorrect. Most citizens in occupied areas will keep their heads down and merely try to survive. Studies of the French Resistance in WWII showed that roughly 1% of the population actively took part in the resistance movement. The Mujahadeen in Afghanistan, while resisting the Soviets, were at about 3% (and they had the 'jihad' concept to help recruitment).* As an adjunct to the above, "Total Resistance" posits that very little of the population will collaborate with the enemy (page 84). Again, history shows otherwise. In the Philippines in WWII, almost the entire pre-war power structure sided with the Japanese. The only major figure to refuse collaboration was the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, who was subsequently beheaded. For European examples, look at Yugoslavia and Ukraine in WWII. Both had significant segments of their population side with the Nazis.* One complaint I noticed with other reviewers is the belief that technology has changed to such an extent that "Total Resistance" is obsolete. In this case I respectfully disagree. Guerrilla fighters typically fight with what they have available. This is the lure of guerrilla warfare--that the weak can use what they have to fight the mighty. Look at the rockets and IEDs that were used in Iraq; most were home made using parts one could find in hardware stores (we were hit by one that was made from Christmas lights left behind by GI's). The point is that, as long as there are men and women willing to fight, guerrilla war will continue.

I love reading any book about outdoors skills, and I regularly practice the skills I find valuable. That being said, I'm the furthest thing from an expert--more of a perpetual student. I'm always looking for new techniques or tricks. With that in mind, I received "Hawke's Special Forces Survival Handbook" in the mail yesterday, and spent all night reading it cover to cover. In short, it is now my favorite go-to survival manual.PROS:* Hawke's writing style is conversational, and easy-to-read. It reads as if he is standing in front of you, explaining the concepts directly.* Hawke's survival techniques are part of a system, which he easily explains. This framework helps because it shows the reader why & when to perform the techniques. Since so much of survival is mental, Hawke figures that in, as well.* The diagrams stand on their own; unlike many survival books I've read, where you have to flip between the diagrams and the text to figure out the concept.* The medical section on first aid is fantastic. I went through the Combat Lifesaver Course when I was in the Army, and this chapter blew that away.* Hawke's descriptions on how to forage for wild plants is the most straightforward & easy to remember that I've ever read.* I found the book to be lightweight and well built. The cover and the pages are water resistant. It is also small enough to fit in the dead space in your pack (or in your cargo pocket for a day hike).CONS:* None. I've seen some reviewers who were upset that they found this book heavy; they might want to try cutting off the front- and back cover, that will help a bit.In all honesty, there is no "one" survival book. Each has something to offer, and some technique you have not seen before. Of course, you can't go around carrying fifty different survival books. So if I can only have one book, it has to be the book that has the most useful information. For me, that book is "Hawke's Special Forces Survival Handbook."

Despite only being a state for roughly 40 years, Illinois was fourth in the Union for "most soldiers" sent to fight the Confederacy. Professor Hicken set out to write a book about these men (and a few women) who fought to preserve the Union--and he succeeded marvelously. "Illinois In The Civil War" is a fantastic book that balances the "map level" war of strategy with the war on the ground, as the soldiers saw it.One thing I really enjoyed about the book was Hicken's detailed writing about the units themselves. Because each regiment was raised in a specific area, they each had an interesting "flavor." For instance, the 33rd Illinois was made up of college kids from what would later be Illinois State University. The 45th Illinois were tough lead miners from the Galena area. Some units seemed nondescript, but for the fact that they always seemed to be in the heat of battle--like the 36th Illinois, that helped save the day at the Battle of Franklin.I'm a big fan of Illinois history, and this book has never left my nightstand. I've visited many of the places Professor Hicken wrote about, and I've used the book on the battlefield parks as a guide. I've recommended "Illinois In The Civil War" to all my friends, and I recommend it to you, too.

Glenn Garvin was a newspaper reporter who spent six years living with the Contras in Honduras & Nicaragua. The results of his interviews is this book "Everybody Had His Own Gringo." Garvin is an excellent writer; had he changed paths slightly, he would have been an excellent novelist.The book covers the history of the Contras; how they came to be and who filled their ranks. If there is a central theme to "Everybody Had His Own Gringo," it is that the Contras were a living Rohrshach test--everyone saw in them what they wanted. To the Reagan administration they were brave freedom fighters; to the American left they were the worst type of terrorist. Yet neither of these camps really made an effort to find out what the Contras were about; they were just a means to a political end. Garvin took the time to meet the Contras, and find out what actually motivated them. What he found was a complex organization that was often at odds with itself, and which often had differing visions of what they wanted to achieve.In "Everybody Had His Own Gringo," Glenn Garvin has produced the best first hand account of the Contra insurgency in Nicaragua.

Colonel Whitman's "Bataan: Our Last Ditch" is the best book I've read on the Bataan Campaign. Whitman, an Airborne Infantry officer in the US Army, is also a fantastic researcher who has painstakingly produced a fantastic book. "Bataan" gives a nice "map level" view of the war, showing where each unit deployed and fought. At the same time, there are plenty of anecdotes and veterans stories to show how individual soldiers acted during the campaign.If you are interested in the history of the Philippines, or the Bataan Campaign, I think you will enjoy "Bataan: Our Last Ditch."

I read this book after finding it at the PX at Fort Gordon, Georgia. Professor Tierney's book is an examination of the American military's past experiences with insurgencies and guerrilla warfare. The book is well written, easy to read, and nicely researched. I especially enjoyed the chapters on Central American insurgencies, which is Tierney's specialty.If you enjoy reading about the history of insurgencies and guerrilla warfare, I recommend "Chasing Ghosts." I would also recommend Laqueur's "Guerrilla." Laqueur goes into insurgencies on a global level. Though it is out of print, used copies can be had very cheaply.

I read "Beating Goliath" for a PoliSci course in grad school. I've always been interested in insurgencies and guerrilla warfare, and I like to read every book I can get my hands on. This was one of the better books, as the writer's style is both informative and well written. Record's central idea is that the side with the greater organizational will to win is the side most likely to prevail in an insurgency. An example he cites is the British Empire during the American Revolution; part of the English lack of will was knowing that they had a stable homeland to return to. Record also addresses the importance of the insurgency having outside support as a factor in victory (ie Chinese support for the NVA & Viet Cong).All in all, "Beating Goliath" is a well written political science book, that adds to the rich literature on insurgent warfare.

I bought this knife just before my first deployment. I have a cursed habit of losing pocket knives (and sunglasses, but that's another story), so I didn't want to pay too much. Against character, I haven't lost this knife, and it is now nine years old.A few random points:* This knife is sturdy! I've used it to cut, stab, poke and pry. It is still going strong.* The star-head screws that hold the handles on, and hold on the pocket clip, are still tight and have not needed to be re- tightened.* This knife takes a great edge, and was quick and easy to sharpen (even in the field, under less than optimum conditions).* The handles are magnesium, and covered with a black protective coating. Though the handle feels smooth, I've never had problems with it slipping. I've dropped it or banged it hard a number of times. Despite rough handling, only a little of the black coating has chipped off.* The blade has two small guards; this was the main feature that lead me to buy the knife. The guards allow you to open the knife one handed, and very quickly. It also provides a bit of safety.The Smith and Wesson Magnesium HRT is a rugged knife, and well worth the money.

Great shirt. The color is more brownish red. We are pleased. My husband always wears size medium and this shirt fits as expected. He has another shirt from the same brand, also Medium and the sizing is consistent and adequate.Easy wash and wear. No wrinkles after washing which is a huge plus. All buttons are in place. Good seams.My only complaint is that it was rather tightly wrapped with some pins a little hard to find. But that is not a serious concern and once you are wearing the shirt you totally forget about the pins...

Coke Zero is a crisp and robust soda. It has no calories (as the name states) and it is sweetened with aspartame. It contains glorious caffeine. It's been so long that I tasted regular coca-cola that I am in no position to say if this is truly similar or not. Sorry. I do prefer it to Diet Coke but honestly I think the reason is that the black can is just better looking. Not sure they taste different.Coke Zero has a very low pH but so does your stomach, so no worries. I've been drinking it for years and I'm fine. Something I've noticed about the coca-colas that have no real sugar is that I have yet to meet a microbe that can live in them. I'm no expert on microbes that live in soda. But I think that if you leave a bit of Coke in a tumbler and forget it in your bag for weeks in the middle of summer (ehem), the tumbler will in fact not have grown any sort of mold unlike your roommate's, who may have washed hers and left it slightly damp and did grow mold.It is likely this drink will not be conducive to empowering your gut's microbiome. But I have seen research that suggests Coca-cola is a super-cheap treatment for gastric phytobezoars. So if you think you have one, you can treat it drinking Coke. No need for expensive medications until you try this drink and see if it works. So it's medicinal.On a different note:I was a little skeptical that these cans would arrive as they should in the pantry box. But they did. No issues.

I am very pleased with this set of tools. I'm always trying to clean my teeth with various tools and I am fond of toothpicks for teeth polishing. These tools do not disappoint. They are sharp and sturdy. So many things nowadays are plastic... its important to note these are indeed metal. Even the mirror, that at first I saw as a silly doodad comes in handy! Really, looking at your teeth to monitor dark spots or to figure out what is exactly bothering you in the back of your teeth is useful.The picks are very effective at removing layers of bacterial growth. It's essentially "elbow grease". Bacteria sometimes needs to be physically disrupted in order for a regular teeth brushing with toothpaste to really help with the removal of the plaque. Back when I was a poor undergrad, the university offered free teeth "cleanings" which I tool because I didn't have insurance. I was always baffled that all they did was use these sort of tools. There was no polishing of the teeth with anything fancy. Yet, I am guessing that alone was effective. So, if you can't afford to go to the dentist twice a year, maybe tools like these can help wait it out just a little longer. Not that I am a dentist or in any way qualified to give advise about teeth. All I mean is that my teeth feel very clean after a session with these and I am most pleased. The teeth feel truly clean.*These are SHARP. So beware that if your hand is not steady these may not be for you.*I received these at a discount to test and review.

I have an iMac. Once I adjusted the settings to receive the sound signal from the USB port I was in business (click apple, select system preferences, adjust sound settings to USB port). These are easy to use, the quality of the sound and the microphone are good. I filmed several videos using the headset's microphone and while the voice is clear, I wouldn't say the microphone is of excellent podcast or youtube quality. The quality for this purpose is adequate. There is some noise cancellation, but only some. This is fine for the price point.I like that the cable to the USB port is thick and feels durable. Love that there is a cable and it isn't wireless (no batteries - thanks!). The microphone folds away and fits in the headset seamlessly for a nice sleek look when not in use. The headset is adjustable as it fits me, my husband and my 5 year old son. The cushions around the ears makes the headset comfortable.I received this headset in exchange for a review.

I received this product free for evaluation.The brush is lightweight and made of durable hard plastic. I like the look of pink and black. I am using this brush on my daughter's thin and straight hair. She is three. She loves it is pink. Add a few stickers and you are in business. The shape prompts you to hold the brush near the bristles, this is in part how it helps making brushing more gentle. While I like this design, I suspect not everyone will like this way of holding the brush. It does fine on wet hair.The bristles are made of a single length of flexible plastic. It doesn't have those ends that are rounded that most of my brushes have. These ends tend to fall off over time, usually exposing a harsh plastic ends that hurt the scalp. This brush doesn't have those ends, so you can be reasonably confident the bristles will remain soft to the scalp.It works great for my daughter's hair. She still feels I'm brushing her hair, so this brush doesn't offer a miraculous brushing experience. The help comes from having many bristles of different lengths and being able to comfortably hold the brush steady.

This cartoon's art and graphics are exactly like in the book. It held the attention of my 3 year old, who adores this book. The story is different than in the book, and that is to be expected. It is adorable. I also like the length of the show since it is aimed at the younger crowd. It is about 10 minutes.

At first I was confused, as it said Amazon comedy and at the beginning they show the very sad death of an older mom, with beautiful flashbacks to idyllic childhood memories. I wasn't laughing, I was crying! It was a raw depiction of emotion and the realities we all must face eventually. I can see that this is a dark and intellectual sort of comedy. The kind that makes you think about what you just saw days after you watched it.It is obvious that there will be many subplots. From the double mastectomy of the main character, the relationship with the stepfather, the biological father, the brother. Clearly, the gorgeous girlfriend will be the fish out of water here, I would expect to see comic relief from her. Or at least deep insights wrapped in levity.Very impressed. I would watch.

I've written over 250 reviews on Amazon and I rarely use the word love because it is overused. But I LOVE this game. I do. There it is. I said it.Why?My son, who is 5, is starting to add in his math curriculum. We've done some subtraction using computer games in Starfall and Splashmath, but not officially yet. But he understands "5 take away 3" statements for example. Well, I give him an abacus to play. The game is entertaining as inevitably someone stays behind, someone enters the "endless loop". The game pieces are truly darling. There's a snake, a frog (and to my son's hilarity) a snail and a turtle - funny because, you know those are slow. The vocabulary is also excellent for little ones: during the game you talk about odd and even numbers. You have three dice: two number dice and an operations die. The game is simple to learn and it is neither too long not too short. It is also not mind numbing like Candy Land.When my son rolled a 6-2 and he automatically said 4, I tell you that I was so happy I almost cried. This game hits that balance between entertaining and educational. It's just great.

I got this for my 3 year old daughter who loves playing picnic with her dolls and anyone who will play with her. She has plastic food toys and I thought this would make for a fun addition.Well, it turns out my 5 year old son also likes to play with the pancakes. They are really a fun toy and kids who play pretend for hours will enjoy these once in a while.They are well made and I like that the cook top is included since we do not have the budget or the space to have a big play kitchen.

I received this cream free in exchange for a review.Pros:1. It's absorbed quickly and it is not greasy.2. Very faint fragrance, not really noticeable.3. After application, my regular moisturizer is absorbed as usual.4. The pump style is nice, because you don't dirty the rest of the cream with your fingers, nor do you need a spatula to scoop it up.5. While I can feel I have applied a lotion (slight tingle), I've had no adverse reactions or redness while using this cream.6. The cream's container is darling.Cons:1. I think calling this cream "miracle" is stretching it.2. I need to use two pumps to cover all face and neck - because it absorbs so quickly.3. Not surprisingly, I have been using this cream for a week and have not seen any miracles.

I have been reading Life of Fred, apples (LOF in online forums) with my five year old as bedtime math. I think the stories are strange, but my son thinks they are funny and that's really what matters. Imagine a 5 year old kid who at 7pm will gladly sit at the table to work on 4 or 5 math problems at the end of a story? Yup. That's what Fred is accomplishing, so I'm happy.It is concentrating a lot on the numbers that add up to 7. This doesn't bother me, I think it is very appropriate as a supplement for my son. We have been working on adding doubles, and using manipulatives to add up to 10 on his regular schooling. So it works out well.They have questions that require some thinking for little children, such as: "Sunday is the first day of the week, Monday is second, what day is Saturday?" The question made him think and feel a sense of accomplishment when he figured out the answer.We may get some more of the books in the series. One pet peeve I have is that some people claim this can be a full math curriculum. I disagree! I think it is a great supplement. I suppose it is possible to add extra practice and perhaps be a nice break from regular math short term. But in my opinion this is not a rigorous math program, rather a supplement to help young kids have fun with math.I highly recommend it - as a supplement.

I received these cubes for a discount in exchange for a review.Very lightweight, which is important nowadays. You certainly don't want to add too much weight with a luggage organizer in an era when weight matters as you get charged extra by the airlines. If you want to pack them in empty to fill as you go, you can as they fit inside each other and lay relatively flat at the bottom of a suitcase. Each bag has its own handle, and they are all breathable since they all have mesh. It is a good organizing solution, not only to keep things separate and to easily pack/un pack, but you could just use the smallest cube for your toiletries or makeup and leave the rest at home if you wished.The zippers are good, the material is thin but sturdy. Do not put sharp objects in these bags.I thought that while we were not traveling, these could be used to store things under the bed. And yes, you could use them for that. However, because of the mesh it isn't practical. Dust could easily accumulate. Further, bugs could get in the cubes. So these are not suitable for long term storage on their own. To be fair, these cubes are not advertised for that purpose. They could organize items inside a larger plastic container that is sealed. The mesh allows you to see what's inside easily.Main con:Because of the mesh on each one of these bags, you do not want to rely on these to pack just a few stinky items together with clean ones. The odor will easily spread trough your luggage. You could put the dirty things in a plastic bag, and then pack them in the "cubes". Same goes for wet things.

After doing Saxon Math K last year, I decided to continue with Saxon Math 1 last September with my son. We stopped on lesson 35 and I'm switching to a new curriculum. Saxon has a spiral approach to math. That means that it teaches a little bit of a topic for one or a few lessons in a row and then it starts a new topic or picks up on a topic that had been covered some lessons before. I am giving the curriculum 4 stars because it is solid, and I am sure for some children this approach is the right approach. For my son, who wants to understand things really well right away, this approach is not the best fit. We have switched to a mastery based curriculum (which can be tedious as well, but for different reasons) and I will absolutely update if I have to return to Saxon.This curriculum can get very repetitive. "The meeting" starts every day with similar questions about the calendar, counting to 100, setting the clock and so on. It adds little bits of material and it starts at about 40 min of math per lesson and you end up with about 1 hr of work each day. We are using this curriculum for kinder, so that is a long time for a 5 year old. We always did at least one 5-10 minute "wiggle break" depending on how much writing or sitting we had done. I think that is a decent amount of time to spend on math. That's fine, but the routine had my son just repeating answers by memory and doing worksheets without really thinking about it. And he was doing them fine. It wasn't until I completely changed the calendar routine that I noticed that even though we had been doing calendar daily for a year and a half (Saxon k and 1) he couldn't tell me today's date! We worked on it a few different ways, and it took a couple of weeks and now he has no trouble. But I panicked a little. What if he wasn't translating this dry information into an understanding mathematics?I started supplementing with Life of Fred as bedtime math. And I started adding other math games to add more variety to our math routines, to ensure he was grasping the concepts.As far as parental prep and involvement, I find this curriculum is intensive on the parent. This is not a problem for us, as we work together on all the academics. But I dislike having to cut circles, apples and finding 10 toys you can sit on chairs!I prefer to open the book, find the worksheets and/or manipulatives and go. To use this curriculum you really need the manipulatives kit and the workbooks (there's two of them). The meeting book,  in my opinion, is optional.

I received this thermometer using a discount from an online coupon club in exchange for a review. I'll answer questions posted to the review.I have been a decent home cook for about 12 years. I have never had issues getting anyone sick with my cooking probably because I tend to over cook chicken and pork on purpose, to make sure it's done.With the exception of the thanksgiving turkey that comes with its own thermometer, this is the first time I actually use a thermometer to make sure my chicken is cooked, but not overdone.My observations are as follows:1. It is very intuitive. On/off button. C or F for temperature. Handy chart on the back of the thermometer to see what is the correct temperature of your meats.2. It has a cover. It's a little hard to get it out of it, but you don't need to call your strongest family member to help you.3. Easy meat insertion. Quick to get to temperature, just a few seconds.4. Comes with batteries. Ready to use after a simple wash. Package opens easily.5. Looks exactly like the thermometers I've seen used in food shows.6. I don't believe you are meant to bake this in the oven with food. Remove food, check, remove thermometer.Unfortunately I cannot compare the reading of this thermometer to one more expensive since this is my first one. I didn't give it 5 stars because I don't "love it". It's nice and adequate. It isn't overly wonderful for the price or particularly beautiful. It is functional. How long the battery lasts remains to be seen. So far, so good.

My daughter got Peppa and her family for her birthday last March. Since, we have read several Peppa books from the library. One of the favorite books has Peppa's friends playing with instruments and going to school. I got her Peppa's friends and it has been a good call. She can play with Peppa and her friends for long periods of time. Imagining jumping in muddy puddles and playing school. This is a good companion to the basic Peppa family set of toys. And it's good to have a spare Peppa in case you loose one.These figures are about 2 inches tall. I think it is a good size. I like they are all made of some sort of rubber/plastic material. Clothes cannot be taken off, the figures look exactly as in the stories and show - so what more can you ask for? I think the price is fine for what you get: a toy that your child can play with and act out all sort of stories. These work well with Lego Duplos. We have made a Lego Duplo farm where the friends can play among Lego flowers. The size is exactly right to combine with Duplo play.The paint comes off. I honestly had not noticed until I reading here. My daughter has not complained.

My son is in kindergarten and we are on lesson 27 of Saxon Math 1. For Saxon Math 1 An Incremental Development: Home Study Teachers Edition the workbook is an essential part of homeschooling (unlike for Saxon Math K Homeschool: Teacher's Manual 1st Edition 1994). The parent's manual has the workbook pages printed in a small picture. You *could* make your own workbook pages using the parent's manual - I did this for a few lessons. I soon grew tired of doing that and bought the workbook. Now beware: this listing is workbook part one. You will still need to buy workbook part two. Also, I don't bother with the Saxon Math 1: An Incremental Development Home Study Meeting Book - I didn't use it for Saxon K and I am not using it for Saxon Math 1 either.We are using Saxon Math 1 for kindergarten because we did most of Saxon Math K last year during pre-school. While Saxon Math is not common core aligned, due to the changes in the curriculum for the country, kids in K are now doing addition and subtraction. For this reason, I did Saxon Math K for pre-school and now I am doing Saxon Math 1 for K. This keeps my son more or less aligned with peers doing common core at public school, while still providing a classic approach to math. My son is doing fine with math. In fact, it is his favorite subject. I -the parent- am not in love with Saxon. It is very parent intensive and you have to read the instructions to your child if he is still not a fluent reader. However, my son is thriving using this program and he enjoys it. For this reason we are using it on a daily basis.
