Because no matter how many Bradens are there in her series right now  she managed to make each one uniquely lovable and each story different from the rest.Trust me  YOU. WILL. FALL. IN. LOVE. WITH. NATE. BRADEN. His heart is just so big and so generous, I love how he loved not just Jewel, but Rick and the rest of their family. Its a little heartbreaking that Rick wasnt there to watch their love bloom and get their HEA, it would have been perfect.

Even bad boys need their happy endings, and Michelle Lynn made sure Rob Winters got it in this wonderful love story that will make and break hearts.Everyone who has read this series knew who Rob Winters is. I hated him until book number 4. He was an a**, sometimes I wished him ill, and he really didnt deserve a happy ending, until Chrissys story, where he did something that no one had expect him to do.Is he set to redeem himself in front of the readers eyes? Or will he continue to build all those walls around him and continue to act like he doesnt care about anyone?It was a tragedy that made him close off himself to the people around him, a heartbreaking, life-changing accident that had broken relationships he valued along the way. It has been seven years, and so far, he had distanced himself from people by being rude, mean, douche and again, an a**. But what people dont know, even his friends are the anguish that has been eating him. Can he ever move on?Then here comes the new roommate who caught his attention the moment she walked into his life. Paige had been a breath of fresh air with an ounce of sunshine. But she doesnt take any s*** from anyone even if its from the hottest guy he had ever laid her eyes on. She knows her worth, and she wasnt going to settle for less. She had seen what loving someone who doesnt reciprocate the love can do to oneself. I love her sense of responsibility, the way she takes care of things even if she wasnt the one who should be doing it. She saw through him, and she will do anything to unleash the guy she saw in him. Its not going to be easy, but if theres someone who can do it, it was her. Just like the rest of the girls in this series, shes easily likable.You cant help but swoon and pin over the characters in this series, I was glad to see the rest of the group living up their HEA, all the surprising scenes, those heart-stopping twists and turns that will make you see the characters in different lights.I have never, ever thought Michelle Lynn would teach me to love this bad boy. It was slow, deliberate and she made sure once you fell in love with this guy, hes going to stay in your hearts forever.I love this series, and even loved it more when this bad boy got himself redeemed. This one is another must-read from this author! Never miss a book from this series!

Lady Sophia Barnes is a woman to be admired. Shes brave, shes strong, shes stubborn, and shes generous. She doesnt take no for an answer and poses as a man when she goes on a mission roaming Londons underground.What shes doing is dangerous, but living for a cause, and being brave enough to fight for it is pretty much amazing. She usually comes out of it unscathed, until she needed to use a gun. First, she had to know how to shoot it. Who else would be qualified to teach her discreetly but Lord Quint? The man who broke her heart years ago.I like Quint. He is handsome and smart  complete package. But his family history might bring out something in him that he didnt want. Something he was studying for a long time but still hasnt figured anything out. So, he doesnt allow himself to go out of his house. He became a hermit, and he valued his solitude, until Sophie invaded his home.These two are pretty much amazing. They are easily likable characters even with their secrets and baggage. These are the type of people you want to be friends with, and you want to help badly.The attraction was there, it was since they met and it was brewing, waiting for the perfect time. But with danger lurking and unsure future  would they have a chance to be together?The book was one big adventure and romance. This was one of those reads I couldnt put down, and have gone through the wee hours of the morning to finish.You know that book that you couldnt help but love because of its exemplary tale of woman power at the same time the vulnerability of woman because of their emotion? This is the book. It amazed me, made me laugh, had me in tears and made me fall in love. Joanna Shupe sure knows how to end her series with a bang. You wouldnt want to miss this.

Because with them, it always started with a kiss.These are two are pretty much frustrating and will test your patience, and yet you will admire them for what they have been through, and how they manage to survive what life threw at them at their young age.Alyssa was the new girl in town, and Johnny was a sweet-talking country boy who likes to play in mud. They were perfect for each other. The chemistry was there, the attraction was palpable. The girl just needed to put a label on it, since she was getting more and more confused.Just when everything was going perfectly, tragedy happened that destroyed their relationship. He was grieving, he was pushing her away, and she was hurting. They didnt realize that their choices and their action could dampen their new budding relationship until it was already too late.I couldnt blame Alyssa, really. She made a bad choice, but heck they were both in pain. It was a bad move, but he somewhat pushed her to it. He was acting as if she doesnt exist anymore, as if she meant nothing to him and it stings.When he came back, he was surprised to find the love of his life was different from what he imagined her to be. He tries to win her back by wooing and promising  but the trust has been broken. He needed to do more than groveling to bring himself back into her good graces.I wanted to welcome him back, after all, he was all sweet and attentive. But coming from Alyssas side, I knew it was hard for her to look through everything that has happened to her. The trust has been broken, and she was not the girl he left behind. A lot of things had happened already.Will they get their second chance?Lucia Franco pushed it. She bravely wrote this book and awed me. Topics that are considered taboo, but are happening in closed doors. It creep me out because its raw, its real and its heartbreaking. Its happening around us  we might have been blind at some point and nonchalant at the next but its true. She pointed it out, made her readers see, and gave her readers something to ponder on.We always have choices. Every one of us. Life may throw us some sh**, and we may left with a few sh**ty choices, but we are still left with options, and it will always be up to us to choose among it. Johnny and Alyssa made some bad choices and got the both of them heartbroken, and yet it was their choices that brought them back together. Exasperating, yet admirable young couple  cant help but just love em both in the end.

Avery wanted to have a baby. Her biological clock just went on alarm earlier than expected. Her familys medical history suggests that if she wanted to have a baby, she needs to do it now before its too late. Now her overprotective and hot best friend was volunteering to be her donor.There was no way Drew Flannery would never allow his best friend Avery to have an anonymous donor. He might not be ready to become a father, not to mention he did not have the model dad growing up, but theres no stopping him in doing whats best for Avery. Only if they did it the natural way.Will it mean theyd be crossing that line? Or its just sex after all?These two have that bond they shared since childhood. They have been through tough times individually, and have been there for each other. The sex might be explosive and orgasmic regardless of the place, but the real question is would it be enough to start a relationship? When the doubt sets in and the past came to haunt, will they be able to survive it?Falling in love with your best friend could be the best thing that could happened to you  but first, someone has to take that risk. I love the relationship that they have, and how they took care of each other. I can understand the predicament Drew was in, although I was really thankful that his younger brother came to the rescue and knock some senses into her.Romantic, steamy and a great short read. Its a classic tale that never gets old.

Good girl, Mia Reyes is on her way to UCLA to becoming a doctor. Her future has been carefully planned by her overprotective parents. Now, she was definitely in heaven as she has been asked to tutor one of the most sought-after rock stars! Excitement came crashing down when she meets him. He was rude, arrogant and pretty much the epitome of the bad boy his name had been attached to. She needed to do this in secret of course; no one needs to know shes tutoring him. Especially not her parents whod pick her up once theyd knew of what she agreed to. Fake kisses, some PDAs and not to mention  room-sharing. This could be harder than she thought.Ryder Brooks is famous. Hes one of the founding members of Seconds to Juliet. All he wanted to do was to write his own music and not something that has been shove into them for singing. But first, he needed to play by the rules which includes being good to his new tutor, Mia.Our bad boy has some past that he didnt want out in the open. In a life that has been thrust in public, he needed something to hold on to. Something that didnt require public scrutiny. But having someone too close for comfort had brought a sense of vulnerability he didnt expect. Mia is different, unlike any other girls he had ever been with. He couldnt help but open up to her. What happens when his secrets reaches the press?I like Mia, the honest, fan-girl feeling shes having just proved to be that this girl might be one of the smartest in her class, but still is a girl who listens to popular music and goes gaga over boys. Shes a breath of fresh air, and easily likable.Its a great romantic, light read that is easy on the heart. I have enjoyed reading it from the moment they meet, their talks, their banters and their sweet moments. With easily lovable characters, throw in some amazing lyrics and music not to mention some scenes to swoon-for, makes this book worth the read.

Hockey is the only world Tyler MacDonald knows and lived on to. At a young age, he can already feel the pressure and he was not even in the NHL yet, the ultimate dream of every young hockey player. Its within his grasp, and yet why doesnt he feel happy about it? Between the constant pressure from his father, and not to mention the presence of scouts during games, how long before the pressure consumes him?Karen Weber lost someone she held close to her heart and now, she was shipped off to a father she really didnt know and his perfect little family. She didnt really belong. Between losing someone and being in a new place surrounded by strangers, this was not definitely the year for her. She looks for the perfect escape, one of the things she found freeing was running. Running is the only thing that kept her together, and that voicemail she kept on replaying on her phone every opportunity she gets. What she didnt expect was to run into Tyler.Then she gets warned by everyone. But how can she stay away when the only one who gets her is the person she should avoid?Amidst the cold weather and the freezing temperature of the rink, the love and chemistry of these two is enough to melt some ice. Its a great short read about family, friendship, and growing up.Sometimes we find love in the most unexpected places, from the most unexpected person.

Jake was sure of Haven. She was IT for him. Haven was sure of Jake. She was willing to do anything for him, including accepting every single truth coming from him even if it kills her. Honesty is important in every relationship, being open to each other is vital. But what if the truth is as sharp as sword that will ultimately slice your heart into pieces?The news was life-changing not just to Jake but to Haven as well. She was a patient woman, and is willing to endure anything. But until when? When the truth comes knocking every time? When you are reminded of it every day?Louise Bay made sure readers would never forget Jake and Haven. Part 3 seemed to be the part where their relationship was put to the ultimate test, and it will be up to them on how their love can endure such test.If you love Haven in the first two of the series, you will have the urge to hug her here. Shes a great, brave girl who is strong enough to fight for her love. She didnt leave when things get tough, she stood tall and fought with everything in her. But a strong girl can only endure muchA stellar ending to the 3-part series that had us experienced a wild rollercoaster ride of emotions and had us hooked.

Gavin is driven, ambitious, he knows what he wants and is not afraid to go after it. This is why he was the next CEO at Holden enterprises. All he wanted was to provide for his grandfather who took him in after he lost his parents. Gavin McLeod was sent to Anticue to work out an acquisition, instead he bumped into this sexy bartender that had rocked his world. What he didnt know was that this woman was the one he needed to secure his future. Now he is torn between work and his growing attraction and fascination to Sunny. He was unlike any other woman he has met.Sunny has a very positive disposition in life, not to mention she worked hard so that she can take her brother away from their past and offer him a better future. She has been taking care of her ever since, so her life has been put on hold. Her world revolved around him and the bar. But just for tonight, meeting Gavin had brought out her recklessness. She wanted him for herself. She wanted to cross that line and give herself something that she really wanted. But what if he was not what she thought he was?What I like most about this book? Intense chemistry, off the charts sexiness, and surprising twists. Not to mention some unforeseen friendships and scenes on the beach that had me swooning.The inside is as steamy as the cover, Alannah Lynne made sure her readers werent disappointed. Its hot, sexy and romantic.

"If my heart beats 100,000 times a day, that means 100,000 times a day, it's thinking about you."I finished the second and third book in one sitting. It was THAT highly addictive. The urge to know the Macys secret was eating me alive, and I wanted to know what it is that had made her that was. What was in her past that she couldnt share with Cal?Despite the initial guesses, Sawyer Bennett still managed to pull off some amazing twist to end this series. It was heartbreaking, gut-wrenching, and it was enough to wish somebody ill (grrr.) Nevertheless, I was just happy that Macy was finally able to share her secret to someone than her best friend. It was freeing, and you can feel the load in her lighten up, especially when Cal stayed, and never left her.It was a dark, dark secret that might have sent someone running, but not Cal. He was strong enough for it: strong enough to catch her, strong enough to be with her, and strong enough to fight for her.It might have taken some time before Macy trusted Cal with it, but Cal was patient. He waited, and Macy risking every single thing within her found it worth it. Cal was everything she deserved, no matter how much baggage she had on her back, he was helpful enough to carry it for her.The sex was still mind-blowing, the chemistry was still off the charts. But this time, YIELD offers us everything we ever asked for: the secret, the emotion, and the happy ending that both of them deserved. Its the best ending to the start of their happy-ever-after.

I love the Sinclair brothers!!! I have read the first book  who starred in Jude, and I was eagerly waiting for this one.Baylor is one of the most determined, strong, and ambitious heroine I have ever encountered. She can be too much, her attitude could rival some men, her temper needs to be in check at times, but hey  this girl could prove to be the first one to be drafted in the NHL. Because she plays really, really well. Enough to topple all the men in college hockey. She had been trained that way. She has been in skates even before she can walk. She was trained to be the best, and determined to be the best there is. Now if she can only tweak the attitude a little, live life rather than competing in every turn  this girl could have been perfect.If Baylor is a worry wart and control freak, Jayden worries, but he was set off to live his life (as pushed by Jude, the other hot Sinclair brother we met at Boarded by Love). It saddens him that he didnt get to be in the draft when Jude did, but his agent insisted he needed to have one more year in college to hone his skills. What came unexpectedly was meeting a girl when he went into a vacation with his brothers.It was the most trying time in their lives: Jude being away, their father leaving them and their mom struggling. He worries for everyone, I was glad Jude talked to him. He still worries, but he gets to enjoy life too. He had never met his match, until Baylor. Not only he challenges him on ice (or street-hockey), but off-ice as well. It would have been perfect, but he got all gentlemanly (didnt handle things real smooth!) instead, he broke her heart. He thought he was never going to see her again  much to his surprise.Because Baylor was now in Nashville. Playing for his team. With her father as coach. Trying to get the captainship of the team. Well, not if he cant help it.What I love about this Sinclair brother is it didnt bother him that a girl could be as good as him. He wasnt a chauvinist who thought girls couldnt play college hockey as roughly as them.  Jayden knew he was good, and he knew Baylor was great as well. But being on the same team, fighting over a championship after what happened could indeed get rough.The passion these two has for the sports is overwhelming. It makes the competition a little bit fiercer, but nonetheless healthy. I love how Jayden is protective of Baylor, and how he tries to get into her skin. But what I love the most is the change in Baylor. From enjoying (or living) in solitude, she was taught not only by Jayden, but by Jace, and sweet Markus that having friends (besides her two crazy female friends who are twins) can be great as well. So day by day, she tries to put down those walls, be a member of a team and finally realize that they were more than just a group of men (and woman) who play hockey. They were a family.Their chemistry was off the charts, they tried to fight it at first (or Baylor) did, but if she was determined, Jayden was persistent. He wore her off, she agreed if only to keep it a secret. She didnt want anything to change. She wanted to protect him from her father. But I was right when I thought keeping it a secret was a disaster waiting to happen.Jayden was a swoon-worthy boyfriend. He cares about her, he wants to show her off to the world. If she will only let him. He respects her decisions, and he wouldnt push her off her comfort zones. So, despite the fact the emotions he was feeling was a bit overwhelming that it shakes his chest fiercely, he bottled it up, until he thought she was ready to let him all in. Problem is, this girl is a control freak. And love is a very uncontrollable emotion. Would they ever make it?I enjoyed Clipped by Love as much as I enjoyed the first book. It made me laughed at times, fall in love in most pages, and had my adrenaline pumped up during those games I felt I was watching while reading it. More than that passionate romance friendship and love for sports, this story taught me that you make things happen if you are determined, and stubborn. But sometimes you cannot do it alone, you need another people to boost you up and support you for you to reach your maximum potential.

Fall in love so easily with this great contemporary romance from Alannah Lynne. Its my first read from this author, and Ill be looking forward for the rest of the books in the Heat Wave Series.It was suppose to be a one-night stand, or so Kat thinks. But for Erik, it was a whole lot more than that. Waking up alone, in an empty bed surprised him. He didnt expect for the girl who shifted his world to run away while he was in deep slumber.Kat Owens was trying to put her life together after a devastating loss to her career and love life. Moving in a new place is hard, but what is harder is resisting her supposedly one-night-stand who tempting her to have a repeat. But Erik was a client, and she had a bad experience mixing business with pleasure. Not to mention, someone is not happy that shes in the firm.Kat has a lot on her plate. More than just starting for scratch, she needs to prove to her grandfather that she can be someone. Distraction was not a part of her game plan. But he was temptation personified. How long can she resist what he was offering?Just as when Kat was ready to open her heart, walls begin to rise around Eriks heart as old wound starts to ache again. Will he be brave enough to face his emotions? Or will he end up running away?Easily likable characters, not-to-heavy drama, just enough to pique your hearts, and great romance makes Saving Me one heck of a read.

Bella Andre and Melissa Foster separately make great novels that have touched millions of readers worldwide, but together? Theyre unstoppable. So yes, my expectations were quite high, and ever since the news went out, I was pretty much excited to read this novel. It didnt disappoint.Both authors have books that tell stories about great romance and amazing family ties, this time we are introduced to a new family that will surely earn a spot in your hearts. Not only that, we are transported into the magnificent Rockwell Island.More than just an island I have fell in love with, Rockwell Island is more of a tight-knit family than a community. More than half of the people are employed by the resort  and are about to lose their jobs if the Rockwell kids choose wrong.They might have grown up in a warm and loving environment, but their grandfather was quite different. He was cold, controlling and one of the reasons why some of them preferred for a life outside the island rather than be in it.Quinn have left the island and built a shipping empire on his own. Returning to Cape Code wasnt on his to-do list but he was forced to do so when the patriarch of the Rockwell family, his grandfather, had summoned them and his four siblings to take over the resort. Each of them had their own business, and Quinn was spending a whole lot of time with mergers and contracts  how can he find time for his grandfathers demands? Not only that, the unexpected happened on his first night on the island.Meeting Shelley.Shelley Walters is a breath of fresh air. Shes wonderful, she follows her heart and her dreams. Shelley came from a prominent family with parents who were too busy to pay attention to her. She didnt want to have a future like that. She wanted something normal, so rich men were off the table. Until Quinn.If Shelley makes him once again appreciate the old things he used to enjoy in the Cape, the things he forgot. Quinn makes Shelley forget about her apprehensions with regards to rich men. Quinn was really trying so hard in changing, in trying to prove that he was different, that he can have time, that she can be a priority. He might slip sometimes, but, he sure is trying. With that  he already won me over.I always believe if you want something, if you want to find time for something  you can do it. It was hard, especially for Quinn at first, but when he finally decided, and found a solution to his problem, making the right choice was easy.I fell in love completely with the Cape Cod Kisses. I love both characters, including the warm characters that surround them. Even Chandler, I think there is more to him than his initial coldness. The dialogues were to swoon for, and you will look forward for the couples small chats. In a short time, they have known each other and fell hopelessly in love.This is the first book in the series, and in no doubt, I will be looking forward for more from these two amazing authors.

The past was not kind to Lady Hawkins. It started with her debut that had shaped her future. She just wanted to forget it, along with the whispers, the feeling of betrayal and the heartbreak that went along with it. Not to mention, her first marriage. Now a widow, Maggie had transformed into a new woman, a modern woman who valued her freedom and expresses her passion for art. Secretly that is, because she is now the renowned political cartoonist, Lemarc who seemed to have a penchant for ridiculing the Earl of Winchester.He broke her heart in the past, but now the Earl of Winchester, Simon Barrett is the rising star in the parliament just like the rest of his men in his family. But the art was ruining him one at a time, he needed to put a stop to it, now if he can only find who Lemarc is.Maggie tries not to let her reputation dampen her spirit. Instead, she lived in it. She valued the freedom and living life that came across in being the Half-Irish Harlot. After all, she couldnt do anything about it. But having Simon near her again, the man who joined the ton in not believing her innocence, proved to be a danger in her heart. She will never fall for him again, she wont risk her heart.But Simon was a formidable force. She broke his heart years ago and left him feeling like a fool. He wouldnt let her do it to him again, but question is can he resist being close to her once again?Can they be both wrong about what happened years ago?Their love story is ten painful years in the making, and I was glad they got their happy ending, not matter how farfetched it was initially. Indeed, love can do everything, even move mountains and surpass whatever painful past there is. Another captivating romantic novel from Joanna Shupe. The Harlot Countess proved to be as engaging as the first one in the series, the anticipation of solving the mystery was up until the final page, and not to mention the sizzling romance between the characters did not allow me to put this book down.

The best things in life are free, and sweet.Get ready for an epic summer of your life. Im so glad this was a timely read for me. Makes me longed to have those wonderful adventures with Maddox and Emma.Emma was just a simple girl who prefers books and her solitude. She wasnt a party girl, so when her best friend was out there having the time of her life, she just sat and read book, until Maddox Wade came over and introduce himself.Maddox life wasnt easy when he was young. But now, he has a good life and was thankful for it. Not just because he now belonged to a wonderful family, but he has an amazing career being the drummer in an up and coming band, Willow Creek.He didnt expect himself to fall in love coming home this summer. But meeting the shy, unpretentious and smart Emma had his world ran out of its axis. It was refreshing to know someone who doesnt know him, and someone who was willing to share adventures and take risk with him, even though he knows she was quite unsure of some of them.He promised her an epic summer, and Emma was going to have one.Emma was afraid of falling in love and risking her heart. Her father had left them two years ago and never came back. She never wished to experience it once again. Thats why she doesnt want to trust Maddox. But Maddox is just too wonderful to resist. She couldnt help but fall in love with him one adventure at a time. He was fun, he was exhilarating and he was something she needed in her life.But when secrets were out in the open, and Maddox might not be the person she thought he was  everything might crumble into pieces. Trust questioned and hearts break, will they be able to make it?Everyone that surrounds them were quite amazing too, even Mathias who started out an a**.Reading this was so much fun, I love them both: I love their zest for life, their quest for adventure and Emma taking the risk. She was a quiet and shy girl until someone pricks her little bubble and brought her out in the open. Every adventure allowed her to bloom.Its sweet, romantic and a perfect summer read.

I love this book way, way more than I loved BAIT, because this time  Blake & Casey were fighting for their feelings. The fight was worth it. They were finally enjoying each other without that guilt feeling that has been nagging them (and me too).Their secret was out  and it was finally a relief. Blake was finally getting braver to do what is right, and not what was expected of her. What surprised me the most in here was Grant. Never in my whole reading of BAIT did I imagine Grant would resort to that. But I guess, pain, and betrayal can push you off the edge. But hey, Blake came clean, she was finally honest about her feelings and was doing something about it.I simply adore Casey. Yep, he can be all alpha, protective and possessive of her, but he waited (or he did try his best) and proved to Blake that he was more than a good lover. He was also a great friend. He tried it slow, putting off temptation and showing her another side of him, and it worked.Their relationship grew, they grew as a person, as a couple and they were finally seeing the light at the end of the tunnel, but theres that certain twist that got my heart up on my throat. THAT COULDNT BE HAPPENING. NOT. NOW. Not when everything is almost perfect. Arggghhhh.This book was the perfect. I dreaded the start, but truly adored the ending. I couldnt stop reading, crossing both my fingers, praying that theyd finally have the happy ending they deserved and waited for. This proved that no one, or nothing can stop true love.

The sex was getting hotter, the emotions getting deeper, and the mystery is getting stronger. Hold on to your seats, because Cal and Macy are just getting started.Finally, someone realized that what they had was more than sex. The sex might have been crazy good, but the emotions are starting to creep in, and it was scaring someone, sure as heck not Cal. Now, he had just to prove to her that what they have is just more than gratifying their carnal desires.The sex was getting hotter, the emotions getting deeper, and the mystery is getting stronger. Hold on to your seats, because Cal and Macy are just getting started.Finally, someone realized that what they had was more than sex. The sex might have been crazy good, but the emotions are starting to creep in, and it was scaring someone, sure as heck not Cal. Now, he had just to prove to her that what they have is just more than gratifying their carnal desires.Can he break through her exteriors and make her trust him?Its refreshing to see a man speechless of a womans ummm, ability in bed. Macy has the power to break and make Cal. He was different from the rest of the men that she was ever been with. But would it be enough for her to spill out her secrets and risk her heart in the process?Its highly addicting, satisfying read that will make you pant, sweat and yearning for more.

They were trouble waiting to happen, I knew it, everyone that surrounds them knew it. I think they were the only one who were clueless of the situation. Both of them were too busy living inside their bubbles to care about anything else in the world.We have this old adage in our country: masarap ang bawal, which translates to: forbidden acts are more satisfying (or the like). Youd be hooked, until such time truth will slap you right in the face and youd be caught red handed.Im uncomfortable with the plot, and even though I love both Casey and Blake, I need to black out that thought that Blake was committed to a clueless man. Someone who was boring, but was good to her. I guess it would have been okay if Grant was cheating or if he was an a**, but no.She made some decisions that I hated, perhaps out of pressure, out of uncertainty, she wanted something that Casey could not give her. She did some things, made some decisions that was hard for me to swallow, and even she regretted it almost immediately.WHAT THE F*** ARE YOU DOING?  sums up my sentiment for this book. Putting that one itty-bitty fact aside  these two are clearly meant for each other. They were happy, and they are certainly at their best when they are together. Now, if only one of them were brave enough to stand up and fight for it.The events had me look forward for the second book, crossing my fingers, hoping this time both of them would be wiser, would be braver and would fight for their feelings, because, what they have may be forbidden, but it was certainly the most honest, unadulterated emotion in the world, and despite the initial uncomfortability they brought to my *coughs* delicate senses, I wished them the best.

I enjoyed the first book of this series #1 Crush, and I was excited to finally read the next book in this series. Real life had forced Nicole and Gabriel to part ways, nevertheless, it didnt stop them from communicating and meeting up every now and then.When a chance of them finally being together arrived, both of them grabbed it. For a while, they were happy. Nicole has some insecurities, but she never lets in the way, because Gabriel was always assuring her. But she couldnt help to feel that he was still keeping something from her.And that something was his past, something that he was not proud of, something he wished to bury, something he was afraid that Nicole couldnt understand or take. But it was something that was haunting him right now.One important thing about relationships is honesty. People who truly love you will accept even your darkest side, no judgment. But when you start to keep secrets, trust is compromise  it could get broken. Hearts could get broken, and relationships would crumble.CLOSER is hotter, sexier, mixed with some interesting characters that you will both love and hate. Like the first book, I finished this one in one sitting, and although the ending did break my heart, I couldnt wait for the next one in the series. Kaia Bennett, youre killing me with the sneak peek!

I've been using the Gerber Suspension multi-tool for several months, and recently picked up the Tekton as a cheap alternative to keep in my vehicle.  I thought comparing the two tools might be useful, since they are reasonably similar in design (see the photo I posted).  The Gerber currently costs 2-3 times as much as the Tekton, so this tool wins on value, assuming you can still get it for around ten bucks.  I think the construction of the Gerber is slightly better, though both tools feel sturdy and I think each will hold up to reasonable use.  The Tekton pliers are of good quality, and they are spring loaded.  Like the Gerber, the tool handles fold around the plier head, so that all tools can be accessed from the exterior of the handle while the tool is folded.  The knife blades and other tools on the Gerber lock in place, whereas the Tekton has no lock.  The lack of a locking mechanism on the Tekton is the tool's greatest shortcoming. You'll need to use care to avoid the blades folding onto your fingers.  Advantage, Gerber. The Gerber also comes with a nylon sheath, while this tool does not.As for the quality of the tools, they are pretty close.  Most tools are common to the two units, though the Gerber lacks a file and the Tekton lacks scissors.  The blades on both tools are reasonably sturdy.  The Gerber has a rather poor flattened phillips screwdriver, while the Tekton has a real phillips head, albeit a small one.  As for size, the handle of the Tekton is a bit shorter, which I consider a slight disadvantage, though the tool is almost as large as the Gerber.  The pliers on both tools are sturdy and provide wire cutters, and I have no trouble applying a strong grip to either tool. Both pliers have a needle-nose design, with the Gerber having a slightly more narrow plier tip.I find the Tekton to be a decent multi-tool that compares reasonably well with the lower end tools from mainstream brands like Gerber or Leatherman.  It's a solid choice for throwing into your toolbox or vehicle for occasional or emergency use.  If I were looking for a tool to use continuously, I would pass on the Tekton and buy a tool with locking blades. Overall, this is a solid 3 star tool that rounds up to 4 stars if you can buy it at a low price.

I really enjoy eating Bob's sugar free mints.  I would enjoy eating them more if I were able to remove the cellophane wrappers first. The cellophane attaches itself itself so tenaciously to the mint that I'm pretty sure the bond could survive a direct nuclear blast.  Hey Bob, just a bit more work on the packaging, please.

The product description is correct in saying that this book contains "enough minutiae of the space shuttle to enable, it seems, the building of one's own orbiter."  On technical matters, this book is brilliant.  It contains a depth of information about the shuttle that is probably unmatched anywhere else.  The printed information and diagrams are exhaustive, not just about the shuttle as it was built, but also about the dozens of proposals that came before the shuttle and influenced its design.  If a technical history is what you seek, you'll find none better than this book.Although I enjoyed this book, it bills itself as a complete history of the shuttle, not just a technical history. The real shortcoming of the book is its failure to examine the shuttle program critically. A 2012 Forbes article said that "criticizing the Space Shuttle is like punching America in the face."  While many people do have an instinctive need to defend the shuttle at all costs, the fact is that the shuttle was delivered years late and came with enormous cost overruns, limited capability, and multiple safety problems that were impossible to remedy.It's important to remember the promises NASA made for the shuttle. In the 1970s it was sold as a safe, extremely low cost, reliable means to access space on a weekly basis.  It would serve the needs of both commercial launch customers and the US military.  In short, it would be so cheap and versatile that it would make disposable rockets a relic of the past.  These promises turned out not just to be unrealistic, but unrealistic in the extreme. Just five years into operating a vehicle that endured for three decades, NASA found itself with a spacecraft that had killed seven astronauts, entered service years late, was exorbitantly expensive to develop and operate, was prohibited from launching commercial satellites, had been abandoned by the military, and had failed to outperform the expendable rockets it was designed to replace. Few technical programs could have survived after such an extreme turn of fortunes, but NASA doubled down with a brave face, and the program carried on. The circumstances of how NASA kept the shuttle going in the face of harsh realities is a story that really should be told.The people selling the shuttle in the 1970s were promising reliable access to space for the low, low price of $118 per pound of payload.  If Congress would just allocate a few billion dollars to develop this revolutionary vehicle, the extreme savings made possible with shuttle operations would pile up year after year. It all sounded great, but the promised per-pound cost of $118 per pound ended up being as high as $27,000 per pound. Shuttle launches that were projected to cost $12 million ended up costing well over $1 billion, a staggering sum of money for one launch to low earth orbit.  This book explains such discrepancies in terms like "estimates had been unrealistically low" (page 288).  That sentence deserves the lifetime achievement award for understatement.  Any way you look at the shuttle's performance on cost, it was a complete debacle. The shuttle failed to deliver on lots of other promises too. You get little sense of that reading this book, little explanation for why NASA's predictions were so tragically wrong. On topics such as these, the author's long association with United Space Alliance may be telling.  USA's bread was buttered on both sides by billons of shuttle dollars, which is a reasonable explanation for why the author goes out of his way to present a "go shuttle!" attitude while steadfastly avoiding asking unpleasant questions.I could give dozens of examples, but here are just a couple.  The book give the impression that NASA management had no idea that cold temperatures endangered the Challenger mission.  "No critical issues were identified to NASA or contractor management officials", the book claims (page 277). It's common knowledge that Larry Mulloy (NASA's manager of the SRB project for Marshall Space Flight Center) was on the phone the night before the Challenger launch, arguing with Thiokol management, pressuring for their support to launch against the advice of Thiokol's best SRB engineers. (How is Mulloy not considered part of NASA management?). If you look at the history of that conference call, NASA managers were clearly more concerned about maintaining shuttle flight schedules than they were about the safety questions raised. True, there probably were higher ups in NASA management who didn't know of the debate over the Challenger launch, but NASA's failure to coordinate and communicate the risk to Challenger across multiple levels of management was a big part of its failing. Donald J. Kutyna raised the issue in a very revealing manner at the Challenger review board hearings:  "If this were an airplane and I just had a two-hour argument with Boeing on whether the wing was going to fall off or not, I think I would tell the pilot, at least mention it."  The Challenger disaster was as much a failure of management as a technical failure, but in this book, the people managing shuttle come in for only the mildest of criticism, and that criticism is delivered very gently.  "The review board said these bad things about us".  The fact that poor NASA management later contributed to the Columbia disaster (another 7 astronauts killed) only confirms that the Challenger review board had gotten it right about NASA's poor management of the program.Similarly, the book takes an uncritical view of the shuttle's inherent design shortcomings. The shuttle was a vehicle with little to no margin for crew safety during critical times during both launch and landing. With shuttle, there were numerous failure modes that would spell certain death for the crew.  There was no practical way to quickly get the crew away from an exploding booster in time to save them, a capability that all previous NASA vehicles had. The shuttle was also susceptible to destruction on landing in a way that previous NASA spacecraft were not, as evidenced by the loss of Columbia.  The fact that NASA would build such a vehicle so dangerous when compared to previous spacecraft is presented uncritically. The shuttle might make a risky business much more dangerous than before, but this is a bold new vehicle and we must ride it. Really?In numerous instances, the author presents data that raises unpleasant questions, yet he refuses to acknowledge the obvious implications of the data. On page 246, the author says that NASA anticipated 581 shuttle flights over a 20 year period.  Later, he says NASA had determined through repetitive studies that an average of 2% of shuttle flights would end in catastrophic failure during launch, as well as an additional 1% that would fail on landing (page 281).  If NASA planned to fly nearly 600 shuttle missions, losing 3 shuttles for every 100 flights, does it not logically follow that they would necessarily lose 18 shuttles and crews to various disasters?  How would shuttle continue to fly with such a loss rate when NASA intended to build only 5 orbiters?  If they did anticipate losing 18 flights, why would they max out shuttle flights with crews of 7 astronauts per flight?  Did NASA actually consider it acceptable to lose 126 astronauts during the normal course of the shuttle program?  Clearly that seems wildly implausible, but as with so many things related to the shuttle, NASA's numbers were little more than fiction designed to sell the program to Congress.  It shouldn't be news to anyone that manned space flight will always involve risk to life, but why did NASA behave as it did for so many years?  Knowing that 3% of shuttle flights would fail, why would they promote shuttle flights as routine and safe, touting the advantages of safe, reliable "shirt sleeve" access to space?  Why recruit civilians like Christa McAuliffe (the first of many civilians intended to fly on shuttle) if they knew full well that 3% of those flights would end in disaster? Yet, the author never asks these questions. In a book of over 500 pages, clearly there was an opportunity to do so. But the approach here is matter of fact.  Space is hard and we always knew people would die (Go shuttle!).All in all, I found this book to be an unparalleled technical history, though one that lacks an honest evaluation of the shuttle's performance. It steadfastly avoids an realistic discussion of the ways in which the shuttle didn't live up to its promises, never asking what could have been accomplished with the $209 billion NASA spent on the shuttle, had they developed a more practical vehicle instead. While this book is excellent on technical details, readers would be well served by seeking other perspectives on the program that consider the failures of the program as well as it successes.  3.5 stars.

I picked up this bag a couple weeks ago from REI on end of season clearance. My first impressions are very good. The bag seems to be well made from quality fabrics and it has been comfortable. The reflective thermal lining is such a good idea I'm surprised I've not seen it before in other sleeping bags. The interior proportions are generous for a mummy bag. I'm a 5'10" male with a few extra pounds, and while it's not as roomy as a rectangle bag, I'll definitely be able to make it work.The best feature of this bag is its low weight and ability to compress tightly. While it's easy to find an inexpensive sleeping bag for car camping, finding a lightweight bag at this price point for backpacking is much more difficult. The Reactor 35 is almost as lightweight as expensive down bags, so it's a great option for backpackers on a budget. My bag wasn't quite as light as advertised. With the stuff sack, mine weighs 2.5 pounds. Still, it's quite a lightweight bag that packs up tight with the included stuff sack.As soon as it gets cool enough outside, I'll be testing the temperature rating and updating this review with those results. In the meantime, I find this to be a high quality bag worthy of consideration even at full price. If you can find one on sale, I think it's a no brainer.  4 stars.

I picked up this bag a couple weeks ago on clearance at REI.  My first impressions are good.  The bag seems to be well made from quality fabrics and it has been comfortable.  The reflective thermal lining is such a good idea I'm surprised I've not seen it before in other sleeping bags.  The interior proportions are generous for a mummy bag, though it's certainly not as roomy as a rectangle.  I'm a 5'10" male with a few extra pounds, and while it's not roomy, I can make it work.  If you're thin, you'll love the proportions.The best feature of this bag is its low weight and ability to compress tightly.  While it's easy to find an inexpensive sleeping bag for car camping, finding a lightweight bag at this price point for backpacking is much more difficult.  The Reactor 35 is almost as lightweight as expensive down bags, so it's a great option for backpackers on a budget.  My bag wasn't quite as light as advertised.  With the stuff sack, mine weighs 2.5 pounds.  Still, it's quite a lightweight bag that packs up tight with the included stuff sack.As for the temperature rating, I had the same experience with this bag that I've had with other lightweight models. My only excursion so far was on a mild night with lows around 50.  Should be no challenge for a 35 degree bag, right?  Overall, the bag was warm.  However, under my bottom where the bag was most compressed, I felt cold coming in early in the night and had difficulty sleeping.  A fleece jacket added under the bag remedied that problem quickly, but again, it wasn't a cold night.  Be aware that this can be a problem with many lightweight bags, and be prepared to supplement the bag with extra insulation as needed.  I will update this review after I've had more experience with the bag.Overall, a good bag that makes some compromises in insulation to achieve low weight.

After spending some time using the $100 tactical light my friend bought for his semi-automatic pistol, I decided to shop around for one of my own.  When I saw this budget option on Amazon, I didn't expect a lot considering the low price.  After giving it at try, I was surprised to find this light is really well made and works well.  In some ways, I actually prefer it to my friend's more expensive light.  It doesn't have any bells and whistles, just an on/off switch and a sturdy clip to attach it to the accessory rail.  But, I prefer simplicity on a self defense item like this.Unlike some lights that have a screw mechanism that tightens onto the gun, this one has a spring loaded hinge that snaps into a notch on the rail to keep the light in place. I prefer this setup, as I think it will do less damage to the gun frame.For what it's worth, this light fits great on the Smith & Wesson SD9VE and SD40VE.  That pistol is similar in size to the full size M&P, so it should work well on the M&P as well.  Even though I have a full size pistol, I prefer my light to be as small as possible and this one fits the bill perfectly.  (See the photo section for my photo of it installed on the S&W SD9VE).A good light at a great price.  Don't hesitate to give it a try.

I've been using this stove for about a year now.  It's a heavy, well-made burner best suited for car camping where size and weight are not big concerns.  For backpacking, you'd do well to explore one of many other stove options that are much lighter in weight. One major advantage of this burner is the low cost and wide availability of the 16 oz. propane canisters that power it. You get far more bang for your buck with this stove, as compared to stoves using the smaller isobutane canisters. At my local big box store, a 16 oz propane canister costs about $2.50, whereas an 8 oz. isobutane fuel canister costs $5.  Twice the fuel for half the cost is never a bad thing. In addition to being inexpensive, propane canisters last a long time and are widely available at retail stores and campgrounds.Lighting this burner is easy. There is no pumping or prep as the fuel is already pressurized in the tank.  Simply turn the knob to release the gas and provide a spark, and you're cooking instantly. The simplicity of this burner also has advantages in reliability. As far as cooking performance goes, this stove excels at any cooking task that requires a high flame.  Boiling water and warming liquids is a breeze.One downside to this stove is that while it does have multiple flame settings, it doesn't have one that I would describe as truly low.  If you're cooking foods that are prone to sticking or burning on thin camping cookware, you may find that this stove burns too hot, even on the lowest setting.  A couple times I've made pancakes on camping trips, and I had to hold my pan in the air above the stove to avoid burning, even on low.  It hasn't been a problem on most foods, but the lack of a very low setting can be an issue here and there. Other than that, this is an inexpensive, reliable, and well-made burner that works great in the outdoors. If simmering or low-flame performance is a must for you, I might pass on this stove. Otherwise, it performs well at a low cost.

This price of this cup set seemed too good to be true, but I decided to take a chance and find out for myself. Having used this set for a few weeks, I find the cups to be decently well made. The handles may not be tough enough to withstand real abuse, but I think they will be durable with reasonable care. This set would be right at home in a commercial kitchen, and is of better quality than most of the cup sets you'll find in big box stores. You could definitely buy a more refined cup set for four times the price, but these measuring cups are a great value for those who appreciate decent quality without breaking the bank. 4 stars.

Having heard some good feedback on the larger XM spork, I decided to try it.  Unfortunately, the seller shipped this smaller "original" spork instead.  Although I like the basic design, I found this spork to be a bit too small and more importantly, quite flimsy. If you're going to replace two eating utensils with one, you need to be able to trust the one. I have no confidence that this spork will last when I'm miles down a trail and this is my only utensil.  Numerous reports of breakage here confirm my suspicion that it won't stand up to frequent use. I'm going back to my TOAKS titanium spork, a utensil that works great and can take whatever abuse the trail dishes out. Alternately, I would prefer the cheap but sturdy plastic camping utensils sold at Wal-mart (and everywhere else).

I've been using the Toaks titanium spork for a while, so when I needed another I thought it would be a good opportunity to compare to the Snow Peak.  Overall, both are very good utensils.  The spoon is slightly larger on the snow peak, and the tines are a little longer and more prominent.  Advantage, Snow Peak.  But...the Toaks spork has a larger handle that is textured, which improves grip and feels better in the hand.  Advantage, Toaks.  (See the photos I uploaded).  Both seem very strong, so it really comes down to personal choice.  After having used both, I have a slight preference for the Toaks.  But in fairness, both come pretty close to spork perfection.  4 stars.

This review refers to the chili mac variety. For shelf stable backpacking food, you could do a lot worse.  Just add 2 cups boiling water, stir, and wait 8-9 minutes.  For the most part, the product reconstitutes well and you can't tell it was freeze dried.  I find that lots of stirring is the key to making sure all the product reconstitutes as it should and there are no crunchy bits.  The meal was tasty enough that I didn't mind eating it at home, which means it's going to be very popular after a long day on the trail.  I also tried the beef stroganoff version and found it pretty tasty, if perhaps a little heavy on noodles and light on beef.As far as portion size, one pouch will feed two people who aren't very hungry, or one who is.  An adult male who's been hiking all day will probably want his own pouch.  For what it's worth, these meals really stand out for backpacking because of their very light weight, durability, and the fact that they leave no dirty dishes behind.  If I were car camping with a big cooler and weight was not a concern, I wouldn't buy freeze dried meals since you could make more tasty dishes with "real" food.  But for their intended purpose, these meals work well. Of course, they also work well for emergency stockpiles, since they have usable shelf lives of many, many years. Good product.

In preparation for an upcoming outdoor trip, I recently tried the Mountain House Freeze Dried chili mac.  For backpacking food, you could do a lot worse.  Just add 2 cups boiling water, stir, and wait 8-9 minutes.  For the most part, the product reconstitutes very well and you can't tell it was freeze dried.  I could detect the slightest crunch in the noodles, but it was extremely faint.  The meal was tasty enough that I didn't mind eating it at home, which means I expect it to be really delicious after a long day on the trail.  As far as portion size, I believe one pouch will feed two people who aren't very hungry, or one who is.  A guy who's been hiking all day will definitely want his own pouch.  For what it's worth, these meals really stand out for backpacking because of their very light weight, durability, and the fact that they leave almost no dirty dishes behind.  If I were car camping where weight was not a concern, a big can of soup or chili might be a better value.  But overall, I am pretty impressed.  Recommended.

I've found this to be a good quality hammock stand for the money.  Having a 10 foot hammock, I originally bought both the 12' version of this stand, but found it to be a bit too small and almost unworkable for a 10' hammock.  I returned the smaller stand and replaced it with this one.  The 15' stand is more substantial in every respect and has a higher weight rating.  It is really built for 2 people, whereas the 12' version seems built for one.  If you're uncertain which to get, choose the larger stand.  It's easy to manage a stand that's a bit too large for your hammock, but very difficult make a too small stand work properly.  I was also pleasantly surprised that the stand will easily break apart for transportation or storage.I would agree with other reviewers that Algoma ships this stand in a box that's too flimsy considering its considerable weight.  My stand arrived with the box all torn up, but the stand was undamaged except for one broken plastic end cap.  All in all, this is a good stand that I believe will hold up to regular outdoor use.

This film gives basic information about the early US and Soviet space programs, but it perpetuates old conspiracy theories that are now discredited.  For example, the film claims that Vladimir Ilyushin preceded Yuri Gagarin into space, but was so injured during the mission that his flight was kept secret.  Though that might have been a plausible theory decades ago when the Soviet program was shrouded in secrecy, we now know a lot about the early cosmonauts, including the ones who were injured or killed. Ilyushin isn't among them, and there is no evidence that this supposed flight ever happened. I suspect this film was originally produced years ago during the Cold War, then recycled recently for digital distribution. That could account for some of the egregious errors this film contains.  Bottom line, the film has some interesting footage from the dawn of the space age, but take the commentary with a very large grain of salt.

Unboxing this bag, I was impressed with the quality and materials.  I love the size of the bag and the feel of the fabrics. It seems to be very well made and I love that this isn't a confining mummy bag. The bag is soft and comfortable, but it's also a pretty thin bag that's not very lofty.  Down is expensive and Kelty certainly didn't use any more than it had to. The lack of loft doesn't bother me too much, as long as the bag is warm.I have taken it camping only once, on a night where the low was about 45, and had mixed results. I was sleeping in a tent with a polyethelene tarp underneath for a ground cloth.  I also had a cheap inflatable mattress underneath that's about 3" thick but provides no insulation other than air.  Around midnight I felt cold coming from the ground in the spots where the down was compressed, like under my bottom.  When I first felt the cold spots, I checked the temperature: 48 degrees.  Those cold spots were present until I stuffed some clothes under the bag for extra insulation. During the night I never felt cold coming from the top of the bag or the foot area, just underneath where the down was compressed.Based on my one experience, I have mixed feelings about this bag.  My theory is that if you slept on a good insulator (like a thermarest foam pad), this bag might keep you warm to its rated temperature. However, if you throw this bag onto the cold ground, you're probably going to get cold long before the thermometer reaches 30. I'm tempted to return it and look for a bag with more fill, but it's not terribly easy to find down rectangle bags. I will probably give it one more go with a good pad and see how it performs. I will update my review after I've done so.

These spoons are made from heavy stainless steel, not the thin metal you'll find in many big box stores. Each spoon is made from a single metal blank, so there's no weld between handle and spoon. I expect these to be quite durable. They would be right at home in a commercial kitchen.  There is little smoothing to the edges, so the spoons feel slightly rough in the hand. I have no issue with the finish, but if you expect a very smooth feel you might want to look elsewhere.  If you're the handy type, I think a few minutes of polishing with sandpaper would improve these spoons. A solid set and good value.

I decided to try this spork in an effort to reduce my pack weight for backpacking. Having used it several times now, I am sold.  The TOAKS spork functions very well and feels like you're eating with a normal utensil, not a specialty utensil that's awkward.  It is also quite strong and weighs almost nothing.  The tines work well for picking up food in fork mode, though retention on any spork isn't quite as good as a real fork.  I have no problems stabbing myself with the tines while eating, as you can do on some sporks.  I prefer this to plastic sporks (Light My Fire, etc), because barring some heroic effort, you're not going to break this one.  The length is also good and the metal is very well finished.  I also enjoy the simplicity of packing only one eating utensil on any trip.I recently got a chance to compare this spork to the Snow Peak titanium spork. Overall, both are good utensils. The spoon is slightly larger on the Snow Peak, and the tines are a little longer and more prominent. Advantage, Snow Peak. But, the Toaks spork has a larger handle that is textured, which improves grip and feels better in the hand. Advantage, Toaks. (See the photo I uploaded). Both seem very strong, so it really comes down to personal choice. After having used both, I still prefer the Toaks spork.  It comes pretty close to spork perfection. Five stars, recommended.

First off, accurate specs are hard to come by on the 96 oz. bottle.  Mine weighs in at exactly 2.9 ounces.  For comparison, a conventional 1 quart (32 oz) Nalgene bottle weighs 6.2 ounces.  So this bottle carries 3 times the water for less than half the weight.  Impressive.So far, I have found these bags to be tough and reliable. I love the wide mouth setup and the fact that the bottle collapses as needed.  The 96 ounce size is probably overkill for the average hiker, but I like having the capability to carry a large quantity of water without having to carry a heavy container.  It's also handy for filling up in the evenings for camp use. At some point I'll probably pick up the 48 oz. bottle too, for shorter excursions. At any rate, it's a good product. Recommended.

I had originally considered a $50 name brand hammock, until I came across this cheap hammock with good reviews.  I ordered the base hammock for ten bucks without the tree hardware.  These kinds of hammocks are pretty simple in construction, and my initial impressions are quite good. The hammock seems well made, and easily packs up tightly in a small stuff sack sewn into the side.  Fabric is thin but feels strong.  It feels silky, like parachute material.  There are no tags on the hammock showing the actual fabric or fabric weight.  There is single stitching along the sides of the hammock, and triple stitching on the ends that bear weight.Speaking of weight, specs are pretty hard to find on this item.  My complete hammock in the pouch weighs exactly 14.4 ounces.  That includes two heavy steel carbiners on each end that weigh 1.4 ounces each.  Backpackers who are serious about weight reduction could replace the steel hardware with rope and shave another couple ounces off.  (See the photos I uploaded for a better idea of how the hammock is made).Overall, I believe this hammock is a bargain.  I saw a very similar hammock on the shelf at Wal-mart this week for $25 plus tax, and the $50+ hammocks I've seen on Amazon are very similar.  For the price, it's a no  brainer.

I've found Lifestraw to be a very good product that has changed the way I hike.  I can now hike long distances without having to carry large quantities of water.  Last weekend, I hiked all day and never carried more than 16 oz. of water with me.  The rest of the day I used my Lifestraw to drink from creeks and streams.  Obviously, this only works in areas where I know there will be natural water sources, but most places I hike fit the bill.  This is both a convenience and a big weight savings.  The product is ridiculously easy to use and it doesn't use charcoal, so there's nothing to leech into the water.For what it's worth, it's easier to drink out of a container than to lie on the ground over a stream, so I usually pack along a disposable red Solo cup that weighs nearly nothing.  Fill up the cup with creek water, and use the straw to drink from the cup.The one shortcoming of lifestraw is the word "personal" in the name.  There is no way to filter water into a container other than your mouth.  You can store dirty water in a bottle and filter it as needed for drinking, but if you need to filter water for food or some other purpose, you're pretty much out of luck.  If that's a requirement for you, I would consider the Sawyer Mini water filter, which costs about the same as Lifestraw.  The Sawyer is similar in concept, but has a bit more flexibility.A very good product that I recommend.

I bought this bed just over three years ago.  It has been a great purchase.  It is quite comfortable, and has been trouble free.  During that time it has had moderate use.  We have had guests sleep on it at home, have taken it on trips where we were a bed short, and have loaned it out for friends' trips to the beach.  It has gained the reputation of being more comfortable than hotel and condo beds.  Over the fall we took it camping for the first time, and I slept far more comfortably than any previous camping trip. The bed lost only a small amount of air over two full nights loaded with two adults.  The built in pump is probably the best feature.  Just flip a switch and the mattress will inflate or deflate. Even with a slow leak, the mattress would be pretty usable considering the ease of adding extra air.  Obviously any air mattress can develop leaks and some people will get a bad mattress.  But considering how comfortable it is and Amazon's easy returns, I have no problem recommending it.

My pet peeve is a computer that drones loudly under the desk all day, so noise is usually my biggest concern in a new power supply.  I installed this one in my desktop a few weeks ago and I'm happy to report it is as quiet as before.  Recommended.

This light is inexpensive, works well, and consumes very little energy.  It is about as bright as a traditional bulb night light.  Emits enough light to navigate a medium sized room with no other light source.  The automatic on/off switch works fairly well, though it may stay on in low to medium light conditions.  It is also fairly green, consuming about 90% less energy than a traditional night light with an incandescent bulb.  Using national average rates for electricity, you can operate one of these lights 24/7 for an entire year for about 50 cents.  Recommended.  If you need an extra bright, low power light, check out the Maxxima MLN-50.

These lights work okay to guide you along a dark path such as a hallway.  They should not be confused with night lights, however, and GE should not label them as such.  While the lights themselves are visible in a dark room, they project little to no light onto the floor or surrounding objects.  Pretty much unusable as a night light.  Good for travelers who might wake up in unfamiliar surroundings but don't want the room illuminated.  The very low power consumption (.25 watts) is a good feature.  If you want a more traditional night light that gives off good light while still consuming low power, check out the Leviton 48561 series or the very bright Maxxima MLN-50.

These bulbs worked great for me.  I previously had a regular 60 watt white bulb outside, and I couldn't make it through the doorway onto my deck without getting a swarm of insects in my face.  These bulbs have made a drastic difference.  The number of insects swarming the light fixture has gone from hundreds to only a small handful, a huge improvement.  For what it's worth, you can buy a two-pack of these bulbs off the shelf at walmart for under three bucks.

Overall, this is a great, inexpensive item.  The mallet is appropriately heavy and does a great job on steaks.  Unlike the metal tenderizers, it is also dishwasher safe, so you can throw it into the machine and not worry about the finish falling off.  (I chose this one because like the idea of having a mallet that can be easily sanitized after coming in contact with raw meat.)  Feels sturdy and quite heavy, as it should be.  As a very amateur grillmaster, I've long been curious why cheap cuts of steak at restaurants are always juicy and tender, while the ones I grill at home emerge with all the tenderness of an old boot.  Marinades and tenderizers didn't help much, but now I think I've figured it out.  I used this mallet for the first time this week, and my steaks came off the grill noticeably more tender and juicy than before. Simply cover your steaks with cling wrap on both sides and give them a good whacking with the flat side of the mallet.  Then marinade as you like and proceed as usual.  I think you'll notice the difference.  Five stars for an inexpensive but eminently useful kitchen tool.

I bought this attachment to take care of thick vines that had overgrown a piece of property I recently bought.  It snapped onto my Troy-Bilt TB20CS trimmer without a hitch.  The blade is very effective against briars and other tough vines.  It should be noted that this attachment does not cut ordinary grass particularly well.  You're better off using the normal string head for that.  But for heavy work, it does the job admirably.  I find that it will take down small trees up to about .75" to 1 inch diameter with ease. This is not an attachment to use near fences or other objects you intend to leave undamaged.  The action is not unlike a circular saw.  As for durability, the blade is quite sturdy and I expect it to last a long while.

Pouring a walkmaker sidewalk looks like a very easy project, but don't forget that mixing hundreds of pounds of concrete will always involve a good deal of work.  I'm fairly happy with my results, but I wish I'd known a few things before I began the project.  Here are a few tips.First, the mold is available off the shelf at some Lowe's stores for a lower price.  I was able to check availability on their website.  It seems some stores carry it and others don't.Second, the mold will not accept 80 pounds of concrete as recommended.  I bought 60 pound bags(cheaper) and then added 1/3 of another 60 lb. bag to get up to 80 pounds.  When I was finished pouring 4 molds, I was surprised to find that I had used only about 60 lbs of mix per mold. It never hurts to have an extra bag lying around if you run short, but I would use 60 lb. bags.  The 60 lb. bags are also plenty heavy without adding another 20 pounds.Don't be afraid to use a bit more water than is recommended.  I used the minimum amount of water and the mix was dry and hard to work with.  In retrospect, I should have added more water. About 3 quarts per 60 lb. bag works well and is still within Quikrete's guidelines.When pouring, it is very easy to spill new concrete onto the adjoining mold that you've just finished.  You learn to fill subsequent molds very carefully to avoid this problem.  One reviewer here recommended spraying the mold with cooking spray to avoid sticking.  I did that before I began my first pour, and I found it worked great.  Even after working with the mold for over 3 hours, the cooking spray remained.  Pulling the mold up after filling was very simple.One word about the Quikrete cement color.  You can use somewhat less coloring agent if you like.  I divided one bottle among four 60lb bags (not two as instructed) and while the end result is more gray than black, I am happy with my results. (Charcoal color).  I used a 1/4 cup measuring cup to get the same amount in each batch, and still had some color agent left over at the end.  It's your walkway, so don't hesitate to experiment.This is a project where you'll get better as you go.  If you are doing multiple pours, do your first mold someplace where imperfections will be less obvious.  I'd practice once behind the shed before I poured next to the front door.I should note that using this form alone results not in a sidewalk, but in a series of individual pavers. I assumed the "stones" would connect.  They do not, though one person who commented on this review says there is a way to connect them.  (See comments).  If you don't follow that second step, grass will crop up between the stones and they can also lay unevenly when the ground settles.  It took about two weeks for grass to appear in my walk.  The walkmaker is an inexpensive alternative to a poured sidewalk.  But as such, it is definitely a compromise.Finally, don't forget to water cure your new concrete when finished.  Quikrete says the surface should be sprayed with water for 5-7 days to achieve full strength. Covering the walk with a tarp or plastic sheet also helps to keep moisture in while it cures.

My stock Ruger LCP always felt like a toy in my hand because its grip is not only small but also slippery.  With this accessory that problem is solved.  The Hogue grip literally transforms the gun.  It adds thickness to the grip and is also quite sticky.  For the first time, my tiny .380 feels almost like a real gun in the hand.  The fit is exceptional. I got mine at MidwayUSA where the price was even lower than here.  Probably the best accessory out there for the Ruger LCP.  Recommended.

For the price, I'm quite pleased with this necklace.  I'm always suspicious of jewelry ordered online, but with Amazon I knew I could return it if the quality was poor.  When it arrived I inspected it with a jeweler's loupe and couldn't really find any substantial flaws. The pendant is beautiful, large, clear and sparkly.  To my untrained eye it looks more like real jewelry and less like costume jewelry.  The wife also seemed impressed, which is really all that matters. The chain is just adequate, but at this price level that's what I expected.  For what it's worth, the back of the pendant is very rounded, so it does tend to turn slightly to the side.  Not a big deal, but something to be aware of.  If you need a better idea of scale, see the customer image I submitted to Amazon.  The pendant appears about the size of a quarter. This item is also available with a clear stone, but I love the blue.  Overall, a good buy that will be a great buy if it holds up over time.

I picked up this vacuum over two years ago at my local Walmart for 46 bucks.  Although there were few reviews on Amazon at the time, the other store's website has over 500 user reviews that are mostly positive.  For the minimal price paid, it's been a really good vacuum. It is better constructed than I would expect, and I am very pleased with the job it's done on my carpets. It uses no bags, a long-term money saver.  You can see the collected dirt swirling in the transparent collection chamber as you vacuum. My old vacuum would clog up frequently, so it's nice to be able to see the unit working without stopping and removing a bag.  One possible downside to this system is the fact that you must clean the washable filters on this vacuum for it to work properly.  I count 4 filters, so you will need to spend some time maintaining this vacuum.My only real complaint is that the handle seems slightly short. It feels as if I have to reach a little farther than I do with other models.  This could just be my perception, and it doesn't pose a major problem.  If I were six feet tall or more, I would want to compare this vacuum's physical height to others before buying. My vacuum came with a one year warranty from Bissell, which is more than you'll find on a lot of consumer products.  No, it's not a Dyson, but for a budget vacuum it does a good job.

A very thorough analysis of the myriad executive orders and pieces of legislation that govern trade relations between the U.S. and Iran.  I found Katzman's book to be the best reference available for navigating the confusing web of regulations put in place over a period of more than thirty years.  I recommend it.

First of all, looking through the reviews and comments, it is fairly apparent that the author monitors the reviews of this book and upvotes/downvotes legitimate reviews posted here in order to support sales of his book.  I recommend reading through all the reviews here before making a purchase decision and take the "helpful" vote with a grain of salt on this title.This self-published "book" contains surprisingly little real content, for a book described as 148 pages.  Chapter 1 begins on page 17 and the last chapter ends on page 93.  Describing 76 actual pages as 148 is a real stretch.  The 76 actual pages are printed in huge typeface that reminds me of a large print edition for the visually impaired.  If this book were printed in a standard font, I suspect there would be no more than 50 pages of usable material.  About 20 pages of the book are nothing more than the same form (of very dubious value) duplicated over and over again.  Really?  Was the goal of this book to reduce stress on the local copy machine?  Like a college freshman writing his first research paper, the author has pulled all the stops to make this book appear far more substantial than it is.  Those expecting a full length book for their money will be disappointed by these shenanigans.From a more practical standpoint, my experience in the industry convinces me that most people need professional representation when applying for Social Security disability, especially in cases that are denied at the initial level and later proceed to the hearing level.  If you do decide to represent yourself, there are lots of websites dedicated to SSDI that cover this material in much greater detail with more current information, at no charge. Disability Secrets, published by NOLO, is one very useful website, though there are many others.

One reviewer advises not to use screens because the pizza will stick and then is ruined, etc. Not so. Screens are a great way to bake pizza, as evidenced by the fact that most major pizza chains use them. Your local Domino's or Papa Johns cooks dozens (sometimes hundreds) of pizzas per hour on screens.  If they all stuck they wouldn't be in business long.  Screens stick very rarely when prepped properly.A new screen has to be coated in cooking spray and baked in a hot oven several times before it is ready for use.  The more you treat a screen before first use, the less problem you will have once you start baking pizza.  It's a bit of an inconvenience with new screens, but it only has to be done once.After a few treatments, the cooking spray will bake on and the screen will start to turn a coppery brown color.  When you get this dark coloration on the aluminum, the screen is ready for use.  The screen should come with prep instructions.  It's also best not to wash screens, as this can lead to sticking.  Pizza places don't wash screens.  You can dust the screen with a brush to remove crumbs, etc, then bake it in an oven to sanitize the surface.
