I bought this humidifer about three years ago at Walgreens, which carries the identical Sunbeam unit labeled with their store brand.  This unit is very inexpensive, requires no filter, and I've had great results with it. It will literally blow a cloud of steam four feet into the air, which is much better than most other humidifers I've tried.  That said, it is important to note that these units are a little finicky.  They will often require a pinch of salt be added to the water in order to produce steam, especially for the first couple uses.  Also, the unit will last longer if the heating element is removed from the water when not in use.  The vaporizer has metal plates that extend into the water tank and heat up to boil water into steam.  Over time the plates can rust and eventually the unit will fail.  Allowing the plates to dry out when not in use should reduce their tendency to rust somewhat.  I have mine for several years and it still works great. I love mine, especially compared to others out there I've tried.  A big help during both flu and allergy seasons.

Before buying this new Venture HC, I had spent many hours trekking with several of the original eTrex models over the years.  I think it's fair to say that while the concept of the original eTrex was great, the execution was frequently disappointing.It disappoints no more.  The Venture HC is the eTrex perfected.  It remedies almost every shortcoming that plagued the original models.  The new high-sensitivity receiver is amazingly effective.  Countless times I've stood in wide open spaces cursing my old eTrex because it wouldn't acquire a single satellite.  Last night I turned on the Venture HC on the bottom floor of my two story house, and it locked onto 8 satellites...through the roof and the upper floor!  No more "need a clear view of the sky" messages. Amazing.The old monochrome display has become color, and the user interface is now substantially more intuitive, while adding even more functionality. The cable, which was serial on previous models, has been upgraded to USB, another welcome improvement.  The case is somewhat wider than before, but the design bears a strong resemblance to the original eTrex.A basemap is included but it's just that - basic.  It shows the largest highways, bodies of water, and has some limited capability to display highway exit services.  If you need turn-by-turn street directions, an eTrex is not for you.  This is a GPS receiver true to Garmin's outdoor GPS heritage.Promised battery life (14 hours) is near the bottom of the range when compared to the existing eTrex models, but is still perfectly adequate and has posed no problems.One weakness that remains is Garmin's waypoint manager PC software.  It has the feel and functionality of a software product released circa 1994.  Garmin could certainly develop a better PC interface.  For $75 you can buy ExpertGPS from Topografix, or download the free version (EasyGPS) from their website. I use the free version and it meets my needs very well.  Either is far more functional than the Garmin OEM software.Still, the software criticism is a quibble.  The Venture HC itself is great.  It is a market changing product that renders all previous eTrex models (and many competitors) obsolete.  Finally, an affordable outdoor GPS receiver that I can wholeheartedly recommend.

I've owned the original eTrex, two different eTrex Legends, and the high-sensitivity Venture HC.  This Legend adds some functionality to the old (basic) eTrex such as basic maps and longer waypoint names, but is obsolete when compared to Garmin's new high sensitivity eTrex models.The problem I have had with both my eTrex Legends is signal acquisition.  Both Legends have had a problem acquiring and keeping signal even in wide open places with a perfect view of the sky.  At times, it simply refuses to find any satellite at all.  At first, I thought I had a faulty unit.  But my second Legend has the exact same problem.  More than once I've had the Legend fail me at a crucial time when I really needed it to work. It's pretty frustrating. I never had this problem with the original eTrex, or the Venture HC.Overall, this has been a device that is great in concept, but very disappointing in reality.  I would strongly recommend skipping this unit and buying the eTrex Venture HC or another newer model with the high sensitivity receiver.  The HC has great signal performance, even in rough terrain.  It has a color screen, basemap, long name support, and sells for about the same price. I think you'll find the difference in performance to be night and day.

I received my frame today and have been playing with it a couple hours.  There seem to be a lot of widely divergent opinions here, so I'll attempt to bridge the gap between the two sides.  The frame is made of plastic, but is sufficiently attractive.  It does not have that inferior quality, sold-only-on-TV look.  It could be confused with wood from a distance, which is good.  The frame didn't immediately recognize my SD card, but I popped it out and then back in, and it worked fine.  The user interface is pretty clunky, but not so bad as to be infuriating like a cheap digital watch.  After a quick look at the user manual and five minutes playing with the frame, I could make it do what I wanted.The main area I was concerned about is picture quality.  The resolution is fairly low - 480 x 234, which is pretty standard at this price point.  This is a device clearly aimed at mainstream consumers - proud grandmas and the like.  If you are a camera snob you should probably look elsewhere.  This should be obvious, but it bears repeating.  Your images are *not* going to look as good as they do even on an LCD computer monitor.That said, most of my decent quality images look decent.  Keep in mind this is a 16:9 wide ratio display.  I put a couple images on the frame that were shot vertically, forcing the frame to shrink them substantially to make them fit.  These shots looked pretty bad, and I ended up deleting them from the memory card.  I also had one shot that was slightly out of focus.  It looks okay on my computer, but looked pretty bad on the frame.  Garbage in, garbage out definitely applies here.  If your pics are shot with an inferior camera or they have other flaws, their bad points will most likely be magnified by this frame.With the bad photos deleted, the ones I left on the frame ended up looking pretty good.  Just don't be surprised if you can't get all your images to look their best.  If you want your "wow" photos to wow others, you might want to spend a bit more money.  But if you start with good looking images and just want something to set on your desk at work, this should be adequate.  For the minimal price, I consider the frame good if not great; a reasonable choice for those with reasonable expectations.

I was aware of this film's poor reviews going in, but it's George Clooney - how bad can it be?  Well, pretty bad.  I could forgive the self-righteousness of this film, but not the mess that is the screenplay.  I spent the first hour wondering when the disjointed plot elements would come together, and the second half realizing they probably never would.  To compare this movie to Traffic is a flattery it does not deserve.  Basically what you get is a rather confused propaganda piece that can be summed up this way:  US government: bad.  Oil companies:  extra, extra bad.  Clearly, Mr. Clooney the politician got ahead of Mr. Clooney the actor on this one.

I heard Taubman touting Secret Empire on NPR and was expecting a really good book. Nevertheless, the book disappointed me.  Although it does contain some useful background material on US reconnaissance efforts in the 1950s, I thought the book contained perhaps one hundred pages of interesting material interspersed with over three hundred pages of dull banter about bureaucratic turf battles, tedious personnel background info, and other tiresome and uninteresting detail.  Oddly, what I felt were the most compelling stories often got short shrift. The development of the SR-71 Blackbird, for example, merits only a couple pages.  The U2 spy plane's remarkable operations over Cuba received only a brief mention.  I find it unseemly that this book would skip over the most remarkable parts of U.S. spy activity in those years.I was also caught off guard by the non-chronological format of the book. Taubman will spend an entire chapter discussing the United States' utter inability to get a reconnaissance satellite into orbit, then a few pages later he will jump to another subject in another decade, casually referring to an entire constellation of advanced US spy satellites.  Wait, where did those come from?  I couldn't help but think that the subjects were portrayed in a hit or miss fashion, and perhaps I had missed the best parts.Finally, the terrorism add-on at the end of the book seems like a half-hearted attempt to make the book more relevant in the post 9/11 world.

This is a very amusing and enjoyable Nero Wolfe novel in which the fat detective is asked by a board of publishers to investigate a case of what he calls "plagiarism in reverse." That is, instead of unknown authors stealing from well-known authors, it's four well-known authors who are accused, one at a time, of stealing from unknown authors. Though the famous authors deny it, the facts make it look as if they did it.Wolfe studies the plagiarized manuscripts and concludes, from style and syntax, that they were all written by the same person. He also tries to bribe each of the four unknown authors (who successfully sued for damages) to reveal who put them up to this. The result: a first murder, a second murder, and a third murder. Wolfe is so upset by the murders that are a result of his "bungling" the case that he refuses to drink any more beer until he solves everything. Fritz is distraught, but Nero is adamant (about the beer).A wonderful read.

This book does not live up to its title. It's not so much about HOW to write a poem, but rather about WHERE poems come from -- which part of our life experiences do we remember and tap into in order to produce poetry. So if you're expecting this to be about HOW, you will be disappointed. Prelutsky writes perhaps twenty chapters about his personal experiences, and after each chapter is the poem that came from that experience. Included in this mix are sidebars called Writing Tips that define things such as "Voice" or "Rhythm." The poems might be funny if presented alone, but when they come after a chapter that details the experience, the poems seem flat. What might have been funny if it was fresh is no longer funny. Still, teachers might want to use portions of this book to encourage students to write poetry.

My only complaint about this beautiful book is that it stops at the year 1970! I would love the book even more if it discussed Inuit art up to and including, say, 1995. (The book was published in 1999.) As it is, though, the artists covered and the photographs of their pieces are uniformly wonderful. You can almost feel the stone, and you can certainly feel the power of the art.

This book and writer were recommended to me by a friend who knows I love mysteries. Unfortunately, I had an extremely difficult, almost impossible, time reading this book for the simple reason that I could not believe the events that occurred, starting with the fact that the Montreal police simply let Dr. Tempe Brennan, forensic anthropologist (as well as a "foreigner" from North Carolina, USA), attend the scenes of crimes as if she were a member of the police force. And then she goes off investigating on her own, too. I really needed the author to work harder to make this whole set-up believable.

In this, the fifth Cadfael novel, the beautiful and wealthy Iveta de Massard, who loves a young squire named Joscelin Lucy, is forced into an arranged marriage with the old and cruel Huon de Domville. But before the marriage can take place, Domville is murdered: strangled to death by a man who wore a ring. Cadfael recognizes the marks of a ring on the neck of Domville. Joscelin is accused, but, as is typical in a Cadfael novel, is arrested, escapes, is hidden by those sympathetic to his cause, tries to flee with Iveta, and is caught again. Then Iveta's legal guardian is strangled. This time Cadfael notices that the strangler was missing a few fingers, and that reveals to him who the murderer was. A well-plotted mystery with a touching ending.

This is a wonderful guide to Colorado mountain passes. For explorers on foot or in vehicle, the author offers all the necessary information on distance, elevation. level of difficulty, side roads, scenic views, and historic interests. For armchair enjoyers of such information, the photos are fantastic (both current-day and historical), and the information on each mountain pass is absorbing. Highly recommended.

This is a sweet story about third-grader Amber Brown, whose best friend Justin Daniels is moving to Alabama with his family. Because the two kids can't express their feelings about losing each other, they quarrel and then don't talk to each other. At the end, they make up. A quick read with sympathetic characters, but nothing unexpected or surprising in the plot.

First, I enjoyed this novel very much: I think it's one of Smith's finest. Second, I found myself asking, "What Limpopo Academy of Private Detection? There's no Limpopo Academy of Private Detection in this book." I asked myself that question about a third of the way through the book, half way through, three-quarters of the way through . . . why did this book bear the title it has? Finally, in perhaps the last 10 percent of the story, we're given the answer.And the answer, I think, indicates that Smith will either end the series as it now stands, or send it off in an entirely new direction. He seems to have gone as far as he can with Mma Ramotswe and Mma Makutsi and their spouses and families and friends. All seem comfortable in their lives, and, truth be told, the "mystery" part of the series dwindles more and more into simple and somewhat obvious underhanded dealings and dishonesties. The characters and the setting, however, are so awesome and inspiring that the lack of any traditional mystery can be overlooked. I'm eager to see if my anticipation is correct . . . or if Smith deliberately planted these hints but intends to ignore them.In any case, the story involves dishonest building contractors, Mma Potokwane of the orphanage, a new house for Grace and Phuti, Charlie and Fanwell, incompetent lawyers, the appearance of Clovis Andersen, and much, much more. And it all flows smoothly and effortlessly. So sit back in y our favorite chair with a cup of your favorite tea and delight in another book in this wonderful series.

This was an unexpected delight of a film. It starts with Jeff, who lives "at home" with his mother, apparently in the basement flat, receiving a wrong-number phone call. The phone rings and Jeff, stoned on marijuana, answers. The caller asks for Kevin. So it's a wrong number, right? Not from Jeff's point of view. He sees this as a call from Destiny, and so he starts looking for the cosmic connection. The first Kevin he encounters robs him. The second Kevin unknowingly leads him to an encounter that will change his (Jeff's) brother's life. For the better. Throughout, Jeff's brother Pat and Jeff's mother either subtly or overtly dismiss  Jeff, particularly since he "lives at home" and is not, in their eyes, a fully functioning, responsible adult.But as it turns out, living at home means listening: being in touch with your "home" -- your core self, your core values. By listening to messages (from other people, from the universe), Jeff behaves as a good person would. At the end, he meets the Kevin that Destiny led him to, and that meeting is a life-saving event. For all concerned.

I'm not a drawer or illustrator of any kind, yet I found Scott McCloud's first book, Understanding Comics, enjoyable and informative. Something possessed me to also read his second book, Making Comics, and I found it as interesting (if not more so) than the first book.McCloud's basic premise is that telling a story in comics form requires the artist to make five fundamental choices: Choice of Moment, Choice of Frame, Choice of Image, Choice of Word, and Choice of Flow. I enjoyed everything in this book, and I especially enjoyed the chapter on World Building.Highly Recommended.

While I enjoyed reading this book and learning about what it is exactly that fact checkers do, and how they do it, I was also made a bit nervous by the amount of detail that fact checkers must check. That's my problem, of course, not theirs: apparently fact checkers love checking facts.The one weakness this book has is that nowhere is the reader given any idea of how long it might take to fact check, say, a 5,000 word article. After reading this book I have no idea whether a fact checker working on an article needs one day, three, four weeks, or more to check an article. Does a fact checker work on several articles at once? It would have been very good for the author to reproduce a double-spaced typed manuscript with a fact checker's notations on each page: this would give the reader a very clear idea of how things work.

This is an easily read early chapter book about third-grader Owen, who with his friend Joseph undertakes a science fair project: raising a lizard named Chuck. Nothing goes right, which causes the boys great frustration -- and might mean that they don't get into Mr. Wozniak's class next year, Mr. Wozniak being a very popular science-minded fourth grade teacher. Fun and funny, but also realistic in introducing setbacks and solutions.

I encourage people to read this book because of the importance of the topic (mass murders in exploited nations, in this case Nigeria, so that oil corporations can lay claim to the land occupied by villages) and the power of Little Bee's Voice. The story is told in alternate chapters: first Little Bee, a sixteen-year-old Nigerian refugee who has been kept in a British detention center for two years; then Sarah, a 30-something editor of a women's magazine who, with her husband Andrew encountered Little Bee on a Nigerian beach two years earlier.The chapters from Little Bee's point of view are engrossing. She is a person who has encountered brutality and horror but has survived. The chapter's from Sarah's point of view are less convincing. She has a very limited range of emotions: usually she sits with tears streaming down her face. When it comes to her husband and her lover, and her husband's death, she behaves abnormally, without common sense it seems. At some point her behavior seems to be nothing more than a plot device, particularly with the trip to London and everything that happens afterwards.Little Bee is very intelligent: I'm not sure she would make the phone call. From the London scene onward, the ending of the book meanders and dissipates, particularly in the final Nigerian scenes.

I bought this book because I wanted to know more about the art of comics. I was amazed at all the things I learned, starting with a definition of comics, a brief history of comics (they are really old!), and proceeding to the vocabulary necessary to understand and discuss comics, from time frames to gutters, to type faces, and so on. Reading this book has made me think differently about comics: I now appreciate them in a much deeper way.

This is probably my favorite flower book, mainly because, in addition to the beginning sections on basic tools and on handling flowers, the book concentrates on dozens and dozens of flowers, in alphabetical order, with luscious full-color photos. The photos are on the right-hand page, and on the left-hand page are numbered hints on the care and feeding of this particular flower. On the bottom half of the left page there's a tinted features box which gives the various names the flower is known by, its colors, its scent, its vase life (very important), cost, and tips for arranging this particular flower, either alone or with other flowers. A great book to consult, a fun book to browse.

I read a review of this book somewhere and decided I'd give the book a try: I like action, I like strong heroes (especially strong female heroes), and while I prefer mystery to slam-bam action, I don't mind if the two appear in some combination. Still, even though I bought the book, I thought I might be disappointed: oftentimes the action element dominates to the exclusion of rational thought. However, this isn't the case with Riot Act, which turned out to be a good mystery-action novel with a strong female hero, Charlie Fox, ex British secret service. The plot is complex, and I like that. The plot unexpectedly involves Charlie's past, and I like that even more. Definitely worth reading.

I have enjoyed every book in the Joshua Croft series. This, the third, struck me as a bit less memorable than the others, but I still very much enjoyed it and would probably rank it 4.5 stars if Amazon allowed for such rankings. In this book Croft is asked to take on the "missing persons" case in which a woman has disappeared with her child. The woman is the ex-wife of a Hollywood star, and she had accused him of child molestation. A court found the star not guilty, which is when the woman and child disappeared. The ex-husband wants Croft to find the missing pair, but Croft won't work for him.Croft does, however, decide to work for the star's uncle, a member of the crime scene in Santa Fe -- that is, a member of the criminal side of that scene. As Croft and his boss, Rita Montdragon, investigate, the case broadens to include assassinations, undercover feds, and illegal immigration. All of the Joshua Croft stories are worth reading: this one is no exception.

I throughly enjoyed reading this book, which, among other things, caused me to wonder how our world might have been different if Poggio Bracciolini hadn't discovered and copied Lucretius's long poem, "De rerum natura." Greenblatt takes the reader on a tour of 15th century monasteries, the papacy, Lucretius's philosophy, Greek and Roman art and thought, the Inquisition, and the intolerance of Christianity as a religion (although he never calls it intolerance).  He also gives us the life story of Poggio and ends the book with Thomas Jefferson and the Declaration of Independence. The book is very well written: the author says exactly what he means to say, and his thought and sentences leave the reader informed and enlightened. Highly Recommended.

In this Nero Wolfe mystery, written near the end of the 1950s, Stout returns to his best writing (as exemplified by some of his earlier Wolfe novels, such as Some Buried Caesar and Too Many Cooks). In this book Archie must attend a party for six unwed mothers, one of whom, Faith Usher, carries around a vial of cyanide just in case she feels like committing suicide. During the evening, Faith dies: poisoned by cyanide in her champagne. Was it suicide? No, says Archie, who had been keeping his eye on Faith and her drink and her behavior the entire evening. Archie claims that nobody had any chance to put anything into Faith's champagne, and therefore she was murdered.The pressure for Archie to change his statement is intense. Pressure not just from those at the party, who don't want a scandal, but also from the police and the Police Commissioner. Archie won't back down, and Nero stands behind what Archie says. And then Edwin Laidlaw hires Wolfe to keep something from being revealed: that he was the father of Faith's child. So Nero promises to solve the murder case before the information about Laidlaw and Faith is revealed.A well-plotted story, with lots of Archie-Nero dialogue.

I've seen Jeff Stetson's one-act drama, The Meeting, which imagines a meeting between Malcolm X and Martin Luther King, two leaders with very different philosophies. It's an exciting play, a rapid, intense look at the issues facing these two African-American leaders during the 1960s. I didn't know about Stetson's novel, Blood on the Leaves, until I read about it in an article by a college professor who uses mysteries to teach social issues. So I bought Blood on the Leaves and read it.Here is the central question of the plot: should whites who committed crimes against blacks in the South during the years of the big civil rights struggles, and who were then acquitted by all-white juries even though some on those juries knew for a fact that the people on trial committed the crimes they were accused of -- should these whites be called to account decades later and brought to justice? In the novel, an African-American professor espouses that Yes, these people should be brought to justice. And then some of the whites start turning up dead. Murdered. And the professor is brought to trial for murder. And the man prosecuting -- not defending, but prosecuting -- the professor is black. The man defending him is white.A highly-charged, complex, gripping premise. But despite the gripping ideas, the story just wasn't exciting. It was slow. There seemed to be no building action, with things becoming more and more tense. Never at any point did I feel I was reading a mystery novel. I DID feel I was reading a book that wanted to raise and have readers think about important questions. I can understand why professors might use this novel to teach social issues: it's certainly more interesting than most, if not all, textbooks. But is it as interesting as a well-written mystery? I think not.

I loved part of this book: the story of the 1893 Chicago World's Fair and architect Daniel Burnham, responsible for the design and construction of the "white city." I learned things about Chicago I never knew before. The nonfiction story was interesting and gripping and read almost like fiction, with a hero and a conflict and resolution.Sad, then, that the author felt he could improve this story by interweaving it with the story of murderer Dr. Holmes. You would think that the killer story would be more interesting than the architecture story, but it isn't. In fact, the killer story is so uninteresting that I almost stopped reading the book a couple of times. But wanting to know the entire story of the buildings and exhibitions of the World's Fair kept me going, and I'm glad they did.Recommended, with reservations: you will most likely strongly prefer one story over the other. Either the architecture story will interfere with the murder story, or the murder story with the architecture story.

I read this book when it first came out, and I've read it and re-read it in the years since: the story is wonderful, the illustrations are magnificent, and the writing draws you in. Or, I should say, it draws some people in. Others may have difficulty relating to or caring about a story told from the point of view of a giant meteorite -- 70,000 pounds of cold stone. I think children will not have any difficulty in relating to the meteorite, Ahnighito, because children have not yet lost the ability to imagine that objects have feelings.That is not to say that this is a weepy, sentimental book. Far from it: it's very informative, conveying to the reader the story of how long the meteorite waited there in the cold, snowy Arctic, and how many times its "rescuers" had to return. There's humor in the story, too, as when the ship carrying Ahnighito is underway, and the meteorite tells us: "Once at sea, the men were upset with me because all the ship's compasses pointed at me and at nothing else."This is an informative, interesting, beautifully-illustrated story that connects all living things. Highly recommended.

I'm not normally a fan of sci-fi or fantasy, but I do love reading about time-travel. I also love realism: kids (or adults) in common situations, learning how to act, taking steps that shape them into the people they become. When You Reach Me mixes sci-fi and realism. The realism comes from the basic story premise: 11-year-old Miranda lives in New York during the 1970s. Her mother is obsessed with becoming a contestant on a tv show, The $20,000 Pyramid, and spends meal times studying and practicing. In school, Miranda encounters the types of people we've all met in school: true friends, false friends, and classmates you just can't figure out. The friendship issues, as well as the true-false issues, drive the story forward.But so does the time-travel aspect of the plot. Miranda witnesses some seemingly weird actions on the sidewalk: she keeps encountering one particular homeless person who acts strangely. Then somebody starts leaving notes-- notes that Miranda does not understand. The first note reads, in part: "I am coming to save your friend's life, and my own. I ask two favors. First, you must write me a letter . . . ." Soon after, a pair of shoes are stolen from Miranda's apartment.This story is well written with believable kids in believable situations (except, of course, for the time travel). Of all the time-travel stories I've read, this is the only one that delves into the "how" of time travel. The "how," coupled with the "why," is especially poignant.

I used to buy these books every year, for a long time. Now I check movie reviews online, on Amazon and Netflix and other such places. But I sometimes miss having one of these books around. I don't even know if they're still produced every year. As time went on, the yearly editions just got larger, and Larger, and LARGER, until, as another viewer pointed out, the books often broke in half at the spine. And as the years went by, the typesize was decreased so that more words could fit on a page. After a while, using these books ceased to be fun. But what I liked best of all about these yearly editions was that they were fun to BROWSE: I was introduced to many movies I had never heard of simply by browsing through this book and reading the descriptions.

Saint Peter's Fair, the fourth book in the Cadfael series, works well as a mystery. There's an initial murder, an initial arrest, then more murder. The story takes place during St. Peter's Fair, so the town and Shrewsbury Abbey are stuffed with visitors, tradespeople, and nobles. Meanwhile, the civil war between the forces of King Stephen and Empress Maud continues, and it looks as if Maud's support may be increasing in strength. The question of which nobles might or might not support her, either secretly or openly, is at the heart of this novel and at the heart of the murders.Although the book, like the town, is stuffed with characters,and sometimes it seems like there's too much of everything going on, the plot is relatively easy to follow, with just enough twists and complications to keep matters interesting, but not so many that the main thread is lost. However, as another reviewer pointed out, Cadfael doesn't seem to play as central a role in this book as he did in the others. In some ways, he's more of a reporter and observer of events than an active participant in them. Still, its his observations, especially about the rose petal on the floor, that lead him to make the right conclusions. Unlike in the previous novels, Cadfael reaches the right conclusions almost too late, and because of this an innocent person is injured. I like this plot element because in real life a hero is sometimes slow or late, so this makes Cadfael seem less infallible and more human. Recommended.

David Thompson, probably the greatest explorer of North America ever, should be a well-sung hero in the States as well as in Canada, the country he immigrated to at the age of fourteen. If you don't know who David Thompson is, this book is a great introduction to the man and his deeds. It's well-organized and well-written. Unfortunately, it does not contain an index, so a reader cannot look up particular people or places. Recommended

I own both this book and the first one, and I use both of them. The first  (The Deluxe Transitive Vampire) was funnier, and more fun to browse through. This one is shorter and easier to use, with clearer explanations. It's difficult for me to choose between them, which is why I keep both on my shelf. It's true that other grammar books are much, much bigger, covering all the grammar rules one can think of, and that a book as clever as this one might really be meant for people who already know the rules of punctuation.This book covers only punctuation, and that is one of its strong points: if you have a question about punctuation, this is the book to consult. Either this or the Chicago Manual of Style, which is about 10 times the size of The New Well-Tempered Sentence. The reviewer who compared this book to Strunk and Whites Elements of Style failed to understand that Elements of Style covers far more than punctuation, so the two books can't really be compared.Recommended -- for both instruction and entertainment.

I used to read Peter Robinson novels years ago, then for some reason stopped. I read this one when it came out, and I enjoyed it very much. Everything in the novel is well-paced and well-plotted, the characters are interesting, and there's a certain feeling of descending doom that I enjoyed, mainly because the characters were not stupid, as doomed characters often are. I'll definitely continue to read books by Peter Robinson.

I have an earlier edition of this book and use it often for the valuable information and examples within. However, as another reviewer stated, there seems to be no thought given to the organization of this book and, therefore, to the way one develops a story character. One does not, for example, start with Labels, proceed to Fleshing Out, and so on. I'm not sure how a writer does create a character, but I doubt it's done by jumping around in random fashion from one method of characterization to another. This book would be so much more valuable if there were some sort of organic flow from one chapter to another, from beginning to end. I vacillated between giving this book three stars and four stars and decided to go with four stars because of the valuable insights the book offers: but the reader has to search for them and dig them out and then reorganize them in some beginning-to-end fashion.

This is the first of the Rosemary Rowe books about mosaic-maker Libertus that I've read. I thoroughly enjoyed seeing "London" during Roman times: for me, the setting was the strongest element in the book, and I will read other Rowe novels in order to experience more of this setting. The plot, too, was interesting, involving the murder of Caius Monnius, the Roman magistrate in charge of grain distribution in Londinium. Rowe does an outstanding job bringing to life the grain storage areas and their administration. But if you find grain a bit boring, never fear: the story also involves chariot racing and the fixing of races. There are additional murders and intrigues. The solution is a classical "rounding up of the suspects." The character of Libertus is less vividly portrayed than are the others in the novel, and the writing is a bit wordy. But I enjoyed the book from beginning to end and plan to read more.

I own an earlier edition of this book, which was one of the first books I ever read on Pueblo pottery, recommended to me by a friend who knows far more about pottery than I do. I found the book informative, well-organized, and easy to read. The first chapter introduces the people: the Pueblo tribes who have made pottery for hundreds of years. Next comes a chapter on the techniques of these potters. After that come separate chapters on the various pueblos, usually grouped: Taos and Picuris; Tewa; the Middle Rio Grande pueblos; then the Acoma, Laguna, and Zuni in one chapter; and, finally, the Hopi. Color photos as well as black-and-white ones of both the pottery and the potters help convey important information and elicit awe and admiration for the beautiful art.

This is the first P.C. Doherty novel I've read, and I must say that I thoroughly enjoyed the Medieval setting and the way it was rendered. At all times I had a sense of the cloaks used for warmth, the weapons, the buildings, the foods, the transportation. In many places I had to look up words ("frumenty," for example, and "arbalest"), but that's to be expected in a book about Medieval times. I also enjoyed the fact that much of the plot was based on actual events: the theft of King Edward's treasures from Westminster, and the subsequent capture of the thieves.The plot kept me interested. I definitely wanted to know who the deadly archer was and why he was killing the people he chose to kill. I wanted to know what horrible crime Lord Scrope had committed at Acre, and even though it's pretty easy to guess what it was, the revelation was satisfying. When it comes to the unmasking of the killer, however, I was disappointed: the clues, if any, were so private to Hugh Corbett's observations that I couldn't go back and reconstruct who was where at what time. I wanted Corbett or Ranulf to list who was where, and discuss it. Even then, the identity of the killer seemed to come out of the blue. Further, Corbett demands to see the manor ledgers (household accounts) near the end of the book, studies them, and reaches some conclusion. What that conclusion is, we never know. It doesn't seem to figure into the solution at all.Two of P.C. Doherty's writing quirks (for lack of a better word) bothered me. Each time I encountered either of them, I felt myself leave the world of the book for an instance. The first of these quirks is that while Doherty keeps to the third-person-limited point of view, there are times when he's writing about Corbett and Corbett's two aides, Ranulf and Chanson, that the author simply switches from one point of view to another in the middle of a paragraph. We may start out in Corbett's mind in the first two sentences, then, Poof!, we're in the mind of Ranulf. Or Chanson.  The other writing quirk is that whenever any character in the book uses a Latin phrase, he or she immediately says it in English after the phrase, as when Edward tells Corbett: "Look, Corbett, Scrope acted sine auctoritate -- without authority." To read these translations this way, in dialogue, is disconcerting. It wouldn't happen in real life, because in real life Edward would know that Corbett knew what the Latin words meant, and he would not translate them into English.All in all, though, I enjoyed Nightshade sufficiently enough to want to read another in the series.

No matter how accustomed you are to research, or how much you think you know about how to find information, you will benefit from considering all the options in this book -- chances are, there will be a resource or option you haven't considered. For that alone, it's worth the cost of the book. Even though this book came out in 1999, and the internet has changed so much in its offerings since then, I keep this book on my shelf to remind myself of all my options.I could list the titles of the 13 chapters in this book (Geographical Research, for example), but in order for them to mean anything, I would have to list all the subtopics under each chapter heading -- and that's a lot! So I'll just say that I think this is an excellent resource to have for anybody who needs to do research of any kind.

This collection of eleven essays, written by eleven different scholars, covers the period in Hardy's life after the publication of his last novel and the first of his poetry collections. The essays cover such topics as "Geology, Genealogy and Church Restoration in Hardy's Writing," Hardy's use of allusions, the presence of the poet figure in the Hardy novels, architecture, the figure of the singer in Hardy novels, and others. Each essay is accompanied by footnotes at the end of the chapter, and there's an index to the book as a whole. Interesting, but definitely written by scholars for scholars.

Even though I much prefer Stout's Nero Wolfe novels to the Nero Wolfe short stories, I enjoyed this shorter-than-usual batch of four. In the first, Wolfe plays Santa Claus because he thinks Archie is going to get married and leave him. Naturally a murder occurs -- and it looks as if the man playing Santa did it.In the second story, Wolfe goes to embarrassing lengths to procure black orchids that don't belong to him, and the result is murder. And it looks to the police as if an employee of Wolfe's (not Archie) committed the murder. If the police only knew that Wolfe was having the event filmed and has hidden the film from them, there would be even more trouble.The third story involves a Fourth of July picnic, Wolfe as the invited speaker, and somebody stabbed in the back while recovering from eating bad snails. The fourth story goes back to the French Resistance during World War II, the murder of traitors, a new life in New York City and then -- more murder.All told, short but satisfying.

This is a very good book, an inspiration to all aspiring poets and even to writers in general. In easy-to-read, humorous accounts of his life as a child, a student, and a professor of poetry, Skinner summarizes the "6.5" practices of, as he calls them, "moderately successful poets." That is: not geniuses, not off-the-scale talent, but ordinary people who, if they have a poetry flame inside, can nurture it and live by it. The 6.5 practices range from the first (and possibly the most important), which can be summarized as Protect Your Talent, to the last, Take the Long View.Each of the practices Skinner lists is of great importance to a writer, and each is presented in such a casual, just-talking kind of manner that the truth of what the author says shines through. His anecdotes, particularly the ones from his days as a security guard, are interesting and intriguing, even. But they're also a bit frustrating to read because in a few cases it seems as if more, not less, is called for. In the chapter on Makes Use, for example, we're given the story of Bobby the Ape (a man, not an ape), and although the story seems unrelated to anything that came before in the book or anything that comes after, it's clear that the story must be there as an example of a poet "making use" of everything that has happened to him or her, everything he or she has experienced. While as a reader I can intellectually understand that Jeffrey Skinner must have made use of the experience of knowing Bobby the Ape, I as a reader also yearn to see an example of HOW he made use of this material. Was it in an entire poem? A stanza? A line? A word choice, even? Surely the writer knows how he made use of it, else how could he put it in the book as an example of making use? In general, I think this book would be even better it it contained some poetry in addition to the one poem by Thomas Hardy that it does contain, and if that poetry illustrated the point the author was making.My other complaint about the book is that a little bit of the author's humorous sidebars (letters to the editor, Pre-MFA Quiz) goes a long way. These sidebars are so long that they cease being funny and seem to exist only to give the book more pages.But my objections are minor in comparison to the worth of the book. If you are a poet and need inspiration to continue writing poetry, read this book. If you're a writer with whom the world is too much late and soon, and need to know that others have trod the writing path and can point out the serpentine trails, the box canyons, the quiet brooks, and the resting places, read this book -- you will welcome it as a thirsty traveler welcomes water.

Many second-in-a-series novels are a touch disappointing, either because they're really stepping-stones to the third in the series, or because the author hasn't taken as much time with the plot and the characters as he or she did in the first novel. At Ease with the Dead does not fall into the "touch disappointing" category. In this novel Satterthwait continues with the characters he created: Joshua Croft, private eye who works for Rita Mondragon, who has been confined to a wheelchair since the shooting in which her husband was murdered (and she was injured).In this book, the client is Daniel Begay, an elder of the Navajo nation, and the crime goes all the way back to 1925, when Dennis Lessing, exploring for oil, robbed a grave, stealing the bones of Ganado, a Navajo warrior. Lessing stole the bones in order to give them to his 12-year-old daughter Alice, who was interested in anthropology. Within a month of the grave robbing, Lessing was murdered -- and the bones disappeared. Now Begay wants Croft and Mondragon to recover the bones.Croft starts with Alice Lessing, now in her 80s. She suggests possible motives for her father's murder and the second theft of Ganado's bones, and Croft investigates these leads -- investigates them despite the fact that he is beaten up and Alice is murdered. Do the theft and murder have to do with academic advancement? With oil rights? Or with something else altogether?This is a very satisfying mystery, well-written, with good pacing and plotting, and interesting characters. If you haven't read any books in the Croft and Mondragon series, start with the first, Wall of Glass, and keep on going.

This picture book tells the story of Isabella, born into slavery, but freed by New York state law before the Civil War. When a former master sells Isabella's son Peter, acting against state law, Isabella takes the white man to court and wins. Her child is brought back from the South. In a dream, Isabella hears a voice telling her she must leave New York. So she begins to travel and changes her name to Sojourner Truth. As Sojourner, she fights against slavery and for women's rights, though the latter isn't covered in this book. Nor is the Civil War. What is in this book is inspiring, but iIt seems strange to me that the story of this important person in American history does not include her struggle for women's rights or the war which freed the slaves. Every time I read this book, I feel as if the story stops in the very middle of Sojourner Truth's life.

Before watching this documentary, I knew only its subject (West Indian cricket team), nothing else. As the film began, with shots of the West Indian bowlers throwing the cricket ball at such high speeds that the opposing batsmen were usually hit by the pitch, I was a bit horrified. This did not seem like sport to me. But I continued to watch and thus I learned (and saw) what the Australian team did to the "Windies" in their 1970s matches. The Australian bowlers intended to hit, maim, cow, intimidate, and obliterate the West Indian players. In fact, that is what the Australians did, with the crowd chanting vile racist epithets to boot. The West Indian bowlers returned home defeated and humiliated -- but only in the cricket matches, not in mind, body, or spirit.In fact, the West Indians analyzed the situation, sized up their opponents, and set about building a team that could defeat those who had defeated them. Yes! A thousand times Yes! If the Australians hurl high-speed cricket balls at you in order to win, then hurl high-speed pitches right back at them. Those who dole out this kind of play should be treated to the same kind of play coming back at them. And when they were -- they lost. The West Indian cricket team proved superior in every way: it could receive the high-speed pitches and hit them, it could deliver high-speed pitches and prevent the opponents from hitting.This is an informative, uplifting, powerful story about a group of men who, despite their differences, formed a team that had the discipline, the intelligence, the strength, and the skill to become a dominant force in world cricket. Highly Recommended!

Fascinating how and why so many middle book in a trilogy are a touch disappointing. I experienced that feeling with the second book in Stieg Larsson's trilogy, as well as with this book -- though I must admit that Larsson's book ended with a bang, as does Catching Fire.I read The Hunger Games after I saw the movie, and I liked the book even better. But I usually make a point of not reading reviews which give away important plot points, and so I deliberately didn't read any reviews about Catching Fire or Mockingjay, so that I could come to the books without knowing much about what was going to happen. I much prefer that: it allows me to experience the story as the author intended me to experience it. So, what I expected from Catching Fire was threefold: (1) I thought we would learn more about the other districts in Panem; (2) I thought President Snow and the Capitol would, in order to get rid of Katniss, force her to participate in the Hunger Games again, then arrange to have her killed off by the other tributes, or by the Gameskeepers; (3) because we got to know Peeta in the first book, I expected that we would get to know Gale in this book.How did my expectations compare to the book itself? Expectation #1: we learned a tiny bit more about the other districts, but in reality not much. We did learn that they were rebelling. I wanted to know more, but I can accept that Katniss and Peeta were closely guarded and not permitted to speak to people from other districts.Expectation #2: I was finding the first third of the book interesting but not riveting: much summary, not much action. And then the author met my expectations about Katniss having to fight again, but on a much higher level than I anticipated, and so I was very pleased with this plot development because I thought it reflected what an entrenched privileged power would do: try to smash every last hope the people have, so as to quell any spark of life or rebellion. Collins' plotting exceeded my expectations, and I was thrilled with the developments. I also liked the unexpected sea-and-jungle setting of the games this time around, and I liked the alliances being formed. However, the game action seemed perfunctory, something to happen quickly, and in a way, off-stage. This slowed the pacing of the games section. I did like getting to know some of the other tributes, and thought their introduction and their roles were well done.Expectation #3: I was disappointed that we didn't get to know Gale in any depth at all, and I was even disappointed that Peeta remained pretty much the same as he had been in the first book. We see that Gale has changed, but I didn't see a change in Peeta. There's a slight change in Katniss as she comes to admire those who defy the Capitol outright by speaking of revolution. But Katniss herself is a touch disappointing here: she comes across as more naive than she should be for a 17-year-old who has lived what she has lived. I would expect somebody in her position at this point in the plot would be a bit quicker on the uptake, a bit more able to intuit and reach conclusions (as when Plutarch showed her the watch with the mockingjay).These disappointments aside, I still enjoyed the book a lot. It flows quickly and in a very logical (and dire) direction. The people of the districts are heroic in their resistance against the draconian Capitol which enslaves them. I am looking forward to the final book!

In this, the third Brother Cadfael novel, Gervase Bonel of the landed gentry prepares to legally turn over his manor and lands to Shrewsbury Abbey in exchange for the Abbey allowing him to live in a small house and to take care of him the rest of his life. But before the agreement can become legal, Bonel dies suddenly: murdered by monkshood added to the sauce of his dinner. Cadfael had prepared monkshood as an ointment earlier, and is able to determine the cause of death. Cadfael also learns that Bonel's wife, Richildis, is the woman he had once been betrothed to, and that Edwin, her son by a previous marriage, is suspected of the murder. Even though Edwin was not Bonel's son, Bonel promised Edwin that he would inherit the manor and lands. So it seems that Edwin has a major motive to kill Bonel before the giving away of the estate becomes legal. But do others have an equal motive? What about Muerig, Bonel's illegitimate son? What about Richildis herself? And . . . could anybody at the Abbey be so unholy as to murder?Cadfael solves the mystery through keen observations and deductions, and, most importantly, by his knowledge of Welsh customs and law.A very satisfying read.

This is a good travel guide to Ontario. The first section is titled "Discover Ontario" and gives an overview. Then come the following sections:TorontoThe Niagara RegionLake Erie to Lake HuronOttawaEastern OntarioGeorgian Bay and Cottage CountryThe NorthThese are followed by Background, Essentials, Resources, an Index, and a List of Maps.Each section starts with an overview of that area, then a list of the towns, with suggestions for each town. Under Hamilton and Vicinity, for example, there are Sights (including the Art Gallery of Hamilton and the Workers Art and Heritage Centre, among others). Next come Entertainment and Events, followed by Food. After that comes Information and Services, and Getting There and Around.All of the information is compact, nothing is prolonged. This is a good guide for somebody who wants to know the main points of each town and then wants to learn more on his own.

The photos in this book are stunning, showing us the Arctic, a world that few of us have encountered. The explanations of the meaning of various inuksuit, the stone constructions of the circumpolar world (to use the phrase from the book flap) reveal how important the physical world is to the Inuit and, by extension, to all our ancestors. Highly educational, highly recommended. A beautiful book in all ways.

I enjoyed reading this story about Erin Swift, who suddenly finds herself entering the seventh grade without her best friend Jilly being in any of her classes. That's bad enough, but when another girl calls Erin "Jilly's puppet," Erin punches that girl in the nose. Not a good way to start off seventh grade. Erin then keeps a computer diary of all her thoughts and feelings about things. She finds herself interacting with students in a new way: a way she wouldn't have interacted with them had Jilly been there. This is an enjoyable read, but also a predictable read.

I've owned both the first and third editions of this book and am considering buying the most recent . . . or waiting until the fifth is published. For serious writing or word-searching, I use a regular Roget's thesaurus, which works mainly through the index, distinguishing between the different uses and classes of individual words. However, on many occasions I want a very quick, very immediate reference that will give me a bunch of synonyms for a word. When that's what I want, I use Roget's Super Thesaurus.

This nonfiction picture book tells the true story of how one farm family, along with their neighbors and the farm animals, survived the Vermont flood of 1927. The story is narrated by the young daughter in the family. An uplifting tale because it shows humans coping with disaster, helping others cope, and helping all living things survive.

Although there's a lot of funny dialogue between Nero Wolfe and Archie Goodwin at the beginning of this book, the story as a whole seemed rote, as if the author were going through familiar motions without heart. In this story millionaire Otis Jarrell hires Wolfe to discover whether his (Jarrell's) daughter-in-law is stealing business secrets and selling them elsewhere. In order to uncover the truth, Wolfe has Archie take a job as Jarrell's secretary and move into the Jarrell penthouse. Archie does, and then murder follows. More than one. The mystery is solved at the end when Wolfe interviews the suspects and presents a piece of evidence given him by Inspector Cramer. Worth reading if you're a Nero and Archie fan. Maybe even if you're not and just want the taste of a 1950s mystery with lots of wit and cleverness.

For a book that's supposed to be exciting -- 15-year-old Alfred must retrieve the magical sword Excalibur, and then must retrieve it a second time from somebody bent on using it to take over the world -- this one isn't. There's a certain feeling of dullness and drabness in this book, a kind of plodding onward but without exciting ups and downs. Interesting premise, but the story just didn't come to life for me.

This book is an absolute delight to browse through and to read, again and again. It starts with color and black-and-white photos of baskets that are 4,000 years old, or older. This chapter is followed by one on materials and one on tools. After that come chapters on the various European nations, often grouped, as in "The Low Countries."Each chapter is well and clearly written, with an explanation of the baskets of each nation and the materials and techniques used in each country. The photos are absolutely gorgeous.Above and beyond how good the contents of the book are is the fact that anybody reading this book will readily see and understand that basketry is still practiced in the European countries, still respected, and that the baskets are still used by people whose ancestors depended on baskets for the past hundreds, if not thousands, of years.

I enjoyed the Sandilands mysteries that were set in India more than I enjoyed this one. Perhaps the setting helped move the novel along in the India books. This book is interesting in the way that any mystery novel set in another time and another place is interesting: the reader gains vicarious pleasure from reading about the transportation, communication, furniture, clothing, and customs of that particular era. If you enjoy reading mysteries more for the setting than for the plot, then I think you will like both this book and the other Sandilands novels. But I found the pace slow and the plot not memorable.

This book just got weird.First off, we get it, their related by marriage...WHATEVER...but the constant need for the author pointing out how taboo the two being together sexually was, was over the top.I felt like the story had great potential in the beginning. This bully shows his feelings through being a massive bully (high school years).The issue that forced both of them to leave their rich lifestyles and start their own wasn't even mentioned until late in the book as "confessions" like they were something that could keep the two apart (and they weren't).I thought the first sex scene was totally hot and loved the angry build up to awesome sex.But after that, it just fell.It's like he turned a total 180 and became everything he wasn't. He wasn't even alpha...he was just a regular man. LOL.The H turned too soft, the h became annoying...the direction the story took to bring down the uncle was boring and very unrealistic. The parent's having a baby together and being a daughter....a very sick thought.The fact that these two always referred two each other (in sex too) as brother and sister just over the top trying to be taboo that it was just silly and eye rolling.I do recommend this book, this could be very promising for anyone that loves a different kind of romance. Hopefully you enjoy it more than I dd.

Great # 2 in this series (I do recommend reading # 1 first to fully appreciate everything going on).Tony is the owner of Alvarez Security and the leader among his group of Alpha friends.His story is tragic and literally makes you cry when you read it and everything that came to pass with it.Sherrie is a great heroine who is smart, funny and unfortunately related to trouble that follows her around.Tony is (from book 1) immediately drawn to the h and apparently they had met in a period of time that the details weren't in the books So he'd rescued her before. She feels like all he is doing is just constantly trying to save her.It is a little too sweet for the person that doesn't have a sweet tooth in romance, but the story and characters are captivating enough that its easy to over look once you get into the story.Overall the story is very entertaining, sexy and full of alpha goodness,

This book had great potential. I mean, it's still a good book, but just started falling flat.The first half or so was great. It was entertaining, had strong leads and support characters. Great Alpha of a H and a smart, normal, ready to try something different heroine.I loved the other guys that were friends with the H and see great things coming our way for all of their stories.However toward the last half of the book I began to feel things were getting to boring, too drawn out and overall the story just started to lose it's grip on me.This was a very hot read, with a great alpha. Take a look, it may be amazing for you!

This book was recommend over and over in regards to a strong villain-ess H that falls for a sweet h.First off, it took the majority of the book for anything to happen. It had some hot moments, but overall, the h remained "out of the loop" from all the supposed feelings the H had for her. She just thought of herself as another prisoner he was trying to steal the powers from.It got a little old when the h retreated to this train of thought over and over and continued to beat the H over the head with it.The H does, IMO, cheat on the h after they discover their feelings are mutual. He does it because he's trying so hard to prove to himself and her that he isn't going to take advantage of the fact that she's there only because he has her imprisoned there.Toward the end, when everyone's true spots are shown to all those around, it's almost too little to late for me. Its so hard to believe that such a strong personality change can occur with the H without making him seem weak, weird or really...sane.So overall it was interesting, but got a little too long in regards to waiting for the h and H to figure each other out and then admit it all.Very different, so I guess that's why I was more into that if it was a more standard story line.

This was a good alpha read.The H and h were very devoted to each other and there was plenty of possessiveness, adoration and sexual feelings going on from our H to our h.It was, in typical Maryann Jordan fashion, a little OTT with how awesome, perfect and beautiful the heroine was, but when you know to expect it, it's not too distracting with the corniness that can make an eye roll.However, also in typical Maryann Jordan fashion, it was exciting, had great sex scenes and kept you entertained through out the book.This author is quickly becoming a go to for me.

This was just okay for me.I really enjoyed the whole story. I loved the big, bad...not always the sharpest tool in the shed, Hero that really took to our h and her daughter.With meeting and watching Pax and his brother in action in book one, I did feel a bit bored with the two together and their story.I felt like the story did drag out a bit - even though there was lots going on.I liked that the h knew how to put her foot down when the time finally came to "check" our H when he started retreating back in his head out of fear of what the heck was going on in this new situation he was in.The sex scenes were fun to read and the development of the relationship was entertaining.Definitely read book 1 first.

This was a really fun read.First off, if you are familiar with CC Wood, you know to expect lots of great fun and comedy with a great mixture of total sexy moments. This book fell right in line with what I needed and expected from Ms Wood.I loved that, while we find vampires and the supernatural exist, it isn't some huge world building paranormal read that distracts from the romance. It was very simplistic since it takes part in our normal world with the secretiveness of the paranormal.Everything we need to learn, we learn along with the heroine.The H was total CC Wood Alpha greatness. The sex scenes...mmmmmm-deliciously vampir-istic - know what I mean??Very funny, very entertaining and I am totally looking forward to picking up the rest shortly!

This definitely isn't for the easily disturbed.Basically after watching her BFF get murdered because a man used her as a shield, our heroine falls in love with the man that saved her.Add sex, insanely insane gross characters and some more vindictive psycho's and woo-la you have Outlaw Revenge.It was definitely OTT in the grit department. I mean, there is no sugar coating when it comes to a man that finds the human dead shield of a woman he used arousing because she was still warm to the touch....Luckily, the h and H in this were not as sick or I couldn't have read it.I do think it's a little unlikely the h would have sex covered in her best friends blood, befriend the man that used her as a shield and be able to try and live a normal life - even for a gritty MC romance story. It's just all a little much.I felt there was some rush, leaving several things unexplained or just not addressed at all.I'm not sure if i'll pick up more in this series and I would recommend this read. But again, be warned. if you're looking for the warm and fuzzy's - look elsewhere.

This was an exceptionally written Total BAMF Alpha read.Layla Frost knows how to write a book. I was very surprised when i went to find more from this author to find this is her only book available. She writes and sounds so much more seasoned (and she probably is, but maybe just not published).The story was great! Everything I love - a totally cool , fun, smart and down to earth heroine. A mysterious, man of few words BAMF that likes what he sees and goes after it.It was awesome and SO fun to read. I unfortunately, devoured it quickly. It was one of those that you loved to hate to love when your at the end.This was off the charts sexy, entertaining, HILARIOUS fun. I not only recommend this read - I demand you read it if you love a good, solid Alpha HEA with no cheating and LOTS of sexy and fun moments. Definitely for anyone that loves KA.

Loved, loved loved! Why did I skip over this book? Don't you hate that?? When you skipped a book in a series because it didn't sound up your alley - read the rest in the series then went back, because DUH!, and then you kick yourself for missing an awesome book? That was me this weekend.I thought the book was fun, sexy and loved the alpha male that Lani Lynn Vale wrote as the H.Great series addition and enjoyed the suspense and characters.Totally recommend - in series order only.

This was just okay for me.It was a little cheesy and predictable.The only UNpredictable part really did feel like it came from left field and made me wonder if I missed something that would have made the whole situation the h was in the middle of make more sense. I mean part of it was "ahhhh" but the other was like "wtf?".It was not the best told story, very basic, kept you mildly pulled in.The H was Alpha/Possessive, but only when pushed to be it or when he thought his brothers smiles were pointed in her direction.The h's past issues made her very vulnerable, however, also made her seem lacking. The things that made her have "episodes" didn't really make sense. Sometimes angry shouts did it, sometimes it was like she had a backbone of steel. It just seemed inconsistent. I also didn't get the whole school scene. I also felt the whole situation with the stalker didn't make sense when the author tried wrapping it up. It was also disappointing to the only excitement of the story.So overall, this is just okay for me. Nothing special, nothing that really had me connecting to these two characters - and really nothing that had me itching to read more about Serenity Springs.There was a lot of introduction to other characters and it was pointed out who the couples would be. This was done kind of cheesily too. Ehhh - we'll see. Maybe the next ones will be better and not so corny and confusing.

This is one of those WAYYYY OTT H stories. Like so OTT it's a little cheesy and weird instead of fun and sexy.However, since I don't mind those, once I get my head in the zone, it was pretty good.The reason I didn't give it too many stars is because one, it was too short for a story that would have been way better (even with our crazy Alpha) with some length. Also, I felt the h needed more time to heal. It was a little too unbelievable and some what off putting for the h to be totally okay with leaving one troubled, scary man to another. Especially one that warned and often showed his violent side. The h was just too comfortable with it.Everything else was good, the smex, the way they met....again, with some more length it could have been great.

This was a super fun read.Not only was the H sexy, smart, funny, Alpha, possessive and a reforming man hoe, he also dirty talks with the best of them - making the scenes that much more intense and fun to read.This book has some great emotional parts involving other characters. Parts that brought the story and all the characters together as a whole and made you fall in love with the story that much more.I felt that both characters really had a great, fun chemistry and was totally believable.Great addition to the series!

This  fell flat for me.I felt like the H and h just couldn't and wouldn't get on the same page. The h was a little OTT with her rebuff of the H because he hurt her feelings ONE time when she was acting like a slut. She just needed to get over her hurt pride.The H was more possessive and concerned about his bratty, drug addicted sister than the h.I didn't read book 1, but honestly, wasn't too impressed with those two in this book to go back and want to read.Just one big "eh" all the way around.

This was a pretty good read.Basically these two meet, become attracted and then.....become Dr./patient.They both decided to become Dr./patient AFTER they met and knew they were both attracted to each other. However, the major angst/issue in the whole book is that it is unethical and wrong for the H (the Dr) to date or want the h. Especially since he decided it was okay to do a pelvic exam on her. At first I got it - it was new/exciting for them...but then about half way through, I was like, Get Over It Already! I mean these two acted like they couldn't sneak around or deny the fact that he made sure her "goodies" were still good. They acted like he was her High School Teacher or something. Yeesh.So other than that fact, it was definitely off the charts steamy. I mean, this H could DIRRRTTY talk. However, I felt like the smex scenes took way too long. >crazy for me to admit that< But they did. Everything was so long and drawn out.....overly detailed. I mean at first it was enjoyable...but every time?? Too much.Also I felt like, when the H found out the h's secret, he went OTT in jerk mode. I felt like he had some more groveling to do before >I< could forgive him.  The h was just the H's doormat too often as well. Whatever he wanted, he was more important, his career was more important, his life, his friends....it was all about him.So anyway, yes, good book, good smex and a good Alpha. Just some personal issues I took up with it, but it is still worth a read. Fun, short and sexy.

I don't think I have EVER felt, identified or related to a heroine in a story as much as i did this one.When I cried....I CRIED. As a mother, I felt KA reach into my chest and rip out some of my heart strings in trying to relate to how this h  was dealing with her life.As much as you felt for the h, you did not feel sorry for her in a bad way. She earned and clawed her way back to the top and did it earning respect and dignity.It was amazingly told.Now that's just one part of it.Let's get to the totally juicy, funny, sweet, sexy, ANNOYING and amazing part - Amy and Micky....Micky was a well written classic KA Alpha H. Loved him.I don't want to give anything away. Just know that if you want a true romance between two people, that have been around the block a time or two...two people that both need saving in their own way...and families that need all the inspiration they can get - this is your book. From start to finish it was excellent.

I have less than 10 authors that are an auto buy for me. Regardless of the series/genre/price - whatever. Kristen Proby is now officially one of them. Well, she became officially one of them a few books back, but I just wanted to throw that in here!This is a great kick off to a new series. Compared to her Seattle series, this one is going to be just as good - if not better.The H is the successful, man ho (who definitely knows how to treat and respect a lady) and the h is a successful woman really not looking for anything - but isn't going to say no either.The story line flows great and stays entertaining throughout the whole book. The characters introduced are excellent and a few of them are already getting the buildup in this book for what's going to come in their own.This is not your typical "boss to employee" story, as the h is there working for the H only as a guise. She's an old family friend that has always crushed on the H. She works as an investigator for companies that have someone within stealing from them. She comes in, looks like the new, low on the totem pole girl, and finds out what the heck is going on.Again, very entertaining and very good, sweet romance.

This is definitely my favorite in the series.Finally, less cheesiness (but still SOME), a more Alpha H and a more exciting story line.I don't think you necessarily have to read this in order. The author does a good job recapping.This book was extremely hot and sexy and very entertaining the whole way through.Again, each one is getting better and better and the next one due out is an auto buy for me.

Ehh - this was just okay.Honestly - I went back and read this, because of read all the others after it. I have to admit, after you get over some ridiculously cheesy moments, that you soon grow to adore, it's a great series.The first two, however, are a little OTT with the cheese-ballness. Again, once you get used to it, it doesn't naw at you anymore and you enjoy the story. The others are better than the first and you really don't have to read them in order. Sure it helps, but it isn't detrimental.If you love super Alpha/possessive H's and love it when they find "their one and only's", this is a good series for you.  I didn't find the H in this book as alpha/possessive as the later H's.

I felt like this book - and the characters - totally did 180s half way through.First off - Love me a good ol' "my boss needs to spank me" book. Always promising.However, these two went from totally denying each other (ridiculously and annoyingly so - not in a teasing way) to being in insta' love.  It didn't make sense. I mean, the h, is OBSESSED with the H from birth. Okay, maybe not birth,but pretty darn close to it. She even makes her whole career choice, which includes a master's degree, based on the fact that it's the H's passion. Then half way through the book, it's like it was her passion, even though she never really showed any love for it until she went to school. Even then it never expresses that the h liked what she did, it just kept referencing that she was trying to gain the H's attention with it.Then there's the " I refuse to sleep with my employee" rule the H sets about...at the h's interview with him...that the h tells him and herself she'll see through and get 'em. She's all "...but what about after hours..."Then the H proceeds to UNPROFESSIONALLY bang his girlfriend in the office every day (okay, almost everyday). He keeps ignoring the h...bang girlfriend...ignore h...bang girlfriend....you get it, right? OH but he must remain professional and not date an employee in his tiny firm. WTFE, dude.This TRULY makes the h look like a crazy fan girl instead of the old family friend that respects and loves the H. Hell, it makes the H look like a hypocritical douche bag.Fast forward through the book...the finally start bangin'...two pages later their "we only bang game" is now "we are madly in love game:" but only the H shows it. Suddenly, out of left field, the h acts as if she must choose her suddenly important career over her temporary "just bangin" him" boss. Like he's nothing....like she hasn't obsessed over him in forever...like she...she...she *shakes head* I'm so lost by this point.Don't even get me started on the creepy roommate that has story lines swirling around her that aren't only ridiculous, but serve no purpose and only distract us from what's supposed to be the main story line.Oh and PARIS - WTF? Yeah...you're thinking, "what do you mean "Oh and PARIS""....EXACTLY! That's how I felt reading most of this book...exactly how you feel about reading this review.

I have fallen in love with these characters and I have envied the relationships they have. I'm not talking romantically (though they are amazing and what every girl truly dreams of) but I'm talking about the friendships. They are a family, not just a group of friends and to have a bond like that would be something truly special. I've said it in reviews regarding this series in the past and I stand firm about it. I'm jealous of their family. I want to be a part of that family. To feel as welcome and loved as all of them to do - it's truly something else.This is a book that even though it's an ending to this series, it's kind of like a new beginning, too. Josie and Liam are truly getting a second chance at experiencing everything from the beginning. He may have missed everything with Josie and especially with Noah but things are changing. There's a lot of baggage that they still need to deal with and that's the main struggle you'll see in this book. Josie, as much as I loved her, I wanted to ring her neck. And it's hypocritical of me because I would probably behaving in the same way but seriously, this man loves you more than he loves anything in the world. You have to see that. Everyone else does.This book is filled with surprises though. A character who I, along with many of the characters in this book, have hated for some time now show us their true selves and you can't help but feel pity for them. And you can help but respect them even though that's not something you ever expected to feel regarding them. What can I say...people surprise you when you least expect it.This series shows the potential for the series regarding the children. I have been chomping at the bits just waiting for the next series to come from Beaumont. We've gotten the love stories of all these amazing characters and soon it will be the children's turn. And it's going to be amazing - I just know it. A few things were hinted at in this book and let me tell you, if it happens, I may be the happiest person alive. I'm just so excited thinking about what's to come. So damn excited.This series has been very emotional from the first chapter of the first book to the very last page. You will feel every emotion imaginable and most times, you will feel it more than once while reading not just this book, but every book before it. These characters are real - I swear it . . . I just have yet to meet them. Until I do, I'm envious of them. Heidi McLaughlin has delivered yet another spectacular and memorable book. One you don't want to miss.Reviewed by Jessica @ Step Into Fiction

I am so glad I gave this book a chance. I know I repeat myself often but I rarely like YA contemp. It's not gritty enough for me but I'm starting to see that it's not the case anymore. I've come across more and more YA contemps that appeal to me. Not saying a lot, just more. This is one of them. It's a love story, which I am on board with, duh, but it's also not filled with butterflies and rainbows. It's darker, it's emotional and the entire book is one big struggle.
