For some reason leaves my skin oily after use. Did not work well for me.
Good charger

This jacket is gorgeous, even prettier than the picture. It fits great, it is well made and will go with pretty much any outfit. Was better than what I was expecting. I usually wear medium tops, but bought a small and it fit great..I am in love with this jacket.
Working fine. A bit noisy, but worth 12 bucks all day long.
It's a pretty design. I usually use 8.5 and purchased this seize, but it was big. Maybe consider ordering half size smaller.
Nice quality brushes. Great packing, too. Makes a great gift .
It works fine. Had it for a while now, and it has not disappointed. The opening is small so u have to cut everything, but other than that it is a great juicer for the price.
It's a great jacket...great fitting, feels good, very well sewed.. The collar is kind of strange tough, but if you are into it, it's a great quality product
Nice bangs.
Good case
Great powerful vacuum stick. It works properly and is very convenient.
Would give a zero star if I could. This was humongous and poorly made.. Thank god it was cheap.

The last sharpener you will need!I just received my sharpener, and spend the last hour bringing life to my drawer full of old dull knives.It works great: it is easy to use, fast, and safe. I love the handle.A great buy for home, or even as a gift.

Great buy for acne/oily skin!First of all, let me say that the packaging of the OZ products are great and the size is just right. I have been using this cleanser for a while, and as someone with oily and acne prone skin, I always have a difficult time buying a cleanser because either they leave my skin too oily due to the oils added in the formula, or they make my skin so dry that within 3 days I am peeling  off, and when I apply foundation my face looks a mess. Thankfully, this cleanser has been great. It smells amazing, keeps my skin clean, fresh, and yet dry and soft for many hours. I use it twice a day because my schedule is crazy, but used combined with my oil free make up, prevents my skin from shinning towards the end of the day, which is something my other cleansers could not provide me. Nevertheless, this is not an exclusive acne treatment product, so it works great for other skin types as well. This is a must item, and I definitely recommend it as an effective, and the best of all "organic" product.

I started taking the pills after reading a lot of research and relatives feedback. My Mother has been on it for 2 months  and have dropped two sizes! My cousin has been taking it longer and has lost 20lb already. The biggest difference I noticed since I started taking the pills is that I  don't seem to crave sweets at all like I used to. I decreased  the amount of snacking, too and this seems to help. I would recommend this product, but remember to drink a lot of water with it!

A must!!!!!This product is great, the fabric' s quality is good, as well as it's finishing. The size is just right for money and even your passport. It has an adjustable elastic strap, to fit your waist comfortably. Such a great product for traveling without worries. I  had purchased a similar item a few months ago when I travelled overseas, so that I could have my money on me without being worried about its safety when I would fall asleep on the plane, but this one is waaaay much better. I loved it and definitely recommend this product.

It smells adorably. It feels good. It is not too sticky. The very bottle can be used by women for "something else" ;)  There is plenty of it there. It is useful for blowjobs - the smell and texture is fine.. even you should add more and more- the bottle has pretty much not to care about it :-p I've used this. Later I've tried some other lubs and now I came back to my big rounded bottle again. Ilang ilang is one more plus to all this.

I use the Vassarette Women's Undershapers during more than 1 year. It really does its work and the quality is good. I'm satisfied with the durability too. I wash them everytime I wear and they still look and feel good. I would recommend this to a friend. The only thing - when it's hot I feel discomfort due to its synthetic fabric.
Gorgeous dog. We use it during 1 year and it's as nice as new. Everything works perfect. I like how it calls baby to play, but as all parents I like reduce sound button more ;)
Yesssss, this is how we also use them - to attach other toys and to chew & bite. NONE of the links is broken after more than 1 year of being used. I like its quality a lot.

The rattle is pretty nice - bright functional and durable. I gave it 4 stars just because there is a piece of fabric there and I like to wash toys frequently so it just took some time to make it dry again. We used it and it's still as new!
A very light texture. It has a light pleasant smell and feels so good on skin. NOT oily nor sticky. Simply amazing. I've bought one just to try but I definitely had to buy double pack better.

The 18 months old baby easily stack the parts together because of the big holes in the bottom. Also it's easy for him to understand where to place the shapes in the sorter - these are basic shapes - and they are only 4- it is easy for a baby. I've bought other sorters with MANY shapes - it's hard for a baby to understand what goes where...

I bought ALL K's Kids books for my baby- we spend much time learning. THIS book is one of his favorites- it really shows the differences between growth, speed, etc. Our books are in Russian - I will place pictures of every page with pleasure- they are same as English just translated. Awesome quality.

We draw with my little 18 months baby. It works perfect. The pen is not dangerous. It fall down many times, also baby stands on it - and it still works perfectly. Nice purchase.  P.S. We don't use those additional pictures (cards) - even though they are good and help to draw simple things- baby just bites them.. as any other paper. He is just too little.. I'd be glad if they are made of plastic.. right now i hide them away to use later..

A very bright and nice toy. Due to the big holes it's easy for a baby to grab the parts. I've been buying it because of the letters, numbers and pics. Pick-a-boo is also great, though I am afraid to leave that egg shape thing when baby stays alone in bed- it looks like he can put it into his mouth. At least his 11 y.o. bro already did it.. put that "egg" in mouth.
My daughter is wearing it but it didn't impress me much. My daughter is wearing it without the fleece - using it like a jacket..
Amazing quality- feeling of holding a masterpiece in your own hand. Baby looks gorgeous wearing them - a little man.. Watch pics. welcome))
Good boots - watch my pics.
The only one minus- it takes too much time to lace them up;)P.S. Thank you for your pretty note inside the box, guys- it made my day.You're amazing!
It looks very stylish and it feels warm. Really nice one.
My daughter is very satisfied with this purchase. Watch the pictures))
We wish to order the same but a little bit bigger- 'cause it looks and feels really good. Mu hubby loved this coat very much.
The quality is nice and it looks so well. I like it. Watch the pics))
I've expected another kind of the very material... though it was silly to expect one for this price. I think it actually costs it's money.

The backpack is a little bit too small for the school books. Also if you wish to put even a tiny umbrella there and/or other necessary things except books, forget it either. This is as for the size- but the quality is pretty well. Looking pretty nice. I always add lots of pictures to my reviews- you're welcomed to see them.

I do hope this collection of "short stories" will not be a prequel to the actual story but that all these bits will be incorporated in the work to come.As they are, they are well written and intriguing, but they are also dissatisfying: they read like pages fallen out from the loose binding of a much larger book; they feel incomplete and they raise a narrative tension that goes nowhere.Furthermore it is my opinion that a fairytale such as "Beauty and the Beast" can very well span over a long arc full of events and details, but that these events will need to build up a single crescendo and that a HFN ending will simply not do, a HEA being imperatively required.

It is the same old, annoying story here:the author has written a short novella, then it has cut it into several very short pieces; the first is a freebie to lure the reader in, the others are outrageously expensive and to get the whole story one needs to pay quite the sum.It is an unethical practice and I will never endorse it with MY money.And to think that the story seemed interesting with potentially interesting characters.

The idea of upturning the usual -in the end monotonous- lore about alpha wolves and mates, dominant and submissive partners, roles in bed, etc. was a clever coup de thtre and could have been the foundation of a nice story, seeing that Ms Rosa can write.WHAT FOLLOWS MIGHT BE CONSIDERED A ***MILD*** SPOILER************************************************The frank "I-couldn't-care-less-about-what-you-wolves-think-must-happen-between-mates" of the bear shifter is refreshing and also quite humorous. Unfortunately this does not lead to entertaining skirmishes and witty dialogues ending with a balanced relationship between equal partners: Jack simply wants the prerogatives of the dominant partner and the second half of the -too short- story is simply about Derrick accepting the fact.**********************END OF ***MILD*** SPOILERNothing new or really refreshing happens in this story in the end.A pity.

A short story in length and scope, this little M/M romance is intentionally unsensational but fairly well written, with no typos or grammar mistakes.Plot is comparatively simple but sensible and characters are succintly but well outlined, with the possible exception of Elijah who remains a little distant throughout the story, HEA included.The author still has some way to go to reach real poignancy, but, at least for now, she shows no irritating flaws and especially not those so typical of so many women-authors trying to write M/M fiction.For those readers who care, there is no sex scene and only some swearing here and there.

Unfortunately, what one gets with this freebie is just a snippet:it is the beginning of a well written M/M erotic fantasy, with two interesting and fairly complex characters, but at about 900 kindle locations it is more or less as satisfying as reading two chapters.There are at least four more parts (others might be published, in time) and, while at $1,19 they are not outrageously priced, the total sum remains too high.Not to mention that this cutting a single story into little parts which are not self-contained is a very widespread but still questionable practice.The quality of this first part (no typos, no grammar mistakes, fluid writing) is such that I wish the author completed his story and published the final result in one volume and for a reasonable price.

Should the author happen to read this review, he will be dismayed to learn that a number of typos and grammar mistakes have escaped his and his friends' attention, an exhausting search he writes about in his afterword.That said, they are too few to be disrupting and this is one of the best fantasy I have read in a while together withThe Boy Who Couldn't Fly Straight (The Broom Closet Stories Book 1)While the author seems young (at least young-at-pen), nothing in this M/M urban fantasy is short of professional and well thought of.The Potter series looms in the background and the trio of leads bears similarities to the more famous one but their psychologies are different enough not to spoil the fun and plot is certainly not derivative. Despite some naive turns of events, not too many, the story is original and compelling and the magic lore feels fresh.The book is the first in a series and that is apparent in the several loose threads Mr Early starts to weave into the second half. The complexity of references is not comparable to that of the Potter series, where essentially every page has implications that tie it to future events, but it is more than enough to hint at a rather complex and exciting intrigue.Narrative tension is always there and characters, who appear stereotypical at the beginning, grow up into multi-faceted personalities later on.Descriptions are long and good, even the ever difficult combat/action scenes. Curiosly enough, this work, though far from short, could easily bear many more pages.The M/M element is emotionally explicit but never graphic.While I am writing this review, this title is unavailable on Am. where I got it in the first place. I hope the author is simply revising and adding more pages to it; to retire it from the market would be a real loss.

On paper this M/M werewolf short novel -a self-contained standalone- could be considered unsuccessful for several reasons:- It is essentially devoid of plot -what little there is is extremely simple-;- it is essentially made up of a chain of climactic situations where most things are told and very few shown;- it casts all-powerful and bidimentional leads who get rid of their problems with a wink of their eye; when they face a difficult problem, a new character appears to solve it for them;- sex scenes are explicit but repetitive in premise and vocabulary;- its underlying ethics are questionable: everybody, and the leads especially, is very ready to take offence and decidedly trigger happy; the basic idea is that common people are unable to determine their own life and a superior, benevolent being is needed to guide them;- writing is fairly fluid but it is also peppered by many grammar mistakes and hindered by missing words.- I may not be an accomplished latinist but "Regem Lupus" is an eyesore. It should be "Rex Luporum" or at least "Rex Lupus/Regem Lupum".That said, the reading experience is still fairly entertaining and it is not difficult to read this work to its last page. This is why I have raised the original one-star rating.

Like every reader of M/M romances I am more than willing to cut a book some slack about strict believability and consistency for the sake of a passionate interlude.In this short romance, though, nothing makes sense. Characters behave like overgrown children, plot is just a chain of improbable events and everything feels stiff and contrived, not to mention hurried.

What this novella really lacks is rhythm. And narrative tension which is usually the same.What we get is many dialogues/musings about little or nothing, starting with the lead having lost her parents when she was too young to remember  and making a wordy fuss about it despite having been raised by a uncle with her older brother.Series need to indulge in details to manage world building and length but a modicum of interest should be achieved.

This M/M novella is the first instalment in a fantasy series.Basic plot and world building are interesting and the author has the raw talent of a born storyteller.While the lead develops amorous feelings for his male best friend, bigoted readers need not worry about it. The most they do is kiss and those kisses are only mentioned and not described. Therefore I see no reason why the author should have tagged his work as gay-themed.Unfortunately there are several problems and they must be mentioned because they stand in the way of enjoyment:- editing is quite sloppy. There are typos, word-switches ('cease' instead of 'seize' was recurrent), grammar mistakes and consistency issues far exceeding what may be tolerated in an indie work;- writing is good here and there but more often clumsy and clunky. The author should make the effort of revising his technique to achieve a better fluidity.- the fantasy genre is known for its descriptiveness. In every work, many pages are dedicated to characters' training, travel experiences, military tactics, battle scenes, meaningful dialogues. In mediocre books they are usually very boring but they are the warp of successful ones.Mr Burgess seems to have nor time nor patience to put down these moments and it detracts from the story: things happen too fast. There is a reason why a fantasy volume usually exceeds 400 pages often topping 600; the feeling of reading a draft is thus difficult to avoid.I think the author should enlist the help of a competent editor and try and rewrite this series giving it more breath and scope. It would be worth it.

Most reviewers appear to be so happy about this short M/M romance, but I could never get into it.The leads are stiff and unlikeable, plot is mechanical and unlikely, writing is far from fluid.Not for me.
This very short M/M shifter erotica is surprisingly good. A couple more pages would not have hurt but it is still enjoyable as it is.

This short M/M werewolf short story could have been great if the author had payed just a little more attention to it.The plot is rich in interesting developments but the delivery is very hurried, transitions skipped and editing lacking.A missed opportunity.
At about 245 kindle locations this werewolf erotica is really short and yet I have found it difficult to finish it as it lacks plot, characterization and rhythm. And it is not sexy at all.

All right, this M/M serial dabbles in dubious consent and harassment.It may please some readers, I suppose.I doubt it will please anyone, though, that this is a short short story cut in six parts, the first (about 200 kindle locations) being a freebie, the other five costing 3,40$ each. One could also purchase two bundles: episodes 1-3 for 3,86$ and episodes 4-6 for 3,92$.Every author can set the price s/he wishes, of course, but it is up to the reader to spend the money.I will not.
This item is included in the collectionSoul Bond: 1650 - 1970See my review there for full details.
This item is included inSoul Bond: 1650 - 1970Please refer to that full review.
Please refer to my review ofSoul Bond: 1650 - 1970where this short is included for details.

Read the blurb of this collection of three M/M BDSM short stories carefully and raise it to a power before purchasing it, because what you will get is extreme.It is not extreme because of the sexual practices described -which are quite tame and unimaginative- but because the author is perfectly content with his fictional world where only masters and slaves exists and slaves are lesser humans who have no say in their lives because of ferociously enforced laws and, even more than that, because of their ingrained, biological instincts (a dystopian hybris if ever there was one).Readers who think that BDSM can very well trespass the door of the bedchamber even in healthy relationships may find such a narrating device more than titillating but in my opinion it ends by being a double edged sword. In such a predetermined context a writer of genius is required: here writing is fluid, typos are annoying and there is no genius to be found.As a consequence the scope of the psychologies involved is disagreeably limited: the characters of every story are essentially identical to each other; the dynamics are always the same, predictable and boring. The slaves always try to put up a fight but they are soon tamed by their lovers' superior strength and masculinity.Reading this collection -several other stories set in the same world are available- was a bit like reading history books about the condition of women/slaves in our past: disheartening.

All in all this is an enjoyable if very short M/M vampire erotic novella, the first part in a series.Writing is generally fluid, the leads are likeable, side characters interesting and the take on the vampire lore rather new.Yet there are problems:- The story is very, very light in that the mystery is no more than a pale excuse; psychologies are bi-dimentional and the growing attraction between the leads is hurried and quite a bit over the top.- The end comes and there is luckily no cliffhanger, but it really feels like the original story was chopped into parts to be sold separately for no real reason.- Editing is an issue as there are typos and rather crude grammar mistakes.- A final problem may be a personal one but is no less annoying: I happen to be a native speaker of Italian with an excellent grasp of French and I have found EVERY SINGLE Italian or French phrase/expletive used in the book to be wrong as only google-translated idioms can be.Just to make a -blatant- point, "Vincent Kamateros" is NOT an Italian name, Vincent being English (the Italian is "Vincenzo") and Kamateros being a Greek surname.Second, there would be no reason for Vincent, his sister and Angelo to speak English instead of Italian between each other.While it would be unpractical to write long dialogues in a foreign language and translate them in a footnote, the fact could be implied by the simple use of italics.Third, it would perhaps make sense for Vincent to adopt an anglicised version of his name to use in the US, but his Italian family and friends would never use "Vince" and "Cent" as pet names.Most readers will hardly notice or care, but to me it betrays a lack of research that I deem unprofessional.I am sorry, but stars had to go from the rating because ot this shabbiness.
The concept of this M/M fairy tale was good but I needed more. More development and more depth, possibly more pages.

This author's approach to a very common lore in this M/M werewolf short story, the first in a yet to be published series, is interesting and his writing is far from bad.What I missed, and missed did I it badly, was a convincing pacing and/or rhythm to the story. The plot feels confused -although it is not- because events are not well chained together. Everything happens very fast but not in a breathtaking "I cannot put this book down" kind of way.With a more careful stylistical approach, I think this could become a great story.

Erotica featuring a tentacled being is bound to be kinky.This specific work is even kinkier than expected and adds another element that I cannot spoil for you but that I feel is redundant.The psychological twists are too stretched to be believable but writing is really not bad.Unfortunately the author has taken the common but annoying decision of cutting a short story into three very short parts, offering the first as a freebie and the others at too high a price. It feels like a total rip-off and, although I am interested in seeing how the story ends, I will not be purchasing it at these conditions.

This novella is possibly one of the structurally most bizarre works I have ever read.Her author wreaks havoc on every literary convention creating at the same time a story an a genre and I have no idea whether this novelty depends on her being an amateur or a refined stylist.After the first few pages, though, one adapts and her plot, basically a mystery set in a urban fantasy setting, flows forward pushed by the outrageous characterization of the leads more than by its simple chain of events.The novella ends with a moderate cliffhanger implying that a sequel is foreseen. I am not sure whether the author will manage to strike this strange but entertaining balance in the next instalment as well, but this first volume is worth a try.

This short M/M werewolf story shows an interesting approach.Unfortunately it could have used fewer 'she' where 'he' was expected making me think about a M/F story badly adapted; it could have used more pages and less "me tarzan you jane" attitude.

While grammar and vocabulary choices exceed the standards of indie authors, writing is wordy, especially during the sex scene. As a consequence rhythm falters and the story, which is already derivative, ends by being dull.

Reading other reviews I had to wonder at how prudish many SF readers appear to be: that the story features two gay leads and two short sex scenes appears to be the end of the world for them.That said, this short story may be more romance than pure SF, but  the SF elements are well thought of and interesting in themselves.Writing is fluid, the plot develops logically and there are a couple of very moving moments.

This M/M dark fantasy short story is interesting and entertaining.Despite some grammar mishaps, writing is professional enough and the story is good, fairly original and has three interesting characters.Unfortunately, the author (like many do) has divided her far from long story into several short parts: this first one is free, the other five are not and the sum of the current six parts (there might be more in the future) far exceeds what I deem legitimate for a work like this.

This is one of the best parodies I have read in a while.Of course it is extremely over the top both in gory and in sexual details and will not be to everybody's taste but I have found it well thought of and decidedly entertaining.The main reason for this success is that its author is just as skilled a professional writer as the writers of the parodied zombie/apocalypse stories would be. So skilled in fact that the story here and there becomes convincingly horrifying: I missed a laughter or two, actually.Complaints:- this is just part one of a series. It is quite short and not self contained, ending with a rather steep cliffhanger. I got this as a freebie but part two is rather expensive and no longer than this one.- Am. lists this work as gay but, at least for this first part, that definition is quite far fetched. There are plenty of detailed M/F scenes and the gay element is more than vague.

Despite a couple of annoying typos, this very, very short story nicely complements the work it is supposed to be the sequel of.It cannot stand on its own and frankly I would have used it as the previous instalment's epilogue as it sets no new atmosphere but simply concludes that story, which was not overly long to begin with.

This short story reminds me of the mythological movies of the 1960s with their blatant inaccuracies and their display of testosterone/muscles/scantily clad female bodies.If you are game, you are entertained, at least for a short while.Here things are complicated by explicit gay sex and by a taste for kinky descriptions of gore and death. The latter I could have done without but it is not like the author did not warn about it in the blurb.

This is a little M/M short story detailing the unsensational events of a Winter evening and the meeting of two men who might decide to start a relationship; we think it will happen but we do not know for sure as the story ends before that.Everything in this work is understated (and there is no sex) but the end result is so much better because of it: often there is no need to shout what can be mentioned in passing.The past of the two men is only vaguely hinted at, but this stylistical choice does not make it any less painful and is consistent with the unsensational approach.What is clear, though, is how uncomfortable the life of non believers must be in predominantly judeo-christian and conservative US; I must also disagree with the blurb, as Kai does not appear to reconsider his dislike for the season.Writing is fluid but perhaps not as nuanced as the tone of the story required.

This M/M short story belongs to a loosely connected series.WhileHaunted Heaven: A Wild Skies Gay Romancewas a light but entirely satisfying romance, this episode involves more complex psychologies and situations and they are not fully developed. The lack of pages does not help.All in all it is a romantic read with a HEA but it needed more.

This is my second work by this author.It is far more traditional in its being set in an ethically acceptable alternate universe similar to our own but with supernatural in it and in having the required HEA.It is too short though: nothing more than a short story in length, it could have used more pages to better describe the transition from business transaction to romance.

This author has chosen to make some of his (her?) works available for free here on Am. and I gave them a try.This M/M short story -apparently the first in a yet to be published series- at first reminded me of Hollis Shiloh and her heart-wrenching habit of creating horrible, dystopian worlds where a romance manages to be born.There is that, of course, in this alternate reality setting similar to classist XIX century Britain plus the werewolves. The main character and POV bearer, though, is not innocent and naive as he would be with Ms Shiloh: he has been hurt before and he has grown a thick emotional armour. His meeting his partner is underwhelming in that, never for a moment, the author obliterates the harsh reality of their situation.This very adult approach is both rewarding and disappointing for lovers of romance. The work might require a sequel to untie all the emotional knots the author chooses to leave on his characters at the end of the story.Writing is generally good and professional even if sometimes not sharp and cutting enough for the crude approach chosen by the author.

This M/M romance, a short story in length, is part of a loosely connected series.I got it for free but, more than that, it is professionally written and has a simple but logical plot. The required HEA is delayed by some over the top melodrama but it fits the story.

This M/M cowboy romance is sort of a work in progress: these first two parts are available for free, while a third part has been published for a fee which I deem far too high and I will not buy it.There are some editing issues: the type-setting is particularly simple without indented paragraphs and justified margins. This makes for a difficult reading experience, especially when the POV shifts from one lead to the other, a shift that is never clear and makes the chain of events confusing to follow.That said, the story is better than expected. There is talent for storytelling here and characters are interesting. The author needs to work on the transitions from a scene to the next, though, which are rather abrupt and leave the reader with the feeling of having missed a paragraph or two.A competent editor might be needed to revise a potentially good story and a new price scheme should be put in place.
The number of typos and grammar mistakes in this short story makes reading it a chore. An ordinary plot does not help.

There are paragraphs, in this M/M novella, the first instalment in a fantasy series, that bear the mark of a great writer: writing is harsh, clipped, utterly convincing.This, added to a original and interesting lore and a quick plot, could have lead to an excellent reading experience but for one problem: the two leads feel stiff and distant, their motives always hazy, their psychological development hidden and unclear.As this concern even the POV bearer, one of the two leads, whose feelings should be crystal clear and are blurry instead, relating to the story and rooting for the characters becomes difficult.Several typos/mistakes require further attention from author and/or editor.

I do not understand what has happened here.The first half of this short M/M SF novella is not a masterpiece, but is well thought-of, well written, well plotted and sports two interesting characters. It is quite an entertaining read, rich in narrative tension.Halfway through, though, the author suddenly loses her focus: plot becomes hurried and senseless, dialogues becomes absurd, writing becomes shabby and full of typos and grammar mistakes.I do hope she will revise her work.

This short M/M short story could be considered self contained as it ends with no cliffhanger, but is in fact the first instalment in a yet to be published serial.As others have said, one might need to pay more than one expects for the whole if every part is as short and priced as this is.Writing is generally professional but the end result is not satisfying: perfectly good paragraphs are followed by slower, less interesting ones.

I am not sure about this short story, the first instalment in a as yet to be defined series:on the one hand the author can write and her style is simple, smooth and pleasant; on the other hand, the plot has more than a touch of soap-opera and a thick basis of sentimental TV drama, with lovers who face difficulties simply because they hesitate to make choices they know they need to make.This is a genre that frankly irritates me and I know I will drop the series.

This little short story has explicit M/M content but it is not erotic.It is not exceptionally well written (some grammar flaws here and there) but it manages to capture a precise, eloquent snapshot of the life of a -presumably- thirty something/middle-aged gay man when he realises he has settled for an unhealthy relationship instead of looking for a man who really loves him.It is short, concise, fluid. The mood is not cheerful but it never becomes too heavy or depressing.A good job.

At approximately 1300 locations (the rest is previews) this M/M supernatural short story is interesting but far too expensive, at least at its current price.The lead is well rounded and sexy and his interaction with both his antagonists is well thought of. Where the story loses focus is in the supernatural moments: I understand the author is going for ambiguity and trying not to give background information which could slow the plot but the end result is confused and detracts from the story.The supernatural element assumes a fairly traditional judeo-christian worldview: even if I am always eager for author to relinquish that particuliar lore, I admit that here it is not obnoxious.Grammar could be better.

If one takes into account that this is a debut novel from and indie author, any criticism has to be toned down as this fairly long M/M fantasy novel, the first in a series, has really much to recommend itself.While Rowling's "Potter" series is a clear influence, Mr Jacobson manages to deliver an original, interesting plot with a rich cast of main characters.Side characters, which are many and relevant for the story, are not as well outlined and that betrays the author's lack of experience: if one fails to remember the actions of a side character at the end of the book, it usually means that that character lacks distinctive personality.One also may feel that Charlie's self hatred/homophobia is far too exaggerated and, most of all, unjustified as he does not appear to have grown up in such a bigoted context.Other sides of his development as a person betray some in depth research on the part of the author and do not fail to move the reader.Writing is always fluid and professional but rhythm falters here and there. The classical "I couldn't put this book down" does not apply here, as there are several slow moments: nothing too bad or embarassing but a competent editor might suggest some useful revisions.I hated the epilogue as it introduces an obnoxious cliffhanger: it was already more than clear that Charlie and Grace were not done yet and there was no need for such an epilogue whose content should have been moved to the beginning of the second instalment.There are typos and grammar mistakes: they are not disruptive but should be removed with next revision.

There is nothing wrong in this little short story/romance and writing is good.Unfortunately I could not relate with the leads who, though likeable, were not alive enough for me to really root for them. This is why, for me, the story is sweet, cute and forgettable.

In this M/M short story the author tries to mix romance and BDSM and, while the romance part is satisfying, the BDSM remains a foreign body in the narrative. I feel the problem is not having allowed Rafael to be openly affectionate, which is rather refreshing, but that Wyatt simply looks like a guy who just needs a long, hearty hug.Having failed to struck the intended balance, this story is not successful even if writing is fluid.
This very, very short M/M vampire short story is far from awful.Unfortunately writing is not so good as to make such a short snapshot really meaningful. Quickly read, soon forgotten.

While single paragraphs of this short M/M werewolf short story may be considered fluid and well written, they fail to come together into a sensible story.Plot and characterization are quite weak and the story, the first instalment in a serial, fails to keep its reader's interest.

The author of this M/M werewolf novel, the first in a series, has talent: it is kind of rough and uncouth, but it is obviously there, in a story that manages to flow forward and even entertain despite serious issues.Everything here is simple, bordering on the simplistic. Plot is very straightforward, characters are likeable if bidimentional and development hardly there at all.There are grammar mistakes and writing is often plain.The main problem lies in content and ethics, though.In Mr Colton's world gay men are cleft in two groups: there are the pretty twinks, all girly and submissive, both in bed and outside of it and then there are the real men, all hairy muscles and raging testosterone. The only redeeming quality of this unsufferable partition -which exists but hardly represents the totality of the gay world- is that the alpha male is really in love with his submissive pup.Unfortunately all other stereotypes are there, including the most annoying of them all: according to Mr Colton, a man can either be submissive or assertive in bed and if he happens to be submissive in bed he must perforce be unable to fend for himself in his life; he must of course defer to his stronger partner for all relevant decisions and content himself with being pretty, faithful and a bit on the wanton side, but only with his legitimate partner.The villain is essentially a character who did not accept the way of Mr Colton's world and that is rather hard to stomach.Add to this explicit sexism the stereotyped hyerarchies of the most stale werewolf novels and you will have a work whose main fault lies in its predictability.

I want to like this.  But it is made so cheaply.  The handles on the side appear and feel like painted plastic.  The handle for the lid is painted plastic and came with deep gashes and scratches on the cheap plastic shiny black circle in the middle of the cheap plastic silvery handle.  So I either live with it or return the whole thing over a 10 cent part.  The main housing is stainless.  I found one small defect in the stainless steel part.  But it's not enough to fret over.  I'd like to just leave this sitting out but don't want to have to look at the gashes in the lid handle.
I think I've seen this same thing at the dollar store.  Does not look as good as the picture indicates.  Disappointed.

The picture gives the impression the controller is a fob.  It isn't.  It's pretty large and thick, maybe about 3/4 the size of a deck of playing cards.  The controller plugs themselves are also quite large, about like a large lamp timer.  I don't like the bright red LED on the front when a controller is on.  That's fixable with a little electrical tape.  And others have pointed out the slightly unusual 12V battery.  They're sold at local stores and on-line.  But you probably wont find them at the corner gas station.  So that's the bad.  The good is that I got this to control a fan and light across the room in my home office.  Now when I get a call, I can turn off the fan noise without having to get up.  When dark in the AM, turn the bright pole light on across the room,  then shut it off as the sun comes up without disturbing my work at the computer.  There are other kits like this on Amazon.  But the plug on this one comes out the bottom, which is why I bought this one over the other kits.  If space is tight, there's a lot less sticking out  at the wall since the plug runs down the wall.  It also supports grounded devices.  The fan I'm using is a high speed, large fan with grounded plug.Thumbs up!

I've been using this drive for over a year.  I opened it up, put it in my HP Envy m7-j120dx and I couldn't be happier.  I got a 2nd one last year and use it to periodically image the internal drive, as a backup in case of failure.

I'm not sure what's up with this tuner.  I have 2 of these off a splitter that also have a 950 (not Q).  The 950 pulls in every channel strongly.  The 955Q can't pull in anything without major signal loss.  It's a splitter, so the incoming signal is the same on all 3 units.  You also need a CD/DVD drive to install the software.  Even if downloading off their website, it wants the original CD to be put in the drive, even if your computer doesn't have one.  There are ways around this - ripping it on another computer and mounting it.  But what a hassle.
Great price.  I replaced a broken pole saw that cost almost twice as much with this one.  They work the same.  No complaints.

I know it's just salt and pepper shakers.  But the eyelashes on the white one are messed up.  I've bought several items of this brand as gifts and 50% of them have come with defects, chips or poor paint.
Much nicer product than I expected, based on the other reviews.  Has some weight to it.
I use this for closing watch backs after opening them to change the battery and gasket
Good flip flops at a good price.

I was using Total but switched to Crest.  My dentist asked what I'd been doing differently because "strings" were in my mouth from the Crest.  I was instructed to switch back to Total and haven't had any complaints from the dentist since then.

I bought this at Disney World in Orlando.  The park version has different colors and the holes are in a different place, probably as a way to identify it was made for the park.  But it's a nice looking set.

These are perfect for the salt and pepper I keep in the bathroom.  Previously, I was just using regular plastic S&P shakers.  These make all the difference for when I need quick access to S&P but am sitting on the toilet.  And it's stylish at the same time.

Cute item as a gift.  However, I'm having to return it.  The black chihuahua is missing paint on the stomach.  It's a little bit sloppy painted other places, but no worse than other similar, cheap items from China.  The item box was already ripped when I opened the shipping box.  So it's possible this had been previously returned.  I'm debating trying a 2nd time or not.Update:  I returned it and tried a 2nd time.  The 2nd one was fine.

They changed this.  I bought one before and it fit the Remington pole, which was a good thing when the original chainsaw that came with the pole broke.  This thing is hard to adjust a loose chain.  Also, it no longer fits the pole.
Tastes good and the price is similar to the regular grocery store
Breaks too easily, otherwise is ok.

After owning this a month and upgrading to Windows 10, I was a little frustrated.  When it's on, it works ok.  Drive transfer speeds at 9mb/sec - 18mb/sec, mostly around 12mb/sec on USB 3.0.  But the more serious problem is that it just randomly shuts itself off all day long.  It's plugged into a laptop that's on all the time and Windows has been told not to put the USB hubs to sleep.  I didn't have this issue at first when on Win 7.  Also, I had one drive that must've had a slightly mis-aligned SATA port on back because it had significant trouble sliding in, probably putting strain on this case's SATA ports, which are soldered to the board and not moveable.One of the reviewers has said the hold the "sync" button down until Power Sync turn orange.  This makes the unit come on and off with the computer.  I tried that to see if it'll resolve the random shutdown problem.  It's finally been able to stay on for about 6 hours.  So that must have solved the issue.  For that, I'll bump it up to 4 stars.  Be sure to set it to this mode.

The base is too large, would be nicer if it was a rectangle.  It also came with a scratch in the plastic on top of the base.  Does not come with any sort of power supply but does come with a fairly short USB cable.  You'd sort of expect that when you buy a lamp, you can plug it in out of the box.  You have to provide a power supply yourself, separately.  The dimming flickers slightly.  To dim, hold and press the power button.  To get brighter, do it again.  To turn it off, tap the button instead of holding it.  But then when turning it off and back on, it loses the previous power setting.  Puts out a pretty bright, white "daylight" type light.  It can dim down really low as a nightlight if the flicker doesn't bother you.  Not the best fit and finish as some of the light leaks out of where they snapped it together.

This is one weirdly cut shirt.  The first problem is the hot fabric that also wrinkles, despite being polyester.  It looks like a potato sack when worn, having no tapering and being too wide.  The sleeves are made in some strange way that despite the shirt being too wide, the sleeves are somehow too small and feel like they pull on the shirt.  Also, the stitching is poor and has a pucker sewn into it.

The rust looks nothing like on the website.  It's salmon or sort of orange-colored in real life.  These are cut extremely weird.  The crotch puckers out and the legs are too tight but the waist fits fine.  The pockets are also tight to get into.

These are nice as far as the style and having the extra pocket for a small water bottle.  That's a very cool feature for FL tourism.  But the sizing chart says M is size 33-35.  I'm not so sure about that.  I was a size 34 and they were wearable but a tad tight.  In the past week, I took off a few pounds and now these fit well.  But I'm still a 34".  There's a little elastic in the waist, but no not much.  I like the style and extra pocket for drink, so I'm ordering more for the yard.

The ANT+ stick for syncing via PC seems to have issues with USB 3 ports.  When plugged directly into my computer, it may or may not work at 6 inches of range.  After reading a lot of complaints about it having issues with USB 3, I put it on a 2 foot USB 2.0 extension cable, essentially downconverting the USB 3 port.  I then just let it dangle behind the computer desk.  Now I can get about 6-8 feet away and the connectivity issue appears solved.  So I'll knock off 1 star for that.  Alternate ANT+ sticks are also available on Amazon and auction sites.If I pair/sync via iPhone, it does work fine, from a normal distance, pretty far away.  It also minimally integrates with Apple Healthkit for 3 factors.  Step counting isn't totally accurate but I guess is close enough.I appreciate that this device is waterproof and doesn't need constant recharging thanks to running off button cell batteries.So if you get bit by the connectivity issue, try a USB extension cable.  I suspect a shorter one would work fine.  I just happened to only have a long one.Also - The latest firmware update, which Garmin Express will install if it needs it, will detect sleep automatically and attempt to auto-sync 5x a day if you're in range of your phone (and the app is running) or your computer.

Seems to be very slow.  I'm plugged into a USB 3 port.  Transfer speeds from an external USB 3 HD to an identical external USB 3 drive case is around 12-16MB/sec.  Not impressed by this as it's in USB 2 range.  I have a mix of USB 2 and USB 3 devices plugged in, which, according to USB specs, shouldn't affect speed of the superspeed devices as compared to the high speed devices.  After this 2 day operation completes (to copy about 1TB of data), I'll do further testing  But so far, I'm disappointed it's so slow.
Cool shirt that's cut a little bit trim.  I'm about to be in my mid 40's and can still pull off these kind of clothes.  I don't know for how much longer though.  :-)

I go the DBB version of this fan to reduce future maintenance and replacement of the fan.  On low, it's really quiet.  Medium produces a slight high pitch whir.  High is a very noticeable high pitch whir, even with the case closed up.  It does push some decent air, so I left it on high to see if I learn to ignore it.  The DBB model has no LED's which surprised me a bit.The switch to change the speed is nice if you're sound-sensitive and willing to live with less airflow.  I don't like the noise on high (-1 star).  I do like the airflow and the speed switch.  Overall, seems solid.

I ordered this shirt elsewhere for cheaper.  Since I have it, I'll review it.  The sizing is like an Asian shirt.  Large is actually a small.  The size seems to be 2 sizes off.  One of the worst purchases I've ever made unless I lose 50 pounds.  If I had bought an XXL, I'd be ok with it.  Be aware the fabric is tight and doesn't stretch, which is probably why this tightly cut shirt doesn't fit.

You have to read these very fast or the colors continue to change.  There's a learning curve involved.The process is - catch urine mid-stream in a clean container.Dip the strip for 2 seconds.Rest strip on side on paper towel.Read at exactly 60 seconds.Because there are a lot of items it measures, you'll have a hard time reading everything before the colors continue to change.  Strip could be cut in 1/2 to reduce the number of items trying to be evaluated at once, except you'll get your fingers in it.  Urine is sterile, so don't be too grossed out by that prospect.The bottle I got was manufactured March 2015 and says it's good to March 2017.  I'm going to keep it in a vacuum sealed jar to extend the full shelf life.

I got this elsewhere for about the same price.  The face is pretty small, which I like for my smaller-sized wrist.  The functions are confusing.  It does't have auto DST.  I like how the analog and digital time are synched together.  The watch's main downfall is the incredibly cheap plastic lens on it.  You can find $10 watches on the auction and Chinese import sites with more scratch-proof glass and various non-plastic materials.  So unfortunately, a couple mishaps and this watch can get really scratched up.  I had an older version from Costco that was a lot more durable and lasted 10 years.  I'd give this watch maybe 2 or 3 years before it's in the trash.  But we'll see.
After a few months to a year, the plastic blades became unbalanced and this thing rattles when on.  It's a great idea but the cheap materials is its downfall.
Got this for travel.  Might stick it in my office bathroom to use during the day.  Uses the same heads as the rechargeable I use.  And the batteries last a long time.

Very easy to use.  I thought I had glucose issues.  Got this and now see that I don't.  The medical folks I work with highly doubted glucose was my issue.  It turns out it probably was a mild UTI.  But the $9 was worth it to put my mind at ease and I didn't have to go pay for labs.
Works perfectly and lasts a long time.

Mostly ok.  It sits oddly on my toilet and took fiddling to get it in the right spot.  I ended up putting some rubber bumpers and felt bumpers to keep it in place and from banging/scratching the porcelain tank.  I re-did my bathroom and really don't want to put holes in the wall for another toilet paper holder.  So this does the trick for now.

The material is nice and thick.  I don't like the way the pattern ended up with a big black spot right in the middle of the rear.  Also, I don't agree with those who say to go up a size.  I got a L for 33" waist, per the advice of the reviewers.  I usually wear M and wish I had gotten a M.  There's no drawstring.  With the looser, larger size and no drawstring, any swimming activities are at your own risk.
Not sure this is legit or a placebo, but seems to help with sleep.

This bracelet could stand to be 1/2" bigger around, maybe even just 1/4" would help.  I typically wear 8" or slightly smaller bracelets.  6'1" guy, but fairly small-ish wrists. On a positive note, I don't like floppy bracelets.  8" is probably the max wrist size for this item.  If you wear bigger than that, don't bother.  It's also sufficiently stretchy to get on relatively easy.  The black looks like leather but is animal friendly.
Another surfer t-shirt.  Fit is as expected.
Much brighter than expected, which I guess is ok.  It's a t-shirt.  Use it.  Wear it.  Move on to a new one.

Really nice shirt, slightly mesh and good for outdoor activity.  Looks stylish.  The sleeves were a tad longer than I expected they'd be.  Be aware that it's a bit loose.  So if you're between medium and large, go smaller.
Good value.  120 pills in a big bottle and only 1 is needed for the dose specified.  Pills are soft caplets, not hard tablets.

This was a waste of money.  Maybe I'm expecting too much.  But with the guard folded back, it's impossible to tell where the trimmer is cutting.  I messed up my sideburns the first time.  The light stays on the entire time it's recharging, even after it's full.  When unplugging it, the "charging" lights continue to rotate, as if it's confused.  The 5mm length is still a little short.  A competitor for $15 less goes to 10mm.  This unit only goes to 5mm.  I should've gotten the other one, which is also sold on Amazon.

Absolutely fantastic.  I've bought many of these and have been swapping out CFL's.  Most dim well.  A few hum at very low dimming.  So I use those in non-dimming applications.  The style is a little odd.  But it's not noticeable behind a lamp shade.  I call these "donut lights."
I have this shirt, purchased elsewhere.  It's excellent style and I wear it all the time.  But definitely go 1 size up.  XL is like a L in other brands.

I've got to give this 2 stars, unfortunately.  After taking it out of the sealed bag, I immediately saw two pulls in the fabric on the front.  Back in the bag it goes for a return.  It's a good thickness.  How did it get pulled so easily?  I want to try again but am afraid to risk it.  I think I'm done trying to order shirts on-line after too many problems.Update:  I ordered another one and it was in perfect condition.  Upping it to 4 stars, with 1 off for quality control.

Decent quality.  Doesn't feel like polyester.  Kind of thick.  But the problem is the sizing.  The large is cut like a small or a medium.  Definitely size up at least 1 size, maybe more.  It's too bad because it's otherwise nice.
Wow!  I'll be buying this over and over again.  It's like dessert.  110 calories in 2/3 cup.

Stretchy strap, big enough for American guy wrists.  Looks much better in person than in the picture.  Self-winding but not a glass back.  Very quiet winding mechanism.  I might get the black one too. Time seems fairly accurate for a Chinese mechanical watch.  The sub-dials are a little hard to see due to the metallic shiny background.
5 stars!
Not very strong flavor no matter how long it steeps.

It's a made for TV Lifetime movie, so I was not expecting it to be very good at all, but being a big Stephen King fan I knew I had to check it out. It is much more graphic than anything ever shown on that network I'm sure, though the only other movie I've seen on Lifetime is Lizzie Borden. Maria Bello is great in this. Without her acting talents this would be decent at best. She really elevates the material. Big Driver is dark and disturbing and worth a watch for King or revenge thriller fans.

Horns is really weird with a good mix of dark humor and horror elements. Daniel Radcliffe totally shakes off Harry Potter and delivers a solid performance, as does the entire supporting cast. Reviews were mixed, so I took a reasonable $12.99 gamble and now I'm glad to have it in my collection.
Humor, gore and all around fun. It is in English this time around, so no subtitles like the first film. If you like Shaun of the Dead, this should please you.

I found this by chance at the store for $80 and it is worth that and them some. The box didn't have any of the contents labeled but I did enough research online to know that it came with Rise of the Planet of the Apes (Blu-ray), Dawn of the Planet of the Apes (Blu-ray & Blu-ray 3-D), 4 ape cards and a little booklet. I think some sets overseas also come with all the original Ape films on bluray. The bust itself is beautiful and close to life size. Very realistic and it looks much better in person than in any picture I've seen. Caesar now guards my ever growing blu-ray collection.

Rarely does a David Fincher film let me down. I'm not too fond of The Social Network, but I like what he did with The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo. Gone Girl in some ways reminds me of another dark thriller from last year called Prisoners. Both are great, but this one is perhaps the better of the two. Ben Affleck is a very good director and he proves here that his acting has only gotten better and better with each passing film. Rosamund Pike deserves an Oscar nomination. I remember her as a Bond girl in Pierce Brosnan's last turn as Bond and countless other mostly under the radar movies, but she finally gets a role to show her true acting talents. She is hypnotic to say the least. The whole supporting cast and writing is top notch as well. So far this and Begin Again are my favorite flicks of 2014.

I own every single concert DVD and Blu-ray that Dream Theater has put out and this is my favorite. I read a complaint about the sound quality, but I thought it sounded great. I really like the song selection, mixing old and new tunes so every concert release has fresh material. Every band member is in top form as expected. Crazy technical guitar, bass and keyboard playing. James Labrie's vocals sound better here than he did when he was younger. Mike Mangini is a machine on drums and while I always respected his talent, this blu-ray has made me a huge fan. Worth every bit of $15!

I don't have as much time as I did in the past to write movie reviews and it has been a long time since I have written one, but I just had to say something about this one to hopefully get more people to see it. Begin Again is a great film with wonderful performances, music and even some humor that never felt forced. I had a free pass to see it, but I will surely be buying the blu-ray when it comes out. Mark Ruffalo is dare I say Oscar worthy and Keira Knightly has a good voice to go along with a very nice performance here. What an unexpected and pleasant surprise.

I didn't plan on seeing this film until I bought both Hunger Games steelbooks that came with two free passes. I was not expecting much at all due to the reviews, but I'm happy to report that Divergent is way better than the critics are saying. It's not quite up to The Hunger Games, but it also strays far away from the awful Twilight franchise, which I was initially afraid it would end up being. The story is interesting and the cast is pretty good, especially Shailene Woodley as Jennifer Lawrence lite. I have a feeling the sequels will be even better since this is really just a long, yet engaging setup.

Not nearly as memorable as 300 and if it were not for Eva Green, 300: Rise of an Empire would be a 3 star effort at best. She is comes off as both sexy and scary, being that she is an evil warrior woman you don't dare mess with. There is an empty void where Gerard Butler's presence is missed. He has done a bunch of awful movies since 300 I know, but he was pretty good in the role of Leonidas. Overall, it is much of the same in terms of visuals and bloody action.While far from spectacular, It's not boring in the least and I liked the fact that it is a prequel/companion piece/sequel all rolled into one.

This is an absorbing and dark crime drama on HBO that only lasts 8 episodes and will have a new cast and story next season. The writing is second to none and every supporting cast member, both small and large roles, fits just right. We all know by now that McConaughey can really act. After years and years of his talents being wasted, recent films like Mud, The Wolf of Wall Street and Dallas Buyers Club have put him on a career track that few actors ever experience. His work here on True Detective is in my mind the best thing he has ever done. Just hand him the awards and get it over with. Woody Harrelson plays a great foil to his very dark view of the world and the chemistry between the two is outstanding. The beyond beautiful Alexandra Daddario has a brief but "revealing" role. Sorry, just had to throw that in there. Game of Thrones is my favorite show, but now HBO has a real contender to fill that Breaking Bad void in my life.

I know that many people are split on the first Hobbit film, but I for one really enjoyed it. The Desolation of Smaug suffers from being the middle child and thus having no beginning or end, but it moves at a pretty good pace for being a little on the bloated side. All the acting, sets, music and action are top notch. Some of the FX are hit and miss, but the dragon Smaug is an absolute wonder in both look and sound (voiced by a deep and menacing Benedict Cumberbatch). Martin Freeman remains likeable as Bilbo and the addition of Orlando Bloom (back as Legolas) and Evangeline Lilly as a beautiful Elvish warrior makes for some entertaining fight scenes. It does end on a major cliffhanger as expected, but it felt like it was done to make sure people turn up this time next year for the third and final chapter. I could have easily ended a few minutes later after concluding this part of the story and using the next film to lead into The Lord of the Rings.

This version of Carrie is a modern take on the 1976 version, based on Stephen King's first novel. It adds a few new elements and the cast is quite good, but it is another remake that does not need to exist. We all know what is going to happen and it is nearly a copy in structure. Chloe Grace Moretz has the acting ability to almost make me forget that she is too pretty for the role. The prom scene lacked the impact of the original, but overall it was still enjoyable and better than most of the new takes on classic horror films. Worth at least one look.

Gravity is a pretty easy movie to sum up. Beautiful visuals thanks to 100% convincing CGI, great acting and a musical score that adds so much to what you are seeing. There is not too much of a story other than survival in space, though some character development emerges as the movie goes along. Sandra Bullock delivers a performance that should get her another Oscar nomination. Her acting here is very natural and believable. George Clooney is likeable and a perfect contrast to Bullock's uptight and nervous character. I expect to see Gravity up for multiple awards (Picture, Director, Actress, Visuals Effects and numerous other technical ones). Sure it is more of a thrill ride than a structured movie, but it is unlike any movie I've ever seen, especially in IMAX 3-D.

Almost on the same level as Pitch Black and a huge return to form after The Chronicles of Riddick. Vin Diesel in his best role delivers memorable lines and lethal kills. The CGI is very good and the movie has a good build up and payoff. The ending could have been better than the quick one chosen, but Riddick is a worthy action/sci-fi/horror hybrid that reminds us why Vin Diesel was a star to watch after 2000's Pitch Black.

If the first Kick-Ass movie was your kind of thing, Kick-Ass 2 more than delivers. The first film was more unique and original, but this one gives you even more laughs and great performances by Chloe Grace Moretz and Jim Carrey.Hit-Girl still rules and it was fun seeing a much larger cast of good and bad characters. Carrey is not in the movie for very long, but he sheds his goofy facial expressions for a realistic and believable tough guy role. He should do more stuff like this. McLovin is much better here this time around and goes from Red Mist to the supervillain with a name I can't repeat here. Aaron Taylor-Johnson is once again good as Kick-Ass, but he spends most of the time (like the first movie) just getting beat up.The violence is a little extreme, but I was expecting more given that Jim Carrey is now against the film due to this fact. Yes it has flaws, but it is a fun ride that had me smiling throughout. Oh, stay after the end credits for a short but important scene.

A family gets together after many years and everyone begins arguing at dinner when all hell breaks loose from some outside intruders. That is pretty much the simple setup.While You're Next is far from original, it does many things right. You care about some of the characters a little more than the average slasher film and the female lead is really smart for a change. Finally an intelligent and tough person to root for instead of yelling at them for doing every idiotic thing in the book. Plenty of gore, solid thrills and even a decent twist or two makes this horror film an enjoyable if somewhat familiar take on home invasion terror.It's also worth mentioning that this film was suppose to be released years ago after much buzz, but something happened with the studios and they shelved it until now.

I didn't really appreciate The Crow until I saw it again as an adult. It is now part of my Blu-ray collection and ranks among my favorite graphic novel adaptations. Great acting by Brandon Lee (don't think it would have worked without him) and gothic visuals. Such a promising start to a career that was sadly cut short due to a freak accident during filming.

James Wan is a horror director that might have finally peaked with this one. His first SAW film was the best of the bunch and while Insidious had flaws, it also had some great scare moments and visuals. The Conjuring is a near perfect ghost/demonic possession movie. The scares are not cheap and they are 90% effective. A couple felt a little forced, but overall this is one the creepiest movies I have seen in theaters.Based on a "true story" that takes place in 1971, a family becomes the victim of some evil forces in their new house. Two paranormal investigators are brought in to gather evidence. They are based on the famous couple that also investigated The Amityville Horror years later.The acting is great all around from the kids and adults. I like how they didn't use any big name actors. Vera Farmiga, Patrick Wilson and Ron Livingston are relatively well known, but thankfully no huge star power here to completely take you out of the film.Very little gore, no foul language or nudity in a horror movie? Believe it or not, this thing earned the R rating for pure scares alone. Now don't get too overhyped or anything. I personally didn't jump in my seat or want to cover my eyes (though many scenes are quite chilling), but plenty of people around me did.This is the first movie that has made me want to review it in a month. The Lone Ranger (2 and 1/2 out of 5 stars) and Pacific Rim (3 and 1/2 out of 5 stars) didn't surprise me enough to warrant my time reviewing them.The Conjuring is my favorite film so far this year. Let's leave it at that.

Now I enjoy X-Men, Spider-Man, Iron Man and all of the Avengers, but for me they don't compare to Batman and Superman. In fact, after Nolan's Dark Knight Trilogy, I would rank Man of Steel as the second best of all the recent comic book turned movies. I knew going in that the critics were nearly 50/50 on the good and bad side of the fence, so my expectations might have been lowered enough to prepare for the worst and surprised when it didn't happen.The story begins with the same old origin of Superman, but there are enough little changes in the script and nice visual touches to make it seem fresh. As expected, the CGI FX and Hans Zimmer's score are stunning throughout.Henry Cavill makes for a good and believable Superman and Michael Shannon plays a memorable villain in General Zod. Russell Crowe really surprised me with a strong emotional turn as Jor-El. He is a good actor, but his work of late has been rather weak. I normally can't stand the character of Lois Lane, but I like her here, so that is saying something about Amy Adams.It's not perfect of course. The narrative did not always gel, jumping around too often, and it ran for maybe 15 minutes too long.I saw it in digital 2-D due to all the bad IMAX and 3-D reviews. It cut my ticket price in half and I didn't feel like I missed out. Also, my full theater clapped and cheered loudly when it was over. I had not heard a reaction like that in a long time.With the 129 million dollar opening weekend, I feel this is but the first film of a trilogy that will probably get even better now that the foundation has been laid down.4 and 1/2 out of 5 stars

Into Darkness is better than the last cartoony yet enjoyable relaunch from 2009, but it seems to be trying to hard to feel like a Star Trek film. It doesn't help that the story this time around is far from original. Still, it is a lot of fun with great CGI, good acting and a nice dose of humor. Benedict Cumberbatch makes for a strong villain due to his still gaze and deep voice, though he fails to measure up to the charisma that Ricard Montalban brought to the role of Khan.I would still take The Wrath of Khan, The Undiscovered Country or First Contact any day over these last two entries, but they do have a wide appeal and in my opinion are more enjoyable than the last two Iron Man movies.After watching Into Darkness it's no wonder that J.J. Abrams is taking over the other epic Sci-Fi saga, which is his true love anyways. It really shows.IMAX 3-D looked great and was worth the extra $5.00.

Iron Man 3 is an improvement over the last installment, so it is a bummer that it ultimately lacks a clear and memorable villain. Ben Kingsley is a great actor of course and his acting is fine here, but without giving too much away, I feel cheated by the advertisements. I will leave it at that. Robert Downey Jr. turns in his best Tony Stark performance yet. I don't like his ego in reality, but he sure was made to play this character.The CGI is of the highest quality as expected and while most of the movie lacks action, the final act easily makes up for it. In Iron Man 3 you get more Tony Stark the man than you get Tony Stark in the Iron Man suit.The writing is pretty good and there are some very funny lines, but it can almost get too silly at times. They also felt the need to throw out references to what happened in The Avengers film every so often. We get it.IMAX 3-D was not really worth it. The 3-D was done after the fact and it only added so minor depth.For the first BIG movie of 2013 it is a good start. Here is hoping that Star Trek: Into Darkness and Man of Steel bring a little more to the table.

This film was way better than I expected going in. It features some of the best visual effects I have seen in a long time, but it doesn't sacrifice character development or a good story in the process. Oblivion feels like a much more complete movie than the director's last effort, Tron: Legacy, which was pretty much just eye candy. The musical score is also a thing of beauty. I need this soundtrack!I may not like Tom Cruise the person, but he can more than hold his own on screen. Morgan Freeman is always good, even in a tiny role like this. The two female leads are easy on the eyes with Andrea Riseborough turning in a memorable performance as Jack's (Tom Cruise) mission partner/lover and Olga is well...easy on the eyes.The story does get a little confusing from time to time and some of the twists were a bit obvious (at least to me), but by the end I pretty much had it all figured out. I will surely be adding this one to my blu-ray collection.

I've been a fan since I bought Horror Show back in 2001. I include myself in the majority group that think Matt Barlow will always be the voice of Iced Earth, but newcomer Stu Block is nothing short of spectacular here. He has the low and high range of Barlow, plus he can scream as high as the bands previous vocalist, Tim "Ripper" Owens. If you weren't totally sold on him after Dystopia (I think most were), this 2 1/2 hour live performance will make you a believer. The band is tight and the energy from the crowd is unlike any concert DVD/Blu-ray that I own.This is a great buy for the price. You get 2 CDs and 1 DVD that capture the entire show, along with a few extras that show the making of this one of a kind concert that was filmed on some ancient stone ruins. The picture is near Blu-ray quality and the sound is loud and broken up nicely.With founder/guitarist Jon Schaffer leading the way and Stu delivering the lyrics, Iced Earth should be cranking out nothing but classics in the near future. It's also refreshing to know that an American band is representing "Iron Maiden" style metal, when most of the better bands right now are from Europe. Looking forward to what they come up with next.

I think it is safe to say that Evil Dead is one of the best horror remakes ever. It is similar enough to the original (although much more serious, with little humor), but feels like more of a sequel instead of a copy. It does start off a little slow with some less than realistic dialogue, but it picks up as soon as they find that twisted brown book. From then to the end it is non-stop gore, gore and more gore. I don't know how they got away with some of this stuff. I've seen much worse, but it doesn't hold anything back. For a lower budget film, the make-up and thankfully non-CGI effects are some of the best in recent memory. There are a few creepy moments, but I wouldn't call this movie scary. The cast is good for this genre, but the only real standout is Jane Levy as the main girl who gets possessed. She goes through every emotion and is very believable.They showed the new trailer for the remake of Carrie and it looks to be another good stab at a classic.Evil Dead is worthy of my Blu-ray horror collection.

Side Effects is a film you can't really describe without giving anything away. Avoid the trailers if possible, make it through the slow build up and you will get quite a few surprises in the second half. Easily one of the best thrillers I have seen in a long time. Jude Law in his best performance in years as a psychiatrist and Rooney Mara, fresh off of The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo, knocks it out of the park again as his depressed patient. She has become one of my favorite actresses. Catherine Zeta-Jones is effective and Channing Tatum has little to do, but is adequate enough. Never boring and often surprising, if this is Steven Soderbergh's last movie, he went out at the top of his game.

Four stars might be a stretch, but there were enough memorable characters and magical moments to just barely save the day. Then again it's pretty sad when the two best characters are a CGI china doll and a talking monkey in a suit. I loved both of them.James Franco as Oz shines and fails from scene to scene. Mila Kunis as one of the three witches can't seem to shake her That 70's Show/Family Guy voice and it get really annoying, especially towards the end. The other two witches played by Michelle Williams and Rachel Weisz thankfully fare much better.The IMAX 3-D is done really well and is worth the extra money, though the film is way too CGI heavy. Beautiful, but hollow. I did like how the first 20 minutes was in 1:33:1 screen ratio and black and white. It gave the opening the right feel.Danny Elfman usually works his musical magic with Tim Burton and often sounds like a broken record, but his Oz score fits the tone and visuals. Some of the pieces are quite beautiful.As pure entertainment, I had a good time. Miles from the 1939 classic, but a trip to Oz is worth your time.3 and 1/2 out of 5 stars

If you liked the remake or the prequel, this "direct" sequel to the original 1974 film will probably entertain you enough. You have your iconic villain, heavy gore, two gorgeous babes and a typical paper thin script. I mean the main girl in this is in her early 20's and was born right after the 73' massacre, so the movie would take place in the mid to late 90's right? Not unless someone traveled back in time and brought an iPhone with them. Also there is a grave that marks a person's death in 2012. There is nothing scarier than a 60-year-old Leatherface chasing you down. If you can get past these huge flaws by the writers, there is some slasher enjoyment to be had.

The Last of the Mohicans is one of my favorite movies, filled with great acting, music and scenery. This film transports you back to 1757 and into the wilderness where the Indians thrived. Daniel Day-Lewis showed even back in 1992 that he had an acting range like no other, going from his Oscar win in My Left Foot to this colonial "white Indian" action hero. Madeline Stowe made the love story aspect believable and Wes Studi is easily one of the most memorable villains ever. The final sequence on the mountain, with almost no dialogue and the hypnotic music building as the action unfolds is something you will never forget.This is the best version out there. It's a combination of the theatrical and director's cut versions. The Blu-ray's picture is not as sharp as I was hoping, but it is still a vast improvement over my old DVD copy.

Side Effects is a film you can't really describe without giving anything away. Avoid the trailers if possible and make it through the slow build up and you will get quite a few surprises in the second half. Easily one of the best thrillers I have seen in a long time. Jude Law in his best performance in years as a psychiatrist and Rooney Mara, fresh off of The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo, knocks it out of the park again as his depressed patient. She has become one of my favorite actresses. Catherine Zeta-Jones is effective and Channing Tatum has little to do, but is adequate enough. Never boring and often surprising, if this is Steven Soderbergh's last movie, he went out at the top of his game.

Wow! Rush is one of the few "older" bands that still manages to put out solid music every few years or so. I've been listening to Clockwork Angels since it came out in June of last year. Every song is very good to great, featuring some of their best melodies to date. Geddy's bass playing is at an all time high, while Lifeson creates some memorable riffs and Peart fills in all the rest like the legend he is. One of the most complete albums I have heard by any band. Leave it to Rush to put out one of their best albums 40 years into a career. Anyone giving this less than 4 stars needs some serious help.

Hansel & Gretel: Witch Hunters is like a bloody and F-Bomb filled version of Van Helsing. In this case, that is a good thing. Van Helsing was pretty bad, but they pushed this one far enough with the R rating to please the horror fan inside me. The witches look nice and creepy and most of the CGI is well done. Jeremy Renner (Hansel) is a fantastic actor, though he is mostly wasted here and Gemma Arterton (Gretel) is more of the focus based on her looks and her character's personality. Famke Janssen has fun with the lead evil witch role. This film barely runs 90 minutes and it is light on story and high on action, but I had a good time watching it. Worth a future rental if you don't mind turning your brain off and just enjoy the fact that it is not as bad as you feared it would be.Oh, the IMAX 3-D was better done than most non-blockbuster type action films.Edit (7/6/13): I had to knock it up a star after watching the Unrated Cut. Still a very fun movie upon second viewing.

Mama is a good semi-creepy horror movie about two young children who spend five years alone in the woods and are later found and adopted by their uncle (the Kingslayer actor from Game of Thrones) and his wife (the always great Jessica Chastain in full goth mode, trading in her trademark red hair for black and sporting tattoos). Of course, something the children call "Mama" comes home with them and thus the horror begins. Maybe a little too much CGI used, but most of it looked okay. All in all, this is a well made ghost story that packs a few scares and has good acting throughout.
